Whole_Text.header: Tidal wave in the Netherlands in 1682
Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about the history of the Netherlands. The tidal wave of January 26, 1682, was a storm surge that struck the Delta region in the Netherlands and Flanders. Due to a combination of a spring tide and a storm with northwesterly winds, the water level rose exceptionally high and caused numerous floods. The villages of Valkenisse, Bommenede, and Retranchement were flooded. In Goeree-Overflakkee, twenty-two people drowned. In Dordrecht, a mill collapsed on its occupants, people who had sought refuge there, killing ten of them.
List of natural disasters in the Netherlands

Article_Name: Raz-de-marée de la Saint-Thomas en 1163 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about the history of the Netherlands. The St. Thomas flood occurred in the Netherlands on December 21, 1163, on St. Thomas's Day. These floods mainly affected Holland. Throughout the year 1163, the region had been affected by floods, causing several dike breaches along the Meuse. The main consequence of the St. Thomas flood was a complete blockage of the Old Rhine's mouth at Katwijk, which was already heavily silted. As a result, the Rhine could no longer discharge its waters into the North Sea. Several polders in Holland and Utrecht were flooded. On the orders of Floris III and without consultation, the Old Rhine was dammed at Zwammerdam in 1165, but from that moment, Utrecht also faced flooding, leading to a short war between Utrecht and Holland. Around 1200, a new drainage channel was dug via the Haarlemmermeer further north, thus resolving the water issue.

The evacuation of the Rivierenland is one of the largest evacuations in recent Dutch history. On January 31, 1995, and in the days that followed, 250,000 people and 1 million animals were forcibly evacuated from large parts of the Gelderland river area due to the dangerously high water levels of the Meuse, Rhine, Waal, and IJssel. The duration of the evacuation ranged from five days to two weeks.

In the 1990s, the threat of high water seemed to have been largely brought under control through large-scale government measures. The final touches were being made to the Maeslantkering at the Nieuwe Waterweg near Hoek van Holland, the last part of the Delta Works. The last high water disaster along the Meuse was in 1926. However, in December 1993, high water in the Meuse broke records. In the area around Roermond and Venlo, the river overflowed uncontrollably, and villages located outside the dikes were flooded. With three thousand cubic meters of water per second, more water had never flowed through the river. Thousands of houses were submerged, and about 12,000 people had to be evacuated. Analyses of recordings by the air force revealed that the river dikes were weak and unreliable in many places.

At the beginning of 1995, the situation along the Meuse was once again threatening; it rained heavily in northern France and the Ardennes. Other rivers also quickly became overfilled; on January 25, the water level of the Rhine at Tolkamer rose by two meters in a single day. A few days later, the Rhine overflowed in the German city of Cologne. In large parts of Gelderland, the water reached the tops of the dikes, and in Deventer, the quays were flooded. Due to the immense pressure, groundwater also rose. Many dike roads were closed to traffic, and crisis centers prepared for large-scale evacuations, with dike monitoring implemented everywhere. Threatened villages and cities organized flood disaster teams under the leadership of the mayor. The army and civilians filled and placed long rows of sandbags on the dikes. If the threatening dike breaches had become a reality, many areas in the Betuwe, the Bommelerwaard, and the Land van Maas en Waal would have been submerged up to about five meters. This meant that only the attics of many homes would remain dry. There would not have been enough time to evacuate afterward. Therefore, residents were informed that mandatory evacuation would take place on very short notice. Belongings were hastily moved to the upper floors, which might remain dry in case of flooding. Livestock and household goods were transported out of the threatened area. In Dutch Limburg, there were limited floods between January 22 and 28. The un-diked villages of Itteren and Borgharen, after the Meuse flooding in 1993, were submerged for the second time. Near Deventer, a dike of the IJssel was at risk of giving way.

Because, according to the government and Rijkswaterstaat, the necessity was great, the parliament decided in the short term to finance far-reaching measures to prevent a situation like in 1995 from happening again in the future. A large plan was drawn up to accelerate the strengthening or construction of new dikes in the river area starting from the year 2000; the Delta Plan for the Major Rivers. The Rhine branches and the Meuse have been given more space to safely discharge water through the implementation of the Room for the River program. With the opening of the Reevediep high-water channel in early 2019, the last project of Room for the River was officially completed.

Parking or Sint-Laureins Mariakerke, near Hoek, was engulfed in the Braakman.

The natural disaster of Holstein, also known as the Fastelabendsflut (Fastnacht Flood) of 1648 or the Holstein earthquake of February 14, 1648 (according to other sources February 15, 1648), was an extremely unusual combination of two natural events in the Holstein Elbe marshes.

The unusual natural event for this region extended from Freiburg/Elbe in Lower Saxony via Glückstadt along the Geest edge to Hamburg. On the late evening of February 13, 1648, "violent storm winds" arose, which developed into a hurricane overnight, accompanied by rain and hail showers. In the Elbe estuary and on the Elbe, various ships sank or were pushed ashore. The hurricane toppled the church towers of Glückstadt, Krempe, Wewelsfleth, Brokdorf, Kollmar, Horst, Uetersen, Rellingen, Wedel, and the St. Catherine's Church in Hamburg. At the same time, it destroyed countless buildings, lands, and uprooted hundreds of thousands of trees. Thousands of people were in extreme distress and danger. Within hours, a devastating storm surge followed, as well as—allegedly—an earthquake that triggered fires. During the storm surge, parts of the low-lying Elbe marshes were flooded meters high. Due to the simultaneous earthquake, more church towers and buildings collapsed and also caught fire. Countless people and animals lost their lives, the area was completely flooded and devastated for several months, followed by "great and diverse misery."

The main source for the storm is the poem "Holstein, forget it not" by the Wedel pastor and poet Johann Rist, along with the accompanying reports of several eyewitnesses who described the devastation caused by the storm in their parish. Most of these eyewitnesses were pastors from the neighborhood who were friends with Rist, and other friends of Rist, such as Georg Greflinger, also contributed their own eyewitness accounts, some in poetic form. In Krempe, the church tower was destroyed, but fortunately, the rest of the church, including the altar, pulpit, baptismal font, organ, and bells, remained intact, as reported by Pastor Johann Hudemann. In Wedel, entire houses were washed up in the higher-lying districts. The church tower of St. Catherine's Church in Hamburg was "lifted from its original masonry and fell onto one side of the church roof with such a terrible crash and clatter that it was believed heaven and earth had collapsed or merged together." In Drage, "the tower, which had always stood a few steps away from the church, was firmly moved to the walls of the church without shifting its structure." Similarly, it was reported from Bad Bramstedt: "On the Monday after Esto mihi at night around 11 o'clock, a great earthquake arose from the storm wind, through which the church tower was knocked down, causing great damage to the church, so that six new beams along with the rafter structure had to be brought in again." Johann Rist reported on this catastrophe: "[...] between Monday and Tuesday during Shrovetide week, such a terrible storm arose that the earth along with the largest buildings trembled and quaked, and at the same time such dreadful thunder and lightning were seen and heard that perhaps no person under heaven can be found who has ever experienced anything like it: Yes, large pieces or lumps of fire are said to have fallen on the city of Freiburg or other places in the same area [...]." The Wedel pastor further reported: "Yet I have found nothing that can truly be compared to what we experienced. For where has it ever been seen that such a storm wind and earthquake arose simultaneously, which in such a short time within three hours caused such incredible damage, crushed and destroyed so many buildings, towers, spires, churches, houses, mills, and the like, uprooted so many hundreds of thousands of trees, and brought people into such fear and distress that, if it had been possible, they would have gladly seen themselves in the abyss of the earth." Rist's poem itself consists of 800 Alexandrines, accompanied by extensive notes. Rist interpreted this storm, as well as the death of King Christian IV just a few days later, as a sign of divine wrath, primarily due to the excesses of Shrovetide. In his book, he not only described the catastrophe itself but also called on his congregation and readers to repent. For this purpose, the book also contains a long penitential hymn with 16 eight-line stanzas. Since this hymn was accompanied by musical notation, it was likely intended to be sung during worship services.

This article is a stub about the history of the Netherlands. Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The tidal wave that occurred in 1282 in the Netherlands had dramatic consequences; the connection between Texel and the mainland was broken.

The All Saints' Flood of 1532 occurred from October 31 to November 2, 1532. It is considered the third All Saints' Flood. The storm surge flooded large parts of the Belgian, Dutch, German, and Danish coasts. Based on historical records, it is estimated that several thousand people died in North Frisia. In East Frisia, the villages of Osterbur and Ostbense were lost. At St. Nicholas Church in Klixbüll, the height marker from 1532 (NN+4.16 m) is the oldest preserved marker of a North Sea storm surge. On Fanø, the easternmost settlement of Albo was lost. For the island of Strand, which was torn apart in 1634, the All Saints' Flood of 1532 was one of the most devastating floods of the 16th century, with chroniclers reporting eleven dike breaches and 1,500 people drowning.

Article_Name: Raz-de-marée de la Saint-Nicolas en 1196 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about the history of the Netherlands. Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The St. Nicholas flood occurred in the Netherlands.

This article is a draft concerning the history of the Netherlands. The tidal wave in the Netherlands in 1014 refers to a significant tidal wave named (Stormvloed in Dutch) that occurred on September 28 and 29, 1014, in the Netherlands. It was probably the first breakthrough of the sea through the almost closed coastline of the lowlands in the southern Netherlands. The previous major disaster was the great flood of December 21, 838. The storm of 1014 first hit the English coastline and then continental Europe, pushing the North Sea over the dikes of present-day Zeeland, which was part of Frisia and Flanders. According to sources from that time, the Netherlands, and particularly the former island of Walcheren, suffered heavy damage. Restoration likely took an unusually long time. The chronicle of the Quedlinburg Abbey in Saxony reports that there were thousands of deaths.

The Emerentia flood or Pontian flood was a storm surge that struck large parts of the Netherlands on January 23, 1610. There had already been a considerable northwesterly storm in the days prior, and on the 23rd, it reached its peak. It was the most severe flood since the All Saints' Flood of 1570. Heavily affected areas and places included: Waterland north of Amsterdam with Zaandam and Westzaan, and Medemblik, Enkhuizen, Hoorn, Texel, Wieringen, Dordrecht, Rotterdam, Workum, Hindeloopen, Stavoren. The Emerentia flood is named after the day (January 23). If using the Julian calendar, it is called the Pontian flood (January 14). The storm surge was the result of four days of stormy weather from the northwest. In the days prior, this had already caused high tides, but on this day, the storm battered the coasts of Flanders, Holland, Germany, and Denmark even more severely. The dikes had already been weakened by the storm that had struck a year earlier on February 11 and 18, 1609. And because the storm had already caused some dikes to break in the days before, large parts of North Holland, South Holland, Friesland, Groningen, Gelderland, and Overijssel were flooded. The village of Petten was at risk of being completely washed into the sea along with its dunes. Nearly two-thirds of the island of Texel was submerged. In Medemblik, water filled the streets, and Enkhuizen was also hit. The water reached up to the church there. The entire northern part of Overijssel, the river basin of the IJssel and the Maas, was completely flooded. In Groningen, the Emderland was underwater. The damage caused by this flood was enormous. Many houses and barns were washed away, and much livestock drowned.

Whole_Text.content:
The Storm Surge of 1906 is a storm surge that primarily affected Zeeland and Flanders on March 12, 1906. Because the flooding occurred during the day, there were no casualties. However, the damage was immense, but no land was lost.  
In Vlissingen, very high water levels were measured, which were only surpassed during the flood disaster of 1953. After this storm surge, it was decided to equip the dikes with Muralt walls.

The Sint-Pontiaans flood or the Sint-Pontius flood, named after Saint Pontian, took place on January 13, 1552. It affected the entire western coast of the Netherlands. This storm surge caused significant damage. In North Holland, near Den Helder, 15 meters of dunes were washed away, among other things. Large pieces of peat were also washed away in the northern part of North Holland. In Zeeland, several polders were flooded. The island of Agger, Bath, and Hinkelenoord completely disappeared under the waves. The lower areas between Bergen op Zoom and Ossendrecht were also entirely flooded. 838 · 1014 · 1042 · 1134 · 1163 · 1164 · 1170 · 1196 · 1212 · 1214 · 1219 · 1220 · 1221 · 1248/1249 · 1277 · 1280 · 1282 · 1287 · 1288 (I) · 1288 (II) · 1322 · 1334 · 1362 · 1374 · 1375 · 1377 · 1404 · 1421 · 1424 · 1468 · 1477 · 1509 · 1514 · 1530 · 1532 · 1552 · 1566 · 1570 · 1610 · 1643 · 1651 · 1675 · 1682 · 1686 · 1703 · 1717 · 1726 · 1741 · 1775 · 1776 · 1784 · 1799 · 1808 · 1809 · 1820 · 1825 · 1855 · 1861 (I) · 1861 (II) · 1877 · 1906 · 1916 · 1926 · 1953 · 1962 · 1993 · 1995 · 2006 · 2021

Whole_Text.content: After the St. Lucia flood overflowed Groningen in December 1287, the province of Groningen was hit again within a year by a storm surge, the Simon and Jude flood. Because the dikes had not yet been repaired, the water had free rein. According to the Bloemhof chronicle, the sea entered the land at Oterdum (a new flood in 1290 washed away the sluices of Oterdum), Usquert, in the Marne, and in Zuurdijk. As a result, the sea reached lower areas such as Garmerwolde, Woltersum, and Oostwold. 838 · 1014 · 1042 · 1134 · 1163 · 1164 · 1170 · 1196 · 1212 · 1214 · 1219 · 1220 · 1221 · 1248/1249 · 1277 · 1280 · 1282 · 1287 · 1288 (I) · 1288 (II) · 1322 · 1334 · 1362 · 1374 · 1375 · 1377 · 1404 · 1421 · 1424 · 1468 · 1477 · 1509 · 1514 · 1530 · 1532 · 1552 · 1566 · 1570 · 1610 · 1643 · 1651 · 1675 · 1682 · 1686 · 1703 · 1717 · 1726 · 1741 · 1775 · 1776 · 1784 · 1799 · 1808 · 1809 · 1820 · 1825 · 1855 · 1861 (I) · 1861 (II) · 1877 · 1906 · 1916 · 1926 · 1953 · 1962 · 1993 · 1995 · 2006 · 2021

Article_Name: Raz-de-marée de la Saint-Clément en 1334 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about the history of the Netherlands. Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The flood that occurred in 1334 in the Netherlands.

The storm surge of 1566, which caused much destruction in North Holland, occurred in the spring, while most storm disasters took place in the autumn or winter. Both sea dikes and inland dikes were affected.

In Zeevang, a water board district with the jurisdictions (legal areas) of Edam, Middelie, Warder, Kwadijk, and Oosthuizen, various storm disasters occurred in the sixteenth century, including those of 1532, 1552, 1560, and 1566, which were mentioned in a manuscript from 1567. This was written by secretary Jehan Purtyck on behalf of commissioner Jacob van Quesnoy, both associated with the Court of Holland, and was deciphered by Lex Ritman in 1965. The storm disasters caused numerous damages and even dike breaches, forcing the construction of inner dikes (dike sections moved inward), as in 1532, 1552, and 1566, which were mentioned in the manuscript. Inner dikes were constructed not only in cases of dike breaches, where the dike could not be restored to its original location due to scour holes, but also when it was realized that a dike could no longer be maintained due to the reduction of the foreland (area outside the dike). These inner dikes created a "horn or curve," a bend in the dike. The manuscript referred to an "inlaegerdyck" (inner dike) or "ingeleyde dyck" (laid-in dike). The inward relocation of a dike that could no longer be maintained was called an "inlaege" (inlay). Today, the terms inner dikes and inlays are understood differently, which can lead to confusion. In the manuscript, the dike section that was left outside the new inner dike was called a "dyckstal" (dike stall). At the inner dike between Axwijk and Kwadijk and the one in front of the Bernardine monastery of Galilee, between Nieuwendam and Ilpendam, the old dike stall still remained.

During the disaster of 1566, which occurred during Easter, the wind initially blew from the northwest, pushing the water from the North Sea into the Zuiderzee, but after a long time, it shifted to the northeast. As a result, the water struck with great force against the sea dikes of Drechterland, Zeevang, Katwoude, Waterland, Marken, Amstelland, and Gooiland, causing severe damage in several places. In addition to the sea dikes, some inner dikes were also seriously damaged, such as the Beemsterdijk near and in Oosthuizen, where it was written in the manuscript that the waves crashed over the dike against the western wall of the church, damaging the dike and causing the church gutter's kettle to overflow because it could not handle the water. The damage to the Beemsterdijk in front of the church was all the greater because the foreland was missing and was also absent or very narrow in other places. The inner dike laid north of Hobrede in 1566 was undoubtedly attributable to this storm disaster.

The Oostdijk or Zeevangs-sea dike, which was specifically mentioned, had not suffered the same amount of damage everywhere because this depended, among other things, on the size of the foreland. In many places, the dike was hardly or not at all affected, but at other points, it was severely damaged. In general, it could be stated that half of the landowners had little more than a "croene opte deympte" (coin and land measure) in expenses to bear, while the rest had to spend more or less on repairs. Such a storm was not common, and only 8 or 10 years ago had there been some storms that had severely damaged the Oostdijk.

About three weeks after the storm during the Easter days of 1566, a meeting was held at the hospital in Edam, attended by the mayor of Edam, the aldermen of Oosthuizen, and the peacemakers of Kwadijk, Warder, and Middelie. They wanted to deliberate on the costs caused by the storm disaster. At this meeting, a petition from the residents of the Oosterweren, located east of the Ye (the Die), was read aloud by the mayor of Edam, Claes Heynricxz. Lou. This petition was addressed to the "common court" of Edam and the "peacemakers" of Zeevang. The Oosterweren requested permission to construct a secondary dike in the Oostdijk at the expense of the entire Zeevang. The response from the meeting was that the residents of the Oosterweren first had to ensure the necessary dike repairs and could then submit a new request, but in principle, there was no objection to this secondary dike being constructed by the "common land" as a "common work." In short: at communal expense. According to witnesses from the manuscript, this secondary dike was very likely constructed, as no refusal had been heard of.

In the context of the foregoing, it is enlightening to provide an overview of the walen (whirlpools) that were observed in 1567, albeit possibly as now dry depressions. Also, walen that had since disappeared without a trace due to being filled in were mentioned if they could still be remembered in 1567. In the sixteenth century, these were called braeck, breeck, wael, weel, grontbraeck, and grontwael. These whirlpools formed on the inner side during a dike breach and, according to those present, were older than the Nieuwendam over the Purmeraa (1400 or 1401), which provided protection against the Zuiderzee, around the Purmer and Beemster. There were two exceptions to this: the waal south of the Slingerdijk (between Oosthuizen and Etersheim) and one in the Axwijker dike. The latter had been diked out by the construction of an inner dike. The manuscript described in detail how the walen looked in 1567. They could consist entirely of water or partially, with the rest overgrown with reeds/rushes. They could also have become completely overgrown. Furthermore, some holes had been completely or partially filled. In the latter case, the remaining surface consisted of water, water and reeds/rushes, or entirely of these plants. The walen were filled with earth, sods, or mud and then used as hayland, oatland, yards, or building land for houses. Between the Nieuwendam and Ilpendam, there were 7 walen, and between this place and Purmerend, even 22. Slightly to the east of that, there was 1 waal. Between Edam and Axwijk, there were 2 walen, and in this place itself, 4. Going from Axwijk to Kwadijk, one encountered 2, and in Kwadijk itself, there were 7 (there used to be a few more). Between Hobrede and Oosthuizen, no walen were found, and south of the Slingerdijk, there was 1 (from 1552). Around the Purmer, about 50 walen were mentioned, but there must have been more in earlier times. Some names are known: Dirck Heynezoons braeck and Gerrit Foppezoons braeck in Axwijk, and Cruysbreeck, Willem Maertszoons braeck, Jacob Wouterszoons braeck, and Campbreeck in Kwadijk.

An overview of the secondary dikes in the area completes the picture. Between Edam and the Nieuwendam at the Purmer, there were 4; between this dam and Ilpendam, there was 1; between Edam and Kwadijk, there were 3 (the southern one, estimated to be more than 30 years old, and the middle one were younger than the Nieuwendam); in Kwadijk, there was 1 (laid approximately 30 years ago); and between Hobrede and Oosthuizen, there were 3 (from south to north: 1566, 1552, and older). The names of some secondary dikes are known. Between Edam and the Nieuwendam, the first was the Driespronck, and from the western end of Axwijk to the eastern end of Kwadijk stretched the Quae Horn. An interesting detail is that to the west and east of Axwijk, there was a polder lake outside the dike created by the secondary dike, while in front of the Bernardine monastery of Galilee, between the Nieuwendam and Ilpendam, there was a polder lake behind the secondary dike. These polder lakes and secondary dikes are already mentioned above.

Whole_Text.content: For the third consecutive year, the Ommelanden (in the current province of Groningen) were struck by storm surges. According to the chronicle of Emo, two storm surges even occurred in 1221; on February 24 and September 18. The area was flooded by seawater, as in previous years, undoing repair efforts. Whole_Text.content: For articles with the same name, see Saint Elizabeth's Flood. This article is a stub about the history of the Netherlands. edit - edit code - edit Wikidata The Saint Elizabeth's Flood of 1424 occurred from November 18 to 19, 1424, in the southwest of the Netherlands. While drainage work was underway following another flood three years earlier, this flood dashed hopes of reconstruction. Part of the affected area would later become the De Biesbosch National Park.

Whole_Text.header: Tidal wave in the Netherlands in 1134
Whole_Text.content: The tidal wave that occurred in 1134 in the Netherlands was the first major tidal wave since that of 1014. It mainly affected the southwest of the present-day Netherlands, as well as the northern Flemish coasts of present-day Belgium.
This tidal wave had several consequences:

The Storm Surge of 1220 or Epiphany Flood is a storm surge that took place in the year 1220 in the Ommelanden (in the current province of Groningen). The area had already been affected a year earlier by the St. Marcellus Flood. However, because the St. Marcellus Flood had caused such enormous devastation and the repair work was still ongoing, most residents had not yet returned to their old place of residence. Therefore, no deaths are mentioned. 838 · 1014 · 1042 · 1134 · 1163 · 1164 · 1170 · 1196 · 1212 · 1214 · 1219 · 1220 · 1221 · 1248/1249 · 1277 · 1280 · 1282 · 1287 · 1288 (I) · 1288 (II) · 1322 · 1334 · 1362 · 1374 · 1375 · 1377 · 1404 · 1421 · 1424 · 1468 · 1477 · 1509 · 1514 · 1530 · 1532 · 1552 · 1566 · 1570 · 1610 · 1643 · 1651 · 1675 · 1682 · 1686 · 1703 · 1717 · 1726 · 1741 · 1775 · 1776 · 1784 · 1799 · 1808 · 1809 · 1820 · 1825 · 1855 · 1861 (I) · 1861 (II) · 1877 · 1906 · 1916 · 1926 · 1953 · 1962 · 1993 · 1995 · 2006 · 2021

Whole_Text.content: The storm surge in 838 occurred on December 26 and affected a large part of northwestern Holland, which at the time belonged to the Frankish Empire. The lack of good dikes was a significant cause of this flood.

The storm surge is mentioned in two independent writings. One source is attributed to the French bishop Prudentius of Troyes. The other writing that mentions this storm surge is the so-called Annales Xantenses, a Carolingian chronicle. Both sources report significant flooding, resulting in the destruction of a large number of places. In East Frisia, Leybocht, a sea inlet near the town of Norden, was created on this occasion.

Article_Name: Raz-de-marée de la Sainte-Agathe en 1288 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about the history of the Netherlands. You can share your knowledge by improving it (how?) according to the recommendations of the corresponding projects. edit - edit code - edit Wikidata The Saint Agatha's flood is a flood that occurred on February 5, 1288, Saint Agatha's Day. This flood affected the present-day region of Zeeland and South Holland.

The flood of 1820 inundated a large part of the Alblasserwaard after several dikes broke on January 23. The lock between the Linge and the Steenenhoek canal in Gorinchem broke on January 26. An area of approximately 1,300 km² was flooded during this disaster.

This article is a stub about the history of the Netherlands. edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The tidal wave of 1322 flooded a large part of what is now the Netherlands and Belgium. The flood mainly affected Zeeland, South Holland, and Flanders, but also Friesland, Groningen, and areas along the major rivers Rhine, Meuse, and IJssel were underwater. The number of deaths is unknown.

In Flanders, almost all the coastal islands were swept away. Later, John the Fearless would realize that the dikes of Flanders needed to be unified and reinforced; this would lead in 1404 to the construction of a dike from Dunkirk to Sas van Gent called the Count John's dike.

The Sint-Martens flood occurred from November 12 to 13, 1686, just after Saint Martin's feast day. The storm surge affected Groningen the most. The northwesterly storm hit Groningen during the night. The dikes broke: all the dikes along the Ems and the Dollart were swept away, resulting in all of northern Groningen and the Oldambt being flooded. Pieterburen and Uithuizen were submerged, and Groningen lay by the sea. The storm surge caused the death of 1,558 people, 1,387 horses, and 7,861 cows. 631 houses were washed away, and 616 houses were damaged. The Maria Church in Uithuizermeeden was also heavily damaged, despite its location on a mound.
This article is a stub concerning the history of the Netherlands. Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The tidal wave that occurred in 1280 in the Netherlands.
List of natural disasters in the Netherlands

The flood of 1809 was the result of a significant rise in water levels that particularly affected the Betuwe region in the center of the Netherlands in January 1809. It caused nearly two hundred casualties.

The Betuwe is a particularly fertile region in the center of the Netherlands. It is located between the two main branches of the Rhine, the Waal on one side and the Lower Rhine then the Lek on the other, which separate near Arnhem. The estuaries of the Waal and the Meuse cross the Biesbosch, a vast area of polders reclaimed by the sea during the Saint Elizabeth flood in 1421, near the city of Dordrecht. The Biesbosch thus forms a marshy buffer traversed by multiple small waterways, whose freezing occurs more quickly than in a vast estuary.

The winter of 1808-1809 is particularly harsh, and many waterways in the Netherlands, including the Biesbosch, freeze. The Pannerden Canal, forming the section of the Lower Rhine at the division of the Rhine into two branches, freezes. As a result, a large portion of the Rhine's waters that were supposed to flow into the Lek is forced to pass through the Waal. In mid-January, the Waal's dikes give way in two places: in Lent, near Nijmegen, and in Loenen, a few kilometers downstream. The river's water pours like a torrent inland, destroying farms and villages. The bulk of the flooding is stopped by the Diefdijk, a dike crossing the Betuwe between Gorinchem, Leerdam, and Culemborg, thus forming a true inland sea. While the Betuwe is the hardest-hit region, floods occurred throughout the area between the Meuse and the Rhine, up to Arnhem. Starting on January 28, the King of Holland, Louis Bonaparte, travels to Gorinchem to assess the extent of the damage and support the affected populations. Louis himself helps reinforce the dikes with sandbags, coordinates relief efforts, and visits the most isolated villages in the territory to encourage the population. To facilitate the water's flow, the dike is breached at Dalem. These efforts are in vain as the Diefdijk also gives way on January 31 near Kedichem, and the flooding extends across the entire Betuwe, reaching Alblasserdam. The damages are estimated by the Ministry of the Interior at 6 million florins.

The flood of 1855 was a flooding caused by dike breaches in the central Netherlands on March 5, 1855. The Gelderse Vallei and the Land van Maas en Waal were particularly affected. The floods also occurred outside these areas, throughout the Betuwe, in large parts of North Brabant and Gelderland, and the area stretching in the Gelderse Vallei from Rhenen and Wageningen to Amersfoort and the former Zuiderzee. Thirteen people drowned.

On March 5, 1855, the Rhine was found to be blocked by large masses of drifting ice. At that time, the water level was more than six meters above the Amsterdam Ordnance Datum. When the ice started moving that day, the water broke through the Grebbe dike, creating a 150-meter-wide breach in the dike in a very short time. The damage was immense, and several houses were severely damaged or completely destroyed. The exact number of fatalities is unknown. Subsequently, King William III visited the Land of Maas and Waal. He would later award honors to people who had rendered exceptional service during this disaster. Since 1855, there have been no more floods in the Gelderse Valley. However, it was not until 1931 that a commission was established to further investigate the drainage in the Gelderse Valley and make recommendations. In 1955 and 2005, the flood disaster was officially commemorated in Veenendaal. On the Kerkewijk, there is a monument with the names of eleven victims of the disaster, and part of the exhibition in Museum Veenendaal is dedicated to the disaster. A memorial stone has also been placed on the quay wall of Renswoude Castle.

Info_Box:
Date: 5 to 13 March 1855  
Region: Gelderse Vallei and the Land of Maas en Waal  
Deaths: 13

Whole_Text.header: Flood and storm surge of Kanpō
Whole_Text.content: The Kanpō Flood and Storm Surge refers to one of the largest-scale water-related disasters in early modern Japan, which struck the Kinki, Shinetsu, and Kanto regions of Japan from July 28 (August 28, 1742) to August in the second year of Kanpō. Particularly severe damage was suffered in areas such as the Chikuma River basin and Edo.

The damage caused by the three days of storms on July 28, 29, and August 1 was immense. In Kyoto, the Sanjo Bridge was washed away, and floods struck Fushimi and Yodo downstream of the Katsura River. In the Shinano Province, a flood known as "Inu no Mansui" occurred on the Chikuma River, and the Tone River, Arakawa River, and Tama River in the Kanto region all overflowed simultaneously. Particularly in Edo, located downstream of these rivers, the city was hit directly by a storm surge caused by the storm, flooding from the Tone River levee breach, and another storm on the 8th, which is believed to have been separate. Many bridges, including the Ryogoku Bridge, were washed away, and the submersion of residences led to a large number of drowning deaths, causing significant damage, especially in the downtown areas (Kanpo 2nd Year Edo Flood). Additionally, there was significant damage in places like Takada in the Echigo Province.

This article is a stub related to Japanese history. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this article (P: Japan / P: History / P: Historical Studies / PJ Japanese History). This article is a stub related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this article (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

The Odawara Great Tsunami was a storm surge that occurred on September 28, 1902, along the western coast of Sagami Bay. Centered in Odawara Town, Ashigarashimo District, Kanagawa Prefecture (now Odawara City, Kanagawa Prefecture), it caused significant damage, including deaths and destruction of houses.

The day was a Sunday. A typhoon (later called the Ashio Typhoon) was passing through, and from around 4 o'clock, rain was accompanied by wind, with the wind and rain becoming intense from around 7 o'clock. It began to calm down around 10 o'clock, but at around 11 o'clock, during high tide, large waves from the coast overtopped the embankments for about two hours, and seawater entered the urban area. The wave height was said to be about 6 meters near Odawara and Hayakawa. Incidentally, this event was caused by a storm surge, but due to the term "kaisho" (sea surge) also being used for tsunamis, some literature and materials describe this event as a tsunami. However, this event was not caused by an earthquake, and interpreting it as a tsunami is not accurate.

At that time, the coastline of the Odawara area had frequently suffered damage from storm surges, and it was pointed out that the breakwaters were not adequately developed. Using this storm surge as an opportunity, the construction of breakwaters was suddenly taken up as an important issue in Odawara town administration. In October of the same year, the town organized a Coastal Breakwater Construction Committee, and on October 20, submitted a petition for the construction of breakwaters to the Governor of Kanagawa Prefecture. As a result of continued petitions, construction began with prefectural subsidies and local contributions, and in April 1905, a coastal breakwater approximately 2,150 meters in length was completed.
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

On the night of January 30 to 31, 1877, a severe storm raged in the North Sea region. There were casualties in the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and Germany. The Westpolder and the Reiderwolderpolder in the north of Groningen flooded, with 14 and 37 people drowning, respectively.

The Westpolder, north of Vierhuizen, lies on the border of the former Lauwerszee and the Waddenzee. The polder was constructed between 1873 and 1876. During its construction, 13 polder workers drowned in an earlier flood. On the night of January 30 to 31, 1877, the polder was struck by a storm surge, resulting in 14 fatalities; hours before the water reached its highest level, it was already spilling over the dike. The dike broke in two places simultaneously, and within a few hours, the entire polder was submerged. The situation was worst in the workers' houses with single-brick walls. Some houses collapsed with the residents who had climbed onto the roofs. Others tried to reach the farms, but not all succeeded. With boats from Zoutkamp, the polder residents were rescued with great difficulty the following day. Some families did not survive the disaster. Thirteen victims were buried in a mass grave in Vierhuizen. The fourteenth victim, a girl visiting the polder, was buried in Houwerzijl. In 1931, a simple monument was erected to commemorate the disaster. In the nearby Zoutkamp, the dikes held, but even there, two people, a man and a woman, lost their lives.

At Nieuwe Statenzijl, large-scale land reclamations were underway on both the Dutch and German sides of the border. The dikes could not withstand the high waves. The breach at Nieuwe Statenzijl is described in a 1906 booklet by J. Bakker from Drieborg, who was an eyewitness to the disaster. He reported that the wind turned into a hurricane by the evening of January 30th, and the Dollard became like a roaring lion. The workers did not understand the nature of the Dollard and had no idea what awaited them. They did not flee even as the water began to surge over the dikes. By 11 o'clock in the evening, the sluice could no longer withstand the seawater, and the sluice keeper, who had only moved into the new sluice keeper's house fourteen days earlier, took refuge in the gauge house with 16 other people. Everything around the gauge house was swept away; the sluice and the sluice keeper's house were completely destroyed. The arrival of daylight was awaited with anxious anticipation. The scene was most sorrowful, according to Mr. Bakker's account. All the houses had been washed away: the seemingly indestructible sluice house, the sluice, the dikes, both on the Dutch and German sides. When investigations were later conducted, 35 bodies of men, women, and children were found. Women were still clutching their children in their arms. The flood had overwhelmed and swept them away. In a large grave at the cemetery in Ditzumerverlaat, 27 victims were buried in one day, and another eight the following day. Two bodies that washed ashore on the Dutch side were brought to Nieuw-Beerta and buried there. Farmer J.H. Ebels rendered great service during this disaster. He provided shelter to many in his barn and supplied them with food. At the German border office opposite Oude Statenzijl, a cradle with a sleeping child drifted ashore.

The Zuiderzee coast also suffered heavily. Especially the area around Zwolle experienced several dike breaches, causing a large number of houses to collapse and leaving 260 people homeless. Tragic was the accident with the steamship Willem III, en route from Sneek to Stavoren. On the Fluessen lake, the cabin windows of the ship broke, causing it to take on water. When the rudder also broke, the ship became stranded. Although the ship did not completely sink, 20 people drowned. The survivors had to wait fifteen hours to be rescued, either hanging in the masts or standing on the bridge up to their chests in water. At sea, 31 people lost their lives in three shipwrecks.

The German Wadden Islands experienced significant dune erosion and flooded polders. The fishing fleet of Yarmouth lost 70 ships, resulting in 112 fatalities. In Hull, large parts of the city were underwater. In Ostend, seawater entered the city, undermined the pavement of the streets, and flooded cellars.

Info_Box:
Date: January 31, 1877  
Region: Groningen  
Deaths: >216

Whole_Text.content: This article is a draft concerning the history of the Netherlands. In the winter of 1248/1249, three storms occurred: The coast was breached, particularly at Callantsoog, where the hinterland was flooded, and an island was formed. Dikes of the Elbe were destroyed. The German region was also affected.
List of natural disasters in the Netherlands

Whole_Text.header: Storm surge series from December 19 to 24, 1954
Whole_Text.content: The storm surge series from December 19 to 24, 1954, was triggered by two consecutive hurricane lows, which moved with their core over the German Bight to Jutland during the relevant period and claimed at least 70 lives in total. The hurricanes and the storm surge of December 23/24, 1954, caused severe damage in Germany and the Netherlands, both in forests and cities, as well as to dikes and coastal protection structures.

A prevailing westerly wind situation reached its first peak on December 4, 1954, when the federal territory was crossed by the storm field of a rapidly moving hurricane low passing over the German Bight and Jutland towards Scandinavia. It reached its final peak between December 19 and 24. On December 23 in particular, when the second hurricane low with a core pressure of less than 955 hectopascals moved southeast from Jutland towards Bornholm, wind speeds estimated at 180 km/h at the time were observed over the German Bight in the sea area near Borkum. The development of the second hurricane low was very similar to that of the Holland storm surge in 1953 and the Capella hurricane in 1976. Similar to the two aforementioned hurricanes, a trough formation occurred on the rear side of the second hurricane low on December 23, which is a drop in air pressure observed in aging cyclones. This led to a redirection and thus to the development of the very severe storm surge in both the Capella hurricane in 1976 and the Holland storm surge, as the passage of the trough in these two cases coincided with high tide. However, on December 23, 1954, the redirection of the track occurred at a more favorable time: no extreme storm surge could develop because the storm subsided significantly during the rising storm tide. A situation like that on January 3, 1976, would have meant a catastrophe of unimaginable proportions in 1954, given the very poor condition of coastal protection structures and the much too low dikes along the entire German North Sea coast at the time.

Due to the dramatic development of the weather situation during the course of December 23, 1954, it initially had to be assumed that the entire German North Sea coast would be affected by a very severe storm surge. The forecasts for December 23 indicated an expected maximum water level of 999 cm P.N. or 499 cm NN for Cuxhaven. Thus, water levels at the Cuxhaven gauge would have been expected to approximately match the levels reached during the February storm surge of 1962 and the Capella hurricane of 1976. The storm surge of December 23/24, 1954, encountered a largely undeveloped and completely outdated dike system. During the war and hardship years from 1914 to the early 1950s, dike maintenance was marked by severe material shortages, labor shortages, and more, so that many dike sections not only had insufficient height but were also in poor maintenance condition. It was only due to favorable circumstances that Germany did not experience a flood disaster like the one in the Netherlands and Belgium in 1953 during Christmas 1954. In 1954, nine years after the end of World War II, German authorities had no army units available to support rescue and security measures. Civil defense was also not yet developed enough to be capable of handling such a disaster.

Severe damage occurred on the North Sea islands. Parts of the beach wall at the western tip of Borkum were completely destroyed. Severe damage also occurred at the western tip of Baltrum. Dangerous situations arose at the sea dike east of Bensersiel and Neuharlingersiel, where the heavily damaged sea dike partially broke. However, the damage was quickly repaired, and the danger was averted. At Maadesiel in Wilhelmshaven, all efforts came too late; the dike could not be held and broke over a length of 70 to 80 meters. On Neuwerk, the situation became so critical that the population had to seek shelter in the lighthouse. Severe dune erosion occurred on Sylt.

At the power dikes of the Ems, dangerous situations arose due to their insufficient height; near Leer, the Ledasperrwerk, which had only been put into operation in July 1954, had an extremely positive effect. It prevented the storm surge from penetrating the river areas of Leda, Jümme, Sagter Ems, and Soeste and causing damage there.

Insufficient dike heights, a multitude of buildings and facilities in and on the dike, as well as the poor condition of the dikes, led to dangerous situations along the Weser. Near Nordenham, a dike broke, causing the flooding of the hinterland. Traffic on the Hude–Blexen railway line came to a standstill because the railway facilities in Elsfleth, Nordenham, and Blexen, as well as the Lemwerder station on the Delmenhorst–Lemwerder railway line, were flooded. In the port areas, which at the time were not yet protected by flood walls and flood gates, severe damage occurred in some cases because the water could enter storage sheds almost unhindered. Along the river courses of the Hunte, Lesum, Hamme, Wümme, and Ochtum, the storm surge penetrated far into the hinterland. Parts of Bremen-Huchting were also flooded. Here, as in other residential areas not protected by main dikes, the situation became so dangerous that the small garden areas inhabited by bombed-out residents at Wardamm, in Surfeld, on Stadtwerder, as well as on Rablinghauser and Woltmerhauser Groden, had to be partially evacuated. In the area of the municipality of Hasbergen, which today belongs to Delmenhorst, several hundred hectares of land were flooded. The farmsteads located on mounds could only be reached by boat until after Christmas 1954. The situation became critical at the Ritterhude lock on the Hamme. To prevent a breach of the connecting dike to the lock, the responsible authorities had the lock opened, as neither the lock nor the connecting dike had sufficient height to withstand the storm surge. However, the very high flow velocities occurring in the lock chamber during the storm surge led to scouring and severe damage to the hydraulic structure.

The storm surge also penetrated far into the hinterland along the tributaries of the Elbe. At that time, the Oste, Stör, Lühe, Este, Schwinge, and Ilmenau were not yet secured with storm surge barriers, resulting in flooding of low-lying urban and harbor areas in cities such as Stade, Itzehoe, Buxtehude, Elmshorn, and Bremervörde. In many places, the water reached the crest of the dikes, which were far too low. In Hamburg, low-lying districts in the city center, such as Baumwall, were flooded; severe damage occurred in the harbor area, which at that time was not yet protected by flood gates and flood walls. A very dangerous situation arose in Moorfleet in the Süderelbmarsch. A dike breach that had already begun there was prevented at the last minute by all possible means.

Nine years after the end of the Second World War, the cities were still partly characterized by plots of ruins with high wall remnants. The high wind pressure of the hurricanes caused unstable walls to give way and collapse, for example, in Bremen and Berlin. In Hamburg, the roof of a high-rise building on Grindelberg was torn off, and the debris was hurled onto another high-rise building. Severe damage from windthrow occurred in the forests of northern Germany. In Wilhelmshaven, a worker was killed on the site of the then munitions defusing facility by the ceiling of a massive bunker, which was pushed in by the wind pressure.

The New Year's flood of 1721 caused significant damage to the North Sea coast from December 31, 1720, to January 1, 1721. Three years after the Christmas flood of 1717, the even higher New Year's flood destroyed numerous dikes that had been provisionally repaired. The storm was not as severe as in previous floods but lasted longer.

On Föhr, the water penetrated the land after the dike broke and flooded the Föhr marsh. On Nordstrandischmoor, all the walls of the parsonage were pushed in, and the church was devastated; the pulpit, altar, confessional, and all the seating were washed away. All houses were damaged, and three were swept into the sea. The Hallig Hooge was flooded, and the water carried away four houses, with the remaining houses almost completely ruined. Nordmarsch was partially flooded by the high tide. Two hours later, the houses on the mounds were struck by water, and seven of them were swept away. A woman and her two small children drowned. The church on Langeneß was damaged, and the churchyard was so severely devastated that many corpses were washed out of their graves and carried away. Additionally, seven cows and 39 sheep drowned. On Oland, almost all houses were damaged. All polders in the Duchy of Schleswig were flooded, except for the two Christian-Albrechts polders in the Tondern district. Südermarsch was struck by water, and the Porrenkoog was completely submerged. In Husum, the water rose higher than during the floods of 1717 and 1718; bridges were destroyed, and water remained in the houses for days. At the Eddelaker Brack in Dithmarschen, the water swept away some nearby houses, resulting in the loss of several lives. At Kudensee, a new brack formed, 50 to 100 feet wide and 16 feet deep. It was assumed that the water this time stood almost a foot higher than during the floods of 1717 and 1718. In the villages of Aebtissinwisch and Seedorf, the water rose almost two feet higher than during the 1718 flood, causing even more damage. A three-acre piece of high moor nearby, which had already suffered greatly during the previous flood, was torn away, rendering the lands of two neighboring farms unusable. The Elbe dike from Sankt Margarethen to Wewelsfleth was severely damaged and almost completely torn apart, causing the floodwaters to pour over it at a height of more than a ton. The houses on the dike in Brokdorf were partially washed away or heavily damaged. The water flowed into the Gujer marsh and then over the Ohlenburgsfühldeich, where a ground breach occurred, flooding the Beckmünder land and Brockmoor entirely. On the other side of the Stör, Heiligenstedtenerkamp, Hochdorper, and Barenflether land were partially flooded. At Heiligenstedten, the flood ran through all the houses on the dike, and in the new poorhouse, the water stood over a foot high. The Wilsterau overflowed, and the villages of Moorhusen and Neuendorf-Sachsenbande were submerged under four to five feet of water. In the Wilstermarsch, this flood also surpassed the floods of previous years in extent and height. The Wilstermarsch was turned into a lake by the flood, with five people drowning and much livestock lost. The island of Helgoland was separated from the Düne due to the storm surge when the stone wall, the land connection, was flooded and eroded. Some houses on the foreland were swept into the sea. In East Frisia, the dikes were relocated further inland due to a lack of earth, and the villages of Bettewehr II and the submerged Itzendorf from 1717 were de-diked and abandoned.

The second January flood of 1976[1] on the night of January 20 to 21, 1976, was one of the highest storm surges of the 20th century on the German and Danish North Sea coast and the Elbe region. 17 days earlier, on January 3, the slightly stronger first January flood of 1976 had occurred due to the Capella hurricane, which was the highest storm surge of the 20th century in many areas.

The storm surge of January 21, 1976, marked the end of a west wind weather pattern that had persisted since December 1975. The peak of this weather pattern was the Capella storm of January 3, 1976. The starting point for the development of the weather situation leading to the storm surge was the western Atlantic off the American East Coast and Greenland. Here, on January 19, 1976, subtropical warm air advanced far to the north. At the same time, very cold polar air from the Greenland/North Canada region moved southward to the west. Under these conditions, a low-pressure system formed, which deepened rapidly and moved slowly from the Iceland region over the European North Sea to southern Sweden. On the backside of the storm low, the Azores High intensified, resulting in a very strong northwesterly flow that allowed the polar cold air ready on the backside to advance into Central Europe. A very sharp air pressure gradient developed in the process. Due to its spatial size and low movement speed, the low-pressure system was able to form a very large storm field, which on January 20, 1976, extended from southern Greenland into the German Bight. This meant that a very severe storm surge had to be expected along the German North Sea coast, even though the peak wind speeds in the German Bight were far from reaching the levels of the Capella storm or the Adolph Bermpohl storm of 1967. The strongest hurricane gusts occurred at low tide, but in some places, such as the Halligen islands off the North Frisian coast, the tide still rose higher than during the devastating storm surge of 1962, in some cases reaching or exceeding the levels of the Capella surge. In Bremerhaven, a water level of 4.91 m above sea level was recorded (only 40 cm below the 1962 record). The Hallig Hooge measured 9.12 m above sea level (2.5 m above mean high tide, only 2 cm below the highest level ever recorded). In Havneby on Rømø, for example, the tide was higher than during the first January event (and also the fourth-highest event since 1825). A month later, on February 23, there was another severe but significantly lower storm surge (Büsum NN+4.04 m).

The damage remained comparatively minor because many dikes along the North Sea coast had been reinforced after 1962. On Sylt, for example, where the water level was similarly high as in 1962, the new dikes held only with additional sandbag reinforcements. In some places, dikes that had been hastily repaired after the first January event broke again. In the evening at 7:30 PM, a water level of 4.50 meters above normal high tide was forecast for the Halligen. Many people had spent days clearing mud from their homes and now had to leave their houses again when the disaster management team in Husum declared a full alert at 12:30 AM. Although the water along the coast did not rise as high as feared, it was higher on some Halligen than on January 3. Many of the Halligen were flooded again. On Amrum and Föhr, water levels were measured 20 centimeters higher than 17 days earlier. New significant damage occurred on Amrum. Land erosion took place on the southern beach of Wyk on Föhr, but the Wyk seawall and the pre-fillings proved effective as on January 3. Near Steenodde, ten houses were at risk due to an impending dune breach, which ultimately did not occur. Although the water level in Husum was 78 centimeters lower than on January 3 and 33 centimeters lower than in 1962, the disaster management team ordered the evacuation of Grothusenkoog in Eiderstedt. However, its 25 residents refused to leave and chose to stay with their livestock. Near Westerhever, three firefighters were in danger; they were blown off the dike into the water by the storm but managed to save themselves. On Sylt, four meters of the cliff were torn away near List, and the beach hall was now only 30 meters from the edge of the cliff. At the Hörnum gauge, water levels were higher than on January 3, and there were again significant dangers for the border area north of the Hindenburg Dam. In Denmark, the new Friedrichskoog near Højer Sogn and the Rutebüllkoog were evacuated, over 500 sick and elderly people were brought to safety from Tønder, and evacuation was again ordered for the 7,500 residents. As a precaution, a long train was ready at the station. In the Haseldorfer Marsch, at the northern edge of the Elbe estuary, the dikes destroyed between Holm and Hetlingen during the first January flood were not fully closed until January 20. Due to the expected water masses, the situation became dramatically tense again on the night of January 20 to 21. Surge heights of 4 to 4.50 meters above mean high tide were expected. Around 6 PM, soldiers formed a sandbag chain and reinforced the inner slopes of the broken dike sections. Starting at 8 PM on January 20, precautionary evacuation began in the Haseldorfer Marsch. By 1 AM, all lower-lying farms had been cleared of people and livestock. Due to flood warnings from Cuxhaven, disaster alarms were triggered at 2:30 AM. By 4 AM, the evacuation buses provided by the Bundeswehr and police vehicles were withdrawn from the marsh to avoid being trapped in the event of another flood. At 6 AM, the water masses reached a height of 3.87 meters above MTHW, but the patched dikes withstood the water masses, and an all-clear could be given. In the Kehdinger Land near Dornbusch in the Lower Saxony Elbe region, a section of the dike that had been only hastily repaired after the first January flood broke. This led to further significant flooding in the inland area. However, the consequences here were limited. For the storage facilities in the Hamburg port area and the adjacent areas where dikes had broken on January 3, this storm surge had particularly severe effects. Due to immediate construction measures, most dike breaches had been closed or hastily patched, but industrial and storage halls in Hamburg and other adjacent areas were again flooded meters high.

Although the second January event was probably one of the highest North Sea floods of the 20th century overall, it remained surprisingly unnoticed. Bernd Rieken pointed out in 2005 that, for example, Die Welt and the Süddeutsche Zeitung, both on January 22, largely limited their reporting to the front page of an issue.[16] The author places this in the context that the first flood in 1976 was already seen as a success experience of the "feasibility" mentality of the 1970s – while during the 1962 event, "civilization-critical tones"[16] could still be found, including the quote of the "finger of God" – and notes that "it therefore need not be surprising that [… it] only elicited a minor response in the national press."[16]

Whole_Text.content:
Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The flood of 1861 affected a large part of Betuwe, in the Netherlands, with several dikes breaking.  
After a cold period around Christmas 1860, ice blocked the course of the Waal. Residents quickly became concerned about rising water levels, and on January 5 at 4 a.m., a breach in the Waaldijk at Brakel caused significant damage. The house of the lord of Poederoijen served as a refuge. The villages of Nederhemert, Well, Ammerzoden, Hedel, Rossum, and Gameren are well situated along the dikes, but many houses had already been built in the polders below the villages and were flooded. The villages of Bruchem and Kerkwijk suffered greatly from the flood. The choir of the large Reformed church in Kerkwijk was completely submerged.

Article_Name: Watersnood in het Land van Maas en Waal 1861

Whole_Text.header: Flood in the Land of Maas and Waal 1861
Whole_Text.content: The flood disaster in the Land of Maas and Waal in February 1861 was a flood caused by ice drift in the Waal. A significant ice dam formed in the Pannerdensch Canal due to drifting ice, leading to an increased flow of water and ice floes through the Waal. An ice dam had already formed near Ochten on January 31, but it gave way under the pressure of the water. At a narrowing near Varik, the ice got stuck again. This time, the ice did not move again, and the water began to rise. In several places, the water flowed over the dikes until it broke through the Waalbandijk near present-day Beneden-Leeuwen on February 1. In the subsequent flooding, 37 people drowned, all residents of Leeuwen. The victims were people who lived just behind the dike or had sought protection on the dike behind an emergency dike. The breach caused the entire Land of Maas and Waal to flood. It took until May for most of the water to recede. The water in the Waal was so high that it eventually flowed over the dike near Alphen into the Maas.

After this flood, the immediately preceding flood in the Bommelerwaard in 1861, and King Willem III's visit to Brakel and Beneden-Leeuwen, Rijkswaterstaat announced the initiation of a study on river regulation to investigate 'which means could be employed to alleviate the experienced calamities as much as possible and to prevent their recurrence.' This led to the initial works of the later Maas improvement.

Info_Box:
Year: 1861  
Date: February 1, 1861  
Region: Land van Maas en Waal  
Deaths: 37  
Damage: enormous

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about the history of the Netherlands. On November 16, 1377, the coastal regions of Holland, Zeeland, and Flanders were affected by severe flooding following a tidal wave. Many dikes gave way, and many villages were flooded.

During the flooding of the Meuse in 1643, the Meuse reached its highest water level in centuries, and in the centuries that followed, the Meuse would never again reach such a high water level. The many dike breaches and floods caused enormous damage and claimed the lives of hundreds of people. The volume of water discharge is estimated at 3,600 m³/s, more than 15 times the average discharge of the Meuse. In Huy, the high water destroyed factories, mills, and 200 houses, and between 65 and 80 people lost their lives. The Cistercian abbey of Val-Benoît near Liège flooded, and in the city itself, the Outremeuse district was completely submerged. On January 15, 1643, the Pont des Arches collapsed, causing the Saint Paul's Church to flood due to the surge. The water rose in the church, which at the time was located on an island in the Meuse, to a height of 1.35 meters. A plaque with a chronogram was placed in the church: aLtIVs eXpanso fLVMIne DVXIt aqVas (The overflowing river led its waters to this height) indicates the year 1643: L (50) + I (1) + V (5) + X (10) + L (50) + V (5) + M (1000) + I (1) + D (500) + V (5) + X (10) + I (1) + V (5) = 1643. In Maastricht, the Meuse reached a height of 47.89 meters above NAP, almost a meter higher than during the major floods of 1926 and 1993. At Meers, the dikes and the old part of the village were washed away. The old castle of Elsloo disappeared forever into the Meuse: the ruins can still be seen during very low water levels. The village of Obbicht was completely washed away on January 15 after a dike breach, possibly resulting in more than 500 deaths. At the time, the village was located further west where the nature reserve Negenoord is now, in present-day Belgium. The Meuse used to bend westward under Obbicht Castle, ran northward between Stokkem and Obbicht, and turned eastward again near Dilsen. In Venlo, the highest water level of 19.50 meters above NAP was reached on January 17, as evidenced by an embedded memorial stone in the city center stating that this level was reached on St. Anthony's Day 1643; the feast day of Anthony of Egypt is January 17. 838 · 1014 · 1042 · 1134 · 1163 · 1164 · 1170 · 1196 · 1212 · 1214 · 1219 · 1220 · 1221 · 1248/1249 · 1277 · 1280 · 1282 · 1287 · 1288 (I) · 1288 (II) · 1322 · 1334 · 1362 · 1374 · 1375 · 1377 · 1404 · 1421 · 1424 · 1468 · 1477 · 1509 · 1514 · 1530 · 1532 · 1552 · 1566 · 1570 · 1610 · 1643 · 1651 · 1675 · 1682 · 1686 · 1703 · 1717 · 1726 · 1741 · 1775 · 1776 · 1784 · 1799 · 1808 · 1809 · 1820 · 1825 · 1855 · 1861 (I) · 1861 (II) · 1877 · 1906 · 1916 · 1926 · 1953 · 1962 · 1993 · 1995 · 2006 · 2021

The All Saints' Flood of 1627 occurred on November 7, 1627. The storm surge flooded large parts of the Elbe marshland in the Lower Elbe with dike breaches and significant damage in the Altes Land, the Haseldorf Marsh, Elmshorn, and Uetersen.

The bad weather in Liguria on October 29-30, 2018, is a series of atmospheric events that occurred during those days in Liguria, affecting a large part of the municipalities along the coasts of the Riviera di Ponente and Riviera di Levante, the regional capital, and the inland areas, as part of the wave of bad weather in Italy in October-November 2018.

The persistence of adverse weather phenomena for several days, following which the Civil Protection of the Liguria region had already issued yellow and orange weather alert warnings for the respective basins, led the same body to declare a maximum alert level (red alert) for the entire day of Monday, October 29, 2018, for basins B, C, D, and E, corresponding to the Genoese Riviera, part of the western Riviera, the central inland area of the region, and the entire eastern Riviera. For basin A, which includes the stretch of the western Riviera between Ventimiglia and Noli, the entire province of Imperia, and the Centa Valley, the alert remained at yellow and orange levels. In the preceding days, violent torrential rain affected almost the entire Ligurian territory, with significant short-term water accumulations recorded—especially in the Genoese hinterland (upper Scrivia Valley, Trebbia Valley, and Bisagno Valley), Chiavari area (Aveto Valley, Fontanabuona Valley, and Sturla Valley), and the La Spezia area (Cinque Terre and Vara Valley)—and the presence of landslides, mudslides, and flooding in various municipalities. In addition to the intense rainfall, another source of danger was the strong gusts of wind (in some measurements in the eastern Liguria exceeding 100-120 km/h and, in the west, up to 180 km/h, as recorded by sensors at the Loano Marina) and the resulting storm surges, which, fueled by the wind's force, affected the entire Ligurian coastline, especially in the Savona, Genoa, and Tigullio areas. The wind was the cause of the death of the only victim of the bad weather: an 88-year-old woman from Albisola Superiore, struck by parts of a roof and cornice blown into the street by the violent and sudden atmospheric phenomenon, who later died at the Savona hospital from the severe injuries sustained. The combined action of the wind gusts and the sea's wave motion caused the most significant damage on October 29 and 30, both in the public and private sectors, during the entire emergency phase of the meteorological event. Violent waves, some as high as 7-10 meters (the maximum height, measured by instruments at the Capo Mele buoy in the Savona area, was 10.31 meters), violently struck the Savona and Genoa coasts, causing the near-total destruction of existing beach facilities (structures, outdoor areas, piers) and the erasure of entire stretches of sandy and pebbly beaches. An initial assessment by the local Italian beach operators' union, in the hours following the storm surge on October 29, estimated that out of approximately 1,300 equipped Ligurian beach establishments, about 100 were completely destroyed, and about 400 were seriously damaged, with damages amounting to at least 50 million euros. In the municipality of Genoa, in addition to monitoring the main Bisagno and Polcevera streams (the latter being a special focus following the collapse of the Morandi Bridge just over two months earlier), the violent storm surge caused damage along the entire Genoese coastline, from Voltri to Nervi. There were collapses of some sections of the Anita Garibaldi promenade in Nervi and devastation in the fishing village of Boccadasse and the private and public infrastructure of the Sturla, Pegli, and Voltri districts, with damages estimated at around 8 million euros. The sea's force also struck port infrastructure: particularly affected were the public port of Santa Margherita Ligure and the international tourist port "Carlo Riva" in Rapallo, with the collapse of their respective breakwaters. The sudden collapse of some sections of the containment walls caused subsequent vulnerability of the ports themselves, as well as the coastal stretches of the two cities in western Tigullio, with flooding and damage to seafronts and commercial activities located there. In Santa Margherita Ligure, after the collapse of about 10 meters of the breakwater in a section renovated and reinforced with work completed in 2014, damages were recorded to port services and the local Coast Guard barracks, the sinking of boats, and flooding of the main road along the marina. Towards Portofino, the fury of the sea caused the complete collapse of a section of the provincial road 227 near the Paraggi hamlet and severe damage to the structure of the famous nightclub Covo di Nord-Est. The road's collapse isolated Portofino from Santa Margherita Ligure by road—the SP 227 being the only drivable artery serving Portofino—making the municipality accessible only by sea, with the help of boats and vessels, or by land via trails and forest paths on the namesake promontory. To address the emergency situation, the Portofino Park Authority and the administrations of Portofino and Santa Margherita Ligure authorized the semi-drivable adaptation (for two-wheeled vehicles and emergency vehicles) of some pedestrian forest paths, particularly the section between Portofino Vetta and Portofino Mare and between the Nozarego hamlet of Santa Margherita and the Gassetta Mill (known as the Gave trail). This intervention, for some techniques considered too cementitious, was later contested by some environmental associations, followed by actual checks by the forest police; at the end of November of the same year, work on the trail was halted by the park authority, also for the adaptation of the other path towards Portofino. On the provincial road section between Santa Margherita Ligure and Paraggi, however, a temporary cantilevered pedestrian walkway was built between late November and early December 2018, initially used exclusively by local residents and later, during the Christmas period, opened to all pedestrians. Among the damages recorded in Portofino, besides the collapse of part of the central and famous "piazzetta" and the problems in connections with the centers of Santa Margherita Ligure, Rapallo, and the Golfo Paradiso, there was an interruption of electricity and gas services in the days following the event. In nearby Rapallo, on the night between October 29 and 30, the collapse of the breakwater, reinforced and expanded during the 2000s after a similar but less violent atmospheric phenomenon, caused major damage, with the sinking of numerous boats in the area between the public and private ports and, with the breaking of various moorings, the escape of hundreds of boats and yachts from the "Carlo Riva" port, which, adrift and at the mercy of the sea's wave motion, sank in the Rapallo Gulf or ran aground on the Vittorio Veneto seafront embankment and other areas to the west (Lido area and Boate stream mouth) and east of the city (San Francesco stream mouth area, near the local sea castle, and Nagge area). On the same night, 20 boaters present inside the marina and trapped in their boats due to the sea's fury were rescued by fire brigade teams. The grounding of the boats, some of considerable size and owned by prominent individuals, indirectly caused a massive media phenomenon due to the event's exceptional nature and scale, with footage and television reports from various national and international broadcasters. Due to the stranded boats, the city suffered damage to several private accommodation facilities along the seafront (damaged in several places) and especially to beach establishments, with the semi-destruction of fixed structures and piers. Along the seafront, there were several problems related to environmental factors, such as the possible fuel leakage from various boats (for these reasons, anti-pollution cloths were quickly installed around the boats); a huge amount of plastic, wood, and mixed waste was carried by the waves and scattered along the entire coastline, even completely clogging the stormwater drains. Compared to nearby Santa Margherita Ligure, which suffered more damage to public assets, the Rapallo area experienced the most damage in the private sector, with the international tourist port "Carlo Riva" being the primary victim. The port infrastructure, built in the 1970s and the first private tourist port in Italy, estimated damages to the structure at 10-15 million euros, and in November, a judicial investigation was opened by the Genoa Prosecutor's Office to determine and ascertain any responsibilities. A similar case file was opened by the Genoese judiciary for the events related to the collapse of the breakwater of the public port in Santa Margherita. In total, about 300 boats, yachts, and vessels were damaged; as of November 15, about 130 had been removed, with complex and delicate operations on the seafront and marina. Within the Rapallo municipal territory, severe damage was also recorded in the marine hamlet of San Michele di Pagana, with the destruction of local beach establishments and various commercial and dining activities, damage to stretches of beach and cliffs, the collapse of the pier in front of the square, the collapse of a section of the coastal road to Rapallo near the Arches Beach, and the collapse of various portions of the retaining walls of the land overlooking the sea and the coastal walkway connecting to the small inhabited area of Prelo. Towards the east, further storm surge damage was recorded in Zoagli, with the collapse of some sections of the cliff (both the eastern and western ones) and damage to commercial activities, and again in the eastern Tigullio area, with similar but less severe issues in Chiavari, Lavagna, Cavi di Lavagna, Sestri Levante, and Riva Trigoso. In the La Spezia Riviera, the damage caused by wind and storm surges was recorded in Monterosso al Mare, Vernazza, Riomaggiore, Portovenere, and the provincial capital itself. In the Western Riviera, the atmospheric phenomena affected the municipalities of Arenzano, Cogoleto, Celle Ligure, Albisola Marina, Savona, Bergeggi, Alassio, Finale Ligure, and other locations along the Savona coast. A similar situation also occurred in the province of Imperia, with damages recorded in the capital and Sanremo.

The exceptional nature of the atmospheric event, especially due to the vastness of the affected area, inevitably caused significant monetary damage across all economic sectors and infrastructures, both public and private. An approximate calculation, revised multiple times by the various affected territories, led to an estimate of damages by the Genoa Chamber of Commerce exceeding 100,000,000 euros in the municipalities of the Genoa province alone: 477 reports were filed by businesses and activities in 25 municipalities of the Genoa metropolitan city, of which 117 were in Genoa itself (damages of about 33,400,000 euros), 73 in Rapallo (about 23,500,000 euros), and 61 in Santa Margherita Ligure (about 23,300,000 euros). In the Imperia area, the estimate was about 18,000,000 euros for the municipality of Imperia alone. In the province of Savona, the assessment mainly concerned damage to various beach establishments, with a total exceeding 30,000,000 euros, including volumetric and commercial value lost and necessary for restarting. To address the initial critical issues, in January 2019, the National Department of Civil Protection allocated 6,500,000 euros for initial emergency interventions, of which 2,700,000 euros were to cover expenses incurred by municipal entities for assistance interventions and the remaining 4,700,000 euros for the restoration and adjustment of roadways. Specifically, 57 municipalities were involved in the funding allocation: 21 in the province of Savona, 15 in the province of Genoa, 14 in the province of La Spezia, and 7 in the province of Imperia. This amount was supplemented by an allocation of about 1,500,000 euros from the Liguria Region and an additional 8,000,000 euros allocated by the Stability Law for coastal defenses in Liguria.
Other projects
