Article_Name: Incendio forestal de Moratalla de 1994, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The Moratalla fire of 1994 began on July 4 of that year in the Spanish municipality of Moratalla, in the area known as Peñón del Serrano, due to a possible electrical failure. Almost the entire La Muela mountain range, the entire Cerezo mountain range, and the mountains located between it and the sanctuary of Nuestra Señora de la Esperanza in Calasparra, on the banks of the Segura River, were mainly burned, with the Hondares mountain range being spared. Investigations pointed to an electrical failure caused by the contact of a pine tree with the power lines, producing a spark, as maintenance work had been carried out on the area's wiring in previous days. The first signs of fire were calls from Moratalla residents around 10:30 in the morning on July 4, alerting about smoke coming from the mountain range. At its peak, the fire reached several fronts in Moratalla, Benizar, Camping La Puerta (which was evacuated), Calasparra, the Sotos and Bosque de la ribera de Cañaverosa natural reserve, and Cieza, covering a total of 90 km. Among other reasons, because it did not reach large population centers, there were no fatalities. It is currently considered the worst fire recorded in the Region of Murcia and one of the most significant in Spain.
The fire spread rapidly due to several factors:

After the fire, the Government of the Region of Murcia carried out various reforestation tasks with Pinus halepensis (Aleppo pine), cleaning of waste generated by forestry work, and construction of infrastructure in the area to combat fires, such as access roads and the creation of water points for the supply of firefighting resources.  
After the fire, a mesh had to be installed to prevent the fall of stones in the river conglomerate cliff that houses the Sanctuary of Hope. This site on the right bank of the Segura River was not affected in its garden area or the sanctuary itself, but it was on the left bank of the river and throughout the surrounding area, with very old specimens of hackberry (Celtis australis) on the right bank also burning but regrowing. The entire riparian forest area around the sanctuary is, twenty years later, in a state of conservation even better than in 1994 due to the intervention with the planting of native species on the right bank of the river.

Info_Box:
Location: Northwest Region, Region of Murcia (Spain)  
Date: July 4, 1994  
Source of ignition: Contact of a tree with the power line  
Reason: High temperatures with strong winds

Whole_Text.content: The Gotland forest fire in 1992 (also known as the Kraklingbo fire and the Torsburgen fire) was a massive wildfire that began early in the morning on July 9, 1992, on the island of Gotland, when a fire broke out in the forest in the southern part of Torsburgen. The fire did not claim any lives but became one of the largest forest fires in the country in recent times. The forest fire covered an area of more than 1,000 hectares, of which about 740 hectares were forest lands. As a result of the fire, the largest rescue operation in modern Gotland history was carried out.

On July 9, 1992, Gotland suffered from a severe forest fire. The beginning of the summer of 1992 was unusually warm and dry, and the ground was parched. On this day, there was also a fresh southern wind of about 15 m/s. The fire started in the forest on the southern part of the ancient Torsburgen castle, a few hundred meters north of Ardre Luka. The fire quickly spread and soon became a crown fire, and due to the wind, a fire tornado with a two-kilometer front formed, advancing north towards the Heideby farm and the Kräklingbo church. The fire was fought on three fronts. Two flanks, each six kilometers long, were slowly spreading outward, and a 2.5-kilometer-wide front in the north was spreading very quickly.

Within 24 hours, on the morning of July 10, 1992, the fire had reached a width of one kilometer and a length of about five kilometers. By this time, around a hundred firefighters, 60 conscripts from the Visby garrison, and several volunteers were at the scene. A rescue center was established at the fire station in Kräklingbo. A Q-90 helicopter from Visby and a Q-4 helicopter were deployed to fight the fire from the air. Later, an additional Q-97 helicopter with a blocked crew was deployed. Finally, a Q-91 helicopter also participated. During the fire, these helicopters flew a total of almost 44 hours. A total of 414 barrels of water, approximately 800 cubic meters, were dropped. Throughout the day, the fire came closer to three farms in Hejdeby, and emergency services prepared to evacuate all residents of the area. Chaos reigned on the farms, and many people did not know what to do. Nisse Olofsson, a former fire station chief in Kräklingbo, along with 20 other people, took on the task of fighting the fire in Hejdeby. They managed to set a counterfire, and when the fire was just 10 meters away from Thor's farm, they succeeded in stopping it. The flames then rose 30 meters into the air. By the evening of July 11, firebreaks around the area were secured, but the fire was still burning intensely inside. On the morning broadcast of July 13, local radio announced: "The rescue service management asks us to announce that all firefighters and fire protection staff on leave should report to the Visby station as soon as possible." Shortly afterward, it was announced that the worst danger seemed to have passed. On the night and morning of July 13, light rain fell on Gotland, which helped extinguish the fire. During the night, an intensive firefighting operation was conducted in Thorsburgen itself, hoping to prevent the fire from spreading further in the area. However, personnel had to be withdrawn from the area due to falling trees. About fifty firefighters guarded the southern part of the site, and it was now considered that the fire was fully under control.

In total, the fire affected more than 1,000 hectares, of which about 740 hectares were forest lands in the predominantly Kräklingbo and Gammelgarn areas, impacting 41 landowners. In Torsburgen itself, almost the entire forest in the central and northern parts was damaged by the fire. It took a month before rescue services could declare the operation complete. The total cost of the rescue operation is estimated at approximately 18.5 million Swedish kronor. The armed forces supported the rescue operation by providing 400 military personnel, communication equipment, helicopters, and vehicles. However, the forest fire of 1992 was not the first in Torsburgen. When Carl Linnaeus visited Torsburgen in the summer of 1741, he noted that the plateau was almost completely devoid of forest, "for fire had long since consumed it." The fire Linnaeus refers to is likely a large forest fire that devastated significant parts of the parishes of Alskog, Ala, Ardre, and Kräklingbo in the summer of 1655. In the spring of 1993, the Swedish Forest Agency made several attempts on plots below the plateau, the so-called cage, to plant birch, pine, Austrian black pine, and larch. Black pine was chosen partly because it is more tolerant of high lime levels, and the long needles of this tree provide a lot of sparse growth.

Info_Box:
Tip: Forest fires  
Cause: The source of ignition is most likely a cigarette [1]  
Country: Sweden  
Location: Krioklingbo (Torsburgen), Gotland  
Date: July 9 -- July 13, 1992

Whole_Text.content: The Kure City Forest Fire (Kureshi Sanrinkasai) was a large-scale forest fire that occurred in Kure City, Hiroshima Prefecture, around 11 a.m. on April 27, 1971 (Showa 46). The fire was extinguished approximately 24 hours later, and although it did not spread to residential areas, it claimed the lives of 18 people, making it one of the worst forest fires in the postwar period [Note 1]. Additionally, this fire is referred to by various names, such as "Kure City Forest Fire" (Fire and Disaster Management Agency) and "Obariya Forest Fire" (Kure City Fire Department), named after the location where it occurred.

At 11:10 a.m. on April 27, 1971, a fire broke out in the privately-owned forest of Obariyama near the Kado-no-Kuchi irrigation pond in Hirocho, Kure City. The cause of the fire was a bonfire used for boiling water at a construction site by workers engaged in disaster recovery work on the waterway. The fire was fanned by the wind, spread to nearby dry grass, and quickly expanded. On that day, the weather was clear and dry, and a fire warning had been issued since the previous day. Additionally, there were adverse conditions with strong winds blowing from the east-southeast at an average of 5 meters per second and a maximum of 14 meters per second, causing the fire to rapidly engulf the forest.

At 11:18 a.m. on the same day, the Kure City Fire Department's East Fire Station received a report of the fire, and 16 firefighters rushed to the scene to begin firefighting efforts. However, the scale of the fire gradually expanded, prompting the dispatch of reinforcements, including 109 fire engines, 84 Kure City Fire Department personnel, and over 400 volunteer firefighters to the disaster site. Additionally, the fire department contacted the mayor of Kure City and the governor of Hiroshima Prefecture, requesting the deployment of the Self-Defense Forces. Ultimately, more than 1,900 personnel, including Kure City Fire Department staff, Hiroshima City Fire Department staff, Ground Self-Defense Force members, Maritime Self-Defense Force members, Forestry Bureau staff, and local volunteer firefighters, were involved in the firefighting efforts.

The fire's intensity did not subside easily and continued to burn for over 24 hours. By around 11 a.m. on the following day, April 28, the fire was extinguished with the help of rainfall. As a result, 115 hectares of national forest, 85 hectares of municipal forest, and 140 hectares of private forest, totaling 340 hectares, were burned. Fortunately, the fire did not spread to urban areas or residential houses. However, the unexpected situation led to a major tragedy, with 18 firefighters who were engaged in firefighting efforts being caught in the fire and losing their lives.

Whole_Text.header: Causes and lessons of the great disaster
Whole_Text.content:
As previously mentioned, the fire in which as many as 18 firefighters perished by burning to death was unprecedented [Note 2], and it was a tragedy that occurred during firefighting operations. The sequence of events is as follows. 

The East First Squad had been dispatched ahead to extinguish the forest fire, but the East Fire Department Chief sent the second squad, which was dispatched later, to the scene first. This second squad descended the ridge of the northern peak and entered the valley to prevent the fire from spreading eastward. However, due to strong winds blowing from the east-southeast that day, around 2:30 PM, the flames spread to fallow farmland, intensifying the fire. The first squad observed this and instructed the second squad to retreat, but by then, there was no response from the squad leader. By that time, the intensified flames were racing down the steep slope, and the entire valley was already engulfed in thick smoke. 

In response to this situation, the first squad immediately conducted rescue operations, but by 4:02 PM, the bodies of 13 firefighters were confirmed, and by 5:02 PM, the bodies of an additional 4 firefighters were found, totaling 17 fatalities. At 4:19 PM, one severely injured individual was rescued, but they succumbed to burns and passed away at the hospital on May 1. 

The cause of such an accident was attributed to the flames spreading at an unexpectedly rapid pace down the steep slope, leaving the firefighters with no escape route. To investigate this, researchers from the Fire and Disaster Management Agency visited the site and compared it with three similar forest fire cases that had occurred in the United States. They demonstrated the dangers of firefighting on steep slopes. As a result, it was determined that the phenomenon known as "flare-up" [Note 3] was responsible. 

Additionally, the decision by the first squad to send the second squad to the east side, downwind, despite the strong east-southeast winds, was criticized as a misjudgment. The issue of potentially underestimating the unique and localized meteorological conditions was raised, referencing past incidents such as the Iwanai Great Fire during the Toyamaru Typhoon in 1954 (Showa 29). This highlighted the necessity of considering the specific meteorological conditions of a region or district in future firefighting operations, leading to the installation of anemometers and hygrometers in mountainous areas nationwide. 

At the time, firefighting techniques for forest fires, such as aerial firefighting, were underdeveloped, and only one civilian helicopter was used for aerial firefighting in this incident. It was pointed out that "if aerial firefighting using helicopters and airplanes, as in the United States, had been the main method, such a tragedy might have been avoided." This led to calls for the enhancement of firefighting techniques and equipment for forest fires and the development of new firefighting agents. Particularly, as a lesson from this fire, firefighting helicopters began to be utilized in large-scale forest fires thereafter.

On March 25, 1977 (Showa 52), a forest fire occurred on Mt. Nukisan in Hiraodai, Kokuraminami Ward, Kitakyushu City, resulting in the deaths of five firefighters. The cause of the fire was a grassland controlled burn, and similar to the Obaruyama incident, flying sparks on steep slopes spread the damage.

Burned Area: 340 ha (840 acres)  
Cause: Fire caused by burning

Article_Name: 2000년 동해안 산불 - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: The East Coast wildfire is a massive wildfire that started on April 7, 2000, in Toseong-myeon, Goseong County, Gangwon Province, South Korea, and continued for 191 hours until April 15, burning 23,794 hectares of forest in areas including Goseong County, Samcheok City, Donghae City, Gangneung City in Gangwon Province, and Uljin County in North Gyeongsang Province, and displacing over 850 people.

Article_Name: Incendie du parc national de Tyresta de 1999 — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about Sweden. The Tyresta National Park fire of 1999 occurred from August 1 to August 7, 1999. Approximately 450 hectares of forest, about 10% of the park's total area, were destroyed during this incident. Although there were no casualties, it remains the fire that triggered the largest firefighting operation ever conducted in Sweden[1].

The fire broke out on Sunday, August 1, 1999, in the Tyresta National Park and the surrounding nature reserve. Having started east of Lake Stensjön, it quickly spread westward, crossing the Stensjön and Lanan lakes. By the evening of the same day, more than 200 hectares were engulfed in flames. The fire was very difficult to control, partly due to the challenges firefighters faced in accessing the heart of the park. More than 500 firefighters and twelve helicopters were needed to bring the fire under control. The fire was declared extinguished after a week. The toll was 450 hectares burned, including pines over 400 years old. Nine months later, the park was reopened to the public. The area affected by the fire was profoundly altered; where centuries-old trees once grew, there is now a charred and barren landscape, dominated by newly exposed rock.

The regeneration of the forest provided an opportunity for a new ecosystem to develop, by virtue of ecological succession. The fire thus gave scientists a unique opportunity to study the benefits of fire on forest life. Woolly and Bohemian geraniums were observed shortly after the fire, before wind-pollinated species, such as Scots pine and fireweed, took over. Although it was harmful to certain species, such as the capercaillie, others benefited from the fire, such as Melanophila acuminata. Furthermore, a few new species were discovered following the fire, such as Tritozyga tyrestaenensis. The fire, having destroyed the thick layer of peat covering the ground, also provided an excellent opportunity for archaeologists to explore the region. In 2000, an archaeological study succeeded in identifying more than 120 sites, most of which date back to the Stone Age. Quartz fragments, probably used for making weapons and tools, were particularly found.

Info_Box:
Type: Fire

Coordinates: 59° 11' north, 18° 17' east  
Date: August 1, 1999 - August 7, 1999

Whole_Text.content: The forest fire at Vännebo in 2008 was an extensive forest fire near Vännebo between Norhyttan and Ulriksberg in Ludvika municipality from June 10–13, 2008. The fire area on both sides of the Pajsoån is about six kilometers long in a west-east direction and up to two kilometers wide. A total of nearly 800 hectares (8 km²) burned, and the fire was the largest in Sweden that year in terms of area. The fire started when control was lost over a controlled burn. Large areas of young forest (up to 10-12 years old) were completely destroyed. The damaged forest is mainly owned by Bergvik Skog, managed by Stora Enso. About 100 hectares are privately owned and represented by Mellanskog.

Whole_Text.content:
Etajima Town, Aki District, Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan (now Etajima City)  
The Etajima Town Forest Fire (Etajima-chō Rinya Kasai) was a large-scale forest fire that occurred on June 1, 1978 (Showa 53) in Etajima Town, Aki District, Hiroshima Prefecture (now Etajima City).  
As of 2014, it remains the largest forest fire in Hiroshima Prefecture's history. [1]

It was a forest fire that occurred mainly around Mount Kuman and Mount Furutaka on Etajima (Nomi Island), burning continuously for over 44 hours across two days and nights, destroying 947 hectares, which accounted for 76% of the town's forest area in Etajima at the time. The spread of the fire was attributed to the weather conditions and topographical factors of the time. Reforestation efforts have since progressed, and the area is now covered in greenery.

Etajima corresponds to the eastern part of Nomi Island, which floats in Hiroshima Bay in the Seto Inland Sea. The highest peak is Mount Kuman with an elevation of 399.8m, and to its southeast stands Mount Furutaka with an elevation of 370.3m. The mountains form a ridgeline running from northwest to southeast. The slopes of these mountains are steep, ranging from 20 to 40 degrees, and the narrow coastal plains house residential areas and ports (such as Koyo Port). Additionally, along Etajima Bay in the southwest of the island, there are facilities related to the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force (such as the Target Drone Maintenance Unit, the Officer Candidate School, and the First Technical School of the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force). Due to the geographical factors of these steeply sloped mountains, fire-fighting water sources such as rivers and reservoirs were almost nonexistent in the event of large-scale fires. The bedrock at the fire site consists of granite (biotite granite) from the Mesozoic Cretaceous period, and the soil is weathered into gravel or sand-like material, known as "masa" soil. The burned vegetation, or the vegetation at the time, was dominated by compensatory vegetation, as barren mountains were prominent due to the poor soil on these steep slopes. As part of forest conservation projects, red pine and broad-leaved forests were planted.

This year, low rainfall continued mainly in western Japan from January. Until April, there was almost no influence of cold air, and in May, low rainfall occurred due to the influence of migratory high pressure systems. Among these, particularly in northern Kyushu, water shortages occurred, and water intake restrictions were implemented in Fukuoka City. Then, in June, due to the influence of the Pacific high-pressure system, high temperatures continued even during the rainy season, resulting in abnormally low rainfall. In Hiroshima Prefecture, an abnormal dryness advisory (at the time, now known as a dryness advisory) had been in effect since May, and due to this situation, forest areas at fire sites were also dry. Notably, on June 1, when the fire occurred, the advisory was still in effect.

On June 1, 1978 (Showa 53), around 4:00 PM, a grass fire near Miyanohara in Etajima Town spread to the forest and continued burning for over 44 hours across two days and nights. By the first day, it had reached the area near the summit of Mount Kuman, spreading further to the area around Mount Furutaka on the second day, and expanding even more on the third day. It burned 947 hectares, which accounted for 76% of the town's forest area at the time, and was extinguished at 12:45 PM on the third day. At one point, the fire approached residential areas, prompting evacuation advisories. In addition to local firefighters, the Self-Defense Forces were dispatched following a disaster deployment request from the prefecture. A total of 1,343 personnel from the Maritime Self-Defense Force's 1st Technical School and Officer Candidate School were deployed, along with the use of firefighting equipment. The direct damage to standing trees was estimated at 150 million yen (at the time).

The restoration of forests lost due to administrative actions initially focused on preventing landslides and later shifted to emphasizing forest conservation. Additionally, a greening campaign under the slogan "Everyone's Forest with Everyone's Effort" was promoted by the residents of Etajima Town.

Whole_Text.header: Wildfire in the forest of Ashikaga City, Reiwa 3 (2021)
Whole_Text.content: The 2021 Ashikaga Forest Fire (Reiwa 3 Ashikaga Forest Fire) was a fire that occurred around 3:30 PM on February 21, 2021 (Reiwa 3) in Ryogaizan and Tenguyama, Nishinomiya-cho, Ashikaga City, Tochigi Prefecture, burning 167 hectares.

Around 3:30 PM on February 21, 2021, a fire caused by dry air occurred in the forested area of Nishinomiya-cho, Ashikaga City, Tochigi Prefecture. According to firefighters, it was confirmed that approximately 50 square meters around the rest area near the mountain summit were burning. Ashikaga City issued evacuation advisories to 207 households in the city, but since some households could not evacuate immediately, city staff visited these households in pairs to check their health conditions and distribute masks and throat lozenges. About a month after the fire, on March 30, Ashikaga City announced that the cause of the wildfire was "presumed to be cigarettes." According to the city's fire department, multiple cigarette butts were found near the presumed ignition point, located 200 meters southwest of the mountain summit, leading to the conclusion about the cause of the fire.

The humidity at the time of the fire was 12%, a dry condition. During this season, there is a strong north wind called Akagi Oroshi, a seasonal wind blowing from Mount Akagi (Gunma Prefecture) to the north, and on the 23rd, a maximum instantaneous wind speed of 17 meters per second was observed in the nearby city of Sano[N 1]. The strong winds caused the fire to spread further and also interrupted firefighting efforts by helicopters[N 1].
On February 26, 2021, firefighters from 14 fire departments and headquarters, as well as over 100 members of the Ashikaga City Fire Brigade, were engaged in firefighting activities.

Helicopters from the Self-Defense Forces and the Tochigi Prefecture Fire and Disaster Prevention Aviation Unit, as well as fire and disaster prevention helicopters from the Miyagi Prefecture Fire and Disaster Prevention Aviation Unit, Saitama Prefecture Disaster Prevention Aviation Unit, Ibaraki Prefecture Disaster Prevention Aviation Unit, Yamanashi Prefecture Fire and Disaster Prevention Aviation Unit, Toyama Prefecture Fire and Disaster Prevention Aviation Unit, Tokyo Fire Department Aviation Unit, and Yokohama City Fire Bureau Aviation Firefighting Unit, conducted firefighting activities.

In response to this fire, donations of supplies have been pouring into the evacuation center established by Ashikaga City, both from within and outside the city. On the 27th, 10,000 masks were donated by the industrial waste disposal company Nikkan (Utsunomiya City) [N 14]. Additionally, donations exceeding 10 million yen (as of February 27, 2021) were made through the city's hometown tax system [N 14]. Although Ashikaga City is not recruiting volunteers, it is reported that nearly 50 offers of volunteer assistance have been received [N 14]. On March 21, 2021, a charity event for this fire, "Ashikaga Support Marche in Tochigi," was held at the plaza in front of the Tochigi Yatai Kaikan in Tochigi City's Mancho district [N 15].

In response to the incident, the "Ordinance to Protect Beautiful Forests from Fires" was enacted and implemented. It prohibits certain activities in all forests throughout the city. The purpose is to improve moral awareness, and no penalties are imposed. [N 16]  
[N 17] Additionally, during firefighting efforts, someone flew a drone, causing helicopter firefighting activities to be suspended for 1 to 2 hours. In response, the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism's Aviation Bureau revised the Aviation Law Enforcement Regulations to allow the designation of "emergency operation airspace." [N 18]

In Ashikaga City, a large-scale forest fire burning 72 hectares occurred in 2014, taking about two weeks to be extinguished [N 19]. On April 22, 2021, another forest fire broke out in Midori City, Gunma Prefecture, adjacent to Ashikaga City. At Oiwayama Bishamonten, located about 800 meters from the fire site, approximately 150 cultural properties were removed to avoid damage from the fire. However, due to the removal work and aging deterioration, damage was later found in 10 cultural properties, including the prefecturally designated cultural property, the principal image of Bishamonten [N 20].

Whole_Text.content: The forest fire at Lake Maggiore began on January 30, 2022, in the Swiss canton of Ticino.

Since January 30, 2022, around 4 a.m., the forest on Monte Gambarogno above Lake Maggiore was burning. In some areas, there had been no rainfall since December 8, 2021. Due to the strong north foehn, the fire spread quickly. According to the Ticino cantonal police, it involved six hectares of forest. Firefighters from Gambarogno and Bellinzona, three helicopters, and a Super Puma from the Swiss Army helped to reach the difficult-to-access area. On January 30, 45 people from the village of Indemini and 13 people from the hamlets of Ri, Pezze, and Boè were evacuated from their homes. For safety reasons, the border crossing to Italy at Indemini and the cantonal road passing through the wildfire area were closed. Support came from Italy. On January 13, 2022, Swiss authorities had imposed a ban on outdoor fires due to the drought. The firefighting efforts had to be interrupted during the night of February 1, 2022, due to darkness. However, the ten-member ground team remained on-site in subzero temperatures. In the following days, additional teams with a total of six helicopters were deployed. By February 9, 2022, 200 hectares of forest had burned. Due to the strong wind, the firefighting helicopters could only be used to a limited extent. On February 11, 2022, the firefighting efforts were concluded.

On January 31, 2022, the Ticino cantonal police were unable to provide any information on what caused the forest fire.[1] On February 2, 2022, the cantonal police of Ticino and Schwyz, as well as the public prosecutor's office, confirmed that their investigation had led them to two Swiss individuals. A 26-year-old and a 28-year-old man were arrested and interrogated. They are accused of negligently causing a conflagration. According to the public prosecutor's office, the two wild campers had neither adhered to the fire ban nor followed the usual precautions when handling fire. They also failed to extinguish the fire properly.[7][8] On February 9, 2022, Ticino television reported that the suspects had called the Ticino fire department. The two did not know the phone number of the Ticino fire department, searched for it on Google, and ended up contacting the volunteer fire department in Tessin on the Baltic Sea in northern Germany. When they realized their mistake, they hung up and did not call again. As reported by Radiotelevisione Svizzera, they later cooperated with the authorities and expressed their regret over the forest fire.[4][5] According to the police, the suspects are no longer in custody.[6]

Article_Name: Feux de forêt de 2023 au Canada — Wikipédia

Whole_Text.content: Edit - edit the code - edit Wikidata The 2023 wildfires in Canada are a series of wildfires occurring in Canada. Hundreds of outbreaks have been reported in total, including dozens that have become uncontrollable, forcing authorities to evacuate tens of thousands of people from regions threatened by flames and smoke. They are part of a vast series of fires affecting the entire country at this time. The wildfires are impacting air quality in Quebec and the eastern United States. As of early December 2023, there are still 281 active fires, including 41 uncontrolled, out of 6,673 fires reported during the year, of which 6,392 have been extinguished[1].

According to Radio-Canada, which cites figures and maps from the Société de protection des forêts contre le feu (SOPFEU), a government organization, more than 12 million hectares of forest have been destroyed since the beginning of 2023, mainly in the West and East of the country, and the main outbreaks were still not under control at the beginning of August. This total area of forest lost to fire, while provisional, roughly corresponds to a quarter of the surface area of metropolitan France. A disaster of such magnitude is unprecedented in Canada's history.

More than 6,068 fires have broken out in Canada since the beginning of the season. 1,063 are still active, including 686 deemed out of control. In total, the threshold of 16 million hectares burned has been surpassed. The province of Quebec has been the hardest hit, in the Abitibi-Témiscamingue region.

The fires were mainly triggered by lightning strikes during storm episodes. Thus, in May 2023, several fires ignited and spread quickly, overwhelming forest firefighting services. Favoring the spread, the low amounts of snow in the winter of 2022-23 left little moisture in the soil, causing rapid drying of vegetation. Several trees were also damaged during an ice storm, which increased the available fuel by adding dead wood to the layer of dried leaves. The absence of heavy rains subsequently maintained and worsened the problem.

As of July 18, 2023, 105 fires are still active in the province, 82 of which were out of control. Including international aid and members of the Canadian Armed Forces, 951 firefighters were deployed in Alberta. Across Canada, 885 fires, including 600 out of control, were recorded. On July 20, a Bell 205 helicopter from a private company equipped as a water bomber crashed near Rivière-la-Paix while fighting forest fires. The pilot, Ryan Gould, died. Statistics Canada announced in July that the hundred fires that ravaged Alberta during the month of May caused a 6.6% decrease in natural gas and conventional oil production.

On July 13, 2023, the government of British Columbia announced, as the province was affected by nearly 360 wildfires, the death of Devyn Gale, a 19-year-old firefighter, killed by a falling tree during a wildfire near Revelstoke. At the end of July, a 25-year-old Ontario firefighter died following the overturning of his all-terrain vehicle while participating in the fight against the Donnie Creek fire, about 150 km north of Fort St. John.

In Nova Scotia, they cover an area of 200 km2, mainly in Shelburne County[12]. Evacuation orders and local states of emergency have been implemented, leading to the evacuation of more than 20,000 people[13].

On August 2, the Society for the Protection of Forests Against Fire (SOPFEU) reported that twenty fires were active in the intensive zone, 70 in the northern zone, and that since the beginning of the year, 1,539,688.1 hectares had burned in the intensive zone and 3,580,256.7 hectares in the northern zone. Large-scale fires broke out in Abitibi-Témiscamingue, on the Côte-Nord, and in Northern Quebec. The Quebec government evacuated the most affected regions. As of November 14, 2023, SOPFEU reported a total of 4.5 million hectares of forest burned during the year 2023.

The government of Quebec implemented on June 9, 2023, a lump sum compensation of $1,500 per evacuated residence upon recommendation or order, while for Indigenous communities, compensation will be provided by Indigenous Services Canada. Municipalities must be reimbursed for expenses related to all evacuation measures, while relief organizations must be reimbursed for certain additional operating expenses.

The Society for the Protection of Forests Against Fire (SOPFEU) received assistance from the European Union on June 8, 2023, following the activation of the European Civil Protection Mechanism. France, Spain, and Portugal provided detachments comprising nearly 300 firefighters, while the Emergency Response Coordination Centre provided an expert. The French detachment, commanded by General Éric Flores, director of the Hérault Fire and Rescue Service (SDIS) and vice-president of the National Federation of Firefighters, consisted of 58 firefighters and 42 rescue firefighters from UIISC 1. The European reinforcements, equipped with specific fire boots and trained in the specificities of Quebec terrain, which does not allow the use of forest fire-fighting vehicles, were deployed to fires in the Chibougamau region (French and Spanish detachments) and Lebel-sur-Quévillon (Portuguese detachment, with support from U.S. reinforcements). A second detachment of 120 firefighters and rescue firefighters took over on June 28 before being replaced by a detachment of the same size on July 19. This last detachment included technicians responsible for deploying the Fenics telecommunications module. The efforts of these various detachments were concentrated around Pascagama, Windfall, and Chibougamau. To ensure coordination with local firefighters, a liaison officer worked within SOPFEU's command post and another in Winnipeg at the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre. On August 10, 2023, the mission of the last French detachment ended. The United States, Mexico, and South Africa also provided assistance, as did South Korea, which deployed a detachment of 150 firefighters on July 2.

In August 2023, all residents of the city of Yellowknife were ordered to evacuate before noon on August 17 due to wildfires. The evacuation order also applied to the communities of Ndilǫ, Dettah, and the Ingraham Trail road. As of that date, there were more than 230 wildfires in the Territories, and up to 20,000 km² had burned. On August 24, 2023, nearly 4,500 evacuees from the Yellowknife area were registered at the emergency reception center in Edmonton.

Fires are leading many companies to suspend their activities with a significant impact (6.8%) on the price of lumber futures contracts. Public Security Minister François Bonnardel indicated in early June his intention to authorize the forestry industry to harvest burned wood as soon as possible. This wood must be recovered as quickly as possible to avoid attacks by xylophagous insects such as the black longhorn beetle or cracking due to rapid drying. The forestry industry is requesting the rapid implementation of special exploitation plans to be able to utilize this wood.

On June 7, 2023, smoke from the fires reached a large part of the east coast of the United States, notably the city of New York, which had been affected since June 6. The United States Environmental Protection Agency consequently issued an orange alert for a territory of 100 million inhabitants stretching from Chicago to Atlanta, while Washington and New York were placed under a red alert. The severity of the fires acutely impacted air quality, particularly on the lands of Cree or Atikamekw communities, leading to recommendations to wear N95 masks. On June 12, Environment and Climate Change Canada issued a smog warning. On June 26, the smoke plume reached Europe.

With more than 130,000 km2 of forest destroyed, Canadian wildfires had released over 290 Mt of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere by the end of July. The federal government has planned to plant two billion trees by 2030, but academics recommend adapting tree species to limit fire risk in the boreal forest, which no longer serves as a carbon sink. For the entire year 2023, carbon dioxide emissions are estimated at 480 Mt, representing nearly a quarter of the emissions caused by wildfires worldwide during the same period.

This fire strongly fuels conspiracy theories, particularly led by politician Maxime Bernier, who claims that "they are started by eco-terrorists paid by the government to promote lockdowns and retaliatory measures against populations, disadvantaging them for the purpose of the Great Reset" (see also New World Order (conspiracy theory)), this concerning conspiracy theory threatening democratic powers according to its detractors, theories also developed by them following the fires in the Hawaiian Islands that same summer of 2023.

Whole_Text.content: Etajima City, Hiroshima Prefecture, Japan The Etajima City forest fire (Etajima-shi rinyakasai) is a large-scale forest fire that occurred in Etajima City, Hiroshima Prefecture, on January 13, 2024. Firefighting activities ended, and the fire was extinguished on January 17. There were no deaths or injuries caused by this fire.

At around 10:23 a.m. on January 13, 2024, a fire was reported near Mount Daho in Okimi, Ogaki-cho, Etajima City, prompting fire trucks to be dispatched, and the Hiroshima City Fire Department provided support with fire trucks. On this day, Etajima City had issued strong wind and dry weather advisories. In addition to the prefecture and Hiroshima City, helicopters from the Self-Defense Forces and fireboats from Hiroshima City also joined in firefighting efforts, and the fire was brought under control on January 16 and extinguished at 5:00 p.m. on January 17.

Article_Name: Požar na Krasu (2024) - Wikipedija, prosta enciklopedija

Whole_Text.content: On July 18, 2024, at 9:46, a fire was reported on the slopes of Trstelj and Kančnik above the village of Škrbina with two hotspots, one at the very top and the other near Lipa. The fire covered a total of around 90 hectares, initially estimated at up to 120 hectares.

On July 17, 2024, authorities issued a fire hazard warning for southwestern Slovenia. On July 18, around 10 a.m., fires broke out in two locations on the slopes of Trstelj (643 m above sea level) and Kančnik on the Karst Plateau. By 10:30, 45 firefighting units were on the scene. At 10:34, the commander of the Slovenian Civil Protection, Srečko Šestan, activated the national protection and rescue plan. The first aerial water drop occurred approximately half an hour after the fire was reported. At 1:00 p.m., the relevant authorities organized a press conference. During the firefighting efforts, 60 hectares of forest were cleared as an emergency measure. The fire initially threatened communication infrastructure at the top of Trstelj and the Stjenkova mountain hut below the summit, coming within 100 meters, but firefighters managed to protect the infrastructure. No settlements were endangered by the fire. Around 100 members of the Slovenian army also intervened at the scene, providing, among other things, food supplies. Civil protection was activated, with a headquarters set up in Lipa. During the fire, municipal authorities of the Municipality of Renče - Vogrsko advised against outdoor activities due to high smoke and heat exposure. The police issued a similar advisory for the wider region and also banned drone flights. Several roads in the broader Karst area were closed due to firefighting interventions. There were no evacuations of people in the area, but firefighters evacuated a flock of sheep on Trstelj. The international power line Sredipolje–Divača was disconnected. Rumors surfaced that the fire was deliberately set, and the police investigated these claims. Unlike the 2022 Karst fire, this fire affected an area less dangerous due to unexploded ordnance, but around 3 p.m., a 75-mm shell from World War I exploded near firefighters, with two more shells exploding during the night. Initial estimates suggested the fire affected around 150 hectares of forest, but this estimate was later revised. Aerial and helicopter units collectively dropped 155,000 liters of water on the fire, flying until 6 p.m., while 3,700 m³ of water was also pumped from the water supply system, according to Simon Vendramin, the intervention leader. By 5:30 p.m., the fire was still not under control. Firefighting planes dropped 3,000 liters of water every 12 minutes, completing a total of 56 runs. The night intervention leader on July 19, 2024, partially handed over fire coordination to foresters from the Forest Service. Mulching and mowing of central grassy strips on roads, as well as the creation of firebreaks, were carried out. By noon, 480 firefighters were on the scene, with a total of 550 protection service members involved. The fire was under control by noon. On July 19, Prime Minister Robert Golob visited the site, highlighting the benefits of purchasing firefighting planes, legislative changes, and upgrading the Karst water supply system. On the night of July 20, rain began to fall, aiding firefighters in containing the fire's edge. Around 350 firefighters were active at the site. On July 20, Srečko Šestan deactivated the protection and rescue plan. A total of 400 firefighters participated in the intervention, supported by helicopters from the Slovenian police and army, as well as two new Air Tractor AT-802 planes, which were deployed for the first time. Firefighting units arriving in the Karst on the morning of July 20 assisted other units in removing firefighting hoses from difficult-to-access terrain. Some units that had planned to arrive on the morning of July 20 had to cancel their intervention due to local storm responses elsewhere in Slovenia. On July 22, 2024, around 8 a.m., another fire broke out but was quickly extinguished. Roads closed due to firefighting interventions were reopened on July 22. Fire patrols were conducted in the broader fire area until July 25. After the fire was extinguished, Agriculture Minister Mateja Čalušić emphasized the need to simplify obtaining landowner consents for implementing further fire prevention measures and establishing recovery plans.

Article_Name: Incendios forestales en Chile de 2025, la enciclopedia libre

Whole_Text.content: The wildfires in Chile in 2025 originated on January 9 of that year in multiple locations in the regions of Coquimbo, Valparaíso, O'Higgins, Maule, Ñuble, Biobío, Araucanía, Los Ríos, and Los Lagos. As of February 9, the most severe fires have been concentrated in the La Araucanía Region.

On January 20, the authorities assessed the forest fires and maintained monitoring due to the forecast of high temperatures between the regions of Coquimbo and La Araucanía. It was reported that as of 12:30 p.m. that day, 8 fires were being fought and 16 were under control nationwide. The importance of coordination among the organizations of the National System for Disaster Prevention and Response (SINAPRED) to address the situation was emphasized. On February 8, the Chilean Meteorological Directorate issued a yellow alert for intense heat for several communes in the Coquimbo Region, including La Higuera, Vicuña, Paihuano, Río Hurtado, Monte Patria, Combarbalá, Illapel, and Salamanca. Maximum temperatures were forecasted to reach up to 36°C, increasing the risk of forest fires. Authorities urged the population to take precautionary measures and avoid activities that could generate sparks or fire in vegetated areas. The following day, the national director of the National Service for Disaster Prevention and Response (SENAPRED), Alicia Cebrián, reported that 15 forest fires were being fought nationwide, mainly concentrated in the La Araucanía Region. Although the Coquimbo Region did not have active fires at that time, the alert for high temperatures and the call for prevention remained in place.

On February 5, a forest fire broke out in the commune of Tiltil, in the Tapihue sector, affecting at least 150 hectares. The fire generated a large column of smoke visible from various localities in the Metropolitan and Valparaíso regions. Firefighters from various companies worked on the emergency to control the fire. On February 7, anticipating temperatures that could reach 40°C over the weekend, the Government of Chile declared a red alert in this region. Additionally, the "zero activity" measure was implemented, which involves the suspension of agricultural and forestry activities, as well as the closure of national parks during the month of February, to prevent fire risks. On February 8, SENAPRED ordered the evacuation of the Hacienda San Enrique sector, in the commune of Santo Domingo, due to a forest fire threatening the area. The measure was communicated through the Emergency Alert System (SAE).

On February 7, the Meteorological Directorate of Chile issued an extreme heat alert for the O'Higgins Region, with temperatures that could reach 37°C. Authorities recommended avoiding direct sun exposure, staying hydrated, and wearing light clothing and sunscreen. Additionally, the closure of national parks in the region was ordered to prevent forest fires. Two days later, regional authorities held a technical meeting to assess the situation in light of the extreme temperatures. Despite adverse forecasts, there was no significant increase in forest fires over the weekend, with only three incidents reported, which were controlled and extinguished. Preventive patrols were reinforced, and the community was urged not to light fires and to report risky behaviors.

On January 25, a forest fire occurred in the commune of San Javier, Maule Region, affecting more than 1,500 hectares. A Red Alert was declared in the area. On February 7, an alert was issued for an extreme heat wave in the region, with temperatures nearing 40°C. Authorities have recommended avoiding sun exposure and staying hydrated. Additionally, several national parks have been closed to prevent the risk of fires. The following day, the Chilean government declared a state of emergency in the Maule Region due to the magnitude of the forest fires. A curfew has been established in some communes to prevent acts of vandalism and facilitate emergency operations. Furthermore, fires have been reported in 15 sectors, with around 60 arrests for suspected arson.

On February 9 in the Ñuble Region, 22 forest fires remain active, while another six are under observation and 51 have been controlled. A curfew has been implemented in 12 communes of the region to prevent incidents and protect the inhabitants.

The Government of Chile declared a red alert in the Biobío Region on February 7 due to an extreme heatwave, with temperatures reaching 40°C. This measure involved the mobilization of resources to prevent and combat forest fires. Additionally, the closure of national parks in the region was ordered to reduce risks. On February 8, four active forest fires were reported in the communes of Mulchén, Hualqui, Santa Juana, and Tirúa, affecting more than 1,200 hectares. The most critical situation occurred in Mulchén, where the flames consumed approximately 1,200 hectares. Authorities evaluated the possibility of implementing a curfew to facilitate emergency efforts. The regional director of the National Forestry Corporation (Conaf), Esteban Krause, reported 11 fires in the region, highlighting the one in Chumulco in Mulchén, which affected around 1,300 hectares. He also expressed concern about a fire in the Punta de Parra area, in the commune of Tomé. The following day, SENAPRED declared a Red Alert for the Biobío Region due to the simultaneous occurrence of forest fires that directly threaten populated areas and pose a risk to people's lives. This decision was made after the emergence of new fire outbreaks in different parts of the commune of Mulchén. The regional presidential delegate, Eduardo Pacheco, reported that the fires are concentrated in three points of the region: Punta de Parra (commune of Tomé), Chumulco (commune of Mulchén), and La Greda (commune of Penco). It was noted that, so far, no people or homes have been directly affected by the forest fires. On February 14, two fire outbreaks in the forests of the hills of Lebu, the capital of the Arauco province, forced the evacuation of residents in that sector of the commune with sound alerts and notifications to cell phones. On the same day, a red alert was declared for the commune of Los Álamos due to a forest fire in the Araucana Tres Pinos sector that was dangerously approaching populated areas and had consumed 33 hectares of forest. The fire was brought under control the following day, and the alert was canceled.

On February 8, the fires in the La Araucanía Region forced the evacuation of more than 860,000 people. The death of an 84-year-old woman due to the flames was reported. Adverse weather conditions, with temperatures exceeding 40°C and strong winds, have made controlling the fire difficult. A red alert was declared in the region and a curfew in some municipalities. Additionally, five arrests have been made on suspicion of intentional arson. The following day, the Chilean government declared a preventive state of emergency in the La Araucanía Region. Authorities have deployed military patrols to prevent possible intentional fires. It has been reported that several fire hotspots remain active in the region, complicating containment efforts.

On January 9, the Regional Directorate of SENAPRED declared a Preventive Early Warning for the Los Ríos Region due to an extreme high-temperature event forecasted between January 11 and 12. A decrease in humidity in vegetation fuels and winds from the west were anticipated, conditions that favor the occurrence of forest fires. Authorities urged the population to take extreme precautions to prevent the generation of fires. On February 1, a forest fire in the Los Lagos commune affected an area of 4.7 hectares of vegetation. Thanks to the response of CONAF brigades and firefighters, the fire was controlled on the 5th of the same month without any reported damage to homes or injuries to people.

On January 12, the Regional Ministerial Secretariat of Agriculture reported that, to date, 125 forest fires had been recorded in the region, compared to the 2023-2024 cycle, affecting an area of 83.26 hectares. This figure represents an increase of 9 fires compared to the same period of the previous season. Authorities called on the population to intensify prevention measures, especially given the high temperatures and winds forecasted for the following days. On January 23, the Regional Presidential Delegate of Los Lagos, Paulina Muñoz, along with the Regional Director of CONAF, Miguel Leiva, and the Seremi of Agriculture, Tania Salas, provided an update on the 2024-2025 forest fire season. From July 1, 2024, to January 22, 2025, 167 forest fires were recorded in the region, affecting a total of 170 hectares, with seven in the province of Palena, 13 in the province of Osorno, 68 in the province of Llanquihue, and 79 in the province of Chiloé.

On January 20 in the Metropolitan Region, a fire in the commune of San José de Maipo affected more than 300 hectares of native forest and recreational areas. The fire forced the evacuation of residents and tourists, leaving several people displaced and causing damage to properties and tourist facilities. Emergency brigades worked hard to contain the fire and prevent its spread to inhabited areas. On January 20 in the commune of Cauquenes —Maule Region—, a forest fire consumed more than 500 hectares of native vegetation and forest plantations. The disaster left several families displaced and caused significant damage to agricultural infrastructure. Local authorities declared a red alert and coordinated efforts to control the fire and provide assistance to those affected. On February 8, Virginia Martínez, the first Chilean pathologist, died in the commune of Curepto due to the forest fire. During the January 20 fires in the La Araucanía Region, commune of Los Sauces, three brigadiers from the CMPC company died while fighting the flames. On February 8, a forest fire in the commune of Purén left 12 people displaced. Six homes and four additional structures are being evaluated to determine the level of damage. Local authorities have provided support to the affected families and are monitoring the situation to prevent new fire outbreaks.

In October 2024, the Government presented the 2024-2025 Action Plan to address forest fires, which includes the operation of 283 daytime brigades and 28 nighttime brigades, totaling 311 brigades nationwide; the incorporation of 74 aircraft, including planes and helicopters, for firefighting; the implementation of programs to reduce burns and manage combustible plant material; and the allocation of M$156,000,000 for the season, aimed at strengthening fire prevention and combat.

Whole_Text.header: Incorporation of the CH-47 Chinook helicopter
Whole_Text.content: To strengthen response capacity, the CH-47 Chinook helicopter, which has a water drop capacity of up to 10,000 liters per flight and a transfer speed of 220 km/h, was added to the fleet of the National Forestry Corporation (CONAF). This aircraft will operate from the Bernardo O’Higgins airfield in Chillán, Ñuble Region, and joins other additions such as two tanker planes with a capacity of 15,000 liters each and the Air Tractor AT-802A aircraft.
To monitor forest fires in real-time in Chile, CONAF has made digital tools available, including interactive maps and an alert system.

Climate change in Chile has been identified as a key factor in the increase of forest fires in the country. It is estimated that fires could increase by 30% by 2050 if preventive measures are not taken. Additionally, the lack of urban planning in areas that combine forest zones with human settlements has worsened the crisis.

On February 8, President Gabriel Boric declared a preventive state of emergency and curfew in several communes of La Araucanía due to forest fires that, according to him, show signs of having been intentionally caused. The president stated: "We have well-founded reasons to believe that a large part of the fires affecting the La Araucanía area today are intentional." He also instructed the Investigative Police (PDI) to deploy their best teams to investigate and find those responsible. Up to that date, more than 60 people had been arrested for their alleged involvement in starting fires in the region. On February 9, the National Disaster Prevention and Response Service (Senapred) issued evacuation alerts for areas of La Araucanía due to the spread of forest fires. Authorities reported that, as part of the investigations, five people were arrested that weekend, adding to the more than 60 previous arrests related to intentional fires. The penalties for these crimes can reach up to 20 years in prison.

Cooperation between Chile and the state of California in the United States has been strengthened for combating forest fires. CONAF teams have received training from CAL FIRE experts in advanced fire containment strategies.

Info_Box:
Location: Regions of Coquimbo, Valparaiso, O'Higgins, Maule, Nuble, Biobio, La Araucania, Los Rios, and Los Lagos (Chile)  
Date: January 20, 2025 - present

Whole_Text.content: This article is a stub about meteorology or climatology and the Mascarenes. Jenny is the name of a tropical cyclone that hit the Mascarenes in February 1962.

It formed near Diego Garcia on February 25, 1962, then moved towards Mauritius and Réunion Island at a speed of 35 km/h. On February 28, the alert was triggered in Mauritius at 4 a.m. It reached Réunion around 12:40 p.m. and lasted 2 hours.

Jenny hits Réunion with winds of 250 km/h and gusts reaching 280 km/h. It causes 37 fatalities and 150 injuries. The eastern part of the island was extremely affected. 16,000 people were left homeless.

Article_Name: Ciclone Olga (2010) – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Cyclone Olga (JTWC designation: 09S, or simply Cyclone Olga) was a tropical cyclone that affected the Solomon Islands and Australia at the end of January 2010. Being the seventh tropical system and the fourth named tropical cyclone of the 2009-2010 Australian region cyclone season and the fourth tropical system of the 2009-2010 South Pacific cyclone season, Olga formed from an area of meteorological disturbances on January 18, with the Regional Specialized Meteorological Center (RSMC) in Nadi, Fiji classifying it as tropical depression "04F." Moving west-southwest, the depression left the RSMC Nadi's area of responsibility to enter the area of responsibility of the Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) in Brisbane, Australia, two days later. On January 22, the system became a significant tropical cyclone and reached its peak intensity the following day, with maximum sustained winds of 95 km/h (1-minute sustained), according to the JTWC, or 100 km/h (10-minute sustained), according to the TCWC in Brisbane. From then on, Olga weakened rapidly before ceasing to be a significant tropical cyclone and making landfall in Queensland, Australia, on January 24. After several days over land, Olga became a significant tropical cyclone again on January 29, over the Gulf of Carpentaria, and made landfall on Queensland's west coast on January 30 with winds of up to 65 km/h. Over land again, Olga fully dissipated later that day. As a tropical depression, Olga caused two deaths in the Solomon Islands. In Australia, damages were limited to floods and flash floods, amounting to nearly 90 million dollars in losses.

Tropical Cyclone Olga formed from an area of meteorological disturbances east of the Solomon Islands that began to show signs of organization on January 18. As soon as the disturbance showed initial signs of organization, the Regional Specialized Meteorological Center (RSMC) in Nadi, designated by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) for monitoring tropical cyclones in the South Pacific Ocean, classified the system as a tropical disturbance, assigning it the designation "04F." Being in a region with reasonably favorable meteorological conditions, with moderate wind shear, areas of deep convection began to form around a broad and poorly defined low-level cyclonic center. Consequently, on January 19, the RSMC in Nadi classified the system as a tropical depression. Moving southwest, the depression left the RSMC Nadi's area of responsibility to enter the area of responsibility of the Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) in Brisbane, Australia, later that day. As a result, the RSMC in Nadi issued its final advisory on the system. Moving into the Coral Sea, the disturbance remained disorganized due to a slight increase in wind shear. However, even under unfavorable meteorological conditions, the low-level cyclonic circulation center began to consolidate with improved upper-level outflow. Consequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC), the United States Navy agency responsible for monitoring tropical cyclones, issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert (TCFA) on the system that evening (UTC), indicating that the disturbance could become a significant tropical cyclone within 12 to 24 hours. Shortly thereafter, the TCWC in Brisbane classified the system as a tropical cyclone and named it "Olga." The system continued to organize rapidly, and as the cyclone began to exhibit curved storm bands, the JTWC also classified the system as a significant tropical cyclone early on January 23 (UTC), assigning it the designation "09P." Moving westward along the periphery of a subtropical high to the south, Olga rapidly intensified as wind shear decreased. Consequently, the TCWC in Brisbane classified the system as a Category 2 tropical cyclone on the Australian scale later that afternoon (UTC). However, a sudden increase in wind shear and the cyclone's interaction with the remnants of Cyclone Neville prevented Olga from continuing to intensify. As a result, Olga reached its peak intensity on January 23, with maximum sustained winds of 95 km/h (1-minute sustained) according to the JTWC, or 100 km/h (10-minute sustained) according to the TCWC in Brisbane. From then on, Olga began to weaken as it moved southwestward toward the coast of Queensland, northern Australia. Consequently, the TCWC in Brisbane downgraded Olga to a Category 1 tropical cyclone early on January 24 (UTC). Olga continued to weaken that day, and all of its deep convection areas were removed by strong wind shear. Olga ceased to be a significant tropical cyclone later that morning (UTC), according to the TCWC in Brisbane. Later that day, the JTWC issued its final advisory on the system as weather models no longer predicted significant intensification of Olga before the system reached northeastern Australia. That evening, Olga's remnants made landfall in northeastern Australia and began moving west-northwest with no significant changes. However, two days later, the system began to show signs of reorganization as it approached the Gulf of Carpentaria. Wind shear subsided, and the formation of a mesoscale anticyclone over the system allowed for the establishment of good upper-level outflow. Consequently, the JTWC issued a new TCFA on the system on the afternoon of January 26 (UTC). Hours later, the JTWC resumed issuing regular advisories on Olga as curved storm bands formed around the low-level cyclonic circulation center. However, Olga unexpectedly moved south-southwest over the Northern Territory, moving away from the Gulf of Carpentaria. Over land, Olga began to weaken once again, and the JTWC issued its final advisory on the system on the morning of January 28 (UTC). Once again, forecasts failed, although the initial prediction prevailed; Olga's remnants moved northeastward, and on the morning of January 29 (UTC), the disturbance reached the Gulf of Carpentaria. Due to excellent meteorological conditions at that time, the JTWC issued another TCFA. Over the warm waters of the Gulf of Carpentaria, the system rapidly intensified, and the JTWC resumed issuing regular advisories on the system later that afternoon. Practically at the same time, the TCWC in Brisbane reclassified the system as a significant tropical cyclone. Moving east and southeast, Olga quickly crossed the Gulf of Carpentaria and made landfall on Queensland's west coast near the town of Burketown around 20:00 (UTC) that day, with winds of up to 65 km/h, according to the JTWC. Once again over land, Olga weakened, and the JTWC issued its final advisory early on January 30 (UTC). Practically at the same time, the TCWC in Brisbane downgraded Olga to a tropical low and also issued its final advisory on the system. Olga completely dissipated over eastern Australia later that day.

On January 23, the entire coast between Port Douglas and Cooktown, in the state of Queensland, northern Australia, was on cyclone alert. Days later, as the system approached the Gulf of Carpentaria coast, new cyclone alerts were issued for communities in the coastal regions of the gulf. The alerts and warnings were extended to almost all coastal regions around the gulf as Olga re-intensified on January 29. Still as a tropical depression, the system caused heavy rains in the Solomon Islands. The floods caused the death of two children from a camp and left one person injured. Another 153 people had to be evacuated from the banks of a river near the capital, Honiara. The rains also damaged some homes and bridges and caused landslides in some isolated regions. Few impacts were reported in association with the effects of Olga's passage over Queensland on January 24. In some locations, Olga's effects were more beneficial than harmful; the region faces a prolonged drought, and accumulated rainfall exceeded 200 mm in some areas. Mining production in Karumba had to be halted as a precaution against the cyclone's effects in the region, as the port that ships the mined material had to be closed. The important Bruce Highway, which connects Queensland to the rest of the country, had to be closed at the Houghton River bridge; the river's waters overflowed and threatened the bridge's structure. Floods associated with Olga caused damages exceeding 100 million Australian dollars. As a result, the Queensland government had to allocate funds to assist people affected by the cyclone in 38 state councils.

Whole_Text.content: Daisy was an extratropical storm that hit northwest and central Europe in January 2010, causing phenomena such as snowstorms or blizzards. In many places, more than 50 cm of snow fell in a relatively short time. Additionally, strong wind gusts of gale force occurred in some areas. This combination occasionally caused damage to forest vegetation.

Article_Name: Ciclone Billy (2008) – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: The severe tropical cyclone Billy (JTWC designation: 05S; simply known as cyclone Billy) was an intense tropical cyclone that occurred northwest of Australia in mid-December 2008. Being the third tropical cyclone, the second named tropical system, and the first severe tropical cyclone of the 2008-09 Australian region cyclone season, Billy formed from an area of meteorological disturbances on December 15, west of Darwin, Australia. Moving slowly southward and entering the Joseph Bonaparte Gulf, the system continued to organize rapidly, and the Darwin Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) classified it as a tropical low on December 17. With highly favorable meteorological conditions, the system continued to organize and intensify, and the Darwin TCWC classified it as a full tropical cyclone the following day, naming it Billy. The cyclone continued to intensify until it made landfall on the Australian coast on December 20, in the Kimberley region of Western Australia, with maximum sustained winds of 75 km/h, according to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC). Over land, Billy weakened rapidly and downgraded to a tropical low. The system crossed the region for about two days before moving back over the sea on December 22, when it began to intensify again. The Perth TCWC reclassified Billy as a full tropical cyclone later that day. Billy began to intensify rapidly from December 24 as it moved away from the Australian coast, reaching its peak intensity later that afternoon, with maximum sustained winds of 195 km/h, according to the JTWC, or 175 km/h, according to the Perth TCWC. From then on, Billy began to be affected by wind shear and lower sea surface temperatures, leading to continuous weakening. Already completely disorganized, Billy was downgraded to a remnant tropical low on December 27. Consequently, both the Perth TCWC and the JTWC issued their final advisories on the system that same day. Billy did not cause serious damage in Australia as it struck a region with low population density. Only indigenous communities were significantly affected by the cyclone, mainly due to the associated torrential rains, which left at least two indigenous communities isolated.

An area of meteorological disturbances that persisted east of the region known as "Top End," located in the far north of Australia's Northern Territory, began to show signs of organization on December 16. Initially, the system exhibited only a weak low-level cyclonic circulation and few areas of associated deep convection. However, the disturbance was located in a region with very favorable meteorological conditions, such as low wind shear and warm ocean waters. As a result, the system began to become more prominent, and the Darwin Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) in Australia classified it as a tropical low the following day, equivalent to a tropical depression. Moving slowly southward and entering the Joseph Bonaparte Gulf, the disturbance continued to consolidate, even with its low-level cyclonic center already very close to the coast. Consequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert (TCFA) for the system on the morning (UTC) of December 18, indicating that the disturbance could become a significant tropical cyclone within 12 to 24 hours. With the system's continued organization, the Darwin TCWC classified it as a full tropical cyclone, naming it "Billy." Billy's slow movement allowed the cyclone to continue intensifying, even while being very close to the Australian coast. Good outflow patterns aided the system's intensification. As a result, the JTWC classified the system as a significant tropical cyclone later that afternoon. Billy continued to intensify rapidly throughout the rest of the day. The cyclone began moving slowly southeastward, which helped the system intensify as this trajectory delayed the contact of its low-level cyclonic center with the coast, which would have disrupted its organization. The rapid intensification trend continued on December 19, and that morning (UTC), the Darwin TCWC classified Billy as a category 2 cyclone on the Australian scale. From then on, Billy began moving southward and later west-southwestward that day. Billy made landfall around 22:30 (UTC) on December 19, on the coast of the Kimberley region near the town of Wyndham, with maximum sustained winds of 75 km/h, according to the JTWC. From then on, Billy began to weaken rapidly as it interacted with land. Consequently, the Darwin TCWC downgraded the cyclone to a system with intensity equivalent to category 1 on the Australian scale during the early hours of December 20 (UTC). Moving west-southwestward over the Kimberley region in Western Australia, Billy continued to weaken rapidly as it lost much of its deep convection areas. As a result, the Darwin TCWC downgraded the cyclone to a tropical low later that morning. However, Billy's remnant system remained structurally organized, even over land, and maintained maximum sustained winds of 45 km/h as it moved west-southwestward under the influence of a subtropical high over Australia. Over the Kimberley region, the system left the Darwin TCWC's area of responsibility to enter the Perth TCWC's area of responsibility. After about 48 hours over land, the system reached the Indian Ocean during the early hours (UTC) of December 22. Under very favorable meteorological conditions, such as the very warm waters off the Pilbara coast in Western Australia, low wind shear, and excellent outflow provided by a mesoscale upper-level anticyclone, Billy rapidly re-intensified. Consequently, the Perth TCWC reclassified the system as a full tropical cyclone later that morning (UTC). Initially, Billy was unable to intensify rapidly as it moved southwestward, parallel to the Australian coast. However, from the afternoon (UTC) of December 23, Billy began moving more westward as the subtropical high to its south continued to intensify. This allowed the low-level cyclonic center of the system to move away, resulting in the cyclone's intensification. Consequently, the Perth TCWC classified Billy as a category 2 cyclone on the Australian scale later that night (UTC). From the early hours of December 24, Billy began undergoing a period of rapid intensification, reflecting the very favorable meteorological conditions, particularly the excellent upper-level outflow. Later that morning, a "pinhole" eye began forming at the center of the cyclone's deep convection areas, indicating continued and rapid intensification. At that time, the Perth TCWC classified Billy as a category 3 cyclone on the Australian scale, which also classified the system as a severe tropical cyclone. The rapid intensification trend continued, and the Perth TCWC classified Billy as a category 4 cyclone on the Australian scale later that morning. Later that day, Billy reached its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of 195 km/h, according to the JTWC, or 175 km/h, according to the Perth TCWC. The cyclone maintained its peak intensity for about 12 hours before beginning to weaken. Its eye began to fill with clouds, indicating that Billy had started to weaken as the cyclone began moving west-northwestward when a second subtropical high formed southwest of the system. Billy continued to weaken slowly on December 25 due to the effects of increased wind shear caused by the approach of a shortwave trough and the decrease in sea surface temperatures. Consequently, the Perth TCWC downgraded the cyclone to category 3 on the Australian scale later that afternoon. Billy's weakening trend continued on December 26, and the Perth TCWC further downgraded the cyclone to category 2 on the Australian scale. Wind shear increased on December 27, and along with lower sea surface temperatures, this caused Billy's weakening trend to accelerate, and it was downgraded to a category 1 cyclone later that day. Due to strong wind shear, nearly all of the cyclone's deep convection areas dissipated, further accentuating Billy's weakening trend. Consequently, the JTWC issued its final advisory on the system that night. The Perth TCWC continued to classify Billy as a full tropical cyclone until midday (UTC) on December 28, when Billy was downgraded to a remnant tropical low, and the Perth TCWC also issued its final advisory on the system. Billy's remnant low-pressure area continued moving slowly westward, leaving the Perth TCWC's area of responsibility days later. Within the area of responsibility of the Regional Specialized Meteorological Center in Réunion, the system played a key role in the formation of Severe Tropical Storm Dongo.

Billy did not cause significant impacts in Australia when it crossed the Kimberley region in Western Australia between December 20 and 22; the Kimberley region is not densely populated. Only Indigenous communities were greatly affected, mainly by the torrential rains associated with the cyclone. The Indigenous communities of Kalumburu and Oombulgurri were severely flooded; the communities were completely isolated after access roads to the communities were flooded or damaged by the flash floods. The communities' airstrips were also flooded, preventing air access. In other localities in the region, particularly in the town of Wyndham, no damage was reported in association with Billy's effects in the region.

Article_Name: Ciclone Charlotte (2009) – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: Cyclone Charlotte (JTWC designation: 07P) was the sixth tropical cyclone and the third named system of the 2008-09 Australian region cyclone season. Charlotte formed from a monsoon trough located over the Gulf of Carpentaria on January 8. Moving slowly east-southeast and eastward, the system began to gradually intensify as it crossed the gulf. As it approached the western coast of the Cape York Peninsula, the system intensified into Tropical Cyclone Charlotte. Charlotte continued moving eastward, making landfall on the Australian coast near the mouth of the Gilbert River during its peak intensity, with maximum 10-minute sustained winds of 85 km/h, according to the Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) in Brisbane, Australia. Charlotte caused heavy rainfall, particularly in the northern part of the Australian state of Queensland, which led to severe flooding in the region. Approximately 3,500 homes were flooded. The associated storm surge also caused coastal flooding. Communities were isolated after flash floods damaged several highways. The direct economic losses caused by the storm totaled 26 million Australian dollars (approximately 17.3 million USD).

On January 8, the Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) in Darwin, Australia, identified the formation of a tropical low over the Gulf of Carpentaria. From then on, the system stopped showing signs of organization while remaining practically stationary over the gulf. On January 10, the TCWC in Brisbane downgraded the system to a weak tropical low. However, with excellent meteorological conditions, such as low wind shear and good outflow, enhanced by a subtropical high situated south of the system, the system began to show signs of organization again and started to intensify rapidly from the early hours (UTC) of January 11. As a result, the TCWC in Brisbane classified the system as Tropical Cyclone Charlotte. Hours later, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) issued a "Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert" (TCFA), indicating that a significant tropical cyclone could form in that region within a 24-hour period. During that morning, the JTWC issued its first regular advisory on Tropical Cyclone 07P. Moving east-southeast along the periphery of a near-equatorial high-pressure area, Charlotte soon made landfall on the western coast of the Cape York Peninsula, near the mouth of the Gilbert River, with maximum sustained winds of up to 85 km/h, according to the TCWC in Brisbane, during its peak intensity. From then on, Charlotte began to weaken due to land interaction. As a result, the JTWC issued its final advisory later on the night of January 11. During the early hours of January 12 (UTC), the TCWC in Brisbane downgraded Charlotte to a remnant tropical low.

Charlotte, in addition to an active monsoon in the region, caused heavy rains in the Australian state of Queensland, which led to severe flooding. About 3,500 buildings were inundated. Several drainage systems, as well as highways, were damaged by the floodwaters. As a result, several communities were isolated. The cities of Cairns, Port Douglas, and Mossman were severely flooded. The west coast of Queensland was affected by strong storm surges, which caused coastal flooding. A weather station at Cape Tribulation, north of Cairns, recorded 436 mm of rainfall, the highest in the last 28 years. Twelve communities declared a state of emergency, and emergency management services were activated. The damages caused by the floods amounted to approximately 17.3 million dollars. The Australian Natural Disaster Relief and Recovery Arrangements (NDRRA) provided financial assistance to those affected by the cyclone, 765 Australian dollars per family. Additionally, the localities of Barcoo, Boulia, Burke, Carpentaria, Cloncurry, Diamantina, Doomadgee, Etheridge, Flinders, McKinlay, Mount Isa, Richmond, Winton, Cairns, Cassowary Coast, Croydon, Tablelands, and Hinchinbrook declared a state of emergency, making them eligible to receive aid efforts.

Info_Box:
Formation: January 8, 2009
