Strongest winds: sustained 10 min.: 85 km/h (50 mph) sustained 1 min.: 65 km/h (40 mph)  
Lowest pressure: 987 hPa (mbar); 29.15 inHg  
Fatalities: None  
Damage: At least 17.3 million dollars (values in 2009)  
Affected areas: Australia (Northern Territory and Queensland)

Article_Name: Ciclone Ellie (2009) – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Cyclone Ellie (JTWC designation: 12P; simply known as Cyclone Ellie) was a tropical cyclone that struck the coast of Queensland, Australia, in early February 2009. Being the ninth tropical cyclone and the fifth named system of the 2008-09 Australian region cyclone season, Ellie formed from an area of meteorological disturbance on January 30, over the Cape York Peninsula. Moving slowly eastward, the system soon began to track over the Coral Sea and started showing signs of organization. On January 31, the Brisbane Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) in Australia classified the system as a full tropical cyclone and assigned it the name "Ellie." From then on, the system began to move west-southwest and southwest, continuing to gradually intensify. However, less favorable meteorological conditions prevented Ellie from intensifying further, and it soon reached its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of 75 km/h. The cyclone maintained this intensity until it made landfall on the coast of Queensland, Australia, on February 1. From then on, Ellie began to weaken rapidly, and both the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) and the TCWC issued their final advisories on the system later that day. Ellie caused torrential rains, leading to severe flooding and flash floods along the coast of Queensland, Australia. At least 50 homes were affected in the city of Ingham alone, forcing at least 32 people to seek emergency shelters. The economic damages caused by the cyclone are estimated at 70.7 million dollars.

Ellie formed from an area of meteorological disturbances that began to show signs of organization on January 30, over the Cape York Peninsula, in the northern part of the Australian state of Queensland. Immediately, the Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) in Brisbane, Australia, classified the system as a tropical low. Moving slowly eastward, the system soon reached the Coral Sea. With highly favorable meteorological conditions, such as low wind shear and warm ocean waters, the system began to organize more rapidly, and its low-level cyclonic center started to consolidate continuously with the formation of new areas of deep convection. From then on, the system began to be affected by moderate to strong wind shear, which started to displace its areas of deep convection to the western quadrant of its cyclonic circulation. The system stopped moving eastward as the formation of a subtropical high to its southeast began to steer the disturbance west-southwest. The less favorable meteorological conditions did not prevent the system's development, which was classified as tropical cyclone "Ellie" by the TCWC in Brisbane during the afternoon (UTC) of January 31. Later that night (UTC), the system already showed sufficient organization to be declared a significant tropical cyclone by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, which classified the system based on surface meteorological analyses, as measurements using the Dvorak technique did not reflect the system's true intensity. Moving southwest along the northwestern periphery of a subtropical high, Ellie was unable to intensify due to the effects of strong wind shear, which displaced its areas of deep convection to the western quadrant of the storm, leaving its cyclonic center cloud-free. As a result, Ellie reached its peak intensity on the night (UTC) of January 31, with maximum sustained winds of 75 km/h. Continuing southwest, Ellie maintained its peak intensity for about 24 hours before making landfall on the Queensland coast near the town of Mission Beach, around 15:00 (UTC) on February 1, during its peak intensity. At that time, the TCWC in Brisbane downgraded Ellie to a remnant tropical low and issued its final advisory on the system. Later that day, the JTWC also issued its final advisory on the system as the cyclone moved over land, rapidly weakening. The remnant low-pressure area then continued westward over northern Australia, contrary to forecasts that predicted the system would move eastward again and strengthen once it reached the Coral Sea. The remnant system of Ellie completely dissipated as it passed over the Northern Territory, Australia, days later.

Ellie caused torrential rains on the coast of the Australian state of Queensland, which led to severe floods and flash floods in the region. In the city of Ingham, between the cities of Cairns and Townsville, at least 50 homes were affected by the floods, forcing at least 32 people to leave their homes and seek emergency shelters in a local high school. Overall, the floods and flash floods caused by the heavy rains associated with Cyclone Ellie caused about 110 million Australian dollars (approximately 70.7 million dollars - values in 2009) in damages in northern Queensland alone.

Info_Box:
Formation: January 31, 2009  
Dissipation: February 1, 2009  
Strongest winds: sustained 10 min.: 75 km/h (45 mph) sustained 1 min.: 75 km/h (45 mph)  
Lowest pressure: 989 hPa (mbar); 29.21 inHg  
Fatalities: None  
Damage: Around 70.7 million dollars (values in 2009)  
Affected areas: Australia (Queensland)

Article_Name: Ciclone Humba – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: The tropical cyclone Humba (JTWC designation: 16S; also known simply as cyclone Humba) was an intense tropical cyclone that was active during late February 2007 in the southwestern Indian Ocean. Being the eleventh tropical cyclone and the eighth named tropical system of the 2006-07 cyclone season in the southwestern Indian Ocean, Humba formed from a tropical disturbance north of the Cocos Islands on February 20 and moved southwest, reaching its peak intensity with maximum sustained winds of 150 km/h, according to the JTWC, or 140 km/h, according to the CMRE of Réunion. At the end of February, Humba weakened and, encountering unfavorable conditions, became an extratropical cyclone on February 26, dissipating completely on March 4. As the cyclone remained far from the coast, Humba caused no fatalities or damages.

The area of convection that would give rise to Cyclone Humba was first observed on February 18, about 460 km north of the Cocos Islands, a small group of islands southwest of Indonesia belonging to Australia. The following day, the Tropical Cyclone Warning Center in Perth, Australia, observed the formation of a tropical low (i.e., tropical depression). Around the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) began monitoring the system as a tropical disturbance. At that moment, the system already had a low-level cyclonic center, although large and disorganized. The upper-level outflows associated with the system were favorable, especially on the southern and northern sides of the system, caused by an upper-level anticyclone, which also provided low wind shear. With the system's consolidation, the JTWC issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert (TCFA) during the night (UTC) of February 20, mentioning the possibility of the system becoming a significant tropical cyclone within 24 hours. Around midday (UTC) on February 21, with the continued improvement of the outflows and further reduction in wind shear, the JTWC issued its first regular advisory on Tropical Cyclone 16S. At that time, the cyclone's center was located about 1,745 km from Diego Garcia, British Indian Ocean Territory. Around the same time, the Regional Specialized Meteorological Center (RSMC) in Réunion began monitoring the system as a tropical disturbance as it moved west-southwest, crossing the 90°E meridian, leaving the Perth TCWC's area of responsibility and entering its own. The system continued to intensify steadily, and the RSMC in Réunion classified the disturbance as a tropical depression, designating it as 11R, early on February 22. Moving mostly southwest due to the influence of a subtropical high anchored over Western Australia, the system continued to gradually strengthen, becoming a moderate tropical storm early on February 23 (UTC). At that time, the RSMC in Réunion named the system Humba, which had been submitted to the southwest Indian Ocean cyclone name list by Tanzania. Following a trajectory similar to a southwestward parabola, Humba continued to intensify slowly, and the RSMC in Réunion classified Humba as a severe tropical storm on the morning (UTC) of February 24, and as a tropical cyclone 12 hours later, noting that an irregular eye had formed at the center of the main convection areas associated with the system. Early on February 25, Humba reached its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of 150 km/h, according to the JTWC, or 140 km/h, according to the RSMC in Réunion. At that time, Humba's center was located about 1,655 km east-northeast of Rodrigues. From then on, Humba began to weaken due to the approach of an upper-level trough, which induced an increase in wind shear and a decrease in outflows. During the night of February 25, Humba weakened to a severe tropical storm. With the significant increase in wind shear and the substantial decrease in sea surface temperature, Humba began undergoing extratropical transition, which was completed during the afternoon of February 26, at which point Humba was fully an extratropical cyclone. A few hours earlier, the JTWC had already issued its final advisory on Humba. The RSMC in Réunion continued to monitor Humba's extratropical system until early March 4, when its strongest winds fell below gale-force intensity on the Beaufort scale. At that time, Humba's center was located about 2,230 km southwest of Perth, Australia.

As the cyclone remained distant from the coast throughout its entire existence, Humba did not cause any impact. No weather station or ship recorded its passage. Therefore, no fatalities or damages were attributed to Humba's passage.

Info_Box:

Dissipation: March 4, 2007  
Strongest winds: sustained 10 min.: 140 km/h (85 mph) sustained 1 min.: 150 km/h (90 mph)  
Lowest pressure: 960 hPa (mbar); 28.35 inHg  
Fatalities: None  
Damage: None  
Affected areas: None

Whole_Text.content: Hurricane Daniella is an extratropical cyclone of 2016 that brought adverse weather conditions to Europe and the European part of Russia. The hurricane formed over the Atlantic Ocean and soon struck Northern Europe, with Belarus being significantly affected when the hurricane reached it on January 12. The cyclone then covered the entire central part of Russia. Heavy snowfalls and squally winds hit the Kaliningrad, Bryansk, Smolensk, Nizhny Novgorod, Yaroslavl, and Tver regions. A state of emergency was declared in many regions. In some places, there was even freezing rain. Moscow and St. Petersburg were also significantly affected by the storm, with more than half of the monthly snow norm falling. In Moscow, a third of the monthly precipitation norm fell within a day. Meanwhile, the temperature rose rapidly. During the day, thermometers reached the zero mark. Moreover, atmospheric pressure broke all records. Such low readings were last recorded 70 years ago on this day. Meteorologically sensitive people were particularly affected. Snowdrifts caused numerous traffic accidents, but road services coped with the snowfall, and mobile heating points were deployed on federal highways. Drivers were strongly advised to switch to public transport. Buses, trolleybuses, and trams operated without interruptions on Wednesday. The capital's highways were unusually free. Nearly 40,000 people and 16,000 units of equipment were involved in eliminating the consequences of the storm. Roads were treated with reagents, and snow was transported to special melting points. Airports operated according to actual weather conditions. Many flights were delayed, but the situation stabilized by the evening. Within a day, the hurricane reached Kazan, where a large amount of snow also fell. By the evening of January 15, the cyclone reached the Urals, causing heavy snowfall and a blizzard in Yekaterinburg, and a storm warning was even issued in Chelyabinsk. The Orenburg region also came under the influence of the cyclone.

The particularly negative consequences were in Belarus. The snow cover in Vitebsk reached 32 centimeters. The aftermath had to be dealt with in many villages and district centers alongside widespread power outages. In the Gomel region alone, 140 settlements were left without electricity. The work of energy workers was significantly complicated by freezing rain, which caused precipitation to stick to the wires. Additionally, hundreds more settlements across the country were left without power. The Zhitkovichi district suffered the most from the snow and ice attack—more than 50 settlements were left without electricity there. In the Zhlobin, Rogachev, Mozyr, and Oktyabr districts, "Daniella" left several villages without power, including hospitals, schools, and kindergartens. Energy workers prioritized these areas. More than 40 teams worked on problematic sections. By the end of the day, almost all the consequences of the natural disaster were eliminated. In Russia, due to ice on the wires, several thousand people in the Penza region were left without electricity. On many highways, there were multiple traffic accidents, and long traffic jams formed.

Article_Name: Ciclone Lee-Ariel – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: Cyclone Lee-Ariel was an active tropical cyclone between November 13 and 17, 2007, over the Indian Ocean. The cyclone received two distinct names for being active in two different tropical cyclone monitoring basins: the southwest Indian Ocean basin and the southeast Indian Ocean basin. Lee-Ariel was the third tropical cyclone and the second named system of the 2007-08 Australian region cyclone season. Lee-Ariel was also the second tropical cyclone and the first named system of the 2007-08 southwest Indian Ocean cyclone season. During its existence, Lee-Ariel did not reach land, and for this reason, there were no damages or casualties associated with the cyclone.

A tropical disturbance formed southwest of Jakarta, Indonesia, on November 13, 2007. As the surface cyclonic circulation consolidated, the Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) in Perth began issuing regular advisories on the developing system while it was still within the Jakarta TCWC's area of responsibility. On November 14, the Perth TCWC classified the low-pressure area as Tropical Cyclone "Lee." At this time, the cyclone was still located within the Jakarta TCWC's area of responsibility. Later, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert (TCFA) for Tropical Cyclone Lee and shortly after designated the system as Tropical Cyclone 03B. On November 15, the Perth TCWC classified Lee as a Category 2 cyclone. Subsequently, Lee crossed the 90°E meridian, leaving the Perth TCWC's area of responsibility to enter the area of responsibility of the Regional Specialized Meteorological Center (RSMC) in Réunion. With this, the TCWC issued its final advisory on Lee. Upon entering the RSMC Réunion's area of responsibility, the cyclone was named "Ariel," becoming the first named system in this basin for the 2007-2008 season. Shortly after crossing the 90°E meridian, Lee, now referred to as "Ariel," continued its west-southwestward movement, encountering unfavorable environmental conditions for its existence. On November 17, the RSMC Réunion classified Ariel as a moderate tropical storm. Later that same day, the RSMC Réunion downgraded Ariel to a tropical depression. By the end of November 18, Ariel degenerated into a remnant low-pressure area, and with this, the RSMC Réunion and the JTWC issued their final advisories on the system.
Lee-Ariel remained in the open sea throughout its entire existence. No ship or weather station recorded the cyclone's winds. There are no records of damage caused by the storm.

Info_Box:
Formation: November 13, 2007  
Dissipation: November 19, 2007  
Strongest winds: sustained 10 min.: 95 km/h (60 mph) sustained 1 min.: 110 km/h (70 mph)  
Lowest pressure: 985 hPa (mbar); 29.09 inHg  
Fatalities: None  
Damage: None  
Affected areas: None

Article_Name: Cyclone Ashoba - Simple English Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Whole_Text.content: Cyclone Ashoba formed in the Bay of Bengal near Andaman, 1,400 kilometers (870 mi) away from Visakhapatnam. Early forecasts called for Cyclone Ashoba to affect the Tamil Nadu coast. It was expected to reach the Oman coast on 11.06.2014.
Cyclone Colina is a tropical cyclone that was active in the southwest Indian Ocean from January 13 to 20, 1993. Its trajectory took it over Mauritius and then Réunion.

On January 13 at 12:00 UTC, a depression formed about 450 km southwest of the Chagos. It was named Tropical Storm Colina on the morning of the 15th. On the afternoon of the 16th, the system shifted its trajectory towards the southwest, and on January 18 at 6:00 PM local time, it was located about 500 km off the coast of Réunion. Colina became a tropical cyclone the following night. On January 19, at 6:00 PM local time, the cyclone struck Réunion, and, unusually, its eye crossed the land. The pressure was 976 hPa in Saint-Pierre, 894 mm of rain was recorded in Mafate within 24 hours, waves reached 12 meters in height along the coast, and gusts reached 205 km/h in La Plaine-des-Palmistes. However, the estimated minimum pressure was 970 hPa, and sustained winds were 175 km/h over one minute. After passing over the department, Colina quickly moved away, accelerating southeastward over colder waters. On January 20, the cyclone weakened to tropical storm status, and the next day, Colina became extratropical, dissipating two days later.
On January 19, it passes 215 km west of the island at the stage of a tropical cyclone.

Finally, two indirect deaths were reported, 2,423 people were housed in shelters, and 100,000 households were without electricity. The eye of the cyclone reached the northern coast at 6:30 PM and remained for approximately 30 minutes during which calm returned, before the wind picked up again. An EDF pylon, designed to withstand winds of 250 km/h, was destroyed in La Montagne. For agriculture, the damages were estimated at 136 million francs.

Info_Box:
Appearance: January 13, 1993  
Dissipation: January 22, 1993  
(Post/extratropical storm from January 21, 1993)  
Maximum category: Category 2 cyclone  
Minimum pressure: 970 hPa  
Maximum wind (sustained over 1 min): 175 km/h  
Confirmed damages: Agriculture, telecommunications, public water supply  
Confirmed deaths: 2 (indirect)  
Confirmed injuries: N/A  
Affected areas: Mauritius, Réunion

Whole_Text.content: Cyclone "Vanya" is a southern cyclone named by German meteorologists (Vanja). In December 2023, Ireland and the United Kingdom, Bavaria and Lower Saxony, as well as the southern Central region of Russia and the Black Earth region, suffered the most from the cyclonic vortex.

Cyclone "Vanya" is an active atmospheric vortex that originated in the North Atlantic. The first impact was on the British Isles, where a storm occurred, and Ireland, where a tornado, a rare weather phenomenon for these latitudes, took place. The cyclone then caused floods in Lower Saxony and Bavaria, with water levels rising in the Rhine and Danube rivers. Later, "Vanya" moved towards the Baltic Sea and merged with an Atlantic cyclone. In Russia, the cyclone's impact was most felt in the southern part of the European region. In Rostov-on-Don, on December 12, due to freezing rain that fell for five days with short breaks, public transport was halted, and on December 13, school classes were canceled. As a result of the disaster, more than 180,000 people were left without electricity. The cyclone reached Moscow on December 14, bringing abnormal snowfalls, and by December 15, the snow cover height broke the daily record set on December 15, 1919. At the VDNH meteorological station, the measurements reached 38 cm by 9 a.m., surpassing the previous record of 32 cm. In the nearby Moscow region, 33% of December's precipitation norm fell, while in Central Russia, it was 81%.

Meteorologists give names to tropical cyclones to avoid confusion in issuing storm alerts and warnings. Moreover, the names are pre-assigned according to special annual lists. Non-tropical cyclones remain unnamed, as they can form daily in temperate and high latitudes. The name "Vanya" was given to the cyclone by German meteorologists, explained Roman Vilfand, the scientific director of the Russian Hydrometeorological Center: This is a commercial activity. The Free University of Berlin, which has a good meteorological department, started engaging in commerce and assigns names to cyclones for money. For example, you want to give a gift to a girl for her birthday and name a cyclone after her. The meteorologist clarified that naming a cyclone at the German university costs from 200 euros, while naming an anticyclone costs from 300 euros.

Typhoon Wendy, also known as Typhoon Lusing according to the local name in the Philippines, or Typhoon No. 7 of 1968 as referred to in Vietnam, was a very intense tropical storm that affected several countries and territories in East Asia and Southeast Asia in early September 1968. Forming from a tropical depression in the waters of the Mariana Islands in late August 1968, Wendy quickly developed into a typhoon and reached Category 5 intensity on the Saffir-Simpson scale with a pressure of 920 hPa on August 31. Wendy then moved west-northwest before changing direction westward toward the waters east of Taiwan. After passing north of the Bashi Channel on September 6, Wendy entered the South China Sea, traveled along the southern coast of China, and made landfall on the Leizhou Peninsula on September 8. On September 9, Wendy made landfall in Haiphong, Democratic Republic of Vietnam, before weakening and dissipating inland. Typhoon Wendy left significant challenges in recording its intensity at landfall, particularly in Taiwan, China, and the Democratic Republic of Vietnam, where Wendy caused severe damage, with at least 161 deaths reported in the affected countries.

The origin of Typhoon Wendy was from a tropical depression that formed in the Mariana Islands area on August 27, 1968. A day later, this tropical depression developed into a typhoon and was given the international name Wendy. Wendy began to intensify and reached its peak intensity at 0:00 (UTC) on August 31, 1968, with wind speeds reaching 260 km/h (140 knots, 72 m/s), equivalent to a Category 5 super typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson scale. The typhoon then moved westward and gradually weakened. On September 1, it entered the waters within the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR), passed through the southern waters of Taiwan (north of the Bashi Channel) on September 5 as a Category 1 typhoon, and entered the northeastern South China Sea on September 6. After entering the South China Sea, Typhoon Wendy moved directly westward, along the southern coast of China, making landfall on the Leizhou Peninsula (China) on September 8, and a day later, Wendy made its final landfall in Haiphong, which at the time was part of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam, before dissipating in the Vietnam–Laos border area. Satellite observations of the typhoon during this period were very limited, and there were no reconnaissance aircraft when the typhoon was over the South China Sea at that time, so data on Typhoon Wendy in the South China Sea from various agencies were inconsistent and conflicting. Restored satellite images from NOAA also did not provide clear signals about this typhoon. According to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC), the typhoon only reached tropical storm strength (winds below 65 knots or 33 m/s) and gradually weakened over the South China Sea, making landfall on the Leizhou Peninsula with winds of 45 knots (23 m/s) and weakening into a tropical depression upon entering northern Vietnam. According to the China Meteorological Administration (CMA), Typhoon Wendy regained strength in the South China Sea, increasing by two levels from Level 12 (35 m/s) upon entering the South China Sea to Level 14 (45 m/s) in the southern waters of China, making landfall on the Leizhou Peninsula with Level 12-13 winds on the night of September 8 and early morning of September 9, and rapidly weakening into a tropical depression upon landfall in Vietnam. However, according to meteorological observation data from Vietnam, the typhoon caused strong winds of 50 m/s (Level 15) with gusts up to 57 m/s (Level 17) in Phu Lien (Haiphong) and strong winds of 40 m/s at Hon Dau.

Whole_Text.header: Impact and issues in storm assessment
Whole_Text.content: The center of Typhoon Wendy approached Orchid Island early on September 5,[12] where a station on the island recorded a 10-minute sustained wind speed of 65.7 m/s (above level 17). The station could not measure the typhoon's gust speed due to equipment limitations. The extremely high observation on the island was attributed to the station's high altitude and the influence of the terrain at the measurement location.[13] On Taiwan Island, a 10-minute sustained wind speed of 25 m/s and gusts of 41.6 m/s (equivalent to level 10 winds with level 14 gusts) were recorded in Taitung.[13] Rainfall over 70 hours reached 417.9 mm in Hengchun, 398.7 mm in Taitung, and some areas may have experienced over 500 mm of rainfall.[12] The typhoon caused a foehn effect in Taichung and Hsinchu, with the highest temperatures on the afternoon of September 6 reaching 39°C and 37°C, respectively.[12] The typhoon resulted in 6 deaths, 19 missing, and 3 injuries in Taiwan, with estimated agricultural and forestry damages amounting to 4.354 million Taiwanese dollars.[12] The typhoon made landfall on the Leizhou Peninsula (China) on the night of September 8 with a narrow range of strong winds.[14] According to CMA, the typhoon's wind speed upon landfall reached levels 12 and 13.[7][8] In Zhanjiang, gusts of level 13 (41 m/s) were recorded.[15] However, many wind measurement devices were damaged during the typhoon's landfall.[16] The typhoon caused destruction in a narrow area. A forest was "split in half" by the typhoon [the forest was divided by the typhoon's destructive path], dozens of buffaloes were "thrown" into the sea by the typhoon (possibly meaning blown into the sea by the wind), and hundreds of people went missing in Zhanjiang.[16][14] The typhoon caused significant damage due to shortcomings in weather forecasting at the time. When the Shantou weather radar detected the typhoon, forecasters predicted it would move into the Pearl River Delta. However, radar feedback in the Pearl River Delta did not detect the typhoon, leading forecasters to mistakenly believe the typhoon had "disappeared." It was not until the typhoon approached and was about to make landfall in Zhanjiang that the Zhanjiang radar detected it, less than 20 hours before landfall.[15] In the Democratic Republic of Vietnam, Typhoon Wendy or Typhoon No. 7 made landfall in Haiphong on September 9, 1968, causing severe damage and "devastation" shortly after the United States announced a halt to bombing in the North.[17] At the same time, the North had just experienced two consecutive typhoons, Typhoon No. 3 (unnamed) and Typhoon No. 4 (international name Rose), which caused heavy rain and prolonged severe flooding above alert level 3 in the Red and Thai Binh Rivers in mid-August.[18] Vietnamese records indicate that the typhoon caused strong winds of 50 m/s (level 15) with gusts up to 57 m/s (level 17) at the Phu Lien Meteorological Station (Haiphong), measured by a Munro wind machine, a self-recording wind device from England.[9][2][19][20] The typhoon also caused strong winds of 40 m/s (level 13) at Hon Dau.[10][11] Storm surges were also recorded in Haiphong.[21] Some Vietnamese residents described Typhoon No. 7 in 1968 (Typhoon Wendy) as a "major typhoon," with "extremely strong southeast winds blowing away a house door" and "nearly all orange trees [...] broken."[22][23] Typhoon Wendy caused severe damage to houses, crops, and trees,[24] resulting in 155 deaths, 400 injuries, 87,000 m3 of dikes destroyed, and 18,000 hectares of rice flooded in Haiphong.[25] The intensity of Typhoon Wendy upon landfall in the Democratic Republic of Vietnam has been inconsistently assessed. A document from the Ministry of Construction (Vietnam) evaluated Wendy's landfall in Haiphong as having level 8 winds, notably rating the previous Typhoon No. 4 (Rose) as level 13 upon landfall.[26] Some documents assessed Wendy as level 12 upon landfall,[21] while others estimated Wendy's landfall winds at over 200 km/h despite its "small radius."[2][19] A document by Nguyen Duc Ngu, written in 1999, described Wendy as causing "record-breaking strong winds" and being "rarely seen on land."[11] To date, Decision No. 2901 of 2016 by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (Vietnam) on "announcing updated results of storm zoning, identifying storm risks, storm surges, and wind zoning for inland areas during strong storms and super typhoons" assessed the strongest wind level along Vietnam's coastal strip as level 15, with gusts at level 17,[27] matching the actual measured wind speed of 50 m/s with gusts of 57 m/s at Phu Lien.[9][2][28] Exactly 56 years after Typhoon Wendy, Typhoon Yagi (Typhoon No. 3 of 2024) made landfall in Quang Ninh–Haiphong on September 7, 2024, and was assessed by the Vietnamese government as "the strongest in 70 years on Vietnam's mainland," with officially announced wind speeds of level 14 (45 m/s) and gusts above level 17 (62 m/s) recorded at the Bai Chay Meteorological Station (Quang Ninh).[29][30][31] The gusts were described by Vietnamese meteorological leaders as "the first time Vietnam has measured such winds";[32] however, a document from the Vietnamese meteorological sector recorded Typhoon Yagi as also causing strong winds of up to 50 m/s (level 15) with gusts of 63 m/s (above level 17) at this station,[33] with sustained wind speeds equivalent to and gust intensities greater than those of Typhoon Wendy recorded in Haiphong.

Whole_Text.content: Eventually, on November 26, a weather disturbance was spotted outside the Philippine Area of Responsibility, 752 nmi (1,393 km; 865 mi) east-southeast of Guam. The following day, it became a fully developed Low Pressure Area (LPA). By November 28, it had the potential to develop into a storm. Six hours later, it was named internationally as Nyatoh.

It completely moved away while entering the Philippine Area of Responsibility or PAR, when Nyatoh slightly brushed against the PAR, it was not expected to be named by PAGASA as Typhoon OdettePH, which was in category 4 according to (JTWC), it completely dissipated in the vast Pacific Ocean.

Whole_Text.content: Cyclone Dineo was the fifth tropical cyclone of the 2016–2017 cyclone season in the southern hemisphere, resulting in 130,000 people becoming homeless in Mozambique. It caused heavy rains in Limpopo Province, Mpumalanga, Botswana, and Zimbabwe.

The very intense cyclonic storm Matmo−Bulbul, also known as Typhoon No. 5 in Vietnam, was a strong and long-lasting tropical cyclone that made landfall in Phu Yen Province on October 30 and then continued to sweep through the state of West Bengal in India and Bangladesh on November 9, 2019, at 18:30 GMT, bringing high waves, heavy rain, and flash floods. Originating from the remnants of Typhoon Matmo (Typhoon No. 5) of the 2019 Northwest Pacific Typhoon Season, which moved southward into the Bay of Bengal on November 2, Bulbul gradually intensified into a severe cyclonic storm. This was the fourth recorded tropical storm to move from mainland Southeast Asia across the Andaman Sea (hence JTWC and international media still referred to it as Matmo). Additionally, it was the second storm to reach hurricane strength in this region since 1960.

On October 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded the warning for a tropical depression in the South China Sea to a storm, naming it Matmo (Storm No. 5). On the night of October 30 and early morning of October 31, Typhoon Matmo, with maximum winds of 100 km/h, made landfall in the South Central region of Vietnam, bringing strong winds, heavy rain, and causing flooding. Storm No. 5 resulted in 1 death, 1 missing person, and caused particularly severe damage to Binh Dinh province. Matmo then gradually weakened into a low-pressure area and moved across the Indochina Peninsula, bringing some rain and moisture to Cambodia, Thailand, and Myanmar. On November 2, Matmo's low-pressure area moved to the northern Andaman Sea in the Indian Ocean. Meteorological agencies began monitoring the low-pressure area as it started to develop and grow again. After strengthening into a storm, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) named it Bulbul, but U.S. warning agencies like JTWC considered the low-pressure area 23W (Matmo) to have moved from the South China Sea, so they continued issuing warnings for Typhoon Matmo. Bulbul quickly intensified and reached a peak intensity of Category 2 on the Saffir-Simpson scale while moving northward, prompting IMD to issue coastal warnings for Odisha and West Bengal and to ban all fishing, beach activities, and boating in and around the Bay of Bengal. About a day later, on November 9, Bulbul made landfall near Sagar Island in West Bengal at 18:30 GMT, killing at least 2 people, moving inland into Bangladesh, and causing high waves and storm surges that led to flooding. Bulbul continued moving further inland and gradually dissipated, bringing heavy to very heavy rain.

More than 1.8 million people in the coastal districts of Bangladesh at risk have been evacuated to 4,071 cyclone shelters. Health department officials in these districts have established 1,599 teams to assist those affected by the cyclone. Approximately 56,000 volunteers have been deployed to carry out rescue and relief efforts, while military bases in the coastal districts remain on alert. All coastal infantry forces of the Bangladesh Army have been prepared for rapid response to provide support during and after the cyclone's impact. The Bangladesh Navy and Bangladesh Coast Guard are preparing emergency rescue and relief operations using warships and civilian vessels.

At around 11:50 PM on October 30, 2019, Typhoon No. 5 made landfall in the southern part of Song Cau town (Phu Yen province) with an intensity of level 8-9, gusting to level 11. Strong winds caused many trees in the three provinces of Quang Ngai, Binh Dinh, and Phu Yen to break or be uprooted. Many fish cages and fishing boats were sunk by large waves. In the provinces from Quang Ngai to Phu Yen, there was heavy to very heavy rain. Rainfall over 24 hours was generally 150-300mm, with some places recording up to 384mm. Typhoon No. 5 caused 1 death, 1 person missing, and particularly severe damage to Binh Dinh province.

Although the impact of Bulbul on Odisha was relatively minimal, the storm caused heavy rain and winds across the state, damaging agriculture, uprooting crops, and snapping power lines throughout Odisha. So far, no fatalities have been reported in the state. However, around 350 local villagers in Balesore district were moved to cyclone shelters as the storm approached landfall, but their current condition remains unclear. Around 18:30 GMT, Bulbul made landfall in West Bengal near the Sunderban Dhanchi forest, bringing heavy rain and winds of up to 135 km/h (85 mph) across much of the southern part of the state. Ten fatalities were reported there, four of which were caused by falling trees. A 59-year-old man was electrocuted by a lamp post, and another person died when a collapsing wall crushed him. Additionally, before the storm made landfall, a man was killed after a cedar branch fell on his head. Fallen trees also caused road traffic disruptions throughout Kolkata, and the Kolkata Municipal Corporation worked to clear these blockages. Furthermore, operations at Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose International Airport in Kolkata were suspended for 12 hours. At least 22 people in seven coastal districts were reported dead due to causes such as falling trees, collapsing houses, capsized boats, and illnesses, while many others were injured after the cyclone swept through the coastal areas of Bangladesh. Due to the cyclone, all secondary school exams on November 9, 11, and 12, as well as the Bangladesh National University exam on November 9, were suspended. The Bangladesh Inland Water Transport Authority suspended all operations at three seaports and river transport services during the storm's impact. All flights to and from Shah Amanat International Airport in Chittagong, Cox's Bazar Airport, Barisal Airport, and Jashore Airport were canceled for 14 hours due to severe weather under the storm's influence.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Ramon (2019); (International designation: Typhoon Kalmaegi) was a tropical storm that became a typhoon in November 2019 in the Pacific Ocean. It was spotted 1,000 kilometers east of Catanduanes. It formed near Guam in the Pacific Ocean; it threatened the provinces of Aurora, Batanes, Cagayan, Isabela, Bicol, and Eastern Visayas in mid-November 2019. Ramon brought heavy rains and strong winds to the eastern seas of the Philippines. Ramon entered the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) on November 12, made landfall on November 19 between Batanes and Apayao, moved down to the Ilocos Region, and was expected to exit on November 21, 2019, between the South China Sea and the West Philippine Sea. It made landfall in Santa Ana, Cagayan. Afterward, Typhoon Quiel affected Cagayan and Isabela due to the northeast monsoon pulled from Japan.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Sarah (2019); (International designation: Typhoon Fung-wong) was a typhoon in the Philippine Sea that brought rain to several regions in Northern Luzon, the Cagayan Valley, and Central Luzon, following the impact of Typhoon Ramon in Cagayan and Isabela.
It formed as a Low Pressure Area (LPA) at a distance of 680 km east of Sorsogon, moving northwest towards Cagayan.

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Butchoy (International designation: Tropical Storm Nuri) was a Tropical Depression and the second storm to pass through the Philippines after Typhoon Ambo. Butchoy was first spotted 75 kilometers east of Guiuan, Eastern Samar as a Low-Pressure Area in June 2020. It first made landfall on Polillo Island in Quezon and in the town of Dingalan, Aurora. After crossing Central Luzon, Butchoy became a full-fledged Tropical Depression in the western part of Alaminos, Pangasinan while traversing the length of the West Philippine Sea towards the South China Sea. It made its final landfall in the province of Guangdong, China.

Butchoy formed within the PAR in the eastern part of Eastern Samar while continuing to cross the Philippines. The storm began to intensify in the West Philippine Sea and was given the international name Nuri as it moved northwestward towards China. According to the JTWC, the storm will make landfall in "Yanjiang, China." PAGASA issued Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal #1 in June 2020, bringing heavy rains. It made landfall in Polillo and Dingalan, Aurora.
