Article_Name: 台風5号 (チャンミー) が発生 - ウィキニュース

Whole_Text.content: [August 9, 2020] According to the Japan Meteorological Agency, Typhoon No. 5 (Asian name: Jangmi) formed south of Okinawa at 3 a.m. on August 9 [1]. As of 3 a.m. on the 9th, its central pressure was 1000 hPa, and it was moving north at a speed of 30 km per hour [1]. It is expected to develop further as it moves northward, heading southwest of Naha City, and then proceed northward into the East China Sea [1]. In the Sakishima Islands and the Okinawa main island region, rain and wind are expected to intensify on the 9th, and rough seas are forecast for the waters around the Okinawa main island region, the Daito Islands region, and the Miyako Islands region. Caution is also required for landslides, flooding in low-lying areas, and rising river levels [1]. The Asian name (international name) of Typhoon No. 5 is "Jangmi," which was proposed by South Korea and means "rose" (장미) [2].

Xavier (also Haver) was a snow cyclone that raged in Europe from March 9 to 16, 2013. The disaster affected France, Germany, Belgium, Hungary, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Sweden, Ukraine, and western Russia. The cyclone had the greatest impact on Belarus, which it struck on March 15. For Belarus, "Xavier" became one of the strongest such natural disasters in its history. During the cyclone, heavy snowfall began, accompanied by strong winds. The bad weather caused problems on roads both in populated areas (including Minsk) and beyond. Numerous traffic jams formed across Belarus. The number of traffic accidents significantly increased, one of which resulted in the deaths of two people. The most severe situation was on the M1, M4, and M5 highways. The country experienced a transportation collapse. Through the efforts of authorities, emergency services, and local residents, the consequences of the disaster were successfully mitigated. The cyclone "Xavier" remains in the memory of the population and is often compared to other snowstorms in Belarus.

In March 2013, the beginning of the month in Belarus was abnormally cold: due to the dominance of polar air masses, the average temperature was 2–6 degrees below the climatic norm. At this time, a southern cyclone moved into Eastern Europe, bringing tropical air from the Mediterranean. As a result of the collision of the southern cyclone with cold polar air, a snowstorm formed, which German meteorologists named "Xaver." On March 12, Belhydromet predicted worsening weather conditions in Belarus. On March 14, a red level of weather danger and a storm warning were announced in the Minsk, Vitebsk, and Brest regions. However, information about the danger level scale for "Xaver" was provided by Belhydromet only to the Ministry of Emergency Situations, and the general population could not assess the real degree of weather danger. Coincidentally, on the eve of the cataclysm, the country's leadership (the president, prime minister, and speakers of both chambers of the National Assembly) departed for a meeting of the Union State in St. Petersburg. The first deputy prime minister, Vladimir Semashko, was in negotiations in Moscow. Among the top officials, only the second deputy prime minister, Anatoly Kalinin, remained in Belarus.

The cyclone came from the south, initially covering the Brest and Gomel regions. After midnight, worsening weather conditions were recorded in the country. For example, according to the Slutsk meteorological station, a snowstorm began in the city at 12:20 a.m. At 9:00 a.m., meteorologists issued a storm warning. They predicted very heavy snowfall in the morning and afternoon, with snowdrifts on the roads, urging residents to refrain from traveling. The population ignored the warnings. On the morning of March 15, wind speeds reached 15–20 meters per second, with the wind swaying moving vehicles. When the blizzard reached Brest, the celebration of "Maslenitsa" in Minsk was postponed. Starting at 11:00 a.m., the capital implemented the "Impassable Roads" plan, allowing public transport drivers to disregard schedules and operate according to circumstances. By this time, visibility on the country's roads had significantly deteriorated, and the condition of the road surfaces worsened due to active snowfall. In the capital, vehicles were moving at speeds of no more than 30 kilometers per hour. Meanwhile, in the Chervyen region near Smilovichi around 12:30 p.m., a jackknifed road train blocked the road. When a rescue crew arrived at the scene to handle the incident, a traffic jam had already begun to form. About an hour later, a severe snowstorm intensified. The traffic jam (mainly consisting of road trains) stretched from the bridge in Smilovichi almost to the village of Karpilovka. Cars (at least 500) were lined up in three rows, partially on the opposite lane. Passenger cars caught in the jam were completely buried in snow within two hours. Local authorities and services realized the situation was getting out of control, so classes in the second shift were shortened in schools, and in Pinsk, they were canceled altogether. Even stronger winds and heavy snowfall began around 2:00 p.m. At 3:00 p.m., an 11-kilometer traffic jam was observed on the Minsk–Slutsk highway, starting from the area near the village of Gorodishche. At 4:00 p.m., flights at Minsk National Airport were halted as planes could not land. Flights were redirected to Gomel and Kyiv. Due to blocked access roads to the airport caused by snowdrifts, several thousand people were stranded in the airport building, spending the entire night in waiting areas. Simultaneously, the traffic jam on the Slutsk highway increased from 11 to 20 kilometers. In some sections, vehicles were lined up in four rows. Services halted traffic from the Minsk and Soligorsk directions toward Slutsk to allow clearing equipment to operate effectively. On average, wind gusts reached 20–24 meters per second, with a maximum speed of up to 28 m/s. In Minsk, the snow cover thickness increased by only 11 centimeters, while the maximum recorded daily increase was 26 centimeters (in 1956 and 1992). At the same time, the total snow cover thickness reached 57 centimeters, and due to the strong blizzard actively moving snow masses, drifts in many places were even higher, leading to a transportation collapse. In the Slavgorod district, 26 millimeters of precipitation fell, converted to rain equivalent.

Whole_Text.header: From the evening of March 15 to the morning of March 16
Whole_Text.content: Massive delays in public transport began in the capital. Visibility on the roads was 200–300 meters. Hundreds of people crowded at bus stops. A significant portion of suburban and intercity routes was canceled. For residents of Minsk, the metro became practically the only way to get home, with queues already forming at its entrances by 6:20 PM. The operation of the first metro line was extended until 2:00 AM. From 6:00 PM for over an hour, to avoid overcrowding, trains did not stop at the "Kastrychnitskaya" station, and access to it was blocked. Soon, due to traffic jams at the exits from the capital, entry into the city was closed. According to the head of the "Minsk-Passenger" railway station, Vladimir Grygorovich, delays of electric trains and trains did not exceed ten minutes, although eyewitnesses reported delays of an hour and a half or more. In the Zavodski district of the city, traffic was completely paralyzed. During the storm, taxi rates in the capital increased. According to Naviny.by, a ride from the "Kamennaya Gorka" metro station to Skrypnikova Street was offered for 50,000 rubles, even though the distance was only three kilometers. According to TUT.by, from the same "Kamennaya Gorka" to the railway station, taxi drivers charged 350,000 rubles instead of the usual 70,000. During the stormy night, fares of 400,000 and even 500,000 rubles for trips within the city were reported. However, some drivers were willing to pick up passengers at bus stops and take them home for free or for a "symbolic fee." A large number of traffic accidents were observed on roads across the country. During the cyclone, traffic was complicated on 30 sections of highways. The situation was particularly difficult on the Mogilev (M4 Highway) and partially on the Gomel (M5 Highway) directions. Cars were stuck on roads in the Krupki, Dzerzhinsk, Slutsk, and Borisov districts, and traffic towards Grodno (M6 Highway) was disrupted. On the Brest-Orsha highway (M1), an accident occurred with two fatalities. On that highway, in the section from Smilovichi to the village of Khutor, 32 cars and 7 trucks were stuck in deep snow. A total of 136 people were in these vehicles, including 22 children. On another route, the M4 highway, between 450 and 500 cars were stranded. "Drivers caught in the snowstorm far from populated areas had to spend the night in their cars. Many were forced to abandon their vehicles, which were quickly covered in snow. People helped each other. For example, when we tried to assist a driver stuck on the Dzerzhinsk highway, a jeep with high clearance was ahead of us, creating a path because the road was being covered with snow instantly. Serious traffic jams were caused by heavy trucks, which could only be helped by more powerful specialized equipment," said Alexander Bruy, a traffic police inspector of the Belarusian Ministry of Internal Affairs, in an interview with the newspaper "SB. Belarus Today" on March 19, 2013. By 7:00 PM, it became dark, further complicating the situation. Some people stuck in traffic sought shelter in nearby villages. Even celebrities were caught in the jams. For instance, Russian actor Ivan Okhlobystin was delayed on the Bobruisk-Minsk highway, and Vadim Saranchukov, chairman of the BPF party, was stuck on the road from the capital to Grodno near Volozhin. On Friday evening (the 15th), overnight, and Saturday morning (the 16th), employees of "Alpha Radio" received over four thousand SMS messages, with many people calling and writing to journalists on Skype asking for help. "The weather forecast from the Hydrometeorological Center was there, but no one knew what would happen. When the news broadcast ended, we decided to stay on air for a couple more hours to see how events would unfold. When it became clear that there was little news on informational websites, we asked people to inform us about what was happening on the roads. Initially, listeners just told us where the traffic jams were. But then it became evident that we were not just sharing news but providing information that people urgently needed at that moment. At 10 and 11 PM, we received so many calls and SMS messages that we stopped playing music. Sometimes we would play a song, but people immediately wrote: 'Come back on air!' We received thousands of messages, and the phone did not stop ringing for a minute," said Dmitry Smirnov, a radio host of "Alpha Radio," in an interview with the newspaper "Komsomolskaya Pravda" on March 15, 2014. Meanwhile, Belenergo recorded the maximum number of power outages: by the evening, 1,728 transformer substations, 558 settlements, and 71 farms were left without electricity. Although snowdrifts and roadblocks hindered specialized equipment from reaching the damage sites, by morning, power was restored in half of the affected settlements. By the evening of the 16th, power outages were reported only in a few isolated locations, but even there, electricity was quickly restored by the night of the 17th. Throughout the evening and night, dozens of cars and buses began to emerge from the traffic jams. On March 16, the cyclone left Belarus, heading towards Russia, but for some time, severe traffic jams of about 30 kilometers in length were still observed on the roads. On this day, food shortages were reported in stores. The aftermath of the storm was felt for almost a week.

Whole_Text.header: The struggle with the elements and consequences
Whole_Text.content: Due to the absence of other state officials, all the work on organizing a crisis center to combat the disaster fell on the shoulders of Deputy Prime Minister Kalinin. During peak hours, about 1,200 units of special equipment were clearing the roads. In the capital, about 20,000 people and around 1,000 units of special equipment were involved in eliminating the consequences of the snowfall. Units of the Armed Forces of Belarus also joined the efforts. Starting from 7:00 PM on the 15th, military equipment was deployed to clear roads and rescue vehicles. By 10:00 PM, it was reported that municipal and emergency services were operating in an enhanced mode. Heating, food, and overnight stay points were organized in the capital. Similar points were also set up on the Minsk-Mogilev highway in Smilovichi and Cherven. In response to traffic jams on the Grodno and Moscow directions, district executive committees and the traffic police organized the delivery of hot food and tea. A bus with 40 children returning from an excursion to Mir Castle, blocked on the Slutsk highway in the Uzda district, was freed from the snow trap. In Volozhin, overnight accommodation was organized for 52 people in a hotel and for 25 in a local college dormitory. Vehicle towing was also arranged. Temporary accommodation for people from the M1 highway was organized in the Cherven Construction Lyceum (22 people), Smilovichi Agricultural Lyceum (51 people), and Smilovichi Agricultural College (2 people); one person with a fever was taken to the Smilovichi hospital. On the section of the road where a traffic jam had formed, round-the-clock café services were organized (in the villages of Karpilovka, Natalyevsk, and the town of Smilovichi), where drivers and passengers of affected vehicles could warm up and receive hot food. In the Slutsk district, 20 heating points were set up in all rural clubs near the roads. During "Xavier," the Ministry of Emergency Situations provided assistance 211 times, pulling 363 vehicles (passenger and cargo cars, buses, and ambulances) out of snowdrifts, with 1,172 people inside, including 260 children. Despite the mobilization of all municipal services and the active participation of the Ministry of Emergency Situations, police, and ambulance services in combating the disaster, these efforts were insufficient to bring the situation under control. As a result, many people cleared courtyards and freed vehicles from the snow themselves. During the disaster, there was active mutual assistance among the country's residents: many independently distributed tea to drivers, helped fellow citizens get home, and cleared others' cars and roads of snow. The TUT.by portal's "hotline" organized an online help service on its website overnight, where people could request or offer assistance to those in need. In less than a day, the hotline gathered about 700 comments. Volunteers from the Protestant church "New Life" also joined, with parishioners helping Minsk residents get home. On the 17th, while heading from Russia to Indonesia and Singapore, President of Belarus Alexander Lukashenko issued a directive to all state authorities to promptly clear roads, access to public institutions, and residential courtyards during daylight hours. Deputy Prime Minister Kalinin also conveyed the head of state's appeal to citizens, urging them to actively participate in clearing courtyards and adjacent areas. The fight against the disaster and its consequences was led by headquarters established in the government and locally. They coordinated the activities of all state services (regional executive committees, Minsk City Executive Committee, Ministry of Emergency Situations, housing and communal services, Ministry of Transport, Ministry of Internal Affairs, traffic police, Ministry of Defense, and others). After the cyclone, all streets and corners remained snow-covered for several days, with unprecedented snowdrift heights noted. To combat the snow in Minsk, a massive cleanup day was held on March 19, involving over 80,000 Minsk residents. Among them were 11,000 representatives of political parties and public organizations, and 1,500 representatives of territorial public self-government committees. During the cleanup, about 1,500 units of equipment, including those from external organizations, were used. According to the press service of the Minsk City Executive Committee, 80 tons of salt, over 1,500 cubic meters of sand-salt mixture, and 35,000 cubic meters of snow were removed to treat roads and sidewalks.

In Western Europe, starting from March 9, cyclones Yorick and Xavier passed through. The disaster caused problems on the night of March 10 to 11. France, Germany, Belgium, Hungary, the United Kingdom, as well as, to some extent, the Netherlands and Sweden, were affected. A transport collapse on the roads paralyzed all movement. Heavy snowfall and wind were recorded, which immobilized traffic on intercity highways. Traffic jams stretched for hundreds of kilometers. In Moscow, almost a month's worth of precipitation fell in a single day. While heavy snowfalls hit the capital in the first half of the day, by the second half, due to warming, utility workers were pumping out melted water. Such heavy snowfall in March had not been seen in the central regions of Russia for the past 130 years. In Ukraine, as a result of events on March 15, hundreds of settlements were left without electricity, and thousands of cars were trapped in snow blockades on the roads. After the cyclone began to weaken, frosts struck, leading to icy conditions.

On March 17, Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly Kalinin, summarizing the results of the fight against the natural disaster, noted that the service for passengers of delayed flights at the National Airport "Minsk" was not organized at the proper level. Fuel delivery to motorists trapped by the snowstorm was not carried out promptly. Hot food delivery was not ensured everywhere. And most importantly, having received information about the storm warning, motorists ignored it and set out on the road, violating speed limits. The Ministry of Emergency Situations also noted the lack of awareness among the population. "The fact that people did not listen to us significantly complicated the elimination of the consequences of the dangerous natural phenomenon. After all, our service repeatedly, a day before the blizzard, warned that the roads would be covered with snow. But in fact, during the snowfall, road accidents began to occur, which blocked traffic, creating jams that, in turn, hindered snow removal. And yet, many trips could have been postponed," said Vitaly Dembovsky, assistant head of the Minsk City Department of the Ministry of Emergency Situations, in an interview for the newspaper "SB. Belarus Today" on March 19, 2013. In turn, journalist Paulyuk Bykouski criticized the actions of the authorities and services during the cataclysm, as well as their level of preparedness, but highly praised the mutual assistance and initiative of ordinary citizens. In his opinion, these events showed that the authorities are not ready to take responsibility in a crisis situation, and similar problems will have to be solved by the population independently. "It cannot be said that the state completely withdrew from solving these issues, as the Ministry of Emergency Situations, ambulance, and police genuinely helped people. But the problem of shelter and heating, it seems, was resolved mainly without the participation of the state—except for the distribution of tea to those who spent the night from Friday to Saturday in cars blocked on roads outside the city. [...] The disaster revealed that the Belarusian Ministry of Emergency Situations has little suitable equipment—according to some reports, it has only two all-terrain vehicles with low-pressure tires, which proved truly effective in combating the disaster. One all-terrain vehicle was found with the Red Cross," said journalist Paulyuk Bykouski in an article on TUT.by on April 1, 2013. On March 19–20, shortly after "Xavier," the cyclone "Birk," formed over Germany and Poland, approached Belarus. However, unlike its predecessor, formed by the collision of tropical and Arctic air masses, "Birk" consisted of homogeneous moderate air masses, and therefore was less active. Its atmospheric fronts significantly affected only the weather in Brest and Grodno, as well as the western part of Gomel and the southwestern part of the Minsk regions. The cyclone was much weaker than "Xavier," and, moreover, municipal services were well-prepared, allowing serious incidents to be avoided. That year, snow remained until April 11. Meteorologists and the Ministry of Emergency Situations developed action plans in case of similar cyclones, and in December 2013, Belarusian rescuers conducted a command-staff exercise close to real conditions of a natural disaster. After "Xavier," the color scale of danger levels (previously used by Belhydromet but intended only for the Ministry of Emergency Situations) was included in the weather forecasts of Belarusian media. The action plans of the Ministry of Emergency Situations and road services for similar emergencies were improved. The cyclone left a lasting impression on Belarusians. Weather forecasts often mentioned this snowstorm, comparing it to other similar storms that approached Belarus and assessing the likelihood of a recurrence of the events of March 2013. The Ministry of Emergency Situations even jokingly proposed measuring strong cyclones in conditional "Xaviers." Belhydromet called it the "perfect cyclone," referring to its good predictability, though not everyone agrees with this.

Info_Box:
Data: from March 9 to 16, 2013 (in Belarus from March 15 to 16)  
Places: Belarus (mainly) also affected: France, Germany, Belgium, Great Britain, Netherlands, Sweden, Ukraine, Russia  
Cause: collision of a southern cyclone with cold polar air  
Result: transport collapse  
Fatalities: 0 from direct impact, 2 from indirect impact (traffic accident on highway M1)

Article_Name: 2021年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2021 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2021. Although there is no specific formation period, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to typhoons in the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2021 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (international names) with international numbers starting with 21xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter W. Any tropical depression that enters or forms within the Philippine Area of Responsibility is given a local name by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (the international name is considered official). The Chinese names of storms are currently determined through consultation among the China Meteorological Administration, the Hong Kong Observatory, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan. Before the 2020s, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, Macao, and Taiwan might have differed. The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak state during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

According to the forecast of the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau, tropical cyclone activity affecting Hainan Island during the 2021 flood season is relatively active, and the number of impacts and landfalls may be close to or exceed the annual average.

The Shenzhen Meteorological Observatory predicts that Shenzhen will experience typhoon impacts earlier in 2021, and under the background of global warming and La Niña, the risk of severe typhoon impacts is relatively high. It is expected that 5-8 typhoons will enter the 500-kilometer defense zone of Shenzhen in 2021.

The Hong Kong Observatory predicts that the typhoon season will begin by June this year or earlier, with 5 to 8 tropical cyclones expected to enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong throughout the year, which is considered normal to slightly above normal. Due to global warming, the Observatory expects the annual average temperature this year to be higher than normal, likely making it one of the 10 warmest years on record.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau predicts that about 5 to 8 tropical cyclones will affect Macao, with a normal to slightly above-normal number, including possibly strong typhoons or above. The typhoon season is expected to start in early June or earlier and end around mid-October.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation announced the typhoon season outlook on June 29, predicting that the number of typhoons forming from June to December this year will be below average to normal, with the number of typhoons affecting Taiwan being within the normal range, approximately 3 to 4.

On January 20, a tropical depression was forming but lasted only a few hours. On February 16, a tropical depression formed and was named Dujuan, affecting the Philippines and Palau. In April, a rare typhoon formed in the Northwest Pacific and was named Surigae, which rapidly developed and became the third-lowest pressure tropical cyclone of the 21st century. In July, Typhoon In-fa and Typhoon Cempaka performed a "double typhoon dance," with Cempaka intensifying near the coast, while In-fa indirectly caused the July 2021 Henan floods. In September, Typhoon Chanthu formed and was repeatedly rated as a Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, while Typhoon Mindulle was nicknamed the "aesthetic typhoon" by typhoon enthusiasts. In October, Typhoons Lionrock, Kompasu, and Namtheun performed a "triple typhoon dance," with Lionrock and Kompasu successively striking the southern coast of China, while Namtheun "revived" in the open ocean and intensified to typhoon strength. Entering winter, fewer cyclones formed in 2021 compared to previous years, but all named cyclones developed into super typhoons, which was very rare. Super Typhoon Nyatoh explosively intensified to a Category 4 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale in high-latitude regions, while Super Typhoon Rai first explosively intensified near the Philippines and made landfall in central Philippines at peak strength. After crossing the Philippines and entering the South China Sea, it explosively intensified again in the central South China Sea, becoming the second tropical cyclone in the South China Sea to reach Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content: PAGASA: On February 13, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of the Ulithi Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 2 PM on February 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 PM on February 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On February 17 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD01. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 01W. On February 18 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded it to a tropical depression and tropical storm, respectively. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2101, and named it "Dujuan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a mild typhoon and tropical storm, respectively. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On February 20 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. On February 22 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Dujuan made landfall on Batan Island. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On February 23 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

PAGASA: Bising  
On April 9, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern waters of the Erato Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W.  
At 11:30 PM on April 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium."  
At 2 PM on April 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
At 8 AM on April 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD02. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 02W. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 2 AM on April 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2102, and named it "Surigae." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 8 AM on April 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 2 AM on April 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  
At 2 AM on April 17, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon, and later at 8 AM, further upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to an intense typhoon.  
At 2 PM on April 20, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  
At 8 PM on April 22, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2 PM on April 23, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5 AM on April 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center determined that Surigae had transitioned into a subtropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5 AM on April 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Surigae had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory stated that Surigae had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
On April 27, after transitioning into an extratropical cyclone, Surigae continued to move across the Northwest Pacific and developed into an explosive cyclone, with its pressure dropping rapidly by 20 hPa from 9 PM on the 26th to 3 AM on the 27th, reaching as low as 945 hPa.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 170 knots (315 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Dante  
On May 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters south of Satawal Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 99W.  
At 2 PM on May 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium."  
At 2 AM on May 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 04W. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD04. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2 AM on May 31, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2103 and naming it "Choi-wan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8 PM on June 1, Choi-wan made landfall in Sulat, Eastern Samar, Philippines.  
At 8 AM on June 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2 PM on June 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. The Hong Kong Observatory and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan followed suit, downgrading it at 5 PM and 8 PM, respectively.  
At 8 AM on June 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm for the third time. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory stated that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and merged into a stationary front. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.  
At 2 PM on June 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

On June 10, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern waters of the Xisha Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. On the afternoon of June 11, at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD05. The China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory also followed suit in upgrading it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "medium." At 4:15 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal. At 4:30 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued the No. 1 Signal. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.

On June 12, at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2104 and naming it "Koguma." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2:10 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory canceled the No. 1 Standby Signal. At 5:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 6:00 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals and simultaneously upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.

On June 13, at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. The China Meteorological Administration reported that Koguma made landfall along the coast of Thanh Hóa Province, Vietnam, around 7:45 AM. At 11:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan followed suit. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On June 18, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Pohnpei Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On June 20 at 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On June 21 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 06W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On June 22 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD06. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 23 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and revised the intensity of the previous two reports to 30 knots (55 km/h). At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2105, and named it "Champi." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 24 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On June 25 at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. On June 26 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. On June 27 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Champi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and merged into a stationary front.

PAGASA: Fabian  
On July 14, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium."  
On July 16 at 4:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 11:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 09W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD08.  
On July 17 at 2:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On July 18 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2106, and named it "In-Fa." At the same time, the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory also followed suit and upgraded it. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On July 19 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
On July 20 at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory simultaneously upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  
On July 25 at 12:30 PM, In-Fa made landfall along the coast of Putuo, Zhoushan, Zhejiang Province, with maximum wind speeds near the center reaching 13 on the Beaufort scale (38 m/s) and a central minimum pressure of 965 hPa.  
On July 26 at 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded In-Fa to a severe tropical storm, and at 5:00 PM the same day, it was further downgraded to a tropical storm.  
On July 28 at 3:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On July 30, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
On July 31, In-Fa dissipated after making landfall in Liaoning Province.

On July 16, a tropical disturbance formed in the South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. On the morning of July 17 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." On the morning of July 18 at 7 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:55 p.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued Signal No. 1. At 6 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration issued a blue typhoon warning signal. At 8 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD09. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 10W. At 9 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued Signal No. 1 at 9:40 p.m. On July 19 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2107, and named it "Cempaka." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. On July 20 at 1 a.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a typhoon. At 1:45 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On the same day at 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 21 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and downgraded it, and six hours later further downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 22 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 24 at 11 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On July 26 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.
The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its best track released on November 1, revised its peak intensity to 70 knots (130 kilometers per hour) and lowered the pressure to 980 hPa.

On July 22, a tropical disturbance formed in the northern waters of the Pajaros Rock Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On the morning of July 23 at 6 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high," issued a tropical cyclone formation alert, and classified it as a subtropical cyclone. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD10. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2108, and named it "Nepartak." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. On July 28 at 5 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Nepartak made landfall in Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Nepartak had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, downgraded its peak wind speed to 40 knots (75 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Huaning  
On August 2, a tropical disturbance formed in the Gulf of Tonkin, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." At 9 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
On August 3 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On August 4 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2109, and named it "Lupit."  
On August 5 at 11:20 AM, the China National Meteorological Center announced that Lupit made landfall in Nan'ao County, Shantou City, Guangdong Province. At 4:50 PM, the China National Meteorological Center announced that Lupit made landfall again in Dongshan County, Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province.  
On August 8 at 8:44 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it made landfall in Makurazaki City, Kagoshima Prefecture, Kyushu.  
On August 9 at 5:39 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it made landfall again in Kure City, Hiroshima Prefecture, Chugoku region. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Lupit had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
On August 16 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency concluded that it had merged into a stationary front.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its peak wind speed to 45 knots (85 kilometers per hour) in the best track released on August 5, 2022.

PAGASA: Gorio  
On July 31, a tropical disturbance formed near the eastern coast of Taiwan, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On August 2 at 6 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 4 at 2 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD12. At 4 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 14W. On August 5 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2110, and named it "Ginga." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Hong Kong Observatory respectively upgraded it to a mild typhoon and a tropical depression. On August 6 at 12 p.m., Ginga absorbed tropical depression 12W. On August 10 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Ginga had transformed into an extratropical cyclone. On August 14 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

The Japan Meteorological Agency, in the best track released on November 10, adjusted the peak of Galaxy to 50 knots (95 km/h). The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, adjusted its peak wind speed to 55 knots (100 km/h).

On August 1, a tropical disturbance formed near the waters northwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 12:00 noon on August 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 15W. At 8:00 p.m. on August 4, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:00 a.m. on August 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2111, and named it "Nida." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a mild typhoon and a tropical storm, respectively. At 2:00 a.m. on August 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 a.m. on August 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Nida had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 8:00 a.m. on August 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.
The Japan Meteorological Agency, in the best track released on November 10, upgraded Nida's peak to 55 knots (100 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: On August 6, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters south-southwest of Hawaii, and the Central Pacific Hurricane Center designated it as disturbance 91C. On the evening of August 9, under the guidance of a deep subtropical high-pressure ridge to the north, the low-pressure area moved westward across the International Date Line, entering the Northwest Pacific, and the Japan Meteorological Agency took over issuing updates. On August 10 at 9:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. Due to deep convection consolidating the low-level circulation center, at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 16W. Previously, the Madden-Julian Oscillation increased atmospheric instability, leading to the formation of multiple tropical cyclones. Subsequently, as the Madden-Julian Oscillation entered the next phase, subsiding air suppressed convection activity in the Western Pacific. The absence of the southwest monsoon, intrusion of dry air, and vertical wind shear from the southwest displacing convection eastward exposed the low-level circulation center. These unfavorable factors left the system struggling to survive on sea surface temperatures of 28°C or higher. On August 13 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD14. On August 14 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression but upgraded it back to a tropical storm at 2 PM. On August 15 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it again to a tropical depression, while the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On August 16 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. On August 17 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reclassified it as a tropical depression. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning and rated its remnants as "medium." On August 18 at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On August 19 at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating back to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical depression. On August 20 at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan reclassified it as a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reissued a gale warning for it. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2112, and named it "Omais." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 21 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical storm. On August 22 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 23 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At around 11:50 PM, the Korea Meteorological Administration reported that Omais made landfall near the coast of Goseong County, South Gyeongsang Province. On August 24 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Omais had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On September 1 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into a low-pressure area.

The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its best track released on December 1, 2021, downgraded its wind speed to 45 knots (85 kilometers per hour), considering it to have lost severe tropical storm intensity. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, upgraded its peak wind speed to 55 knots (100 kilometers per hour).

On July 1, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map. At 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and downgraded its rating.

PAGASA: On July 2, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters north-northeast of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. On July 4 at 12:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD07. At 10:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a tropical depression advisory. On July 5 at 4:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 07W. At 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 6:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration issued a blue typhoon warning signal. On July 6 at 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. At 3:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area and canceled the No. 1 Standby Signal bulletin, while the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 5:00 PM and canceled the No. 1 Signal bulletin.

On July 4, a tropical disturbance formed in the Sibuyan Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 97W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On July 5 at 5 PM, the China Meteorological Administration and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau first upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 6 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:15 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal for it, simultaneously warning of two tropical cyclones. At 6 AM, the China Meteorological Administration issued a blue typhoon warning signal for it. At 6:30 AM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued the No. 1 Signal, also indicating the presence of two active tropical depressions. At 8:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On July 7, around 11 AM, the China Meteorological Administration reported that it made landfall along the coast of Lingshui County, Hainan Province. At 2:10 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory canceled the No. 1 Standby Signal for it. At 5 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau canceled the No. 1 Signal for it. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation Tropical Cyclone 08W. On July 8 at 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 30 knots (55 kilometers per hour).

On the morning of July 19 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that a tropical depression had formed in the waters northwest of Wake Island. On the morning of July 21 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On the morning of July 28 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that a tropical depression had formed in the sea area north-northwest of Minamitorishima. On the morning of July 30 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On July 28, a tropical disturbance formed east of Kadena, Okinawa Island, and was designated as 95W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. On the morning of July 30 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 5 p.m. on August 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had dissipated.

On July 31, a tropical disturbance formed south of Japan, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 96W. At 2 a.m. on August 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 a.m. on August 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that it made landfall in Mie Prefecture, Japan. At 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had dissipated.

In the early hours of August 2nd at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that a tropical depression had formed in the northern waters of Taiwan. By 8 p.m. on August 3rd, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered it to have dissipated.

On August 1, a tropical disturbance formed near the waters northeast of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 98W. On the morning of August 2 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it Tropical Cyclone Number 12W. At 2 a.m. on August 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency reclassified it as a tropical depression. At 12 p.m. on August 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that it had merged into the circulation of Tropical Storm Khanun.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On September 1, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium" and classified it as a subtropical disturbance. On September 2 at 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 17W. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD15. On September 4 at 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into a stationary front.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track issued on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On the morning of September 7 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that a tropical depression had formed near the eastern offshore area of Hainan Island. On the evening of September 8 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

On September 27, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northeast of Saipan, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of September 28 at 9 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." On the afternoon of September 30 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating to "low." On the afternoon of October 1 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating. At 2 a.m. on October 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

PAGASA: Nando  
On October 7, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea area northwest of Yap Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 8, at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that it had merged into the circulation of Severe Tropical Storm Kompasu. On October 9, at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On October 10, at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm and assigned it the tropical storm number 24W.

On October 22, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 99W. On October 24 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium," while the Hong Kong Observatory, the China Meteorological Administration, and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 25 at 1:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On October 26 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 26W. On October 27 at 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On October 28 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On December 13, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea area south-southwest of Nanwei Beach, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On the morning of December 14 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:30 a.m. on December 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 1:30 a.m. on December 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 29W. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 30 knots (55 kilometers per hour).

Once a tropical cyclone in the Western Pacific reaches tropical storm intensity, it is named by the Typhoon Committee. These names are provided by 14 member countries or regions, each contributing 10 names, and then sorted alphabetically by the English names of the countries. Names in bold indicate those already used this year, bold names indicate active storms, unused names are shown in gray, and orange indicates the next name to be used. Storm names in 2021 may overlap with some storm names from 2003, 2004, 2009, 2010, 2015, and 2016.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form within, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list is rotated every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2021, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all tropical cyclones that were active in the Western Pacific in 2021, including their intensity, duration, names, and the casualties and damage they caused. All damages are measured in US dollars. Deaths in parentheses refer to indirect causes (such as traffic accidents, landslides, etc.).

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 8 of Reiwa 3 (Asian name: Nepartak [named by Micronesia, meaning: the name of a famous warrior]) is a typhoon that occurred in July 2021 and made landfall in Miyagi Prefecture for the first time in history.

At 9 PM on July 23, a developing tropical depression near Minamitorishima (which formed at 9 AM on the same day) became Typhoon No. 8 and was named Nepartak. The typhoon then moved northward and proceeded northwest over the sea east of Japan. By 9 PM on July 24, the radius of the strong wind area reached 500 km, making it a large typhoon. At this stage, it was predicted to approach or make landfall in the Tohoku or Kanto-Koshin regions by the 27th. If it were to make landfall in areas such as Fukushima, Miyagi, or Ibaraki Prefectures, it would be the first such case since statistics began in 1951. This typhoon's path was extremely rare, as only two typhoons had made landfall on the Pacific side of the Kanto and Tohoku regions from the east since 1951: Typhoon No. 13 in 1989 (which made landfall near Choshi City, Chiba Prefecture) and Typhoon No. 10 in 2016 (which made landfall near Ofunato City, Iwate Prefecture). The unusual path of this typhoon was attributed to factors such as the Pacific High being located farther northeast than usual and the presence of an upper-level cold vortex. 

Subsequently, the typhoon gradually changed its course from northwest to west. Although it did not have a storm zone, parts of the Kanto and Tohoku regions entered the strong wind area on the night of the 26th. The typhoon temporarily moved southward and almost stalled over the sea east of Choshi City by the morning of the 27th. At this stage, parts of Hokuriku and Tokai also entered the strong wind area. During the day, it changed its course northward and moved off the southern coast of Kanto. By the night of the same day, it curved north-northwest and moved from off the coast of northern Kanto to off the coast of Sanriku. Then, before 6 AM on the 28th, it made landfall near Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture. As mentioned earlier, this was the first recorded instance of a typhoon making landfall in Miyagi Prefecture. It then moved northward through northeastern Miyagi Prefecture into Iwate Prefecture, reaching 70 km south of Morioka City by 9 AM and 80 km northeast of Akita City by noon on the same day. In the afternoon, it changed its course westward, passed through Akita Prefecture, and entered the Sea of Japan. At 3 PM on the same day, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone off the coast of Akita Prefecture.

This typhoon exhibited characteristics intermediate between a typhoon and an extratropical cyclone, such as accompanying cold air aloft, which caused strong winds and rain in areas far from the typhoon's center. On July 26, maximum wind gusts of 23.1 m/s were observed in Choshi, 16.1 m/s in Iwaki City, and 15.3 m/s in Kitaibaraki City. On the following day, July 27, a maximum wind gust of 25.8 m/s was recorded in Choshi, and very heavy rainfall of 64.5 mm in one hour was observed on Hachijojima by 4:43 a.m., tying the record for the highest July rainfall. Additionally, heavy rainfall of 32.0 mm was recorded in Higashishirakawa Town, Chiba Prefecture, by 1:11 a.m. on the same day. Later that night, active rain clouds brought strong rainfall of 21 mm in one hour to Minamisoma City, Fukushima Prefecture, by 8:00 p.m.
It made landfall during the Tokyo Olympics.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Gorio (International designation: Typhoon Mirinae) was a typhoon that formed within the PAR on August 4 and had no impact on the Philippines but would enhance the southwest monsoon affecting the entirety of Luzon, along with Typhoon Huaning, both crossing the northern part of the Philippines.

As a Low Pressure Area (LPA), Gorio (Mirinae) is moving in a northeast direction, traversing the Philippine Sea between Typhoon Nida and Typhoon Nepartak, both active in the Pacific Ocean in August 2021. On August 4, a weather disturbance formed in the eastern part of Taipei, Taiwan. It was spotted at a distance of (172 km; 107 mi) south-southeast of Kadena Air Base, Okinawa, Japan, with the typhoon moving northeast towards Tokyo at a slow pace.

Article_Name: 태풍 오마이스 (2021년) - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Omais (OMAIS) is the 12th typhoon that occurred in the Northwest Pacific in 2021, with a name submitted by the United States meaning "wandering around." It was the first typhoon to make landfall on the Korean Peninsula in 2021.

Typhoon Omais formed as a tropical storm with a central pressure of 1,004 hPa, maximum wind speed of 18 m/s, and a gale radius of 110 km at 9 PM on August 20, approximately 850 km south-southeast of Okinawa, Japan (based on the Japan Meteorological Agency's typhoon information). After formation, it moved north-northwest to northwest and developed, reaching its peak as a strong tropical storm with a central pressure of 996 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 26 m/s at 9 AM on August 22, approximately 330 km southwest of Okinawa, Japan. After its peak, it moved into the East China Sea and rapidly weakened due to strong vertical wind shear, passing through Jeju Island. Shortly after, it made landfall in Gwangdo-myeon, Tongyeong-si, Gyeongsangnam-do, at 12 AM on August 24 with a central pressure of 998 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 18 m/s, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency. According to the Korea Meteorological Administration, it made landfall in Goseong-gun, Gyeongsangnam-do, at 11:50 PM on August 23 with a central pressure of 996 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 18 m/s. It then moved out to the East Sea from Pohang-si, Gyeongsangbuk-do, at around 2:50 AM on August 24, according to the Korea Meteorological Administration, and at 3 AM on August 24, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency. As it moved rapidly northeast, it underwent extratropical transition, becoming an extratropical cyclone with a central pressure of 996 hPa at around 6 AM on August 24, approximately 60 km southwest of Ulleungdo in the East Sea, according to the Korea Meteorological Administration. According to the Japan Meteorological Agency, it became an extratropical cyclone with a central pressure of 998 hPa at 9 AM on August 24, approximately 56 km northeast of Ulleungdo in the East Sea.

Typhoon Omais was the first typhoon to directly affect South Korea in 2021. According to the Korea Meteorological Administration on the 24th, Typhoon Omais had a central pressure of 996 hPa, maximum wind speeds of 18-19 m/s, and a gale radius of 110 km, classifying it as a relatively small typhoon, but it brought heavy rain and strong winds. In the southern regions affected by the typhoon, torrential rain of up to 100 mm per hour caused flooding on roads and other damages. The areas most affected were Gyeongsangnam-do, Ulsan Metropolitan City, and Busan Metropolitan City, with Jeollanam-do and Gyeongsangbuk-do also suffering significant damage. Overall, it was a rain-heavy typhoon with more damage caused by rain than wind. No injuries or fatalities were reported due to the typhoon.

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Crising is the third storm to enter the Philippines. On May 13, it was spotted 206 nmi (380 km; 235 mi) east of Davao City, Philippines, with winds of 30 knots and 40 knots. The storm is moving in a west-northwest direction and is expected to make landfall in the province of Davao Oriental. Crising is currently classified as a "Tropical Storm."[1][2] On May 11, the JTWC observed a developing weather disturbance located 184 miles and 341 kilometers west of Palau. This Low Pressure Area formed within one day, and by May 12, a day later, it became a full-fledged storm (Tropical Storm) named "Crising" by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA). Crising, the third storm to enter the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR), is moving in a west-northwest direction, targeting the eastern provinces of Mindanao, including the Caraga region and Davao region. Warning levels were raised in the provinces from #2 to #1.[3]

Tropical storm Crising was raised to level #2, it made landfall in Baganga, Davao Oriental, the storm weakened in the central mainland of Mindanao and became a Low Pressure Area in the area of Piagapo, Lanao del Sur. Some trees were toppled due to heavy rain and wind in Baganga, and 3 men and a carabao were rescued from the rushing "Kabacan River." The evacuation center in South Upi, Maguindanao served as a shelter for residents, and some crops were washed away by floodwaters from the Allah River.

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Namtheun, on October 8, was located 289 nmi (535 km; 333 mi) from Wake Island starting as a small circulation. Later, the JMA recognized it as a full Tropical Depression on October 9. By October 10, Namtheun became a full storm currently rotating in the Pacific Ocean at a distance of 337 nmi (624 km; 388 mi) in the direction of Enewetak Atoll, with wind speeds of 35 knots (65 km/h; 40 mph), gusts up to 50 knots (95 km/h; 60 mph), a 1-minute sustained wind of 30 knots (55 km/h; 35 mph), and a pressure of 1000 hPa (29.53 inHg).
The JTWC launched from the formation of the storm on October 11 when it became a full-fledged storm and was named Namtheun as its international name.

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Maring-Nando is the 21st storm in the Philippines, recording significant reports of damage that affected the Philippines, Taiwan, and southern China. It is subsequently referred to as "Tropical Storm Maring (Kompasu)" which struck Northern Luzon, while affecting Batanes. Later, PAGASA named it NandoPH as a Tropical Depression, which eventually became a Low-Pressure Area (LPA). PAGASA issued the final bulletin on October 9.

The typhoons "Maring" and "Nando" merged to become a severe typhoon, upgraded to typhoon category, and Signal No. 1 was raised with PAGASA issuing warnings in regions of Northern Luzon, while crossing the South China Sea towards Hong Kong and Macau. When typhoon Nando weakened and fully merged, Signal No. 1 was raised in Northern Luzon as typhoon Maring continued to affect the area. A gale warning was issued for the northern and eastern seaboards of the Philippines.

Recorded damaged homes, rice fields, and fishing vessels in the Ilocos Region and Cagayan Valley due to the typhoon. Preemptive evacuations were also conducted for residents near low-lying coastal areas.
