Article_Name: 2021年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2021 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2021. Although there is no specific formation period, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to typhoons in the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2021 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (international names) with international numbers starting with 21xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter W. Any tropical depression that enters or forms within the Philippine Area of Responsibility is given a local name by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (the international name is considered official). The Chinese names of storms are currently determined through consultation by the China Meteorological Administration, the Hong Kong Observatory, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan. Before the 2020s, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan might have differed. The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak form during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

According to the forecast of the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau, tropical cyclone activity affecting Hainan Island during the 2021 flood season is relatively active, and the number of impacts and landfalls may be close to or exceed the annual average.

The Shenzhen Meteorological Observatory predicts that Shenzhen will experience typhoon impacts earlier in 2021, and under the background of global warming and La Niña, the risk of severe typhoon impacts is relatively high. It is expected that 5-8 typhoons will enter the 500-kilometer defense zone of Shenzhen in 2021.

The Hong Kong Observatory predicts that the typhoon season will begin by June this year or earlier, with 5 to 8 tropical cyclones expected to enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong throughout the year, which is considered normal to slightly above normal. Due to global warming, the Observatory expects the annual average temperature this year to be higher than normal, likely making it one of the 10 warmest years on record.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau predicts that about 5 to 8 tropical cyclones will affect Macao, with a normal to slightly above-normal quantity, including possibly strong typhoons or above. The typhoon season is expected to begin in early June or earlier and end around mid-October.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation announced the typhoon season outlook on June 29, predicting that the number of typhoons forming from June to December this year will be below average to normal, with the number of typhoons affecting Taiwan being within the normal range, approximately 3 to 4.

On January 20, a tropical depression was forming but lasted only a few hours. On February 16, a tropical depression formed and was named Dujuan, affecting the Philippines and Palau. In April, a rare typhoon formed in the Northwest Pacific and was named Surigae, which rapidly developed and became the third-lowest pressure tropical cyclone of the 21st century. In July, Typhoon In-fa and Typhoon Cempaka performed a "double typhoon dance," with Cempaka intensifying near the coast, while In-fa indirectly caused the July 2021 Henan floods. In September, Typhoon Chanthu formed and was repeatedly rated as a Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale; Typhoon Mindulle was nicknamed the "aesthetic typhoon" by typhoon enthusiasts. In October, Typhoons Lionrock, Kompasu, and Namtheun performed a "triple typhoon dance," with Lionrock and Kompasu successively striking the southern coast of China, while Namtheun "revived" in the open ocean and intensified to typhoon strength. Entering winter, fewer cyclones formed in 2021 compared to previous years, but all named cyclones developed into super typhoons, which was very rare. Super Typhoon Nyatoh explosively intensified to a Category 4 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale in high-latitude regions; Super Typhoon Rai first explosively intensified near the Philippines and made landfall in central Philippines at peak intensity. After crossing the Philippines and entering the South China Sea, it explosively intensified again in the central South China Sea, becoming the second tropical cyclone in the South China Sea to reach Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content: PAGASA: On February 13, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of the Ulithi Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 2 PM on February 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 PM on February 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On February 17 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD01. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 01W. On February 18 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded it to a tropical depression and tropical storm, respectively. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2101, and named it "Dujuan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a mild typhoon and tropical storm, respectively. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On February 20 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. On February 22 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Dujuan made landfall on Batan Island. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On February 23 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

PAGASA: Bising  
On April 9, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern waters of the Elato Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W.  
At 11:30 PM on April 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium."  
At 2 PM on April 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
At 8 AM on April 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD02. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 02W. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 2 AM on April 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2102, and named it "Surigae." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 8 AM on April 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 2 AM on April 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  
At 2 AM on April 17, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon, and later at 8 AM, further upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a strong typhoon.  
At 2 PM on April 20, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  
At 8 PM on April 22, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2 PM on April 23, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5 AM on April 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center determined that Surigae had transitioned into a subtropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5 AM on April 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Surigae had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory stated that Surigae had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
On April 27, after transitioning into an extratropical cyclone, Surigae continued to move across the Northwest Pacific and developed into an explosive cyclone, with its pressure dropping rapidly by 20 hPa from 9 PM on the 26th to 3 AM on the 27th, reaching as low as 945 hPa.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 170 knots (315 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Dante  
On May 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters south of Satawal Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W.  
At 2 PM on May 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium."  
At 2 AM on May 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 04W. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD04. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm.  
At 2 AM on May 31, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2103 and naming it "Choi-wan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8 PM on June 1, Choi-wan made landfall in Sulat, Eastern Samar, Philippines.  
At 8 AM on June 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2 PM on June 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. The Hong Kong Observatory and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan followed suit, downgrading it at 5 PM and 8 PM, respectively.  
At 8 AM on June 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm for the third time. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory stated that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and merged into a stationary front. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.  
At 2 PM on June 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

On June 10, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern waters of the Xisha Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. On the afternoon of June 11, at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD05. The China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory also followed suit in upgrading it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "medium." At 4:15 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal. At 4:30 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued the No. 1 Typhoon Signal. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.

On June 12, at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2104 and naming it "Koguma." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2:10 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory canceled the No. 1 Standby Signal. At 5:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 6:00 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals and simultaneously upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.

On June 13, at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. The China Meteorological Administration reported that Koguma made landfall along the coast of Thanh Hóa Province, Vietnam, around 7:45 AM. At 11:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan followed suit. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On June 18, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Pohnpei Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On June 20 at 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On June 21 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 06W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On June 22 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD06. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 23 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and revised the intensity of the previous two reports to 30 knots (55 km/h). At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2105, and named it "Champi." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 24 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On June 25 at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. On June 26 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. On June 27 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Champi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and merged into a stationary front.

PAGASA: Fabian  
On July 14, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium."  
On July 16 at 4:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 11 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 09W. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD08.  
On July 17 at 2 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On July 18 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2106, and named it "In-Fa." At the same time, the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory also followed suit and upgraded it. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On July 19 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
On July 20 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory simultaneously upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  
On July 25 at 12:30 PM, In-Fa made landfall along the coast of Putuo, Zhoushan, Zhejiang Province, with maximum wind speeds near the center reaching 13 on the Beaufort scale (38 m/s) and a central minimum pressure of 965 hPa.  
On July 26 at 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded In-Fa to a severe tropical storm, and at 5 PM the same day, it was further downgraded to a tropical storm.  
On July 28 at 3 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On July 30, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
On July 31, In-Fa dissipated after making landfall in Liaoning Province.

On July 16, a tropical disturbance formed in the South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. On the morning of July 17 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." On the morning of July 18 at 7 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:55 p.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued Signal No. 1. At 6 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration issued a blue typhoon warning signal. At 8 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD09. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 10W. At 9 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued the Standby Signal No. 1 at 9:40 p.m. 

On July 19 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2107, and named it "Cempaka." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. 

On July 20 at 1 a.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a typhoon. At 1:45 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On the same day at 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. 

On July 21 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and downgraded it, and six hours later further downgraded it to a tropical depression. 

On July 22 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. 

On July 24 at 11 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. 

On July 26 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.
The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its best track released on November 1, revised its peak intensity to 70 knots (130 kilometers per hour) and lowered the pressure to 980 hPa.

On July 22, a tropical disturbance formed in the northern waters of the Pajaros Rock Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On the morning of July 23 at 6 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high," issued a tropical cyclone formation alert, and classified it as a subtropical cyclone. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD10. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2108, and named it "Nepartak." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. On July 28 at 5 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Nepartak made landfall in Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Nepartak had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, downgraded its peak wind speed to 40 knots (75 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Huaning  
On August 2, a tropical disturbance formed in the Gulf of Tonkin, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." At 9 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
On August 3 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On August 4 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2109, and named it "Lupit."  
On August 5 at 11:20 AM, the China National Meteorological Center announced that Lupit made landfall in Nan'ao County, Shantou City, Guangdong Province. At 4:50 PM, the China National Meteorological Center announced that Lupit made landfall again in Dongshan County, Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province.  
On August 8 at 8:44 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it made landfall in Makurazaki City, Kagoshima Prefecture, Kyushu.  
On August 9 at 5:39 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it made landfall again in Kure City, Hiroshima Prefecture, Chugoku region. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Lupit had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
On August 16 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency concluded that it had merged into a stationary front.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its peak wind speed to 45 knots (85 kilometers per hour) in the best track released on August 5, 2022.

PAGASA: Gorio  
On July 31, a tropical disturbance formed near the eastern coast of Taiwan, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On August 2 at 6 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 4 at 2 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD12. At 4 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 14W. On August 5 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2110, and named it "Ginga." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Hong Kong Observatory respectively upgraded it to a mild typhoon and a tropical depression. On August 6 at 12 p.m., Ginga absorbed tropical depression 12W. On August 10 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Ginga had transformed into an extratropical cyclone. On August 14 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its best track released on November 10, adjusted the peak of Galaxy to 50 knots (95 km/h). The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, adjusted its peak wind speed to 55 knots (100 km/h).

On August 1, a tropical disturbance formed near the waters northwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 12:00 noon on August 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 15W. At 8:00 p.m. on August 4, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:00 a.m. on August 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2111, and named it "Nida." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a mild typhoon and a tropical storm, respectively. At 2:00 a.m. on August 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 a.m. on August 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Nida had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 8:00 a.m. on August 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.
The Japan Meteorological Agency, in the best track released on November 10, upgraded Nida's peak to 55 knots (100 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: On August 6, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters south-southwest of Hawaii, and the Central Pacific Hurricane Center designated it as disturbance 91C. On the evening of August 9, under the guidance of a deep subtropical high-pressure ridge to the north, the low-pressure area moved westward across the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific, where the Japan Meteorological Agency took over issuing advisories. On August 10 at 9:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. Due to deep convection consolidating the low-level circulation center, at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 16W. Previously, the Madden-Julian Oscillation had increased atmospheric instability, leading to the formation of multiple tropical cyclones. Subsequently, as the Madden-Julian Oscillation entered its next phase, subsiding air suppressed convection activity in the Western Pacific. The absence of the southwest monsoon, intrusion of dry air, and vertical wind shear from the southwest displacing convection eastward exposed the low-level circulation center. These unfavorable factors left the system struggling to survive on sea surface temperatures of 28°C or higher. On August 13 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation TD14. On August 14 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression, but at 2 PM, it was upgraded again to a tropical storm. On August 15 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it again to a tropical depression, while the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On August 16 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. On August 17 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reclassified it as a tropical depression. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning and rated the remnants as "medium." On August 18 at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On August 19 at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating back to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical depression. On August 20 at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan reclassified it as a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reissued a gale warning. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international designation 2112, and named it "Omais." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 21 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical storm. On August 22 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 23 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At around 11:50 PM, the Korea Meteorological Administration reported that Omais made landfall near the coast of Goseong County, South Gyeongsang Province. On August 24 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Omais had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On September 1 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into a low-pressure area.

The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its best track released on December 1, 2021, downgraded its wind speed to 45 knots (85 kilometers per hour), considering it to have lost severe tropical storm intensity. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, upgraded its peak wind speed to 55 knots (100 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Jolina  
On September 5, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. On September 6 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 7 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 18W. Simultaneously, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2113, and named it "Conson." At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, China Meteorological Administration, Hong Kong Observatory, and Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical storm; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Conson made its first landfall in Hernani, Eastern Samar.  

On September 7 at 5 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a severe tropical storm.  

On September 11 at 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On September 12 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and downgraded it.  

On September 13 at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.  

On September 14 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

PAGASA: Kiko  
On September 2, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea north-northwest of Chuuk Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W.  
At 2:00 AM on September 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 7:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD16. At 11:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 19W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it.  
At 2:00 AM on September 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2114, and named it "Chanthu." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 5:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 11:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2:00 AM on September 8, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon and significantly increased its maximum wind speed to 240 km/h, indicating its rapid intensification. At 8:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a severe typhoon.  
At 5:30 AM on September 10, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a sea typhoon warning for it. At 5:30 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a land typhoon warning for it.  
At 8:00 PM on September 12, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8:30 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan lifted the land typhoon warning for it.  
At 2:30 AM on September 13, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan lifted the sea typhoon warning for it. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2:00 PM on September 14, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 2:00 PM on September 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 6:56 PM on September 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Chanthu made landfall near Fukutsu City, Fukuoka Prefecture. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 12:22 AM on September 18, it made landfall again in Matsuyama City, Ehime Prefecture, Shikoku. At 6:24 AM, it made a third landfall in Arida City, Wakayama Prefecture. At 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Chanthu had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
At 2:00 PM on September 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

On September 21, a tropical disturbance formed in the western waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 5:00 PM on September 22, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center skipped issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert and directly upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 21W. At 2:00 AM on September 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD19. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2115 and naming it "Dianmu." Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On December 13, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea area south-southwest of Nanwei Beach, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On the morning of December 14 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:30 a.m. on December 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 1:30 a.m. on December 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 29W. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 30 knots (55 kilometers per hour).

Once a tropical cyclone in the Western Pacific reaches tropical storm intensity, it is named by the Typhoon Committee. These names are provided by 14 member countries or regions, each contributing 10 names, and then sorted alphabetically by the English names of the countries. Names in bold indicate those already used this year, bold names indicate active storms, unused names are shown in gray, and orange indicates the next name to be used. Storm names in 2021 may overlap with some storm names from 2003, 2004, 2009, 2010, 2015, and 2016.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form within, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list rotates every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2021, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all tropical cyclones that were active in the Western Pacific in 2021, including their intensity, duration, names, and the casualties and damage they caused. All damages are measured in US dollars. Deaths in parentheses refer to indirect causes (such as traffic accidents, landslides, etc.).

Whole_Text.content: The low-pressure system of October 2006 caused extensive damage due to strong winds and heavy rain from the Kinki region to Hokkaido. Nationwide, the number of dead and missing reached 50, making it an unusually large-scale meteorological disaster for an autumn extratropical cyclone.

Due to the approach of Typhoon No. 16, the activity of the stationary front along the southern coast of Honshu became active around October 4. Additionally, a low-pressure system that formed on the front off the coast of Shikoku at noon on the 5th rapidly developed as it moved along the southern coast of Honshu on the 6th, further intensifying as it advanced to the Sanriku offshore area on the 7th and the eastern seas of Hokkaido on the 8th.  

As this rapidly developing low-pressure system moved north along the Pacific coast of Honshu, violent winds exceeding a maximum speed of 25 m/s occurred on the Pacific side from the Kanto region to Hokkaido. In Onagawa Town, Miyagi Prefecture, a record-breaking maximum wind speed of 30 m/s was observed at 7:30 a.m. on the 7th, and the seas experienced fierce waves exceeding 9 meters.  

Additionally, heavy rainfall exceeding a total of 250 mm from the start of the rain was recorded on the Pacific side of the Kinki, Kanto, and Tohoku regions, as well as the Okhotsk Sea side of Hokkaido. Particularly in parts of the Abashiri Subprefecture in Hokkaido, the total rainfall exceeded four times the average monthly rainfall for October.  

This storm caused one death, 43 injuries, one completely destroyed house, 18 partially destroyed houses, 978 houses with partial damage, 293 houses flooded above floor level, and 1,004 houses flooded below floor level.  

Regarding landslides, there was one debris flow, two landslides, and 34 slope failures.  

As for rivers, eight rivers in eight water systems, including the Abashiri River, exceeded the flood danger level, and 20 rivers in 15 water systems exceeded the flood warning level, resulting in flooding and other damages in various areas.  

In terms of lifelines, approximately 150,000 households experienced power outages in the Hokkaido and Tohoku Electric Power service areas, and 8,056 households in Hokkaido and other areas experienced water supply disruptions.  

Regarding roads, traffic restrictions were implemented on 448 sections of expressways, national highways, prefectural roads, and toll roads.  

For railways, train services were suspended nationwide due to rainfall regulations and other reasons.  

In aviation, 78 flights were unable to land at Narita International Airport (the highest number since its opening).  

Public civil engineering facilities suffered damage at 1,378 river locations, 124 coastal locations, 11 erosion control facilities, 603 road locations (including bridges), 30 port locations, and 5 park locations.  

In the agriculture, forestry, and fisheries sectors, damage occurred at 940 farmland locations, 1,171 agricultural facilities, 222 forest degradation locations, 722 forest road facilities, 6,971 hectares of forest, and 155 fishing port facilities.  

Furthermore, due to this low-pressure system, a series of ship groundings and capsizings occurred at sea, resulting in 19 deaths and 14 missing persons due to maritime accidents.  

Additionally, due to the cold air flowing in behind the low-pressure system, mountain accidents occurred in Nagano and Gifu Prefectures.  

Storm surges also occurred along the coast of Ibaraki Prefecture and other areas.  

Subsequent investigations revealed that an unusual storm surge caused by Ekman transport associated with the low-pressure system had occurred.

This disaster was designated as a severe disaster under the "Ordinance on the Designation of Severe Disasters and Measures to be Applied to Disasters Caused by Storms and Heavy Rain from October 6 to October 9, 2006 (Ordinance No. 53 of 2007)" [5][10].

Due to the stormy weather accompanying this low-pressure system, maritime accidents occurred frequently on the Pacific side of Honshu, resulting in 33 casualties (19 deaths and 14 missing) solely from maritime incidents. Particularly on October 6, two major maritime accidents occurred within just one day, making it an extremely unusual large-scale disaster. The main maritime accidents that occurred consecutively during this period are as follows (all designated as "major maritime incidents").

Due to the stormy weather, not only maritime accidents but also mountain accidents occurred frequently. On October 7, at Mount Shirouma in Nagano Prefecture, a climbing party of seven was caught in a blizzard, resulting in four deaths. This "Mount Shirouma Accident" later escalated into a lawsuit. Additionally, casualties from fatigue and frostbite were reported at Mount Okuhotaka, Mount Ontake, and Mount Mae-Hotaka.

The major characteristic of this large-scale low-pressure disaster is that it was caused not by a typhoon itself but by an "extratropical cyclone with typhoon-like intensity." Furthermore, what is particularly noteworthy is that another low-pressure system, not a typhoon, rapidly developed under the influence of Typhoon No. 16 and Typhoon No. 17, causing a major disaster (it was not Typhoon No. 16 or No. 17 that developed). This rare phenomenon exposed the issue of its difficulty to predict.
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Deaths and missing persons: 50 people  
Injured: 57 people  
Damaged: 1,154 buildings  
Flooded: 1,206 buildings

Article_Name: Siklon Durga bahasa Indonesia, ensiklopedia bebas

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Cyclone Durga is a tropical cyclone that formed in the southwest waters of Bengkulu from April 20 to 25, 2008, in the Indian Ocean. This is the first cyclone or storm named by Indonesia and formed near the equator. Tropical Cyclone Durga is internationally known as Tropical Cyclone Rosie. Tropical Cyclone Durga formed in the Indian Ocean about 1,000 km from the city of Bengkulu, precisely at 9.2 degrees South Latitude (SL) and 95.1 degrees East Longitude (EL). The lowest air pressure was 984 mbar with wind speeds reaching 95 km/h and rainfall between 20 and 40 millimeters. Tropical Cyclone Durga had a probability direction from East to West with an average movement speed of 25 knots. The power of Tropical Cyclone Durga affected the weather around the waters of Bengkulu, Banten, Lampung, and West Java.

BMKG has only had the authority to name tropical cyclones in Indonesia since 2008 when the Tropical Cyclone Warning Center (TCWC) was established in Jakarta, and Durga is a new name created by BMKG. The name is taken from a wayang character in Java. In addition, the character Durga is also a cultural figure in other countries.

Whole_Text.header: Typhoon No. 21 of the Heisei 24 era
Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 21 of 2012 (Typhoon Prapiroon) was a typhoon that formed on October 7, 2012. The Asian name "Prapiroon" is derived from the rain god of the Kingdom of Thailand. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) named it "Nina."

Formation began on October 3, and at 9:00 PM on October 7, it developed from a tropical depression into a typhoon at 17°50'N, 136°35'E east of the Philippines. The typhoon slowly moved northwest while intensifying, becoming a very strong typhoon, and changed its course to the northeast over the Philippine Sea on the 12th. On the 14th, Minami-Daitō Island entered the strong wind area, and on the 15th, Okinawa Island also entered the strong wind area. However, from the 15th to the 16th, it remained almost stationary about 330–380 km south of Minami-Daitō Island, near 22°N, 131°E. On the 16th, it began moving westward again, and on the 17th, it changed its course to the north-northwest and then north, exhibiting complex movements over the sea south of Okinawa. Subsequently, the typhoon shifted its course to the northeast, weakening to a central pressure of 985 hPa, a maximum wind speed of 25 meters per second, and a maximum instantaneous wind speed of 35 meters per second by 9:00 AM on the 18th, with the storm area dissipating. It moved northeast over the sea south of the Japanese archipelago and became an extratropical cyclone over the Pacific Ocean at 9:00 PM on the 19th.

In the Okinawa region, high waves caused by the stagnation of a typhoon have persisted, and the "25th Izena 88 Triathlon" scheduled for the 21st was canceled. Additionally, on Yoronjima Island in Kagoshima Prefecture, a tanker was unable to enter the port due to high waves, leading to a gasoline shortage on the island on the 15th. On the 17th, approximately 90 ferry services, including all routes connecting Okinawa's main island and surrounding remote islands, were canceled, and some flights were also canceled. In Ainan Town, Ehime Prefecture, one person died due to a lightning strike.
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Whole_Text.content: Data on typhoons in 2011 (tropical cyclones that occurred in the northwestern Pacific). The number of typhoons that formed was 21, the fourth lowest on record since statistics began in 1951, and the number of typhoons that formed after October was two, the lowest ever recorded [1]. One reason for the low number of typhoons after October was the less active convective activity over the seas east of the Philippines compared to usual [1]. Due to the low number of typhoons, the number of typhoons that approached Japan was nine, below the average, but the number of landfalling typhoons was three, which was about average [1]. Typhoon No. 6, which made landfall in Shikoku in July, was designated as a locally severe disaster, and Typhoon No. 12, which made landfall in September, caused extensive damage, particularly in the Kii Peninsula. Additionally, Typhoon No. 15, which made landfall in Shizuoka Prefecture in September, traversed eastern Japan and also affected the Tokyo metropolitan area.

Whole_Text.header: The active periods of each tropical cyclone

Whole_Text.content: On May 6 at 9 PM, a tropical depression formed east of the Philippines at 11.9°N, 128.2°E, and was analyzed as a typhoon the following day at 9 PM, being named "Aere" in Asia. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) named this typhoon "Bebeng." The typhoon made landfall on Luzon Island on the 9th, causing agricultural losses equivalent to 2.7 million USD. On the 10th, it moved away from the Philippines, heading northeast toward Japan, and transitioned into a tropical depression southeast of Kyushu at 3 AM on the 12th. By 3 AM the next day, it became an extratropical cyclone over the sea east of Kanto, developing further as it moved toward the Aleutian Islands. This typhoon caused 35 deaths, 2 missing persons, and 1.37 billion Philippine pesos in damages in the Philippines, and also resulted in 4 fatalities in Japan.

On May 20 at 3:00 AM, a tropical depression formed in the Caroline Islands at 8°18'N, 141°36'E, and developed into a typhoon by 9:00 PM the following day, being named "Songda" by the Asian naming system. The name was provided by Vietnam, derived from the name of a river in the northwest of the country. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named the typhoon "Chedeng." The typhoon intensified into a very strong system by May 25 as it moved westward toward the Philippines, reaching a violent intensity on May 26-27. It then weakened while moving along the Southwest Islands by May 29, bringing strong winds and heavy rain to the region. Although it was on the verge of making landfall at 3:00 PM on May 29, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone off the coast of Shikoku and subsequently moved eastward along the southern coast of Honshu, dissipating at 3:00 PM on June 2. In Okinawa Prefecture, 58 people were injured due to the typhoon, and insurance payouts exceeded 2 billion yen, making it the fourth-largest in history. In Ehime Prefecture, one person died as a result of the typhoon.

On June 9 at 3:00 AM, a tropical depression formed in the western Philippines at 14°18'N, 120°18'E, and developed into a typhoon by 9:00 PM on the same day, being named "Sarika" by the Asian naming system. The name, provided by Cambodia, means "singing bird." Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named the typhoon "Dodong." The typhoon subsequently moved northward to China, making landfall in Shantou City at 9:00 AM on the 11th, weakening into a tropical depression by 3:00 PM, and dissipating by 9:00 PM the same day. The typhoon caused 23 deaths, 10 missing persons, and damages amounting to $248 million in China.

On June 17 at 3:00 AM, a tropical depression formed east of the Philippines (latitude 9°28'N, longitude 129°11'E) and developed into a typhoon in the South China Sea (latitude 18°30'N, longitude 114°48'E) at 9:00 PM on the 21st, more than four and a half days after its formation. It was named "Haima" by the Asian naming system. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Egay." The typhoon made landfall in Guangdong Province at around 11:10 AM on the 23rd and made a second landfall in Wuchuan City, Guangdong Province, at 5:50 PM on the same day. It then weakened into a tropical depression in Vietnam at 3:00 AM on the 25th and dissipated on the 26th. Due to this typhoon, northern Vietnam, including Hai Phong City, experienced 9 deaths or missing persons and nearly 300 injuries.

On June 21 at 3:00 AM, a tropical depression formed east of the Philippines (latitude 11°N, longitude 133°24'E) and developed into a typhoon at 9:00 AM on June 22, being named "Meari" in Asia. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Falcon." By 9:00 PM on June 22, it became a large typhoon, moving northward toward the Sakishima Islands by the 25th, approaching with a peak pressure of 975 hPa. As a result, one person was injured in Okinawa Prefecture, and agricultural damage, mainly to sugarcane, amounted to 118.53 million yen. After passing through the Sakishima Islands, it continued northward toward the Korean Peninsula, becoming an extratropical cyclone in the waters near North Korea at 3:00 PM on the 27th and dissipating by 9:00 PM the same day. In South Korea, there were nine fatalities and three missing persons, while in North Korea, there were also fatalities, but detailed information was not disclosed.

On July 11 at 9:00 PM, a tropical depression formed near Wake Island (latitude 18°30'N, longitude 157°18'E) and was named "Ma-on" as it became a typhoon at 9:00 AM on July 12. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Ineng." The typhoon developed while moving eastward, becoming large at 9:00 PM on the 13th, a strong large typhoon at 9:00 AM on the 14th, and an extremely large and very strong typhoon at 9:00 PM on the 15th. It then moved northwest, heading toward Shikoku, and made landfall in southern Tokushima Prefecture at 11:00 PM on the 19th while maintaining its large and strong intensity. After passing Cape Shionomisaki in Wakayama Prefecture before 10:00 AM on the 20th, it moved southward and then northward again, becoming an extratropical cyclone off the Sanriku coast at 3:00 PM on the 24th and dissipating on the 31st. Additionally, as noted in the section on Typhoon No. 7, the Fujiwhara effect occurred between this typhoon and Typhoon No. 7. This typhoon caused damage, resulting in two fatalities in Mie and Kochi Prefectures and one person missing in Nara Prefecture. On August 12, the Cabinet designated the disaster caused by the storm from July 17 to July 20 in areas such as Aki City, Kochi Prefecture, as a localized severe disaster.

201107・09W・Hanna  
The tropical depression (09W) that formed over the eastern seas of the Philippines initially moved slowly westward and was upgraded to a typhoon at noon on July 15, [25] and was named "Tokage" as its Asian name. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Hanna" as its Philippine name. However, this typhoon changed its course eastward as it was drawn in by the approaching Typhoon No. 6 shortly thereafter and was absorbed and assimilated into Typhoon No. 6. This movement is believed to be due to the Fujiwhara effect, where the weaker Typhoon No. 7 was incorporated into the stronger Typhoon No. 6.

On July 25 at 3:00 AM, a tropical depression formed east of the Philippines (latitude 12°41'N, longitude 128°6'E) and became a typhoon at 9:00 AM on the 26th, receiving the Asian name "Nock-ten." The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) named this typhoon "Juaning." The typhoon made landfall on Luzon Island in the Philippines on the 27th, exited at 9:00 PM the same day, passed through Hainan Province on the 29th, and made landfall again in Vietnam on the 30th. It then became a tropical depression near the Thailand-Laos border at 9:00 AM on the 31st and dissipated at 3:00 PM the same day. In the Philippines, 75 people died due to this typhoon, and the total death toll, including Vietnam and other affected areas, exceeded 100.

On July 27 at 9:00, a tropical depression formed in the Caroline Islands at 10°N, 142°E, and by 15:00 on the 28th, it developed into a typhoon and was named "Muifa" by Asia. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Kabayan." The typhoon gradually moved northward toward the Okinawa region at a slow pace while intensifying, becoming a strong typhoon at 9:00 on the 30th, a very strong typhoon at 21:00 on the same day, and a large and very strong typhoon by August 3. It came closest to the Okinawa region between August 5 and 6. Subsequently, the typhoon continued to move northward while weakening, coming closest to the Korean Peninsula by the 9th. By 9:00 on the 9th, it had become a tropical depression in China and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone by 21:00 on the same day.  

In Okinawa Prefecture, the slow movement of the typhoon prolonged its impact, resulting in 42 injuries, including 8 serious cases, and agricultural damages amounting to 662.73 million yen. In South Korea, 4 people died, and in North Korea, over 100 buildings were destroyed, with more than 10 fatalities and injuries reported. Additionally, 4 people died in the Philippines.

On August 3 at 3:00, a tropical depression formed near Wake Island (latitude 23°12'N, longitude 163°E) and developed into a typhoon by 15:00 on the same day, being named "Merbok" as its Asian name. The typhoon moved westward at a slow pace, with its pressure dropping to 980 hPa, but later changed direction to the north. Due to gradually decreasing sea surface temperatures, it weakened and began to take on the characteristics of an extratropical cyclone, becoming an extratropical cyclone by 3:00 on the 10th and dissipating by 15:00 on the 12th.

On August 21 at 9:00 PM, a tropical depression formed in the northern sea area of Palau (latitude 12°24'N, longitude 128°36'E) and developed into a typhoon at 9:00 PM on the 23rd, being named "Nanmado" (Nammadol) as its Asian name. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Mina." It rapidly intensified between the 25th and 26th, becoming a strong typhoon at 9:00 AM on the 25th and a very strong typhoon at 3:00 AM on the 26th. It passed through northern Philippines on the 27th, made landfall in Taitung County, Taiwan, on the 29th, and weakened into a tropical depression by 9:00 AM on the 31st, dissipating on September 1. Due to this typhoon, two fishermen went missing in the Philippines.

On August 24 at 3:00 AM, a tropical depression formed west of the Mariana Islands (latitude 15°12'N, longitude 142°42'E) and developed into a typhoon by 9:00 AM on the 25th, being named "Talas" by its Asian designation. At this time, it had already become a large typhoon. The typhoon moved northward, intensifying as it approached Japan, and made landfall in eastern Kochi Prefecture at 10:00 AM on September 3 while maintaining its large size. It made a second landfall in southern Okayama Prefecture at 6:00 PM the same day. After making landfall and moving out to sea, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone in the central Sea of Japan at 3:00 PM on the 5th and dissipated on the 7th.

Due to the typhoon's slow movement, the effects of heavy rain persisted, with total precipitation exceeding 1,800 millimeters in Kamikitayama Village, Nara Prefecture. In Mie and Wakayama Prefectures, rainfall exceeded 1,000 millimeters in some areas, breaking historical records at many observation points. Flooding occurred in three rivers, including the Sasagase River and Ashimori River, and agricultural damages exceeded 145.3 billion yen. 

This typhoon, which caused significant landslides and flooding, was designated as a severe disaster due to the storm and heavy rain from August 29 to September 7, 2011. The disaster resulted in 83 deaths, 15 missing persons, and over 22,000 flooded homes.

On September 2 at 9:00, a tropical depression formed near Minamitorishima (21°18'N, 149°48'E) [39], and it developed into a typhoon at 21:00 on the 3rd, being named "Noru" by its Asian designation [39]. The typhoon moved northward far east of Japan, gradually taking on the characteristics of an extratropical cyclone, and without causing significant impact as a typhoon, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone far east of Japan at 21:00 on the 6th [39]. After becoming an extratropical cyclone, it moved northwest toward Sakhalin and exited the Japan Meteorological Agency's monitoring area [39].

On September 6 at 3:00 PM, a tropical depression formed over the eastern seas of the Philippines (latitude 19°30'N, longitude 134°34'E) and was upgraded to a typhoon over the southern seas of Japan at 9:00 AM on September 7, receiving the Asian name "Kulap." Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Nonoy." However, even as a typhoon, it did not develop significantly, with a minimum pressure of 1000 hPa, and weakened into a tropical depression near the Tokara Islands by 9:00 AM on September 9. By 3:00 PM on September 11, the tropical depression became part of the autumn rain front over the Korean Peninsula and disappeared from weather maps.  

Due to the typhoon, Orita Shipping canceled its service connecting Kagoshima City and Yakushima on September 9, and Toshima Village in Kagoshima Prefecture postponed its service connecting Kagoshima City and Amami Oshima to the following day. In Wakayama and Nara Prefectures, which had suffered extensive damage from the previous Typhoon No. 12, the moist air from this typhoon caused atmospheric instability again, raising concerns about the potential collapse of natural dam lakes. In Nishihara Town, Okinawa Prefecture, unexploded ordnance disposal work was suspended on September 11 due to the approaching typhoon.

On September 9 at 9:00 PM, a tropical depression formed in the Mariana Islands (latitude 20°24'N, longitude 144°42'E), and 90 hours later, at 3:00 PM on the 13th, it was upgraded to a typhoon and named "Roke" as its Asian name. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Onyok." After becoming a typhoon, it moved eastward until the 15th and then circled around the Daitojima region until the 19th. At 6:00 PM on the 19th, it became a large typhoon, developed into a large and strong typhoon by 9:00 PM the same day, and further intensified into a large and very strong typhoon by 9:00 PM on the 20th. Although the pressure increased as it approached land, it maintained a large and strong intensity with a pressure of 950 hPa even when it made landfall near Hamamatsu City, Shizuoka Prefecture, at 2:00 PM on the 21st. This intensity was the strongest for a typhoon making landfall and passing through eastern Japan since Typhoon No. 22 in 2004. The typhoon then moved northeast, exited into the Pacific Ocean in the early hours of the 22nd, and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone off the Kuril Islands at 3:00 PM the same day. In Kyushu and Shikoku, including Miyazaki Prefecture, total rainfall exceeded 1,000 millimeters in some areas, and due to maintaining a pressure of 950 hPa at landfall, extremely strong winds were observed in places such as Edogawa Ward, Tokyo. At a Cabinet meeting on October 14, the disaster caused by the storm and heavy rain from September 15 to September 23, 2011, was designated as a severe disaster. This typhoon caused 18 deaths, 1 missing person, and over 7,800 flooded houses, making it the third-largest disaster caused by a typhoon in 2011, following Typhoon No. 21 and Typhoon No. 12.

On September 14 at 9:00 PM, a tropical depression formed near Wake Island (20°36'N, 154°24'E) [49], and it developed into a typhoon at 3:00 PM on the 15th, being named "Sonca" [49]. Although the typhoon approached the Ogasawara Islands, it did not cause significant damage, moved along the edge of the Pacific high-pressure system, transitioned into an extratropical cyclone at 9:00 PM on the 20th, and exited the Japan Meteorological Agency's monitoring area on the 21st [49].

On September 23 at 9:00 AM, a tropical depression formed in the northern part of the Palau Islands (latitude 12°36'N, longitude 139°12'E) and developed into a typhoon by 9:00 AM on the 24th, being named "Nesat" as its Asian name. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Pedring" as its Philippine name. The typhoon intensified as it moved toward the Philippines, becoming a strong typhoon by 9:00 AM on the 26th and a large and strong typhoon by 3:00 AM on the 27th. Early on the 27th, it made landfall on Luzon Island while maintaining its large and strong intensity, crossed Hainan Province in the early afternoon of the 29th while still strong, made landfall in Vietnam in the early afternoon of the 30th, weakened into a tropical depression by 3:00 AM on October 1, and dissipated by 9:00 AM on the same day. In the Philippines, at least 35 people were killed and 45 went missing due to this typhoon.

201118・21W・Haitang  
A tropical depression formed in the South China Sea near the Paracel Islands (15°48'N, 110°54'E) at 9 a.m. on September 24 [52], and developed into a typhoon by 9 a.m. on the 25th, being named "Haitang" by Asia [52]. It became a tropical depression just before making landfall in Vietnam at 3 a.m. on the 27th, and subsequently made landfall in Thua Thien-Hue Province, dissipating within a few hours [52].

On September 26 at 9:00 PM, a tropical depression formed east of the Philippines (latitude 18°18'N, longitude 139°36'E) and developed into a typhoon by 3:00 AM on the 28th, being named "Nalgae" as its Asian name. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Quiel" as its Philippine name. It moved westward toward the Philippines while intensifying, becoming a strong typhoon by 3:00 PM on the 29th and a very strong typhoon by 3:00 PM on the 30th. It made landfall on Luzon Island before noon on October 1 with very strong intensity, crossed Hainan Province on the 4th, and became a tropical depression by 3:00 AM on the 5th, dissipating by 3:00 AM on the 6th.

On October 9 at 3:00 PM, a tropical depression formed in the Palau Islands (8°5'N, 135°30'E) and developed into a typhoon by 3:00 AM on October 11, being named "Banyan" as its Asian name. Additionally, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration named this typhoon "Ramon" as its Philippine name. However, even as a typhoon, it did not intensify much, with a minimum pressure of 1002 hPa, and reverted to a tropical depression 12 hours later at 3:00 PM on October 11. The tropical depression then crossed the central Philippine islands and dissipated in the South China Sea at 9:00 PM on October 14. This marks the third typhoon in a year with a minimum pressure of 1000 hPa or higher, a phenomenon occurring for the first time in 23 years since 1988.

On December 13, a tropical depression formed in the Caroline Islands (6°12'N, 145°E) and developed into a typhoon at 3:00 PM on the 15th, being named "Washi" by the Asian naming system. The naming country was Japan, and it means "Aquila" (Eagle). Meanwhile, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) named this typhoon "Sendong." The typhoon moved westward and made landfall near Hinatuan, northeastern Mindanao, Philippines, at 4:00 PM on the 16th, shortly after being upgraded to a typhoon. It entered Malaybalay City, Bukidnon, in central Mindanao around 10:00 PM the same day and crossed the island until early morning on the 17th. It exited into the Sulu Sea and made landfall again on Palawan Island at 4:00 AM on the 18th. Subsequently, it weakened into a tropical depression in the South China Sea near the Spratly Islands at 9:00 AM on the 19th and dissipated by 3:00 PM the same day.

The order starts with the Asian name "Damrey" as number 1 [59]. Additionally, the Philippine name is given when a tropical depression enters the monitoring area of the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA).

Whole_Text.header: A tropical depression not classified as a "typhoon" by the Japan Meteorological Agency.
Whole_Text.content: If there is no tropical depression number, those with a low-pressure number in the pre-tropical depression stage are also listed. Additionally, the Japan Meteorological Agency assigns an alphabet, such as "Tropical Depression a," to tropical depressions expected to develop into typhoons.

On January 18, the Aleutian low developed into an extratropical cyclone with a pressure of 932 hPa, resulting in a strong winter pressure pattern and heavy snowfall, including some areas on the Pacific side. On February 24, a low-pressure area formed over the southeastern seas of the Philippines and developed to 1004 hPa, but it did not become the first tropical cyclone of the year. After the new year, from January 13 to 14, 2012, 91W developed into a tropical cyclone, effectively becoming the last tropical cyclone of the 2011 typhoon season.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴玫瑰 (2011年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Kulap (English: Tropical Storm Kulap, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP172011, International Number: 1114, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Nonoy) was the 14th named storm of the 2011 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Kulap" was provided by Thailand and means rose.

On September 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded this tropical cyclone to a tropical storm, assigned it the number 1114, and named it Rose. On the same day at 7 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 8, this tropical storm experienced a slight Fujiwhara effect with tropical disturbances 91W and 92W. On the morning of September 9 at 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. On September 10 at 8:35 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued its final report. At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final report.
