Whole_Text.content: The Ashio Typhoon is a typhoon that passed through Chiba Prefecture, Niigata Prefecture, and northern Hokkaido on September 28, 1902 (Meiji 35), causing damage mainly from the Kanto region to the southern Tohoku region.

The name "Ashio Typhoon" is unofficial and not determined by the Japan Meteorological Agency (formerly the Central Meteorological Observatory before 1956) like "Isewan Typhoon" or "Second Muroto Typhoon." Due to the severe damage caused by Typhoon No. 22 in 1958 in the Kano River basin, the Japan Meteorological Agency officially named it "Kano River Typhoon." At the same time, Typhoon No. 15 in 1954, which caused the sinking of the Seikan ferry Toya Maru in Hakodate Port and resulted in many casualties, was retroactively named "Toya Maru Typhoon." This marked the beginning of official unique names for typhoons. Therefore, earlier typhoons like "Ashio Typhoon," as well as "Muroto Typhoon" and "Makurazaki Typhoon," are not official names but rather common names. At the time, the term "typhoon" itself was not in use, and the name "Ashio Typhoon" was later given due to the extensive damage in the Ashio area of Tochigi Prefecture. It is unclear when the name "Ashio Typhoon" began to be used. In the 1992 publication "Bofu Taifu Bikkuri Kojiten" (Kodansha Bluebacks, Moriya Shimada), although the damage and observation data of this typhoon are explained in detail, the name "Ashio Typhoon" does not appear. Even before that, prominent meteorologists like Tohei Otani mentioned this typhoon, but they did not use a specific name. It is believed that the name became widely recognized in the early 21st century or, at the earliest, the late 20th century. However, it is possible that it had been used locally or within limited areas for a long time. [1]

The timing and location of the occurrence are unclear. At that time, wireless communication had only recently been put into practical use, and only a few ships were equipped with it. Consequently, the maritime weather observation network was extremely weak, and particularly in the southeastern seas of Japan, there were few ships navigating, making it difficult to obtain meteorological data. Furthermore, small-scale typhoons like this one were hard to detect and typically did not appear on observation networks until just before landfall. The first confirmation of its existence was at dawn on September 28, northeast of Hachijojima. According to the Central Meteorological Observatory's "Meteorological Handbook," the subsequent path was as follows (all times are in Japan Standard Time).
Tateyama: 717.1 mmHg (955.8 hPa)

According to records at the time, the maximum wind speed in Choshi was 64m, and in Mount Tsukuba, it was 103m. However, investigations revealed that the anemometers used at that time produced exaggerated values, and it was decided that observation values before 1924 would be uniformly multiplied by 0.7, with the resulting figures being adopted as the official record. The wind speeds mentioned above are the corrected values.

At that time, apart from this typhoon, another typhoon formed east of Luzon Island in the Philippines on September 21, moving at about 10 km/h and heading northward far southeast of the Ryukyu Islands by September 26. Then, on September 28, after the Ashio Typhoon traversed the eastern Japan region and exited into the Sea of Japan, its center made landfall east of Cape Shionomisaki at 3 PM. It crossed west of Daiosaki, near Hikone, east of Fukui, and west of Kanazawa, passing through the Noto Peninsula, and by 11 PM, it exited north of Sado Island. On the morning weather map of September 28, the two typhoons were almost aligned side by side, and the Ashio Typhoon on the eastern side reached a traveling speed of 60 to 80 km/h while passing through Honshu, which was quite fast. It is believed that this high speed significantly contributed to the intense winds experienced in areas east of the typhoon's path, including Mount Tsukuba. It is thought that the "Fujiwhara effect" between the two typhoons caused the Ashio Typhoon to accelerate. This is considered the oldest recorded case of the Fujiwhara effect observed in typhoons. There are several types of Fujiwhara effects, but when two typhoons align east-west and move northward, their vortices can interfere with each other, causing the eastern typhoon to accelerate and move rapidly while the western typhoon slows down. Similar cases have occasionally been observed since then.

The Ashio Typhoon was a small-scale typhoon with a compact storm area, but its central pressure was low, causing particularly severe wind damage from violent winds and water damage from storm surges. Flooding from heavy rain also occurred. The wind and water damage extended to Chiba Prefecture, Ibaraki Prefecture, Gunma Prefecture, Fukushima Prefecture, Yamagata Prefecture, and other areas, reportedly resulting in casualties, destruction of houses, train derailments, chimney collapses, and the toppling of giant trees.

At Sagami Bay, high tide occurred, causing a storm surge. Additionally, in Yokohama Port, the German mail ship "Preussen," which was docked at the pier, was swept away by strong winds and ran aground in shallow waters, while the steamship "Curley" also ran aground on the breakwater. It is reported that other small steamships and a temporary customs construction vessel sank.

219 people were dead or missing, approximately 8,200 houses were completely destroyed or washed away, and 315 millimeters of rainfall were recorded in Ashio. The Watarase River flooded, and the significant damage in Ashio later became the basis for the typhoon's name. In Ashio Town, the Mikonai Elementary School was washed away, among other damages. Additionally, a debris flow occurred in Nikko Chugushi. The sediment that flowed into Lake Chuzenji caused 3-meter-high waves, resulting in casualties at inns and other locations. These waves flowed over Kegon Falls into the Daiya River, washing away the Shinkyo and Otani bridges. The "Narabi Jizo" statues at Kanmangafuchi were also washed away. It is said that the appearance of Urami Falls changed due to this typhoon. Currently, the Registered Tangible Cultural Property "Moka High School Memorial Hall" at Tochigi Prefectural Moka High School is a building reconstructed the following year after the school building was damaged by this typhoon.
118 dead or missing persons and 20,164 houses completely destroyed or washed away were recorded.

Whole_Text.header: Typhoon No. 1 of the Heisei 22nd year
Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 1 of 2010 (Heisei 22, Asian name: Omais [named by the United States, meaning: wandering]) was a typhoon that formed on March 24, 2010, at 9:00 PM and dissipated on March 26, 2010, at 9:00 AM.

The first typhoon that occurred in 2010. It can be said to be almost average, as it formed in late March. At 9 PM on March 22, a tropical depression formed in the Caroline Islands. It gradually developed while moving northwest, and at 9 PM on March 24, it became a typhoon over the sea east of the Philippines. Afterward, it did not develop further, moved north, and turned into a tropical depression over the sea east of the Philippines at 9 AM on March 26.

Article_Name: 颱風愛麗斯 (1961年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Alice (International designation: 6103, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 05W) was the 6th named tropical cyclone of the 1961 Pacific typhoon season and one of the few tropical cyclones to pass directly over the Royal Hong Kong Observatory headquarters, necessitating the issuance of the No. 10 Hurricane Signal. Alice formed on May 16, 1961, moved through the central and northern South China Sea, and passed over Hong Kong on May 19, causing damage. Two days later, it entered the East China Sea and weakened into dissipation. Additionally, the time taken for the Observatory to issue signals from No. 1 to No. 10 was only 16 hours and 35 minutes, the shortest in history. The No. 10 Hurricane Signal issued due to Alice lasted only 2 hours and 30 minutes, making it the shortest duration for a No. 10 signal in Hong Kong's recorded history. It is also the only tropical cyclone requiring the issuance of a No. 10 signal in May, a record that remains unbroken. Based on measured wind speeds, as no hurricane-force winds were recorded within Hong Kong [1], the No. 10 signal was considered not fully justified for Hong Kong, as the intensity near Hong Kong did not reach typhoon level but was only at the severe tropical storm level.

A low-pressure area crossed the southern Philippines on May 13 and entered the South China Sea the following day. Two days later, the low-pressure area intensified into a tropical depression over the central South China Sea, near latitude 14.5°N and longitude 115°E, and moved northwestward. After several days of further intensification, it strengthened into a typhoon on May 18 and was named Alice. Subsequently, Alice turned northeastward, passing over the northern South China Sea, and made landfall in Hong Kong on May 19. After landfall, it immediately moved northeastward and weakened over eastern Guangdong. Two days later, it entered the East China Sea from the coast of Zhejiang Province and gradually dissipated.

The Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 signal at 4:00 PM on May 18 during daylight saving time, as Alice was located approximately 220 miles (about 354 kilometers) south of Hong Kong, moving northward at a speed of 10 knots (about 18.5 kilometers per hour). At 6:40 PM the same day, the Observatory replaced it with the No. 3 signal. As Alice approached Hong Kong, the Observatory upgraded to the No. 7 signal at 5:50 AM on May 19, followed by the No. 9 signal at 8:35 AM. By 9:00 AM, the Observatory recorded gusts of 69 knots (about 128 kilometers per hour). Based on radar observations, the Observatory anticipated that Alice's eye would pass over Hong Kong around 1:00 PM and decided to hoist the No. 10 signal at 10:30 AM, which lasted for 2 hours and 30 minutes, making it the shortest duration for a No. 10 signal caused by a tropical cyclone in Hong Kong's post-World War II records. According to measured wind speeds, as no hurricane-force winds were recorded within Hong Kong, the No. 10 signal was considered substandard for Hong Kong, with Alice's intensity near Hong Kong not reaching typhoon level but only a severe tropical storm level. Its center began passing through the urban areas of Hong Kong and Kowloon, as well as the Observatory headquarters, around noon that day, with the lowest average sea-level pressure recorded at 981.8 hPa. Initially, the area experienced easterly winds, with the highest sustained wind speed recorded at about 43 knots (about 80 kilometers per hour) and the highest gust at 89 knots (about 165 kilometers per hour). Calm winds were observed for about 16 minutes starting at 1:04 PM. As the eye passed, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 6 signal at 1:00 PM, indicating a shift to strong southwesterly winds. At 4:00 PM, the Observatory recorded sustained winds of about 42 knots (about 78 kilometers per hour) and gusts of 74 knots (about 137 kilometers per hour). As Alice moved away from Hong Kong, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 signal at 7:30 PM and removed all signals by 2:00 AM the following day, with a total signal duration of only 34 hours. According to post-event statistics from the Royal Hong Kong Observatory, five people died, and 20 were injured during Alice's impact on Hong Kong. Additionally, ten vessels were damaged, including one ocean-going ship and nine fishing boats. The urban areas were also affected by the storm, with the Man Wah Village in Ho Man Tin, Kowloon, being particularly severely impacted, where at least six village houses collapsed.

Alice was closest to Macau during the period from May 18 to 19. According to data provided by the Macau Meteorological Bureau, as Alice approached Hong Kong on May 19, strong winds also began to blow in Macau. The Macau Meteorological Bureau recorded an average wind speed of 35 kilometers per hour for the entire day and an average sea-level pressure of 995.7 hPa on that day. Alice's circulation also brought rainfall to Macau, with 55.8 millimeters of rainfall recorded in Macau from May 17 to 20. Below is the data provided by the Macau Meteorological Bureau (May 17-20, 1961):
After Alice made landfall, it struck mainland China, bringing heavy rain to the area, but no records of its impact on the region were noted.

Article_Name: 태풍 다나스 (2013년) - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Danas (DANAS) was active from October 4 to October 9, 2013, and was the 24th typhoon of 2013, recording a minimum pressure of 935 hPa. It affected Japan and South Korea. Danas is a name submitted by the Philippines, meaning "experience."

Typhoon Danas, the 24th typhoon, formed as a small tropical storm with a central pressure of 1000 hPa, maximum wind speed of 18 m/s, and a gale radius of 220 km (northeast radius) at 3 PM on October 4, approximately 360 km north-northeast of Guam, USA (based on Japan Meteorological Agency typhoon information). After formation, it moved northwest and rapidly intensified, reaching its peak at 9 AM on October 7 as a typhoon with a central pressure of 935 hPa, maximum wind speed of 51 m/s, and a gale radius of 440 km (northeast radius), classified as "very strong" and "medium-sized" (based on Japan Meteorological Agency typhoon information), approximately 270 km southeast of Okinawa, Japan. After passing through Okinawa at its peak strength, it weakened rapidly as it crossed the 30-degree north latitude line and approached Jeju Island at 3 PM on October 8, approximately 110 km southeast of Seogwipo, Jeju, with a central pressure of 970 hPa, maximum wind speed of 33 m/s, and a gale radius of 280 km (northeast radius) (based on Japan Meteorological Agency typhoon information), changing its course to move northeast. After changing course, it approached Busan at 9 PM on October 8, approximately 80 km south-southeast of Busan on land (Tsushima, Japan), with a central pressure of 980 hPa, maximum wind speed of 28 m/s, and a gale radius of 280 km (northeast radius) (based on Japan Meteorological Agency typhoon information). After passing through the Korea Strait and Tsushima, Japan, it moved into the East Sea, where extratropical transition accelerated. By 9 AM on October 9, it had transformed into an extratropical cyclone with a central pressure of 992 hPa approximately 240 km east of Dokdo (based on Korea Meteorological Administration typhoon information, central pressure was 994 hPa).

On October 8, Typhoon Danas caused slight wind damage in the southern regions, quickly passed through the Korea Strait, and dissipated over the East Sea on October 9. Overall damage was minimal, and it is said to have helped alleviate drought in Pohang City. There were no direct casualties from the typhoon, but a district office employee, who was seriously injured by a falling tree during recovery work, passed away a month later. The total damage amounted to $228,000.
Typhoon Namtheun was a typhoon in 2010 in the Pacific, with a central maximum wind speed of 95 km/h.

Article_Name: 颱風薇拉 (1977年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Vera (International designation: 7705, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 07W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Hulang) was a tropical cyclone during the 1977 Pacific typhoon season. Vera formed north of 25 degrees latitude, which is rare for a system to develop there and intensify into a severe typhoon as classified by the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan, or a super typhoon as classified by the China Meteorological Administration after 2006 (with maximum sustained wind speeds reaching 51 m/s). Additionally, Vera rapidly intensified from a tropical depression to a severe typhoon within just 48 hours. Its circulation area was extremely small (equivalent to half the size of Taiwan), its rapid development, and its V-shaped trajectory were also considered unusual.

On the morning of July 26, 1977, at 8:00 AM, a tropical disturbance, the precursor to Vera, was observed via satellite imagery, with its center located at 25.5°N latitude and 133.6°E longitude. Over the next 24 hours, the disturbance moved westward and continued to intensify. At 1:00 PM the following afternoon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for the system. By 8:00 AM on July 28, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 07W. Shortly thereafter, the tropical depression was upgraded to a tropical storm and named Vera. Due to the influence of the subtropical high-pressure system east of Honshu, Japan, and the constraint of a tropical depression to the southeast, Vera subsequently moved west-southwest. At 9:30 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a sea typhoon warning for Vera. By 2:00 PM on July 29, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded Vera to a moderate typhoon, and an hour later, issued a land typhoon warning for northeastern and northern Taiwan. At noon on the same day, the high-pressure system began extending southwestward toward Vera's leading edge, causing Vera to shift to a southwestward trajectory. Vera gradually intensified, and by 2:00 PM on July 30, its central wind speed had increased to 100 knots (equivalent to 52 meters per second), making it a severe typhoon under the standards of the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan. That evening at 8:00 PM, satellite data indicated that Vera began shifting to a west-northwest trajectory. Shortly thereafter, its center passed near Japan's Iriomote and Ishigaki Islands. By 8:00 AM on July 31, Vera reached its peak intensity, with a central wind speed of 110 knots (equivalent to 57 meters per second). Its intensity then gradually weakened as it approached Taiwan. At 5:30 PM on July 31, Vera made landfall in Keelung City and moved southwestward along the Keelung River Valley toward Taipei City at a speed of 11 knots (equivalent to 20 kilometers per hour). Both Keelung and Taipei recorded new maximum wind speed records under Vera's impact. After passing northeast of Taipei City, Vera continued moving almost directly westward and entered the Taiwan Strait between Taoyuan and Hsinchu at 9:30 PM that evening. By 9:00 AM on August 1, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan lifted the land typhoon warning. At 10:00 AM, Vera made landfall near the coastal waters northeast of Kinmen County in Hui'an County, Quanzhou City, Fujian Province, China. By 4:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the sea typhoon warning. At 8:00 PM, after passing through Jinjiang and Longyan, Vera weakened into a tropical depression. It then entered Jiangxi Province and dissipated in Guizhou on August 3.

After Typhoon Dama ravaged southern Taiwan with a reverse S-shaped path, Vera followed a few days later with a similarly rare V-shaped path to strike northern Taiwan. Both the south and north caused severe damage to Taiwan. In addition to record-breaking strong winds, northern Taiwan also experienced significant rainfall.

Three container cranes, each worth 40 million New Taiwan Dollars, were blown into the sea at Keelung Port; a tugboat sank at Taichung Port. Regarding land transportation, due to strong winds, communication disruptions, or roadbeds being washed away by water, all train services on various railway lines were suspended. On the highways, the Northern Cross-Island Highway, Central Cross-Island Highway, and Southern Cross-Island Highway experienced multiple landslides due to consecutive hits by Typhoon Selma and Typhoon Vera.

In northern Taiwan, 7 transmission towers collapsed, and 1,004 utility poles were blown down. Other scattered incidents included: a steel frame from an elevated road construction project at Beimen in Taipei City being blown down and crushing vehicles, and houses in the Beitou Datun Mountain area being buried due to landslides. In total, Vera caused 104 deaths, 10 missing persons, 65 injuries, 1,472 houses completely destroyed, and 6,642 houses partially destroyed in Taiwan.

Due to the strong winds and heavy rain brought by Vera, combined with the astronomical tide on June 15, the tide level was 1 to 2 meters higher than usual. Under the impact of floods and high tides, the local water disaster became more severe, and the highest tide levels at major coastal tide monitoring stations all exceeded the warning line. The affected areas in Fujian Province included 4 cities and 25 counties: Ningde, Putian, Jinjiang, and Fuzhou. A total of 27 people were killed, 17 injured, and 821 houses collapsed. Damage to water conservancy facilities reached 8,895 locations, including 1,059 dikes, 354 destroyed bridges, 428 damaged ships, and 844 cubic meters of driftwood. The affected farmland area reached 311,000 mu, including 11,000 mu of economic crops.

Article_Name: 強烈熱帶風暴珊瑚 (2005年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Sanvu (International designation: 0510, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 10W, PAGASA: Huaning) was the tenth named storm of the 2005 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Sanvu" was provided by Macau and refers to a hard substance commonly used in jewelry. Sanvu prompted the Hong Kong Observatory to issue its first tropical cyclone warning signal of 2005, which was the latest tropical cyclone warning signal ever issued in history.

Coral developed into a tropical depression approximately 990 kilometers east of Manila on August 10, initially moving west-northwest. The next day, Coral strengthened into a tropical storm, passing through Santa Ana, Cagayan, and crossing the Luzon Strait and Bashi Channel. On August 12, Coral entered the South China Sea, turning northwest in the afternoon and intensifying into a severe tropical storm that evening. By midday the following day, Coral made landfall in Fengxiang Subdistrict, Chenghai District, Shantou City, Guangdong Province. That evening, it further weakened into a tropical storm and then into a tropical depression by the early morning of August 14, eventually dissipating into a low-pressure area later that morning.

As Coral approached Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau issued a sea typhoon warning at 4:00 PM on August 11 and a land typhoon warning at 2:30 AM on August 13 when Coral entered the Taiwan Strait. Subsequently, as Coral moved away from Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the land typhoon warning at 5:30 PM that day and the sea typhoon warning at 8:30 PM that evening. Under the influence of Typhoon Coral, transportation in eastern Taiwan came to a complete halt on August 12.

Severe Tropical Storm Sanvu brought Hong Kong its latest-ever first tropical cyclone warning signal. The Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 10:40 a.m. on August 12, when Sanvu was located about 770 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. At 1 p.m. on August 13, Sanvu was closest to Hong Kong, located about 300 kilometers east-northeast of the city. The Observatory headquarters recorded a minimum sea-level pressure of 997 hectopascals at 3 p.m. the same day. As Sanvu gradually moved away from Hong Kong, all tropical cyclone warning signals were canceled at 6:45 p.m. that day. Affected by Sanvu's rainbands, the Observatory headquarters recorded over 80 millimeters of rainfall on August 13, and the Observatory issued the Amber Rainstorm Warning Signal twice between August 13 and August 14.

Severe Tropical Storm Sanvu caused the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau to hoist the second No. 1 typhoon signal of 2005. The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted the No. 1 typhoon signal at 12:30 p.m. on August 12, when Sanvu was located about 760 kilometers southeast of Macao. If Sanvu's movement path does not change significantly, there is a chance to change to the No. 3 typhoon signal in the early morning or morning of August 13. As for whether the No. 8 typhoon signal will be hoisted, it is still too early to say. At noon on August 13, Sanvu was closest to Macao, located about 380 kilometers east of Macao at that time. As Sanvu made landfall near Shantou and weakened, the Meteorological Bureau removed all signals at 6:30 p.m. on August 13.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴摩羯 (2013年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Yagi (English: Tropical Storm Yagi, International Number: 1303, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP032013, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Dante) was the third named storm of the 2013 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Yagi" was provided by Japan, referring to the Capricorn constellation (goat).

On June 5, 2013, a tropical disturbance formed over the sea east of the Philippines. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 98W. At 2 a.m. on June 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 a.m. on June 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the development probability to "MEDIUM." At 6 a.m. on June 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the development probability to "HIGH." At 6:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 10 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a strong wind warning for the sea. At 6 p.m., the Central Meteorological Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:50 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 03W. At 9:20 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Rumbia. At 5 a.m. on June 9, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 10 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 p.m. on June 10, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 p.m. on June 11, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 p.m. on June 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 12:30 a.m. on June 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center revised its report, further reducing its wind speed and issuing the final warning. At 2:50 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 a.m. on June 14, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 p.m. on June 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating.

On the afternoon of June 7 at 11:30 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded the low-pressure area that had entered its area of responsibility to a tropical depression and issued the first tropical cyclone advisory, naming it Dante. On the afternoon of June 10 at 10:30 PM, Dante exited the Philippine meteorological agency's area of responsibility, and the final tropical cyclone advisory was issued.

Article_Name: 颱風杰拉華 (2000年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Jelawat (English: Typhoon Jelawat, International Number: 0008, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 13W) was the eighth named storm of the 2000 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Jelawat" (Malay: Jelawat) was provided by Malaysia and refers to the Sultan fish, a type of freshwater carp commonly found in large rivers, known for its delicious taste and popularity among food enthusiasts.

At 18:00 UTC on July 31, a tropical depression formed over the sea south of Minamitorishima, moving westward. At 12:00 UTC on August 1, the tropical depression rapidly intensified into a tropical storm and was named Khanun. At 00:00 UTC on August 2, Khanun strengthened into a typhoon. Moving west-northwest, at 00:00 UTC on August 3, Khanun reached its peak over the northern Mariana Islands, with a very round and large eye approximately 100 kilometers in diameter and a maximum sustained wind speed of 85 knots. Khanun maintained typhoon strength while moving westward for several days and crossed the sea north of Kitadaito Island at 03:00 UTC on August 6. Then, Khanun turned northwestward. In the early hours of August 8, Khanun crossed the sea north of Okinawa, entered the East China Sea, and began to weaken. On August 10, it made landfall near Shipu Town, Xiangshan County, Ningbo City, Zhejiang Province. At 06:00 UTC, Khanun weakened into a severe tropical storm and continued to move inland. At 12:00 UTC, Khanun weakened into a tropical storm. At 18:00 UTC, Khanun weakened into a tropical depression. By 18:00 on August 12, it had completely dissipated. [1]
Gerawa crossed the northern waters of Okinawa Island on August 8, causing power outages for approximately 20,000 households in the area.
In Zhejiang, Jelawat caused minor traffic congestion and blew away some crops.

Article_Name: 颱風摩羯 (2000年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Yagi (English: Typhoon Yagi, International Number: 0019, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 29W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Paring) was the 19th named storm of the 2000 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Yagi" was provided by Japan, referring to the Capricorn constellation (goat).

At 0:00 on October 21, a tropical depression formed over the southern waters of the Mariana Islands. The tropical depression moved northwestward, and at 0:00 on October 22, it intensified into a tropical storm over the northeastern waters of Okinotorishima and was named Koguma. At 12:00 on October 23, Koguma intensified into a severe tropical storm. Koguma continued moving northwestward, and at 12:00 on October 24, it intensified into a typhoon over the southern waters of Okinawa Island. Shortly after, Koguma reached its peak with a maximum sustained wind speed of 70 knots. Koguma changed its path from northwestward to northward. At 12:00 on October 25, Koguma weakened into a severe tropical storm. From October 26 to 28, Koguma made a loop in the waters near Okinawa Island. At 12:00 on October 26, Koguma weakened into a tropical storm. At 0:00 on October 27, Koguma weakened into a tropical depression. At 12:00 on October 28, it completely dissipated. [1]

Article_Name: 颱風姬羅莉亞 (1996年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Gloria (English: Typhoon Gloria, International Number: 9608, Taiwan Number: 9607, Mainland China Number: 9607, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 09W, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Gloring) was a tropical cyclone in the 1996 Pacific typhoon season.

Typhoon Gloria formed in the northern Philippines and moved northwest. It made landfall on Taiwan's Hengchun Peninsula around 4 PM on the 26th, then continued northwest, passing through Kaohsiung, Tainan, and Taichung. It exited into the sea at the Zhuoshui River estuary at 8 PM the same day, weakened in intensity, and moved northwest toward Fujian Province, China, making landfall in Shijing Town, Nan'an City, Quanzhou. Taiwan was affected by both Typhoon Gloria's circulation and the southwest airflow, resulting in several days of heavy rain in Hualien, Taitung, and Pingtung areas. Rail, road, and air transportation in the Taitung area were disrupted. A total of three people in Taiwan died due to the typhoon.

The Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 11:30 am on July 26, when Gloria was located about 700 kilometers east of Hong Kong. Hong Kong experienced westerly winds, with sunny and very hot weather during the day. Affected by Gloria's outer rainbands, there were occasional squally showers starting from the evening. As Gloria made landfall near Xiamen early the next morning, the No. 1 Signal was canceled at 6:45 am. The unstable southwesterly winds trailing Gloria affected the coast of Guangdong, bringing cloudy and rainy weather to Hong Kong in the following one to two days. Gloria was closest to Hong Kong at 2:00 pm on July 27, located about 280 kilometers northeast of Hong Kong. The Observatory headquarters recorded a minimum instantaneous sea-level pressure of 992.8 hPa at 4:00 pm on July 26.

Article_Name: 태풍 페이 (1995년) - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Faye (Typhoon number 9503, JTWC designation number 05W, international name FAYE) made landfall on the southern coast of the Korean Peninsula on July 23, 1995, causing considerable damage. Also known as "Typhoon No. 3 of 1995," it was a typhoon characterized more by strong winds than rain, and the Sea Prince accident caused by this typhoon is well-known.

On July 13, 1995, a low-pressure circulation formed over the eastern waters of the Caroline Islands and gradually took shape while moving northwestward, passing approximately 300 km west of Guam late in the afternoon of July 15. It was soon upgraded to the fifth tropical depression by the JTWC analysis and was recognized as Typhoon No. 3, named "Faye," at 9 PM on July 17. The typhoon then changed its course to the west-northwest and advanced to about 200 km south of Naha, Okinawa Prefecture, Japan, by 9 AM on July 21. From the morning of July 22, it began to gradually turn eastward. At the time of the turn, its strength was classified as "medium" with a central pressure of 965 hPa and maximum wind speeds of 30 m/s, and its size was "medium" with a diameter of approximately 650 km. Initially, it was predicted that the typhoon would not develop significantly due to the influence of shear located to the northeast, and this prediction seemed somewhat accurate as the typhoon only developed to a "medium" strength even after more than four days since its formation. However, the typhoon began to intensify suddenly as it turned, and by 3 PM on July 22, it was upgraded to a "strong" intensity with a central pressure of 955 hPa and maximum wind speeds of 35 m/s. By 3 AM on July 23, it had become a powerful typhoon with a central pressure of 950 hPa, maximum wind speeds of 40 m/s (75 kt), and a 1-minute average maximum wind speed of 55 m/s (105 kt) according to JTWC analysis. This development occurred at a relatively high latitude of over 27 degrees north, making it even more unexpected. Eventually, after passing over the eastern waters of Jeju Island, Typhoon Faye made landfall on Namhae Island at around 4 PM on July 23 with a central pressure of 960 hPa and maximum wind speeds of 35 m/s. Due to its eastward turn after the re-curve, there was speculation that the typhoon might pass through the Korea Strait or make landfall in Japan, but it suddenly changed its course to move directly northward near 32 degrees north latitude and made landfall on the Korean Peninsula. Subsequently, it rapidly weakened while traversing the southeastern part of the Korean Peninsula at a relatively fast speed of 30–40 km/h, and by around 2 AM on July 24, it had significantly weakened to a "weak" intensity with a central pressure of 994 hPa and maximum wind speeds of 20 m/s as it exited into the East Sea through the waters off Samcheok, Gangwon Province. Later that day, at 9 PM, it weakened into a tropical depression over the northern part of the East Sea and completely dissipated near a point about 20 km northeast of Kushiro City, Hokkaido, Japan.

Whole_Text.header: Central pressure and maximum wind speed progression

Whole_Text.content: This typhoon uniquely reached its peak intensity at a high latitude exceeding 30 degrees north. Unlike most typhoons that peak between 15 and 25 degrees north and then gradually weaken, it followed a distinct development process. Although the duration of its peak intensity was not very long due to its high latitude, it made landfall on the southern coast of the Korean Peninsula with near-peak strength, as it reached the peninsula less than half a day after it began to weaken. As a typhoon of "strong" intensity, it was the first of its kind in about eight years since Typhoon Selma in 1987. Its landfall strength (central pressure of 960 hPa / maximum wind speed of 35 m/s) ranks among the strongest typhoons to make landfall on the Korean Peninsula. Notably, according to the JTWC's analysis, it made landfall with a maximum wind speed of 50 m/s (95 kt), making it one of the most powerful typhoons following Typhoon Sarah in 1959 and Typhoon Maemi in 2003. The storm brought by this powerful typhoon caused record-breaking maximum wind speeds in southern regions, such as 46.6 m/s in Tongyeong, 42.3 m/s in Busan, and 39.0 m/s in Yeosu. Additionally, winds exceeding 40 m/s were observed in areas like Tsushima and the western coast of Kyushu in Japan. The typhoon's structural characteristic of a steep pressure gradient near its center amplified the wind's strength. However, these strong winds were mainly concentrated near the typhoon's center or in the dangerous semicircle, affecting areas like eastern Jeollanam-do, Gyeongsangnam-do, and coastal regions. Other areas did not experience such strong winds. Compared to the powerful storms in the typhoon's center and dangerous semicircle, the navigable semicircle on the left side of the typhoon's path was much weaker. Furthermore, as the typhoon rapidly weakened upon making landfall, it had already lost its storm-force winds (winds exceeding 25 m/s) by the time it moved inland over the Korean Peninsula. Thus, while record-breaking maximum wind speeds of 30–50 m/s were observed along the southern coastal regions, areas in the navigable semicircle or deeper inland, such as Jeju Island, northwestern Jeolla-do, and Chungcheong-do, experienced only mild winds of about 10–20 m/s. In terms of rainfall, the typhoon was unremarkable. During its impact on the Korean Peninsula from July 23 to 24, rainfall exceeded 100 mm in some southern regions, such as Namhae and Yeosu, which recorded 218.0 mm and 143.7 mm, respectively. However, most areas received around 50 mm or less, which is below the average rainfall of past typhoons that affected the Korean Peninsula. In summary, Typhoon Fay exhibited the characteristics of a typical "wind-driven typhoon."

On the early morning of July 23, Typhoon Faye, which until the previous day had a highly uncertain path covering a wide range from the southern coast of the Korean Peninsula to Kyushu, Japan, began to take the worst possible course, making landfall on the Korean Peninsula. At 2 a.m., the Korea Meteorological Administration issued a typhoon warning for Jeju Island and the southern offshore waters, and a typhoon advisory for Busan and the southern coastal areas, gradually expanding the warnings and advisories as time passed. However, at 3 a.m. on July 23, the situation became more severe. About 12 hours before making landfall on the Korean Peninsula, the typhoon suddenly intensified, with its strength increasing from a central pressure of 955 hPa / maximum wind speed of 35 m/s classified as "strong" to a central pressure of 940 hPa / maximum wind speed of 45 m/s classified as "very strong" (currently categorized as a "very strong typhoon," but at the time classified as an "A-grade typhoon"). It reached a strength comparable to Typhoon Sarah in 1959, which is recorded as the worst typhoon to approach the Korean Peninsula since the founding of South Korea. As a result, tension heightened across the Korean Peninsula, but the typhoon weakened slightly just before making landfall and rapidly diminished after landfall, preventing the catastrophic damage that had been feared. However, the lack of awareness regarding the storm brought by the first "strong" typhoon in about eight years since Typhoon Selma led to a series of casualties due to non-compliance with safety regulations, such as a car being swept away by waves while driving along the coast, resulting in all passengers being killed or missing. The Seaprincess ship accident, caused by continuing navigation despite the typhoon warning, is a representative example of the lack of caution regarding this typhoon.

This typhoon was initially interpreted to have reached its peak intensity with a central pressure of 940 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 45 m/s, classified as "very strong," before making landfall on the Korean Peninsula with a central pressure of 950 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 40 m/s. However, post-analysis revised the peak intensity to a central pressure of 950 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 40 m/s, and the intensity at the time of landfall on the Korean Peninsula to a central pressure of 960 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 35 m/s.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Wukong (international designation: 0016, JTWC designation: 23W, NCHMF designation: Typhoon No. 4) was a tropical cyclone that formed over the South China Sea on September 6, 2000, and dissipated on September 10, 2000, over Thailand. Originating from a low-pressure area in the eastern South China Sea, it intensified into a tropical depression and then a typhoon on September 6. It continued to strengthen into a severe typhoon on September 8, and on September 10, 2000, the typhoon's center made landfall in Ha Tinh Province, Vietnam, as a severe storm, causing widespread heavy rainfall in Central Vietnam. The name "Wukong" was given by China, meaning "Sun Wukong." This typhoon name was reused in 2006, 2012, and 2018.

On September 4, JMA detected a tropical depression in the western Philippine Sea. It remained stationary until around 12:00 (UTC) on September 5, when it began moving counterclockwise. On the same day, Vietnam issued a tropical depression warning. It then intensified into a storm at around 0:00 (UTC) on September 6, 2000. It continued to strengthen, reaching typhoon intensity at 18:00 (UTC) on September 7 and its peak intensity with maximum winds of 75 knots (140 km/h) at 06:00 (UTC) on September 8. JTWC also upgraded the warning to level 2. The storm then gradually weakened, with Typhoon Wukong skirting along the southern coast of Hainan Island on September 9, at which point Vietnam issued an emergency storm warning. Early on September 10, as it approached the offshore area of Ha Tinh Province (about 70 km east of Ngang Pass), the storm weakened to level 10, with gusts above level 10, and shifted west-southwest. By noon on September 10, it made landfall in Ha Tinh Province (the storm's center passed through Ky Anh District). After landfall, it weakened into a tropical depression and then a low-pressure area in northeastern Thailand at 12:00 (UTC) the same day.

Due to the impact of the storm, the Northern Delta and Central regions experienced winds of level 6-7. Some areas in Nghe An and Ha Tinh had winds of level 8. The storm caused heavy rain in the Northern and Central regions of Vietnam on September 9-10-11.  
The damage caused by the storm is unclear but very significant, estimated at over 1.5 million USD.
Wukong (simplified: 孙悟空; traditional: 孫悟空; pinyin: Sūn Wùkōng; Wade–Giles: Sun Wu-k'ung), is a storm name given by China, meaning "Sun Wukong," a character in the film Journey to the West.

Article_Name: 颱風利奧 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Leo (English: Typhoon Leo, International Number: 9902, Taiwan Number: 9905, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 05W) was the 5th named tropical cyclone of the 1999 Pacific typhoon season and the earliest tropical cyclone since World War II to prompt the Hong Kong Observatory to issue the No. 8 signal. Leo was once assessed by the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center to have a central wind speed of 205 kilometers per hour, with its path directly approaching Hong Kong. However, influenced by the northeast monsoon, Leo rapidly weakened and turned northeast when approaching Hong Kong, significantly reducing its threat to the region.

A tropical depression formed about 170 kilometers southwest of the Paracel Islands on April 28 and was named Leo. It moved northeast in the South China Sea and strengthened into a tropical storm that afternoon. Two days later, Leo further developed into a typhoon. It began to weaken on May 1, becoming a severe tropical storm and moving toward the coastal waters of Guangdong. Leo subsequently approached Hong Kong via a northwesterly path but shifted to an easterly path and moved away from Hong Kong later in the afternoon of May 2. Leo then weakened into a tropical depression and made landfall near Daya Bay that evening, eventually dissipating into a low-pressure area. [1] [2]

The Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 9:40 am on April 29, when Leo was located about 600 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. Leo intensified into a typhoon on April 30. Under the combined influence of Leo and the northeast monsoon, strong winds were recorded in offshore waters and high ground in Hong Kong, with rough seas. The Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 4:15 pm on April 30. Leo continued to approach Hong Kong over the next two days. On May 2, winds strengthened on Waglan Island, reaching gale force before noon. In the afternoon of May 2, Leo's low-level circulation center continued to be steered by low-level easterly winds, moving northwest-northward towards Hong Kong. However, its deep convection was sheared off by upper-level westerlies, weakening it into a tropical storm. As the Observatory predicted that Leo would maintain tropical storm intensity within 100 kilometers of Hong Kong, the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal was issued at 1:30 pm that afternoon. This was the earliest issuance of a No. 8 Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal since 1946. Waglan Island recorded an hourly average wind speed of 90 kilometers per hour and a maximum gust of 130 kilometers per hour between 12 pm and 1 pm on May 2. Leo then passed about 45 kilometers southeast of the Hong Kong Observatory at 5 pm. However, Leo later turned northeast and moved inland, away from Hong Kong, and winds in Hong Kong subsided. During this period, three weather stations in Hong Kong recorded gale-force winds, while three other rural weather stations recorded strong winds. As Leo weakened into a tropical depression while passing east of Hong Kong, the Observatory replaced the signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 5:30 pm. By 8:45 pm, Leo had moved further away from Hong Kong and made landfall near Daya Bay, with all signals being canceled.

Under Leo's influence, there were six reports of fallen trees in Hong Kong. Three men were rescued after being in distress at sea, and a woman sustained minor injuries after slipping in Chai Wan. Slippery roads also caused 13 injuries in three traffic accidents. Most ferry services were temporarily suspended during Leo's impact. Two flights to Hong Kong and Bangkok were canceled. Shark prevention nets at five beaches on Hong Kong Island were severely damaged by large waves. Additionally, a cargo ship sank about 275 kilometers southeast of Waglan Island on April 30 due to rough seas. One crew member died, 13 went missing, and seven others were rescued from the rough waves.

Many citizens were dissatisfied with the Observatory's actions, as Leo quickly weakened into a tropical depression and changed direction shortly after the No. 8 Signal was issued, which was only in effect for four hours, causing public confusion. Due to terrain shielding and the rapid collapse of Leo's wind structure, winds in Hong Kong were relatively weak, leading some citizens to question whether the No. 8 Signal was necessary. Some believed the Observatory should have observed the weather conditions in Hong Kong from noon to dusk on May 2 before deciding whether to issue the No. 8 Signal, rather than hastily issuing it when a tropical storm entered within 100 kilometers of Hong Kong, causing public confusion. In this situation, the issuance of the No. 8 Signal led citizens to mistakenly believe that winds were generally weak during such signals, prompting them to go out, and some even chased the storm along the coast. Others believed that the Observatory's prediction that Leo would enter within 100 kilometers of Hong Kong as a tropical storm justified the issuance of the No. 8 Signal.

The Observatory later explained that all relevant factors are considered when deciding whether to issue higher signals, but public safety is the primary concern. Waglan Island recorded an hourly average wind speed of 90 kilometers per hour between 12 pm and 1 pm on May 2. The Hong Kong Underground Observatory pointed out that this indicated gale-force winds had affected southern offshore areas and showed signs of possibly extending to more areas. It was not feasible for the Observatory to wait several more hours to decide whether to issue the No. 8 Signal, and from the perspective of ensuring public safety, the issuance of the No. 8 Signal was necessary.

Minimum station pressure: 994 hPa (May 2, 04:29)  
Maximum wind speed: 42 km/h (northeast by north wind) (April 30, 10:00)  
Maximum gust: 69 km/h (May 1, 11:51)

Article_Name: 颱風柏美娜 (1954年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Pamela (English: Typhoon Pamela, International Number: 5419, Taiwan Number: 5416, Mainland China Number: 5427, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 16W) was the 19th named tropical cyclone of the 1954 Pacific typhoon season. Pamela is a female name and was the second storm in history to cause the Hong Kong Observatory to hoist the No. 9 signal in November.

On October 27, 1954, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Guam. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Pamela. Initially, Pamela moved mainly northwestward. On October 28, Pamela shifted to a more westerly direction. At 8 p.m. on October 29, Pamela changed course to move northwestward. At 8 a.m. on October 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 8 a.m. on October 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 2 p.m. on November 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 8 p.m., Pamela reached its peak intensity with one-minute sustained winds near the center reaching 150 knots (280 km/h), and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 5 typhoon. At 8 p.m. on November 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 2 a.m. on November 4, Pamela passed through the Bashi Channel and entered the South China Sea. At 8 a.m. on November 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a Category 5 typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 2 a.m. on November 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 3 typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 2 typhoon. At 2 p.m., Pamela made landfall along the coastal areas of Taishan County, Jiangmen City, Guangdong Province, China, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 1 typhoon. At 8 a.m. on November 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m. on November 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning.
When Parmela swept across Taiwan, the minimum pressure was 940 hPa, the maximum wind speed at the center reached 220 km/h, and 231.6 mm of rainfall was recorded.

Palma entered the South China Sea on November 5, and the Observatory hoisted the No. 1 signal at 11:30 a.m. In the afternoon, Palma continued to move west-northwest, getting closer to Hong Kong, and the Royal Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 7 signal at 8:20 p.m. The next day, as the Observatory predicted that Palma would come very close to Hong Kong and might bring hurricane-force winds, the Observatory hoisted the No. 9 signal at 10:15 a.m. This was the second typhoon to cause the Observatory to hoist the No. 9 signal in November and the only typhoon after World War II to lead to the hoisting of the No. 9 signal in November. Palma passed 55 kilometers southwest of the Observatory headquarters. At 3 p.m., the Royal Hong Kong Observatory replaced the No. 9 signal with the No. 8 signal. As Palma moved away, the Observatory canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals at 5 p.m. The Observatory headquarters recorded strong winds for four hours, with the highest hourly average wind speed being 87 kilometers per hour from the east. During Palma's impact on Hong Kong, the maximum storm surge and highest water level recorded at North Point and Quarry Bay were 1.16 meters and 2.83 meters, respectively. Additionally, during Palma's impact, the Royal Hong Kong Observatory recorded 93.5 millimeters of rainfall on November 6, resulting in more than double the normal rainfall for November 1954.
Affected by Parmela, Macau recorded a minimum pressure of 980 hPa, a maximum sustained wind speed of 99 km/h, and a daily rainfall of 41.5 mm.
On November 6, Palma made landfall along the coast of Taishan County, Jiangmen City, Guangdong Province, China, but no recorded impact on the area was noted.

Whole_Text.content: The storm surge disaster of Taisho 6 (1917) was a storm surge disaster caused by a typhoon that occurred on October 1, 1917 (Taisho 6) along the Tokyo Bay coast. The damage was particularly severe in Tokyo Prefecture, where, unlike the great flood of Meiji 43, the disaster was characterized by damage from high waves along the coastal areas. For this reason, the affected areas refer to it as the "Great Tsunami of Taisho 6," and the typhoon that caused this disaster is called the "Tokyo Bay Typhoon." This article also describes the nationwide flooding caused by the same typhoon from late September to early October of the same year.

The typhoon that formed east of the Philippines on September 25, 1917 (Taisho 6) passed near Daito Island on the 29th, caused significant damage to the Kinki region late at night on the 30th (as described later), passed between Shizuoka and Hamamatsu on the same day, and traversed the Kanto region from southwest to northeast on October 1. During this time, it directly hit Tokyo, the capital. In central Tokyo, the maximum wind speed of 43 m/s and the lowest daily sea-level pressure of 952.7 hPa were recorded, with the record for the lowest daily sea-level pressure still unbroken to this day. The typhoon further traversed the Tohoku region and Hokkaido, causing heavy rainfall in various areas, and exited into the Sea of Okhotsk on October 2.

The nationwide damage was extremely severe, affecting three prefectures, one territory, and 25 provinces, mainly east of the Kinki region. There were 1,324 deaths and missing persons, approximately 2,000 injured, 43,083 completely destroyed houses, 2,399 washed-away houses, and 194,698 houses flooded above floor level, making it one of the worst disasters following the Nobi Earthquake of 1891 (Meiji 24) and the Sanriku Tsunami of 1896 (Meiji 29).

When the typhoon approached Tokyo Bay, it coincided with high tide, causing significant damage to coastal areas along Tokyo Bay, such as Kyobashi Ward, Fukagawa Ward, and Honjo Ward, as well as districts along the Sumida River. Storm surges struck twice, flooding areas such as Tsukuda Island, Tsukishima, Tsukiji, Shinagawa, and Fukagawa. The flooding in Tsukishima, Tsukiji, and Susaki was particularly severe, resulting in many drowning deaths. The number of deaths and missing persons in Tokyo Prefecture reached 563, nearly half of the total for all of Japan.

Chiba Prefecture's Tokyo Bay coastline also suffered damage. The entire town of Urayasu was submerged. The Gyotoku salt fields, which had survived numerous floods since the Edo period, were completely destroyed, marking the end of the centuries-old salt production industry in Tokyo Bay.

In Kanagawa Prefecture, Tachibana District suffered the most severe damage. Of the 60 deaths and missing persons in Kanagawa Prefecture, half (32) were from Tachibana District. At Yokohama Port, over 3,100 ships and barges capsized due to wind and waves, and many dockworkers and waterborne residents lost their lives. As Yokohama Port was a key hub of Japan's economic activity at the time, the disaster dealt a significant blow to the nation's economy.

In Tokyo Prefecture, where damage was concentrated, the Kyobashi Ward, which included Tsukuda Island and Tsukishima, saw the deployment of the 1st Division, which provided meals for 7,600 people through its transport corps. In Fukagawa Ward, the military also provided support, distributing meals to 5,000 people. In Honjo Ward, many disaster victims were unable to cook due to flooding from the Sumida River, and 6,917 people were sheltered in local elementary schools.

The novelist and essayist Hyakken Uchida described the disaster caused by the heavy rain on this day as a "hurricane" in his essay "After the Great Storm."

The typhoon and torrential rain that caused this disaster brought a major flood in the Kinki region on September 30 due to the breach of the Yodo River system's embankment, and it is referred to locally as the Taisho Great Flood, Taisho Great Disaster, or Yodo River Otsuka Breach.
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Article_Name: 颱風法茜 (2014年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Faxai (English: Typhoon Faxai, international designation: 1403, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP032014) was the third named tropical cyclone of the 2014 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Faxai" was provided by Laos and is one of the local female names. Faxai was the first typhoon-level tropical cyclone to form in March since Typhoon Mitag in 2002.

On the evening of February 17, a slow-moving tropical disturbance was detected near Pohnpei in the Federated States of Micronesia close to the equator and was designated as "93W." Due to strong vertical wind shear in the surrounding area, the storm developed slowly until the system moved into a region with low vertical wind shear, allowing it to consolidate and develop. On February 26, the tropical disturbance was upgraded to a tropical depression by the Japan Meteorological Agency, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On February 28, the tropical depression was upgraded to a tropical depression by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and was designated as "03W." Hours later, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it "Faxai." Subsequently, Faxai began to intensify rapidly, being upgraded to a severe tropical storm and then a typhoon within just two days from March 3 to 4. The system transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on March 6. After Faxai transitioned into an extratropical cyclone, its remnants were absorbed by another extratropical system on March 8 in an area several thousand kilometers southeast of Japan.

Faxi hardly approached land from its formation to its end, only passing over areas such as the sea east of Guam, the Mariana Islands, the Caroline Islands, and Minami-Tori-shima, and did not cause significant impact.

Article_Name: 태풍 히고스 (2015년) - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Higos (Typhoon Number: 1502, JTWC Designation Number: 02W, International Name: HIGOS) was active from February 8 to February 12, 2015, and recorded a minimum pressure of 940 hPa, making it the second typhoon of 2015. It is a Category 4 typhoon (SSHS). The name Higos was submitted by the United States and means "fig" in Chamorro.

Typhoon Higos, the second typhoon of the year, formed as a small tropical storm with a central pressure of 1000 hPa, maximum wind speed of 18 m/s, and a gale radius of 220 km at 3 a.m. on February 8, approximately 1,390 km east of Guam, USA (based on the Japan Meteorological Agency's typhoon information). After formation, it moved west-northwest and rapidly intensified, reaching its peak intensity as a typhoon with a central pressure of 935 hPa, maximum wind speed of 49 m/s, and a gale radius of 330 km (northern radius) at 3 p.m. on February 10, approximately 1,020 km east of Guam, USA, with a strength classified as "very strong" and size as "medium" (based on the Japan Meteorological Agency's typhoon information). After its peak, it weakened rapidly while moving north-northeast to west-northwest and dissipated as a tropical depression with a central pressure of 1002 hPa at 3 a.m. on February 12, approximately 880 km northeast of Guam, USA. The name "Higos" was submitted by the United States and means "fig." Typhoon Higos set three records as a February typhoon: the first record is that it occurred during the February 8–15 period, which had been a "typhoon-free period" since the Japan Meteorological Agency began typhoon statistics in 1951, filling more than half of that period; the second record is that it marked the third consecutive year of February typhoon occurrences from 2013 to 2015; and the third record is that it tied with Typhoon Mitag (Mitok), the second typhoon of 2002, which had the strongest peak intensity among February typhoons with a central pressure of 930 hPa and maximum wind speed of 49 m/s, based on the Japan Meteorological Agency's standards.

Article_Name: 태풍 앗사니 (2015년) - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Atsani (ATSANI) is the 16th typhoon of 2015. It is a Category 5 super typhoon (SSHS). Atsani is a name submitted by Thailand, meaning lightning.

At 3 a.m. on August 15, a tropical storm with a central pressure of 1000 hPa, maximum wind speed of 18 m/s, wind radius of 150 km, and size classified as "small" formed over the sea approximately 1,810 km east of Guam, USA (based on Japan Meteorological Agency typhoon information). After formation, it moved west-northwest and developed, reaching its peak as a typhoon with a central pressure of 925 hPa, maximum wind speed of 51 m/s, wind radius of 560 km, strength classified as "very strong," and size classified as "large" at 9 p.m. on August 19 over the sea approximately 980 km northeast of Guam, USA (based on Japan Meteorological Agency typhoon information updates). After its peak, it turned northeast at latitude 27°N, gradually weakened as it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone, and according to the Japan Meteorological Agency, it transformed into an extratropical cyclone with a central pressure of 964 hPa over the sea approximately 1,470 km southeast of Sapporo, Japan, at 6 p.m. on August 25. According to the Korea Meteorological Administration, it transformed into an extratropical cyclone with a central pressure of 985 hPa over the sea approximately 1,550 km east-southeast of Sapporo, Japan, at 9 p.m. on August 25.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Judy (昭和28年台風第2号, International name: Judy) was a typhoon that occurred in May 1953. On June 4 of the same year, the Central Meteorological Observatory (now the Japan Meteorological Agency) announced that typhoons in Japan would no longer be named after "foreign female names" and would instead be referred to by "sequential numbers" starting with Typhoon Judy. As a result, Typhoon Judy became the last typhoon to be called by a female name and the first typhoon to be assigned a number after World War II.

At 3:00 PM on May 29 (6:00 AM UTC on May 29), a typhoon formed at 8°3'N, 145°2'E in the Caroline Islands. The typhoon slowly moved westward and grew to a minimum pressure of 940 millibars by June 2 as it approached the sea east of the Philippines. After making landfall on Luzon Island on the 4th, it changed its course from north to northeast and increased speed, approaching Kyushu on the 6th. At 9:00 AM on the 7th, it made landfall near Yatsushiro City, Kumamoto Prefecture. In Makurazaki City, Kagoshima Prefecture, maximum wind speeds of 26.7 meters per second and maximum instantaneous wind speeds of 39.1 meters per second were observed. The typhoon, which traversed western Japan, became an extratropical cyclone at 9:00 PM on the same day (12:00 PM UTC on the same day) at 36°1'N, 136°9'E. Some sources indicate the dissipation point as northwest of Kofu City, Yamanashi Prefecture. Notably, this typhoon was the fourth earliest in recorded history to make landfall in Japan within a calendar year.
On June 5, then-President Elpidio Quirino issued instructions to mobilize all government agencies for relief efforts on Luzon Island, but the scale of the damage remains unknown.
On June 6th, when the typhoon approached, strong winds exceeding 55 meters per second and high waves of about 5 meters struck, resulting in the deaths of 40 people, including children.

Due to the typhoon and the rainy season front it triggered, widespread damage occurred from Kyushu to the Chubu region. There were 37 fatalities, 17 missing persons, and 56 injured. A total of 1,802 buildings were damaged, and 33,640 buildings were flooded. In addition to 74,353 hectares of farmland, 139 ships were damaged. However, some sources report 64 damaged ships, while others report 236.
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).
