At 10:40 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration announced that Podul made landfall in Casiguran, Aurora. At 2:00 AM the following day, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration lifted Signal No. 2. At 5:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center simultaneously upgraded the system to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration lifted all storm signals.

On August 29, at 8:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded Podul to a severe tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded Podul to a tropical storm. On August 30, at 1:30 AM, Podul made landfall in Dong Hoi, Quang Binh Province, Vietnam. At 6:45 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and subsequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 3:45 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On August 31, at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared that Podul had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: On August 31, a low-pressure area formed southeast of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:30 AM on September 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it. At 8 PM on September 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 19, and issued a track forecast. At 8 AM on September 2, the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. Shortly after, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1913, and named it "Lingling." At 10 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 15W. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. The following morning at 9 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon, followed by the Japan Meteorological Agency at 6 AM the next morning. On September 7, Lingling became the first typhoon in history to make landfall in North Korea. [7]

PAGASA: Kabayan  
On August 29, a low-pressure area formed east of Luzon, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. On August 30 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 31 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 18, and issued a path forecast. Simultaneously, the China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On September 1 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it. At 8 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. As the storm left the area of responsibility, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued its final warning at 11 a.m. on September 1, when it was located 390 kilometers northwest of Laoag.  

On September 3 at 3 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1914, and named it "Kajiki." At 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 16W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On September 4 at 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On September 7 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency declared that Kajiki had completely dissipated. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Kajiki's peak intensity was revised to 65 kilometers per hour.

On August 29, a low-pressure area formed in the central-north Pacific, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance 90W. At 2 a.m. on August 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4 p.m. on September 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert for it. At 2 a.m. on September 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 14W. At 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m. on September 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 3 p.m. on September 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1915, and named it "Faxai." At 2 p.m. on September 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. The following morning, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a typhoon. After being upgraded to a typhoon, the system began to rapidly intensify. At 4 a.m. on September 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Faxai made landfall in Chiba City. At 4 a.m. on September 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Faxai had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On the morning of September 13 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded a low-pressure area near the waters of Pohnpei Island to a tropical depression. At 12 p.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. At 4:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." On September 15 at 12 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 3 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 17W. At 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 22, and issued a path forecast. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1916, and named it "Peipah," while also issuing a gale warning. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, China Meteorological Administration, and Taiwan Central Weather Bureau followed shortly after with upgrades. On September 16 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On September 17 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

PAGASA: The previously weakened tropical disturbance 95W near Nimfa redeveloped east of Luzon. At 8:00 AM on September 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 12:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "medium." On September 18, at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 2:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 23, and issued a path forecast. At 4:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "high." On September 19, at 10:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 18W. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1917, and named it "Tapah." Shortly after, the China Meteorological Administration and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also upgraded it. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 10:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it. On September 21, at 7:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 10:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. On September 22, at 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On September 23, at 4:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Tapah had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Tapah's peak intensity was adjusted to 120 km/h.

PAGASA: Onyok On the afternoon of September 25, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 a.m. on September 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 24, and issued a path forecast. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 4 p.m. on September 27, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 19W. At 9:45 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4 a.m. on September 28, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1918, and named it "Mitag." At 9:45 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on September 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 5:45 p.m. on September 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 9 p.m. on September 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 p.m. on October 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Mitag had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 4 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.

At noon on October 4, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern waters of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 2 a.m. on October 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 25, and issued a path forecast. At 9:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center skipped the "medium" rating and directly upgraded it to "high," issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 4 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 20W. At 2 a.m. on October 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1919, and named it "Hagibis." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a strong tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on October 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center simultaneously upgraded Hagibis to a typhoon. Although Hagibis did not enter the Hong Kong Observatory's area of responsibility, it was classified as a typhoon on the weather map. At 8 a.m., the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 2 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a super typhoon. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 5 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency raised its maximum sustained wind speed to 195 km/h, making it the third storm of the year to reach the "violent" level and temporarily the strongest tropical cyclone of the year, though it was later surpassed by Super Typhoon Halong in November of the same year. At 8 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a severe typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its maximum sustained wind speed to 260 km/h, classifying it as a Category 5 hurricane. It became the first storm to reach Category 5 hurricane strength since Super Typhoon Wutip in February of the same year, and Hagibis became the third-fastest intensifying tropical cyclone on record in the Northwest Pacific, following Typhoon Forrest in 1983 and Typhoon Goni in 2020. At 11 a.m. on October 8, Hagibis developed a double eyewall phenomenon, causing its intensity to slightly weaken. At noon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a Category 4 hurricane. At 6 a.m. on October 9, Hagibis completed its eyewall replacement cycle, and its intensity peaked again. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center re-upgraded it to a Category 5 hurricane. At 11 a.m. on October 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Hagibis had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Hagibis's peak intensity was revised to 295 km/h, tying the record set by Typhoon Megi in 2010.

PAGASA: Perla  
On October 15, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 12:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium."  
On October 16 at 2 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 26, and issued a path forecast. At 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 21W.  
On October 17 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On October 18 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1920, and named it "Bualoi."

At 12:30 PM on October 17, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters near the Marshall Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. At 12:00 PM on October 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high." At 10:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it. At 4:00 AM on October 19, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 27, and issued a path forecast. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 10:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 22W. At 12:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. Later that evening at 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1921, and named it "Bualoi." At 8:00 PM on October 25, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Bualoi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Bualoi's peak intensity was revised to 260 km/h.

At 1:15 PM on October 27, a tropical disturbance formed southeast of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 1:45 PM on October 28, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 AM on October 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 28, and issued a path forecast. At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high," and at 5:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8:00 AM on October 29, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 AM on October 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1922, and named it "Matmo." At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 23W. At 11:30 PM, Matmo made landfall along the coast of Phu Yen Province, Vietnam. At 8:00 PM on November 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had dissipated. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Matmo's peak intensity in the Northwest Pacific was revised to 100 kilometers per hour.

At 1:00 PM on October 31, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters near the Marshall Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance 99W. At 1:15 PM on November 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8:00 AM on November 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency skipped the gale warning and directly issued a marine storm warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 29. At 10:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 24W. At 11:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1923, and named it "Halong." 

At 2:00 AM on November 3, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 AM on November 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:00 PM on the same day, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 2:00 AM on November 5, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a strong typhoon and further upgraded it to a super typhoon at 8:00 AM. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency increased Halong's wind speed to 215 km/h, surpassing the super typhoon Hagibis in October of the same year, making it the strongest tropical cyclone of the year. At 8:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a severe typhoon. 

As Halong gradually approached the westerlies, its eye filled in on the afternoon of November 6, and its storm circle shrank. At 2:00 AM on November 7, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency reduced Halong's wind speed to 185 km/h. At 8:00 AM on November 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Halong had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 11:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. 

In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Halong's peak intensity was revised to 305 km/h, tying the record set by Typhoon Tip in 1979.

PAGASA: Quiel  
On the morning of November 3 at 11:30 AM, a tropical disturbance formed in the central South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 10:45 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium."  
On November 4 at 11:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it. At 1 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high." At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 30, and issued a track forecast. At 2 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On November 5 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1924, and named it "Nakri." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon.  
On the night of November 10 at 11 PM, Nakri made landfall in Khanh Hoa Province, Vietnam.  
On November 11 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On November 12 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

At 1 PM on November 10, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters near the Marshall Islands, and the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 AM on November 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 31, and issued a path forecast. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 26W. At 2 PM on November 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1925, and named it "Fengshen." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5 AM on November 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon, and shortly after, the China Meteorological Administration followed suit. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. Shortly after, Fengshen developed an eye, and its intensity began to rapidly increase. At 2 AM on November 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and at the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Fengshen's peak intensity was adjusted to 215 km/h.

PAGASA: Ramon  
At 1 PM on November 10, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W.  
At 2 AM on November 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and directly issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 32, and issued a path forecast. At 5:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
At 5 AM on November 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 27W. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1926, and named it "Kalmaegi." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon.  
At 12:20 AM on November 20, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration announced that Kalmaegi made landfall in Santa Ana, Cagayan, Philippines. At 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency directly downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 PM that same day, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
At 5 AM on November 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.  
At 2 AM on November 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.  
In the best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency on January 14, 2020, Kalmaegi's peak intensity was revised to 130 km/h, and its pressure was revised to 975 hPa. Meanwhile, in the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Kalmaegi's peak was revised to 165 km/h.

PAGASA: Sarah On November 18 at 1:15 AM, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters near Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." On November 19 at 6 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 9 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 33, and issued a path forecast. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 28W. On November 20 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1927, and named it "Fenghuang." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. On November 21 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. On November 23 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On November 25 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

PAGASA: On the morning of November 23 at 5:15 AM, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters near the Marshall Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. On November 24 at 10:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On November 25 at 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 34, and issued a path forecast. On November 26 at 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 29W. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1928, and named it "Kammuri." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a light typhoon. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 4 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory marked Kammuri as a tropical storm on the weather map. At 10 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory marked Kammuri's central wind speed as 65 kilometers per hour on the weather map. On November 27 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On November 28 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On December 2 at 11 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration announced that Kammuri made landfall in Gubat, Sorsogon. On December 6 at 12 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Kammuri's peak intensity was revised to 220 kilometers per hour.

PAGASA: Ursula  
At 1:15 AM on December 19, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 2:00 AM on December 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 1:45 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 11:00 AM on December 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 35, and issued a path forecast. At 5:00 AM on December 22, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 30W. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1929, and named it "Phanfone." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 4:45 PM on December 24, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration announced that Phanfone made landfall in Salcedo, Eastern Samar. At 5:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon, and at 7:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 11:00 AM on December 25, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a typhoon. At 11:00 AM on December 27, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 AM on December 28, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 AM on December 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, Phanfone's peak intensity was adjusted to 195 km/h.

In addition to tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones assessed as tropical storms or tropical depressions by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, but only classified as tropical depressions by the Japan Meteorological Agency.

PAGASA: Amang, a low-pressure area, formed on January 2 in the waters east of the Gilbert Islands. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 90W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) initially rated it as "low" at noon that day, then upgraded it to "medium" in the afternoon. On January 4, the JTWC raised the rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 5 a.m. on January 5, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number 01W. The following afternoon, the JTWC downgraded it to a low-pressure area and issued its final report at 11 p.m. Subsequently, in its best track released on January 8, the JTWC determined that the system only reached disturbance intensity, removing the previously assessed intensity and track.

At 8 p.m. on January 7, the JTWC again rated it as "medium," but downgraded it to "low" at 5 a.m. on January 11, only to upgrade it back to "medium" at 2 p.m. the next day. On the afternoon of January 14, it was downgraded to "low" again, but upgraded back to "medium" at 8 a.m. the following morning. At 3 p.m. on January 18, as the system developed, the JTWC once again raised the rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression at 2 p.m. on January 19, but the JTWC canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and downgraded it to "medium" at 5 p.m. On the evening of January 21 at 9 p.m., the JMA issued a gale warning. On the afternoon of January 22, the JTWC downgraded it to "low" again, and shortly after, the JMA canceled the gale warning. That evening, the system dissipated in the waters east of the Philippines. 

In the best track released by the JTWC on September 16, 2020, the peak intensity of 01W was revised to 30 knots (55 km/h).

PAGASA: Chedeng A low-pressure area formed on March 11 in the waters near the Marshall Islands and moved west-northwest under the guidance of the subtropical high-pressure ridge. Affected by vertical wind shear, the system developed slowly and had a loose structure. The low-level circulation center of the system gradually consolidated on the 13th, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within one day as "medium," skipping the "low" rating. On the afternoon of the 14th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical depression, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also raised the rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. Due to the system's convective outbreak, showing the characteristics of a tropical cyclone, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center successively classified the system as a tropical depression at 2 a.m. and 8 a.m. on the 15th, assigning it tropical cyclone numbers 04 and 03W, respectively. That day, the system turned southwestward. Due to persistent vertical wind shear and weak outflow above the system, the tropical depression did not intensify further on the 16th. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded the system to a low-pressure area at 8 a.m. on the 17th. Subsequently, the system crossed Koror Island, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 2 p.m. on the 18th. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration announced that the system made landfall in Malitbog, Mindanao, Philippines, at 5:30 a.m. on the 19th. Affected by terrain, the system's central convection weakened, and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 2 p.m. At this time, the system resumed a northwest-northward path, entering Moro Bay. In the evening, the system entered the Sulu Sea, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center stated that the system weakened and dissipated during the day on the 20th.  

As the system intensified into a tropical depression, the U.S. National Weather Service issued a tropical storm watch for Ngulu Atoll, Yap Island, and Kayangel Island at 11:40 a.m. on the 15th. The U.S. National Weather Service stated that the aforementioned islands were experiencing northeast winds of 4-5 levels, with stronger circulation on the northern side of the system, making Yap Island more affected than Ngulu Atoll and Kayangel Island. The U.S. National Weather Service later expanded the tropical storm watch to include Koror Island at 5:20 a.m. on the 16th. Yap Island first experienced east winds in the morning, and Ngulu Atoll and Kayangel Island experienced east winds by the early morning of the 17th. As the system moved away, the U.S. National Weather Service successively canceled the tropical storm watch for Yap Island and Ngulu Atoll at 5:35 p.m. on the 16th and 11:20 a.m. on the 17th. After the system passed Koror Island and moved west of Kayangel Atoll and the Caroline Islands, the islands began experiencing southeast winds, and the U.S. National Weather Service canceled all tropical storm watches at 5:20 p.m. The system entered the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration's area of responsibility in the early morning of the 17th, and the agency named the system "Chedeng," issuing Signal No. 1 for parts of Mindanao. The system made landfall in Malitbog, Mindanao, Philippines, at 5:30 a.m. on the 19th and soon weakened into a low-pressure area, prompting the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration to lift Signal No. 1.  

In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 16, 2020, the peak of 03W was adjusted to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On May 2, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of Yap Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 90W. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigned it a "low" development rating, which was upgraded to "medium" the next day. However, the system's development did not meet expectations, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded the rating to "low" on the afternoon of May 3. On the morning of May 7, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, designated it as No. 05, and issued a path forecast. On May 8, at 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area, and at 3 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating. At 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area, and shortly after, determined that it had dissipated.

On May 5, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters west of the Marshall Islands. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 91W, and the following day, it was reclassified as 92W in the cloud system to its north. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center gave it a development rating of "low." On the morning of May 7 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "medium." Shortly after, the Japan Meteorological Agency directly upgraded it to a tropical depression on the weather map. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 06, and issued a path forecast. On May 11 at 4 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded the rating to "low." On May 12 at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also canceled the rating. On May 13 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area, and at 2 PM the same day, it was re-upgraded to a tropical depression. On May 15 at 9 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency once again downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On the morning of May 10 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the remnant cloud band located east of the Philippines to a tropical depression, and downgraded it to a low-pressure area on the afternoon of May 11.

Some islands of the Ryukyu Archipelago recorded southeast winds of force 6 on the morning of June 26. The Japan Meteorological Agency stated that a tropical depression formed in the offshore area north of the Ryukyu Archipelago at 8 a.m. [26][27]. The system moved northward across the East China Sea, and the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that the tropical depression weakened into a low-pressure area by 8 p.m. Its remnants were later absorbed by the circulation of Saola near Korea.

PAGASA: Egay In mid to late June, during the early development of the low-pressure area that preceded Tropical Cyclone Sanba, computer numerical forecast models predicted the formation of a low-pressure area that would follow Sanba towards the waters east of Luzon. This forecasted low-pressure area formed on the 23rd in the waters northeast of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 95W. For several days after its formation, the structure of the low-pressure area remained disorganized until the 27th, when it gradually consolidated and organized in an environment of warm sea temperatures and moderate vertical wind shear, with increasing spiral characteristics. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated the chance of the low-pressure area developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 2 PM, while the Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded the system to a tropical depression. In response to the system's convective bursts and the consolidation of the low-level circulation center, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 8 AM on the 28th, assigning it the number 08. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the rating to "medium" at 9 AM and further upgraded it to "high" at 12 PM, issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. 

Under the influence of the subtropical ridge, the system took a west-northwest path at a speed of 12 kilometers per hour. Affected by vertical wind shear, the eastern side of the system's low-level circulation center became partially exposed. As the system repaired its low-level circulation center, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression at 2 AM, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 04W, and further upgraded the system to a tropical storm at 2 PM. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) upgraded it to a tropical depression at 8 PM. 

At 5 PM on June 30, PAGASA issued Signal No. 1 for the Batanes Islands. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression in the afternoon and issued its final warning at 8 PM. On July 1, at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 5 PM, PAGASA lifted Signal No. 1. On July 2, at 9 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared that the system had dissipated.

PAGASA: Goring On July 17, Tropical Storm Danas was structurally damaged as it passed over Luzon, with upper-level cloud systems moving into the South China Sea; in the afternoon, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned the tropical disturbance the designation 91W. Shortly after, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly rated it as "medium." At 10 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical depression. On the morning of the 18th at 10:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On the morning of the 19th at 10:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center determined that it had made landfall near the Kaohsiung-Pingtung border in Taiwan and canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert. At 11 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued Signal No. 1 for the Batanes Islands. At 11 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration lifted Signal No. 1. On the evening of July 19 at 9 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that the tropical depression had dissipated.

At 2 a.m. on August 6, a low-pressure system formed in the South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance 96W. At 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the system had merged into the circulation of Typhoon Lekima.

On the morning of August 17 at 7 a.m., a tropical disturbance formed, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 98W. At 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low" on the afternoon of the 17th. However, the system developed slowly, with the low-level circulation center exposed. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it from a tropical depression on the morning of the 19th, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating on the morning of the 20th.

On the afternoon of August 19 at 3 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At that time, it was located east of Taiwan. On the evening of the 21st at 10 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had dissipated.

On the morning of September 2, at 3 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the low-pressure area in the central South China Sea to a tropical depression. At 5 a.m. on September 3, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned the disturbance the designation 94W. At 5:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for the system. At 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the system had merged into the circulation of Tropical Storm Kajiki. On the morning of September 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.

On the morning of September 4 at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the low-pressure area east of the Philippines to a tropical depression. It weakened into a low-pressure area at 9 p.m. on the 5th.

On the morning of September 7 at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that a tropical depression had formed in the waters northeast of Taiwan. At 12 p.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. On the evening of September 10 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Marilyn On September 7 at 12:00 noon, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters near Yap Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. On September 10 at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On September 11 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On the same day, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number 21, and issued a path forecast. On September 13 at 4:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for the system and upgraded its rating to "high." At 9:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning. On September 14 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On the same day, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 11:00 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued its final warning for it. On September 15 at 12:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating to "low" and canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.

At 12:00 noon on September 13, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters near Iwo Jima, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 8:00 a.m. on September 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 a.m. on September 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 12:00 noon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its classification.

At 12:00 noon on September 17, a tropical disturbance formed in the western waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 99W. At 2:00 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 a.m. on September 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map. At 12:00 noon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its classification.

On the afternoon of October 1 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the low-pressure area located in the eastern waters of the Philippines to a tropical depression. On the afternoon of October 3 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

On the morning of October 22 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that a tropical depression had formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines. By 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency believed it had merged into the circulation of Typhoon Bolaven.

On the afternoon of November 22 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that a tropical depression had formed in the southwestern South China Sea. On the afternoon of November 23 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

On the morning of November 27 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that a tropical depression had formed near the Hall Islands. On the afternoon of November 28 at 3:15 PM, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into the circulation of Typhoon Kammuri. At 1:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its classification.

At 1:00 PM on November 29, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters near the Mortlock Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 1:30 PM on November 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 11:00 AM on December 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert for it. At 8:00 AM on December 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert. At 1:00 PM on December 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating to "low."

Once a tropical cyclone reaches tropical storm intensity in the Western Pacific, it is named by the Typhoon Committee of the Japan Meteorological Agency. These names are provided by 14 member countries or regions, each contributing 10 names, and are then sorted alphabetically by the first letter of the English name of each country. Names in bold indicate those already used this year, bold names indicate active storms, unused names are shown in gray, and orange indicates the next name to be used. The storm names for 2019 may overlap with some storm names from 2001, 2002, 2007, 2008, 2013, and 2014.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form in, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list is rotated every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2019, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all tropical cyclones that were active in the Western Pacific in 2019. It includes the intensity, duration, names, and the casualties and damage caused by these tropical cyclones. All damages are measured in US dollars. Numbers in parentheses indicate indirect deaths (such as traffic accidents, landslides, etc.).

Whole_Text.header: The name of the delisted tropical cyclone
Whole_Text.content: In the 52nd session of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee in 2020, it was decided to retire the names "Yutu," "Lekima," "Faxai," "Hagibis," "Kammuri," and "Phanfone" because these tropical cyclones caused significant impacts on the member countries/regions of the Typhoon Committee.

Whole_Text.content: The very intense cyclonic storm Matmo−Bulbul, also known as Typhoon No. 5 in Vietnam, was a strong and long-lasting tropical cyclone that made landfall in Phu Yen Province on October 30 and then continued to sweep through the state of West Bengal in India and Bangladesh on November 9, 2019, at 18:30 GMT, bringing high waves, heavy rain, and flash floods. Originating from the remnants of Typhoon Matmo (Typhoon No. 5) of the 2019 Northwest Pacific Typhoon Season, which moved southward into the Bay of Bengal on November 2, Bulbul gradually intensified into a severe cyclonic storm. This was the fourth recorded tropical storm to move from mainland Southeast Asia across the Andaman Sea (hence JTWC and international media still referred to it as Matmo). Additionally, it was the second storm to reach hurricane strength in this region since 1960.

On October 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded the warning for a tropical depression in the South China Sea to a storm, naming it Matmo (Storm No. 5). On the night of October 30 and early morning of October 31, Typhoon Matmo, with maximum winds of 100 km/h, made landfall in the South Central region of Vietnam, bringing strong winds, heavy rain, and causing flooding. Storm No. 5 resulted in 1 death, 1 missing person, and caused particularly severe damage to Binh Dinh province. Matmo then gradually weakened into a low-pressure area and moved across the Indochina Peninsula, bringing some rain and moisture to Cambodia, Thailand, and Myanmar. On November 2, Matmo's low-pressure area moved to the northern Andaman Sea in the Indian Ocean. Meteorological agencies began monitoring the low-pressure area as it started to develop and grow again. After strengthening into a storm, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) named it Bulbul, but U.S. warning agencies like JTWC considered the low-pressure area 23W (Matmo) to have moved from the South China Sea, so they continued issuing warnings for Typhoon Matmo. Bulbul quickly intensified and reached a peak intensity of Category 2 on the Saffir-Simpson scale while moving northward, prompting IMD to issue coastal warnings for Odisha and West Bengal and to ban all fishing, beach activities, and boating in and around the Bay of Bengal. About a day later, on November 9, Bulbul made landfall near Sagar Island in West Bengal at 18:30 GMT, killing at least 2 people, moving inland into Bangladesh, and causing high waves and storm surges that led to flooding. Bulbul continued moving further inland and gradually dissipated, bringing heavy to very heavy rain.

More than 1.8 million people in the coastal districts of Bangladesh at risk have been evacuated to 4,071 cyclone shelters. Health department officials in these districts have established 1,599 teams to assist those affected by the cyclone. Approximately 56,000 volunteers have been deployed to carry out rescue and relief efforts, while military bases in the coastal districts remain on alert. All coastal infantry forces of the Bangladesh Army have been prepared for rapid response to provide support during and after the cyclone's impact. The Bangladesh Navy and Bangladesh Coast Guard have prepared emergency rescue and relief operations using warships and civilian vessels.

At around 11:50 PM on October 30, 2019, Typhoon No. 5 made landfall in the southern part of Song Cau town (Phu Yen province) with an intensity of level 8-9, gusting to level 11. Strong winds caused many trees in the three provinces of Quang Ngai, Binh Dinh, and Phu Yen to break or be uprooted. Many fish cages and fishing boats were sunk by large waves. In the provinces from Quang Ngai to Phu Yen, there was heavy to very heavy rain. Rainfall over 24 hours was generally 150-300mm, with some places recording up to 384mm. Typhoon No. 5 caused 1 death, 1 person missing, and particularly severe damage to Binh Dinh province.

Although the impact of Bulbul on Odisha was relatively minimal, the storm caused heavy rain and winds across the state, damaging agriculture, uprooting crops, and snapping power lines throughout Odisha. So far, no fatalities have been reported in the state. However, around 350 local villagers in Balesore district were moved to cyclone shelters as the storm approached landfall, and their current condition remains unclear. Around 18:30 GMT, Bulbul made landfall in West Bengal near the Sunderban Dhanchi forest, bringing heavy rain and winds of up to 135 km/h (85 mph) across much of the southern part of the state. Ten fatalities were reported there, four of which were caused by falling trees. A 59-year-old man was electrocuted by a lamp post, and another person died when a collapsing wall crushed him. Additionally, before the storm made landfall, a man was killed after a cedar branch fell on his head. Fallen trees also caused road traffic congestion throughout Kolkata city, and the Kolkata Municipal Corporation worked to clear these blockages. Furthermore, operations at Netaji Subhas Chandra Bose International Airport in Kolkata were suspended for 12 hours. At least 22 people in seven coastal districts were reported dead due to causes such as falling trees, collapsing houses, capsized boats, and illnesses, while many others were injured as the cyclone swept through the coastal areas of Bangladesh. Due to the cyclone, all secondary school exams on November 9, 11, and 12, as well as the Bangladesh National University exam on November 9, were suspended. The Bangladesh Inland Water Transport Authority suspended all operations at three seaports and river transport services during the storm's impact. All flights to and from Shah Amanat International Airport in Chittagong, Cox's Bazar Airport, Barisal Airport, and Jashore Airport were canceled for 14 hours due to severe weather under the storm's influence.

Article_Name: 태풍 할롱 (2019년) - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Halong (HALONG) was active from November 3 to November 9, 2019, and recorded a minimum pressure of 905 hPa, making it the 23rd typhoon of 2019. Halong is the name of the typhoon submitted by Vietnam, referring to Ha Long Bay, a tourist attraction in Vietnam.

Typhoon Halong formed as a tropical storm of medium size with a central pressure of 1000 hPa, maximum wind speed of 18 m/s, and a gale radius of 330 km (northeastern radius) at 0:00 on November 3, approximately 1,312 km east of Guam, USA (based on the Japan Meteorological Agency's typhoon information). After formation, it rapidly developed while moving northwest to north, reaching its peak intensity as a "violent" typhoon of medium size with a central pressure of 905 hPa, maximum wind speed of 59 m/s, and a gale radius of 440 km (northeastern radius) at 21:00 on November 5, approximately 960 km northeast of Guam, USA (based on the Japan Meteorological Agency's typhoon information). After its peak, it maintained its strength before turning northeast at 21 degrees north latitude. As it moved north to northeast, it rapidly weakened and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone due to high vertical wind shear and cold air intrusion. According to the Japan Meteorological Agency, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone with a central pressure of 1004 hPa at 9:00 on November 9, approximately 2,000 km southeast of Tokyo, Japan. According to the Korea Meteorological Administration, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone with a central pressure of 1004 hPa at 12:00 on November 9, approximately 2,090 km east-southeast of Tokyo, Japan. Halong was recorded as the strongest typhoon of 2019, surpassing Udip, Lekima, Hagibis, and Bualoi, based on the Japan Meteorological Agency's standards.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Ramon (2019); (International designation: Typhoon Kalmaegi) was a tropical storm that became a typhoon in November 2019 in the Pacific Ocean. It was spotted 1,000 kilometers east of Catanduanes. It formed near Guam in the Pacific Ocean; it threatened the provinces of Aurora, Batanes, Cagayan, Isabela, Bicol, and Eastern Visayas in mid-November 2019. Ramon brought heavy rains and strong winds to the eastern seas of the Philippines. Ramon entered the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) on November 12, made landfall on November 19 between Batanes and Apayao, moved down to the Ilocos Region, and was expected to exit on November 21, 2019, between the South China Sea and the West Philippine Sea. It made landfall in Santa Ana, Cagayan. Afterward, Typhoon Quiel devastated Cagayan and Isabela due to the northeast monsoon pulled from Japan.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Sarah (2019); (International designation: Typhoon Fung-wong) was a typhoon in the Philippine Sea that brought rain to several regions in Northern Luzon, the Cagayan Valley, and Central Luzon, following the impact of Typhoon Ramon in Cagayan and Isabela.
It formed as a Low Pressure Area (LPA) 680 km east of Sorsogon, moving northwest towards Cagayan.

Whole_Text.content: The Yashima Maru Typhoon was a typhoon that made landfall in Japan on October 20, 1933 (Showa 8) and mainly caused damage in western Japan. It is commonly referred to as the "Yashima Maru Typhoon" because the regular passenger ship "Yashima Maru" sank due to strong winds and large waves.

It occurred south of Yap Island on October 11. At the time, the distinction between a tropical depression and a typhoon was unclear, and the definition of a typhoon was also ambiguous, so it is unknown when it was upgraded to a typhoon. Gradually developing while moving northwest, it approached Ishigaki Island on the morning of the 19th, and the island entered the eye of the typhoon. The then-director of the Ishigaki Island Meteorological Observatory, Takuji Iwasaki, provided a detailed report on the changes in observed values, weather transitions, and the behavior of living organisms at that time [1]. From around the time it passed Ishigaki Island, the typhoon changed its course to the northeast, increased its speed, and made landfall in Kagoshima Prefecture early on the morning of the 20th. After passing through Shikoku and entering the Seto Inland Sea, it made landfall near Aioi City, Hyogo Prefecture, around noon, passed through the eastern part of the Chugoku region, entered the Sea of Japan, and exited into the Pacific Ocean via Aomori Prefecture by midday on the 21st.

The regular passenger ship "Yashima Maru (946t)" operating between Beppu and the Hanshin area departed Takamatsu Port for Kobe Port on the morning of the 20th. The Yashima Maru entered Osaka Bay shortly after noon, but as the typhoon passed to the west of the ship, it entered the so-called "dangerous semicircle," causing strong winds and waves, leading to flooding. At around 1:05 PM, it sank off the coast of Suma, Kobe City.  
41 passengers and 26 crew members died, and 2 passengers went missing.  
After the typhoon made landfall on the mainland, it rapidly weakened, so apart from the Yashima Maru disaster, the damage was relatively minor.  
(The above figures are based on the Japan Meteorological Association's "1940–1970 Typhoon Track Map 30-Year Collection" (1973).)
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Typhoon No. 15 of 2004 (Heisei 16, Asian name: Megi) was a typhoon that occurred in August 2004, causing damage from heavy rain and strong winds in the Japanese archipelago. It was later designated as a localized severe disaster.

On August 16, 2004, Typhoon No. 15 formed over the eastern seas of the Philippines and by the 17th passed west of Kume Island in Okinawa Prefecture, moving into the East China Sea. It maintained its strong intensity, traveling northeast through the East China Sea, passing near Tsushima in Nagasaki Prefecture, and made landfall on the Tsugaru Peninsula in Aomori Prefecture around 6 a.m. on the 20th. By 6 p.m. the same day, it transformed into an extratropical cyclone over the southeastern seas of Nemuro City, Hokkaido. From the 17th to the 18th, as the typhoon moved northward from the seas near Okinawa to the East China Sea, warm and moist air from the outer edges of the typhoon flowed into western and eastern Japan, developing rain clouds and causing very heavy rain in areas such as the Shikoku and Kyushu regions. The total rainfall in Tominaga, Shikokuchuo City, Ehime Prefecture, reached approximately 600mm, about 2.5 times the average monthly rainfall for August, which is 240.9mm. Furthermore, as the typhoon stimulated a weather front, the total rainfall during the period up to the 20th exceeded 600mm in the Shikoku region, and in parts of the Tohoku region and Hokkaido, heavy rainfall of 200mm to 300mm occurred due to the typhoon and the front. Additionally, strong winds were observed mainly along the Sea of Japan side from Kyushu to Hokkaido as the typhoon approached.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 9 of 1963 (Showa 38, International name: Bess) was a typhoon that made landfall in Kyushu in August 1963.

On July 30, 1963, Typhoon No. 9 formed west of the Mariana Islands. The typhoon remained relatively stationary and did not develop much until around August 3, but on August 4, it rapidly intensified and began moving northward. Since the Pacific high-pressure system had covered the area near Japan after the end of the rainy season on July 13 of the same year, severe heat persisted daily, and there was so little rain that some areas even experienced concerns about water shortages. Typically, typhoons in August often move northward from the East China Sea along the eastern coast of the continent, but at that time, the high-pressure system was weak, so this typhoon gradually continued moving northward. On August 9, the typhoon made landfall near the border between Miyazaki Prefecture and Oita Prefecture. By August 11, it had transformed into an extratropical cyclone over the Sea of Japan.

This typhoon caused significant damage mainly in the Kyushu region, resulting in 23 deaths, 6 missing persons, and 46 injuries. Additionally, 2,064 houses were destroyed, and 25,166 houses were flooded. Due to the impact of this typhoon, the 1963 Nagasaki Peace Memorial Ceremony was held at the Nagasaki International Cultural Hall.

Article_Name: 태풍 올가 (1970년) - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Olga (OLGA) was the second typhoon to occur in the northwest Pacific in 1970. It was a typhoon that caused heavy rain in the eastern coastal region of South Korea. Even after the typhoon transformed into an extratropical cyclone following its passage through the Japanese archipelago, a large amount of rain clouds flowed into the Korean Peninsula, resulting in more than 400mm of rainfall, particularly in the Yeongdong region of Gangwon Province.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 11 of 1958 (Showa 33, International name: Alice) was a typhoon that made landfall in Shizuoka Prefecture in July 1958.

Typhoon No. 11, which formed near the Caroline Islands on July 14, 1958, moved northward and made landfall near Omaezaki, Shizuoka Prefecture, on the 23rd, passing through the Kanto region. On the 24th, it transformed into an extratropical cyclone near the Kamchatka Peninsula.

Due to the impact of the typhoon, storm surges occurred in Tokyo Bay, and the Nakagawa River breached during high tide, causing flooding in low-lying areas of Tokyo such as Koto Ward and Edogawa Ward. Damage was reported across the Kanto region and northern Japan. According to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government's Construction Bureau, the tide level reached 2.89 A.P.m (A.P. refers to Arakawa Peil, the lowest tide level measured at the Reiganjima gauge in the Arakawa river system), with 13,459 houses flooded above floor level, 22,970 houses flooded below floor level, and 133 casualties. In Yamagata Prefecture, heavy rain in mountainous areas caused rivers to overflow, resulting in one death, two injuries, six completely destroyed houses, 41 partially destroyed houses, and 1,205 houses flooded above floor level. Hokkaido also reported numerous casualties. On the night of the 22nd, in Zushi City, Kanagawa Prefecture, strong winds and high waves from the typhoon caused all beach houses to be completely or partially destroyed. 

Even after the typhoon passed, heavy rain caused by a stationary front led to further damage in various areas. In the Hida River basin in Gifu Prefecture, muddy torrents caused significant damage. Ishikawa Prefecture experienced consecutive days of heavy rain, with severe damage in Nanao City, including house collapses and bridge washouts. In Nagano Prefecture, the Azusa River overflowed, and roads leading to Kamikochi were blocked by landslides, leaving climbers stranded at Shimashima Station. Over 2,000 people were reportedly trapped in Kamikochi and Mount Norikura. 

Nationwide, the typhoon caused 26 deaths, 14 missing persons, 64 injuries, 1,089 houses destroyed, and 46,243 houses flooded, with total damages amounting to 4.3 billion yen. Additionally, the Kanto region in 1958 was struck by other typhoons, including Typhoon No. 21 and the Kano River Typhoon (Typhoon No. 22).
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).
Typhoon No. 18 of 1974 (International name: Shirley) was a typhoon that made landfall in Kyushu in September 1974.

A weak tropical depression that formed off the coast of Taiwan at 3:00 PM on September 2, 1974, moved eastward and became Typhoon No. 18 near Minamidaitō Island at 3:00 AM (JST) on the 5th. The typhoon moved northward and made landfall near Makurazaki City, Kagoshima Prefecture, around 8:10 PM on the 8th, crossing southern Kyushu. On the 9th, it made landfall again near Uwajima City, Ehime Prefecture, from the Bungo Channel, moving eastward across the Shikoku region. It then moved into Tosa Bay and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone at 6:00 AM on the same day. 

At 9:00 AM on the 8th, when the typhoon moved northeast beyond 30 degrees north latitude, a low-pressure system was present in the central Sea of Japan, with a cold front extending from the San'in region to northern Kyushu, moving southward. However, as the typhoon advanced northeast, the front moved southward to central Kinki but then stalled, remaining over central Kinki until 10:00 AM on the 9th, when the extratropical cyclone that had been the typhoon passed through the Kii Channel. As a result, heavy rainfall of 160–350 mm occurred from 9:00 AM on the 8th to 9:00 AM on the 9th, particularly in southern Awaji Island in Hyogo Prefecture, as well as around Kobe City and Akashi City. In particular, Sumoto City experienced record-breaking torrential rain in three waves.

Due to the impact of the typhoon and the front, damage such as river flooding and inundation occurred, especially in Oita and Ehime Prefectures. In Tosa Town, Kochi Prefecture, a flash flood (debris flow) struck houses, killing two people. In Ōtoyo Town, a landslide caused houses to collapse, killing one person. Additionally, in Sumoto City, Hyogo Prefecture, a landslide caused houses to collapse, killing two people. In total, at least nine people died, and more than 8,000 houses were flooded or damaged.

Article_Name: 颱風戴娜 (1967年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Dinah (Japanese: Typhoon Dinah) was one of the tropical cyclones in the 1967 Pacific typhoon season. The storm formed on October 17 near the southern waters of the Mariana Islands and dissipated on October 28, lasting about 11 days. After making landfall on the Atsumi Peninsula in Aichi Prefecture, Japan, Dinah affected the Chubu region, Kanto region, and Tohoku region. It set the record at the time for the latest landfall in Japan within the year, a record that was held until Typhoon Page in 1990. To this day, it remains the only typhoon with a numbering exceeding 30 within the year to make landfall in Japan. [1]

Daina formed near the southern waters of the Mariana Islands on October 17, then moved counterclockwise in the Philippine Sea before turning northwest and continuing to strengthen, reaching its peak around the 24th with a pressure as low as 950 hPa. At that time, a large high-pressure system was dominating around Japan, and forecasts suggested that Daina would move northeast and pass through the waters south of Japan. However, Daina continued westward and, contrary to meteorological predictions, moved west-northwest over the waters south of the Ryukyu Islands, stalling southeast of Miyako Island. On the 27th, Daina suddenly began moving again, turning northeast toward the Kii region of Honshu, Japan, and made landfall at Cape Irago on the Atsumi Peninsula in Aichi Prefecture at 3:30 a.m. the next day. Although Daina transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on the same day, it maintained its intensity and continued to develop, causing severe weather across Japan. Daina was the latest typhoon to make landfall in Japan within a year since record-keeping began in 1951, until Typhoon Page made landfall in Shirahama, Wakayama Prefecture, in November 1990. To date, it remains the second latest on record, but Daina is still the only typhoon with a number exceeding 30 within a year to make landfall in Japan.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation issued a sea typhoon warning on the night of October 24, Taiwan time, followed by a land typhoon warning the next afternoon, and lifted both land and sea warnings by the afternoon of the 26th, with no disaster reports during the period. According to the typhoon warning bulletin at the time, Typhoon Dana was moving slowly westward or nearly stationary over the sea east of Taiwan, while various parts of Taiwan were simultaneously affected by high pressure, with the northeast monsoon temporarily strengthening. The Lanyu Weather Station offshore recorded a maximum sustained wind speed of 29.2 meters per second, while the Beitou Saddle Weather Station recorded a maximum total rainfall of 278.6 millimeters.

This typhoon caused 37 deaths, 10 missing persons, and 41 injuries. Additionally, it damaged 2,959 houses, flooded 26,842 houses, affected 2,481 hectares of farmland, and damaged 181 ships. [6] At the road repair site on National Route 42 in Odomari, Kumano City, Mie Prefecture, a flash flood occurred at the time, causing a mudslide that swept away 30 people, resulting in significant casualties. [4][7] The storm also triggered heavy snowfall, with snow accumulation reaching up to 50 centimeters in the Chichibu area between Nagano and Gunma Prefectures. [2] In eastern Tokushima Prefecture, the total rainfall during the period was 200 to 250 millimeters. In Komatsushima Port, Komatsushima City, heavy rain caused by the storm washed away many temporary moorings, and the cultivated seaweed suffered severe damage. [8]

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 15 of 1965 (Showa 40, International name: Jean) was a typhoon that made landfall in Kyushu in August 1965.

On July 25, 1965, a weak tropical depression formed near Pohnpei Island in the Marshall Islands and moved west-northwest, becoming Typhoon No. 15 over the sea east of the Philippines on the 31st. The typhoon continued westward for a while, then changed course to the north-northwest at 9 a.m. on August 1, and shifted to a northerly course at 9 p.m. on the 3rd. By 3 p.m. on the 4th, it had reached the western sea off Okinawa, becoming a medium-sized strong typhoon, and moved north-northeast through the East China Sea, approaching Kyushu. Between midnight and 3 a.m. on the 6th, the typhoon rapidly intensified southwest of Kyushu, with a central pressure of 940 mb (hPa) and maximum wind speeds of 50 m/s. At 4:11 a.m., it made landfall near Ushibuka City in Kumamoto Prefecture, maintaining its peak intensity (central pressure of 940 mb). It then passed through Kumamoto and Oita Prefectures, re-entered land at Ube City in Yamaguchi Prefecture via Suo-nada (its strength at this time had weakened to a central pressure of 960 mb), and exited into the Sea of Japan by noon on the 6th. The central pressure of 940 mb observed at the time of landfall in Kyushu was the fifth lowest recorded for a typhoon at landfall since statistics began in 1951. Additionally, due to the typhoon's influence, the weather, which had previously been dry due to the extension of the Pacific High, changed dramatically, with strong winds and rain intensifying in various areas, particularly in Kumamoto Prefecture.

Due to the impact of this typhoon, 28 people died, 368 people were injured to varying degrees, 58,951 houses were damaged, and 5,716 houses suffered flood damage. The highest number of deaths caused by the typhoon was in Kagoshima Prefecture, with 15 fatalities. Among them, in Sendai City, a public hall collapsed, resulting in the death of three members of a family who had taken refuge there.

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Butchoy (International designation: Tropical Storm Nuri) was a Tropical Depression and the second storm to pass through the Philippines after Typhoon Ambo. Butchoy was first spotted 75 kilometers east of Guiuan, Eastern Samar as a Low-Pressure Area in June 2020. It first made landfall on Polillo Island in Quezon and in the town of Dingalan, Aurora. After crossing Central Luzon, Butchoy became a full-fledged Tropical Depression in the western part of Alaminos, Pangasinan while traversing the length of the West Philippine Sea heading towards the South China Sea. It made its final landfall in Guangdong Province, China.

Butchoy formed within the PAR in the eastern part of Eastern Samar while continuing to cross the Philippines. The storm began to intensify in the West Philippine Sea and was given the international name Nuri as it moved northwestward towards China. According to the JTWC, the storm will make landfall in "Yanjiang, China." PAGASA issued Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal #1 in June 2020, bringing heavy rains. It made landfall in Polillo and Dingalan, Aurora.
