Whole_Text.content: Typhoons No. 10 and 11 of 2004 (Heisei 16) were two typhoons that successively made landfall in the Shikoku region from July to August 2004. They were later designated as severe disasters.

Typhoon No. 10 (Asian name: Namtheun) that formed over the western sea near Minamitorishima on July 25th strengthened as it moved northwest, reaching the southern sea near Hachijojima on the 28th. From the 30th, it slowly moved west-northwest over the southern sea of Japan while maintaining strong intensity, and made landfall in western Kochi Prefecture after 4 PM on the 31st. It then crossed the Seto Inland Sea and made a second landfall near Iwakuni City, Yamaguchi Prefecture, around 9:30 PM. Afterward, it moved northward over the Sea of Japan and transitioned into a tropical depression at 9 AM on August 2nd.  

Due to the impact of this typhoon, heavy rain occurred from July 29th to 31st on the Pacific side of eastern Japan and in western Japan, with particularly intense rainfall in the southern Kinki region and Shikoku region. From August 1st to 2nd, developed rain clouds flowed from the Pacific Ocean into the Shikoku region, causing prolonged rainfall even after the typhoon had passed. In Ehime and Kochi Prefectures, rainfall exceeded 100 mm per hour.  

From July 29th to August 2nd, precipitation exceeded 1,000 mm in Nara and Tokushima Prefectures and 700 mm in Kochi Prefecture. Reports indicate that some locations experienced over 2,000 mm of rainfall. Observations by Shikoku Electric Power recorded a daily precipitation of 1,317 mm in Kaigawa, Kamikatsu Town, Tokushima Prefecture, setting a new record for daily precipitation in Japan.  

One of the reasons for the heavy rainfall was the extremely slow movement of the typhoon at a speed of 10 km/h, influenced by a high-pressure system on the Sea of Japan.

After Typhoon No. 10 passed, at 9 a.m. on August 4, a tropical depression located over the southern seas of Japan became Typhoon No. 11 (Asian name: Malou) over the southern seas near Cape Shionomisaki, and it made landfall in eastern Tokushima Prefecture after 10 p.m. Subsequently, it made landfall again near Aioi City, Hyogo Prefecture, traversed the Shikoku and Chugoku regions, and turned into a tropical depression by 6 a.m. on August 5. Although the typhoon itself was not very strong, it caused heavy rain, particularly in the southern Kinki region and Mie Prefecture, with some areas receiving over 500mm of rainfall between August 4 and 5. Additionally, the fact that it made landfall in Shikoku shortly after Typhoon No. 10 passed contributed to the severity of the damage.

These two typhoons both had the characteristic of moving from east to west, contrary to the usual typhoon paths, crossing Shikoku and bringing heavy rain and strong winds. While typhoons approaching Japan often move along the archipelago from southwest to northeast, these typhoons moved in a way that cut across the Japanese archipelago. Due to the prolonged and heavy rainfall, landslides, flooding, and road disruptions occurred in various areas.

Due to these two typhoons, 3 people died (including 2 in Kisawa Village, Tokushima Prefecture, whose deaths were officially confirmed on September 23), 15 people were seriously or slightly injured, and there was damage to residences including 11 completely destroyed, 21 partially destroyed, 88 partially damaged, 254 flooded above floor level, and 2,188 flooded below floor level. Additionally, the total damage amounted to 10.3 billion yen. One of the factors contributing to the significant damage was Typhoon No. 10's extremely slow movement.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴瓦爾道 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Vanda was the 8th named tropical cyclone of the 1998 Pacific typhoon season, making landfall in the Kinki region in September and causing damage locally along with Typhoon Vicki, which made landfall the following day.

This system formed on September 20, 1998, in the sea area north of Okinotorishima, moved northward on the same day, and made landfall near Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture. It then moved northward over the Kii Peninsula and weakened into a tropical depression near northern Shiga Prefecture the following day, eventually entering Toyama Bay on the 22nd and dissipating near northern Japan. The day after this system made landfall, Typhoon Vicki, which had formed earlier, also made landfall on the Kii Peninsula. The year this system formed, like the 1975 Pacific typhoon season, was a year in which the 8th named tropical cyclone was generated as late as September, and this system was also the latest 8th tropical cyclone to form in the history of the Northwest Pacific.

Due to the influence of this system and Typhoon Vicki, heavy rain occurred mainly in eastern Shikoku, the Kii Peninsula, and the Tokai region. The maximum rainfall in Nishikawa, Kozagawa Town, Wakayama Prefecture, reached 557 millimeters, with several locations recording rainfall between 300 to 500 millimeters. In addition, strong winds were observed in areas affected by Typhoon Vicki. Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture, recorded wind speeds of 32.4 meters per second (with a maximum instantaneous wind speed of 50.0 meters per second), Tsu City, Mie Prefecture, recorded wind speeds of 29.8 meters per second (with a maximum instantaneous wind speed of 48.0 meters per second), and Ueno City recorded wind speeds of 25.9 meters per second (with a maximum instantaneous wind speed of 56.4 meters per second). On the 22nd, a significant wave height of 7.37 meters was observed at Ishizaki, Shizuoka Prefecture. This system and Typhoon Vicki caused 18 fatalities, 569 injuries, damage to 21,165 houses, and flooding of 8,692 houses.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Yanni is the 9th typhoon that occurred in September 1998. It showed an unusual path by making landfall on the southern coast and then moving southward again, and due to the influence of this typhoon, South Korea experienced damage such as approximately 500mm of rainfall in Pohang.

In the Korean Peninsula, 50 people died due to the typhoon that approached the peninsula. The activity of the front became active due to this typhoon, and in Japan, damage caused by heavy rain occurred over a wide area due to the influence of the typhoon's humid air.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Faye (Typhoon Faye, Showa 24 Typhoon No. 4 [1], International name: Faye) was a typhoon that occurred in July 1949 and caused damage to Kyushu and other areas [2].

Typhoon Fay formed on July 11, 1949, and moved north along the western coast of Kyushu. It grazed Nagasaki Prefecture from July 16 to July 17 and dissipated in the Sea of Japan. In Kagoshima City, Kagoshima Prefecture, the maximum instantaneous wind speed recorded was 41.3 m/s, with total rainfall of 148.4 mm in Kagoshima City and 154.7 mm in Kumamoto City, Kumamoto Prefecture.

Due to the typhoon, 46 people died nationwide, including 30 in Kagoshima Prefecture and 10 in Kumamoto Prefecture, and 12 were injured. Additionally, building damage included 125 completely destroyed or washed away, 247 partially destroyed, 2,054 flooded above floor level, and 4,666 flooded below floor level.

Article_Name: 台風5号 (チャンミー) が発生 - ウィキニュース

Whole_Text.content: [August 9, 2020] According to the Japan Meteorological Agency, Typhoon No. 5 (Asian name: Jangmi) formed south of Okinawa at 3 a.m. on August 9 [1]. As of 3 a.m. on the 9th, its central pressure was 1000 hPa, and it was moving north at a speed of 30 km per hour [1]. It is expected to develop further as it moves northward, heading southwest of Naha City, and then proceed northward over the East China Sea [1]. In the Sakishima Islands and the Okinawa main island region, rain and wind are expected to intensify on the 9th, and rough seas are anticipated in the waters around the Okinawa main island region, the Daito Islands region, and the Miyako Islands region. Caution is also required for landslides, flooding in low-lying areas, and rising river levels [1]. The Asian name (international name) of Typhoon No. 5 is "Jangmi," which was proposed by South Korea and means "rose" (장미) [2].

Article_Name: 2020年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content:
The 2020 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during the year 2020. According to past patterns, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December.  

This article is limited to typhoons in the Pacific Ocean and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2020 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (international names) and are assigned an international number starting with 20xx. The United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter W.  

For tropical depressions that enter or form within the Philippine Area of Responsibility, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration assigns a local name for local warnings, meaning a tropical cyclone may have two different English names (the international name is considered official). Additionally, before the 2020s, the Chinese names used by mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan might have differed. Starting from the 2020s, the Chinese names for storms that were retired and replaced are determined through consultation among the China Meteorological Administration, the Hong Kong Observatory, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan.  

The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

According to the forecast of the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau, tropical cyclone activity affecting Hainan Island during the 2020 flood season is relatively active, and the number of impacts and landfalls may be close to or slightly less than the annual average.

The Shenzhen Meteorological Observatory predicts that Shenzhen will be more affected by typhoons in 2020 compared to 2019. It is expected that 5-7 typhoons will enter Shenzhen's 500-kilometer defense zone in 2020 (compared to 4 in 2019).

The Hong Kong Observatory predicts that 4 to 7 typhoons will enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong in 2020, which is close to a normal typhoon season; tropical cyclones may affect Hong Kong in June or later.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau predicts that around 4 to 6 tropical cyclones will enter within 800 kilometers of Macao in 2020, among which there may be strong typhoons or above. It is expected that the first tropical cyclone affecting Macao will appear in mid-June or later, and the last tropical cyclone affecting Macao will appear in late September.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation announced the typhoon season outlook on June 30, predicting that the number of typhoons forming from June to December this year will be normal to slightly below normal, with the number of typhoons affecting Taiwan being within the normal range, approximately 3 to 5.

Affected by the Pacific El Niño phenomenon, the subtropical high-pressure ridge became strong, leading to a relatively calm Northwest Pacific and South China Sea in 2020 compared to previous years, with no tropical cyclones forming in the first four months. The last time this phenomenon occurred was in 2016. On May 10, a tropical disturbance east of the Philippines intensified into a tropical depression, marking the official start of the typhoon season. This tropical depression rapidly intensified into Typhoon Vongfong, which impacted the Philippines. The South China typhoon season began on June 14 with Tropical Storm Nuri making landfall in western Guangdong, becoming the second named storm of the season. The Pacific subtropical high was abnormally strong in July, making it the first recorded July without any named tropical cyclones. 

However, tropical cyclone activity became vigorous in August, with formation locations shifting westward. In early August, Tropical Storm Sinlaku, with a broad circulation and initial monsoon depression characteristics, affected Guangdong, Guangxi, Hainan, Vietnam, Laos, and Thailand. Simultaneously, another tropical cyclone, Hagupit, made landfall in Zhejiang as a typhoon and impacted Fujian, Taiwan, Jiangsu, and South Korea. In mid-August, Typhoon Jangmi affected Japan and South Korea. Later, Tropical Storm Mekkhala made landfall in Fujian as a severe tropical storm, while Typhoon Higos rapidly intensified and impacted the Pearl River Delta region. On August 21, Typhoon Bavi formed and later made landfall in North Korea as a strong typhoon. From late August to early September, Typhoons Maysak and Haishen consecutively impacted Northeast China, the Korean Peninsula, Japan, and the Russian Far East as super typhoons.

In mid-September, Tropical Storm Noul struck Vietnam. From late September to early October, Tropical Storms Dolphin, Kujira, and Chan-hom formed but did not make landfall anywhere. Starting in mid-October, tropical cyclone activity in the South China Sea became vigorous. Tropical Storm Linfa formed first, bringing torrential rain to Vietnam and causing significant casualties. Tropical Storm Nangka affected Hong Kong, Macau, and Hainan. Tropical Storm Saudel formed on October 19, primarily impacting the Philippines. From late October to early November, Typhoons Molave and Goni caused massive destruction in the Philippines, with Goni becoming the strongest tropical cyclone of the year, reaching maximum sustained winds of 315 km/h. On October 29, Typhoon Atsani formed, affecting southern Taiwan.

On November 7, Tropical Storm Etau formed and later struck Vietnam. On November 8, Typhoon Vamco formed, rapidly intensified, and made landfall in the Philippines on November 11. After Vamco dissipated, tropical cyclone activity in the Northwest Pacific decreased due to increasingly cold weather. On December 5, a tropical depression formed but did not intensify further. On December 17, a tropical disturbance developed into Krovanh, affecting the Philippines, Malaysia, and Thailand. On December 29, another unnamed tropical cyclone formed but dissipated the next day, marking the official end of the typhoon season.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content: PAGASA: Ambo On May 6 at 12:30 PM, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of Yap Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. On May 9 at 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On May 10 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 3:45 PM on May 10, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM on May 11, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD01. At 9:25 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. [Source needed] At 1:00 AM on May 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 01W [11]. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2001, and named it "Vongfong." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. Subsequently, the China Meteorological Administration followed suit and upgraded it. At 10:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On May 13 at 2:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. Due to warm sea temperatures, weak vertical wind shear, and good upper-level divergence, Vongfong steadily intensified, developing a central dense overcast and a cloud-filled eye. At 2:50 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded "Vongfong" to a severe tropical storm. [12] At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. However, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center believed that its intensity began to weaken at dawn that day, with the structure near the center slightly disrupted [13]. Subsequently, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration determined that this tropical cyclone made landfall at 12:15 PM in San Policarpo, Eastern Samar, with a ten-minute average wind speed of 150 km/h at landfall [14]. However, Vongfong did not immediately weaken upon landfall. The Japan Meteorological Agency raised its ten-minute average wind speed to 85 knots and stated that Vongfong had reached its peak intensity [15]. However, Vongfong was subsequently affected by friction caused by the terrain, and its central wind speed rapidly weakened [16]. At 10:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Vongfong to a typhoon [17]. An hour later, the China Meteorological Administration followed suit [18]. Vongfong then crossed several islands, gradually weakening due to friction, with its convection becoming more disorganized [19]. At 2:45 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Vongfong to a severe tropical storm [15]. At 3:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau downgraded it to a mild typhoon [20]. Subsequently, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a severe tropical storm and a tropical storm at 3:30 PM and 5:00 PM, respectively [21][19]. The China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a severe tropical storm at 8:00 PM that day [18]. Afterward, Vongfong continued to weaken, and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm at 3:30 AM on the 16th [22]. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency also downgraded it to a tropical storm [15]. The China Meteorological Administration followed suit at 5:00 AM [18]. Subsequently, Vongfong entered the South China Sea, where it experienced upper and lower-level separation due to the terrain of Luzon Island [23]. After entering the South China Sea, Vongfong continued to weaken. At 4:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded Vongfong to a tropical depression and issued its final warning [24]. The China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Tropical Storm Vongfong to a tropical depression at 5:00 PM and 6:45 PM, respectively [18][25]. On the 17th at 3:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression [15]. At 8:30 AM, the Central Weather Bureau downgraded Vongfong to a tropical depression [26]. At 9:15 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area [27]. On the weather map at 8:00 PM on the 18th, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into a stationary front system [28].

PAGASA: Butchoy  
On June 8, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters east of Samar Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. In the evening, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "low."  
At 12:30 a.m. on June 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical depression.  
At 8 p.m. on June 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD02. At 5 p.m., the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded it to a tropical depression and named it. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
At 2 a.m. on June 12, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 02W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2002, and named it "Nuri."  
At 4 p.m. on June 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 8 a.m. on June 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At around 8:50 a.m., the China Meteorological Administration reported that "Nuri" made landfall along the coast of Hailing Town, Jiangcheng District, Yangjiang City, Guangdong Province. At 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.  
In the early hours of June 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that "Nuri" had dissipated.

At the beginning of 2020, tropical cyclone activity in the Northwest Pacific was unusually quiet. In June and July, the Pacific experienced strong subsiding airflows, while the Middle East saw vigorous ascending airflows. Under the dominance of the subtropical high ridge, only a few tropical depressions formed in the Northwest Pacific in July. In mid-to-late July, numerical forecast models predicted that the monsoon trough would become active, with a broad low-pressure zone forming east of the Philippines, crossing Luzon, and lingering in the central South China Sea. Several low-pressure vortices within this zone were expected to affect the South China coast, Fujian, and Taiwan in early August before moving northward. One of these low-pressure areas formed on July 28, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as 91W. This system was a "monsoonal low-pressure system" with a broad circulation, loosely organized convective cloud bands, and an indistinct center. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low."

Guided by the subtropical high ridge, the system moved west-northwest, making landfall in Luzon on the afternoon of July 29 and entering the South China Sea around midnight on July 30. With weak vertical wind shear and energy provided by the hot 30°C seawater, the system slowly consolidated its organization, exhibiting stronger winds externally than internally. At 1:30 a.m. on July 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its assessment to "medium." At 9:15 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency classified the system as a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. The China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 3:11 p.m. and 8:45 p.m., respectively. At this time, numerical forecasts and official meteorological agencies predicted the system would pass over Hainan and the Beibu Gulf area before making landfall in northern Vietnam.

At 1:30 a.m. on August 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its assessment to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2:00 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical storm, assigning it the international designation 2003 and naming it "Sinlaku." Simultaneously, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan classified it as a mild typhoon. At 4:00 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 04W.

On August 2, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Sinlaku made landfall near Thanh Hóa, Vietnam, at around 2:40 p.m. At 8:00 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10:00 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also downgraded Sinlaku to a tropical depression. On August 3, at 8:00 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather charts. On October 20, in the Japan Meteorological Agency's best track data, Sinlaku's peak wind speed was revised to 40 knots (75 km/h), and its pressure was adjusted to 985 hPa.

PAGASA: Dindo  
At 9:45 AM on July 31, a tropical disturbance formed over the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 12:45 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On August 1, at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number TD05, and issued a tropical depression advisory. At 10:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 03W. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2004, and named it "Hagupit." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon.  

At 5:30 AM on August 2, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a sea typhoon warning for it. At that time, Hagupit was located 490 kilometers east of Eluanbi. As Hagupit moved away, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the typhoon warning at 11:30 PM on August 3, when Hagupit was located 440 kilometers south of Shanghai.  

The National Meteorological Center determined that Hagupit made landfall at 3:30 AM on August 4 in Wengyang Subdistrict, Yueqing City, Wenzhou, Zhejiang Province. At the time of landfall, Hagupit had a two-minute average wind speed of 38 meters per second and a central minimum pressure of 970 hPa. After landfall, its intensity gradually weakened due to terrain effects. The Central Weather Bureau downgraded Hagupit to a mild typhoon at 9:00 AM, and the National Meteorological Center also downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. Three hours later, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  

Hagupit then moved northward and continued to weaken. The National Meteorological Center downgraded Hagupit to a tropical storm at 5:00 PM. At 9:00 PM, Hagupit's center left Zhejiang and entered Jiangsu Province through Wujiang District, Suzhou. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Hagupit to a tropical storm. After moving northeast into the Yellow Sea, Hagupit accelerated. Before moving out to sea, the National Meteorological Center temporarily downgraded it to a tropical depression, but it re-intensified into a tropical storm after moving out to sea. Hagupit made landfall along the coast of Hwanghae-namdo, North Korea, at 3:00 AM on August 6.  

After entering the mid-latitude region, Hagupit gradually lost its tropical characteristics. At 8:00 AM on August 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Hagupit had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone over the Sea of Japan. After transitioning, Hagupit entered a development phase, continued moving northeast, and its central pressure gradually dropped. The following day, it entered a mature phase and developed an occluded front, passing through northern Hokkaido. On August 8, Hagupit detached from the front. Surrounded by cold air, it entered the dissipation phase.

PAGASA: Enteng  
On August 6, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W.  
On August 7 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium."

Subsequently, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On August 10 at 2:50 p.m., Jangmi made landfall at the southern tip of Geoje Island, Gyeongsangnam-do. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.  
On August 11 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Jangmi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone in the Sea of Japan.

PAGASA: Ferdie  
On August 8, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. On the morning of August 9 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 07W. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number TD07, and issued a tropical depression advisory. At 11:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 3:00 AM on August 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 10:30 AM on August 10, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a sea and land typhoon warning for it, making it the first typhoon this year to have a land typhoon warning issued.  
At 7:30 AM on August 11, Mikla made landfall in Zhangpu County, Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8:00 AM on August 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Mikla had dissipated.

PAGASA: Helen  
On August 16, a tropical disturbance formed over the waters east of Luzon Island in the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. The China Meteorological Administration and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau followed suit, upgrading it at 5:00 PM and 8:00 PM, respectively.  

On August 17, at 10:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD09.  

On August 18, at 1:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 08W. At 2:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit. At 8:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Hong Kong Observatory followed at 9:00 AM. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2007, and named it "Higos." At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. PAGASA: Igme  
On August 17, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters east of Luzon Island, Philippines, and was assigned the disturbance number 90W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory.  
At 12:15 AM on August 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the number TD10, and issued a tropical depression advisory at 4:10 PM. At 7:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 09W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. Simultaneously, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and upgraded it.  

On August 22, at 9:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2008, and named it "Bavi." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical storm and issued a sea typhoon warning at 5:00 PM. The China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. The Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it at 5:00 PM. At 11:30 PM on August 22, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the sea typhoon warning.  

On August 23, at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center increased its wind speed to 70 knots (130 km/h).  

On August 24, at 2:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 3:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reduced its wind speed to 65 knots (120 km/h) and canceled the upgrades made at 2:00 PM and 8:00 PM on August 23. At 2:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  

On August 25, at 11:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded Bavi to a strong typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit at 11:45 AM.  

On August 27, at around 8:30 AM, Bavi made landfall along the coastal area near the China-North Korea border in North Pyongan Province, North Korea, and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone in the afternoon.

PAGASA: Julian  
On August 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the northern waters of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 3:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On August 27 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On August 28 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD11. At 2:20 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory stated, "The low-pressure area east of the Philippines is gradually strengthening, and a tropical cyclone seems to be forming." At 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 10W. At 11:45 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2009, and named it "Maysak." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9:45 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and upgraded it. On August 29 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm, and the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit at 5 a.m. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On the morning of August 30, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon. On the same day, the Hong Kong Observatory and the China Meteorological Administration successively upgraded Maysak to a severe typhoon. On August 31, the Hong Kong Observatory and the China Meteorological Administration successively upgraded Maysak to a super typhoon at 9:45 p.m. and 2:25 a.m. on September 1. Subsequently, Maysak's movement speed gradually decreased to 15 to 20 kilometers per hour, maintaining a northwest-northwest path. In the early hours of September 1, it passed between Miyako Island and Okinawa Island into the East China Sea. At the same time, Maysak began to exhibit a double eyewall structure, indicating the start of an eyewall replacement cycle. However, as Maysak entered an area with stronger vertical wind shear and began the eyewall replacement cycle, its intensity started to decrease. At 9:45 a.m. on September 2, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. However, the sea temperature near Maysak remained at 28 degrees Celsius, so its weakening trend was relatively slow. Maysak accelerated to 40 kilometers per hour, continuing to move northeast-northward. The Korea Meteorological Administration stated that Maysak first crossed Geoje Island in Gyeongsangnam-do at 12:40 a.m. on the 3rd and then made landfall in Busan at 1:20 a.m. At 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon. At 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 11 a.m., the North Korean government announced that Maysak had made landfall in Kimchaek City, North Hamgyong Province. The China Meteorological Administration stated that Maysak had entered Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture, Helong City, Jilin Province, around 1:40 p.m. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Maysak had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm and subsequently announced at 8 p.m. that Maysak had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the early hours of the 14th, Maysak took a northwest path at a speed of 15 to 20 kilometers per hour, entering Inner Mongolia at noon, penetrating into northeastern China, and continuing to weaken. The China Meteorological Administration stopped numbering Maysak at 7 p.m.

PAGASA: Kristine  
On August 30, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters east of the Ogasawara Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. On the morning of August 31, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 1:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD12. At 5:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 7:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 11W.  

At 1:00 AM on September 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2010 and naming it "Haishen." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon.  

At 2:00 PM on September 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon, followed by the Japan Meteorological Agency. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  

At 2:00 AM on September 3, the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 9:45 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and upgraded it. Haishen began an eyewall replacement cycle in the evening and developed a double eyewall.  

On the morning of September 4, Haishen completed the eyewall replacement cycle and continued to intensify. At 6:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade Haishen to a super typhoon, followed by the Hong Kong Observatory at 7:45 AM. At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a strong typhoon, making it the first tropical cyclone of the year to reach this level.  

Due to the weakening of the subtropical ridge caused by an upper-level trough, Haishen bypassed the southwestern edge of the subtropical ridge on September 5, changing its course to move northwest at a speed of about 22 km/h, approaching the Ryukyu Islands. It was affected by subsidence airflow brought by the upper-level trough to the north, which eroded its circulation. However, with sea surface temperatures still at 30–31°C, low vertical wind shear, and favorable upper-level outflow, Haishen only weakened slowly, with its convection slightly thinning while maintaining a well-defined eye. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded Haishen to a typhoon. In the afternoon, Haishen re-entered an eyewall replacement cycle, with its double eyewall structure clearly visible on radar images.  

In the early hours of September 6, Haishen entered an area with stronger vertical wind shear, further damaging its structure, and its eye became weaker and rougher. The eyewall replacement cycle was not completed until the afternoon of September 6. The China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Haishen to a severe typhoon at 11:10 AM and 4:15 PM, respectively. Radar images showed that Haishen's eye shrank after the eyewall replacement and passed over the Tokara Islands. At this time, Haishen accelerated to a speed of 35–40 km/h, moving northwest into the East China Sea and heading toward Kyushu, Japan, and Korea.  

Between midnight and the early hours of September 7, Haishen crossed the Tsushima Strait to the north, further accelerating to 45–50 km/h, passing close to the west of Kyushu, Japan, but its eyewall did not sweep over the area. Haishen's environment rapidly deteriorated, with vertical wind shear intensifying further and the sea surface temperature in the Tsushima Strait dropping. The terrain of Korea and Japan also eroded Haishen's convection. Satellite and radar images showed that Haishen rapidly weakened after midnight on September 7, with its eyewall collapsing and convection quickly becoming shallow. The China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Haishen to a typhoon at 5:25 AM and 9:45 AM, respectively. According to the China Meteorological Administration, Haishen made landfall along the coast of Busan-Ulsan, Gyeongsang Province, South Korea, at around 7:30 AM, with wind speeds of 40 m/s (144 km/h). After landfall, Haishen's central dense overcast collapsed, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm at 11:00 AM. The China Meteorological Administration downgraded Haishen to a severe tropical storm at 2:30 PM, followed by the Japan Meteorological Agency at 8:50 PM. At this time, Haishen had crossed Korea, moved into the Sea of Japan, and continued to move north, where sea surface temperatures were only 22–23°C.  

That evening, Haishen made landfall in North Hamgyong Province, North Korea. The China Meteorological Administration downgraded Haishen to a tropical storm at 11:25 PM, while the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center both stated that Haishen transitioned into an extratropical cyclone at 2:00 AM on September 8. The China Meteorological Administration also confirmed this at 8:00 AM, as Haishen moved into Jilin, China. The extratropical cyclone Haishen moved northwest, entering Heilongjiang, where its cloud bands and spiral structure were still identifiable on satellite images. On September 9, Haishen stalled in Heilongjiang before turning southwest and returning to Jilin, gradually weakening and dissipating over Liaoning on September 10.

PAGASA: Leon
