PAGASA: Marce  
On September 19, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern sea area of Okinotorishima, Japan, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 8 p.m. that evening, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 1:30 p.m. on September 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD14. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 14W.  
At 2 a.m. on September 21, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded 14W to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2012 and naming it "Dolphin."  
At 9 a.m. on September 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m. on the same day, the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and upgraded it, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a light typhoon.  
At 8:50 a.m. on September 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 a.m. on the same day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Dolphin had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On September 25, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. That morning, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." On the afternoon of September 26 at 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD15. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On September 27 at 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 15W. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2013, and named it "Kujira." At the same time, the China Meteorological Administration and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan respectively upgraded it to a tropical storm and a mild typhoon. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On the afternoon of September 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. On September 30 at 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for Kujira. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Kujira had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On October 1, a tropical disturbance formed in the western waters of Palau Rock Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 90W. On October 4 at 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation TD16. On October 5 at 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 16W. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2014, and named it "Chan-hom." Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 6 at 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and upgraded it. On October 7 at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the China Meteorological Administration respectively upgraded it to a moderate typhoon and a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory also followed suit and upgraded it. On October 12 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On October 17 at 5:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into a frontal system.

On October 7, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. On the evening of October 9 at 7 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 10 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD17, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 17W. At 11 AM, the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and upgraded it. At 2 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. On October 11 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2015 and naming it "Linfa." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, while the Hong Kong Observatory, the China Meteorological Administration, and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau also followed the Japan Meteorological Agency in upgrading it to a tropical storm. Later, the China Meteorological Administration announced that Linfa made landfall on the central coast of Vietnam at 11:45 AM, with a two-minute average wind speed of 20 meters per second (72 kilometers per hour) at landfall. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning, and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 12 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: On October 11, a tropical disturbance formed in the southeastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD18. The China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. The Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued the No. 1 Standby Signal and No. 1 Typhoon Signal at 8:40 PM and 10 PM, respectively. On October 12, at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 18W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2016, and named it "Nangka." At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center followed suit and upgraded it. At 3 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 13, at 5:40 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal. At 7:30 AM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued the No. 8 Northeast Typhoon Signal. At 7:40 PM that day, the Hong Kong Observatory replaced the No. 8 Northeast Gale or Storm Signal with the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal. On October 14, at 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Nangka had weakened into a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Pepito  
On October 16, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Ifalik Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W.  
At 1:30 PM on October 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium."  
At 2:00 AM on October 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD20; the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 19W; and the China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8:00 AM on October 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2017 and naming it "Saudel." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. The China Meteorological Administration, the Hong Kong Observatory, and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau all upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 PM on October 20, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration announced that Typhoon Saudel, the 17th typhoon of the year, had made landfall in Casiguran, Aurora Province, Luzon Island, Philippines, at 9:00 PM that evening as a tropical storm.  
At 2:00 PM on October 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 9:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it.  
At 8:00 AM on October 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  
At 5:00 AM on October 24, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11:00 AM on October 25, the Hong Kong Observatory further downgraded it, and Saudel became a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM that evening, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 2:00 AM on October 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. The China Meteorological Administration announced that Saudel made landfall near Dong Hoi City, Quang Binh Province, Vietnam, at 3:30 AM. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.  
Afterward, the Japan Meteorological Agency revised its peak wind speed to 65 knots (120 km/h) and adjusted its pressure to 975 hPa.

PAGASA: On October 21, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern waters of Fais Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. On October 23 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 2:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD21. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On October 24 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 21W. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. On October 25 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2018 and naming it "Molave." At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. The Hong Kong Observatory followed suit at 12:30 PM. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 5:00 PM, both the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration and the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 5:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it. On October 25 at 2:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. On October 29 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

PAGASA: Rolly  
On October 22, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters near the southeast of Enewetak Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. Initially, multiple numerical forecasts supported the development of this system, but as the environment and structure showed no significant improvement, the numerical forecasts gradually became less optimistic about its development. It was not until 8 PM on October 26 that the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  

In the early hours of October 27, the system's structure began to steadily consolidate, and its spiral characteristics became evident, prompting the Joint Typhoon Warning Center to upgrade its rating to "high" at 6 PM and issue a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the system, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD22.  

At 8 AM on October 28, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 22W. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. Three hours later, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

At 2 AM on October 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2019 and naming it "Goni." Subsequently, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. Within six hours of being named, Goni began to intensify explosively, with a cloud-wrapped eye visible on satellite imagery. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon, with wind speeds of 70 knots (130 km/h). At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. By evening, Goni began rapidly forming a central dense overcast, with the previous cloud-wrapped eye filling in and gradually transforming into a distinct eye. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon, while the Hong Kong Observatory simultaneously upgraded its central wind speed to the upper limit of 140 km/h.  

At 2 AM on October 30, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a super typhoon. Three hours later, the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit, raising its maximum wind speed to 220 km/h. This demonstrated Goni's rapid development. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 6 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency raised Goni's wind speed to 105 knots (195 km/h), marking it as the first tropical cyclone of the year to be rated as "violent." Goni surpassed Typhoon Haishen of the same year to become the strongest tropical cyclone in the Northwest Pacific in 2020.  

In the early hours of November 1, Goni reached its peak intensity. The Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory assessed Goni's maximum sustained wind speed near the center (calculated as a 10-minute average) at 120 knots (220 km/h) and 275 km/h, respectively. The former tied with Typhoon Meranti in 2016, while the latter surpassed Typhoon Megi in 2010 by 5 km/h, falling just short of Typhoon Haiyan in 2013 at 285 km/h. The China Meteorological Administration assessed Goni's central wind speed (calculated as a 2-minute average) at 68 m/s (245 km/h), 4 m/s short of Megi's 72 m/s (260 km/h). The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan assessed its central wind speed (calculated as a 10-minute average) at 65 m/s (235 km/h), tying with Megi and surpassing Haiyan's 63 m/s (225 km/h) by 2 m/s. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration assessed Goni's central wind speed (calculated as a 10-minute average) at 225 km/h, tying with Megi and falling just 10 km/h short of Haiyan's 235 km/h. Additionally, Goni became the second super typhoon in the Philippines after the 2014 update to typhoon classifications, the previous one being Typhoon Haima in 2016. The U.S. Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed Goni's central wind speed (calculated as a 1-minute average) at 170 knots (315 km/h), tying the records of Typhoon Haiyan and Meranti. The Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center both analyzed Goni's "T-index" using the Dvorak technique, finding it to be 8.0, making it the first tropical cyclone since Typhoon Haiyan in 2013 to achieve a "double T8.0" rating.  

At its peak intensity, Goni made landfall in Catanduanes Province, Philippines, at 4:50 AM on November 1, and made a second landfall in Camarines Sur Province at 7:20 AM. Due to a sharp increase in vertical wind shear and the impact of the Philippine terrain, Goni rapidly weakened after landfall, with high- and low-level separation occurring. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon, significantly reducing its wind speed from the peak of 170 knots to 130 knots. The Japan Meteorological Agency also reduced its wind speed to 90 knots. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further reduced its wind speed to 75 knots, while the Japan Meteorological Agency reduced it to 80 knots. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8 PM, the high- and low-level separation of Goni worsened, prompting the Joint Typhoon Warning Center to downgrade it to a tropical storm. Meanwhile, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm, reflecting Goni's rapid weakening from a super typhoon to a tropical storm in less than a day.  

In the early hours of November 2, Goni entered the South China Sea. At 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. However, six hours later, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it back to a tropical storm.  

At 2 PM on November 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

PAGASA: Siony  
On October 27, a tropical disturbance formed in the southwest-southwest waters of the Chuuk Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On October 29 at 1:45 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD23. At 3:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2020, and named it "Atsani." At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory directly upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On November 4, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
On November 5 at 2 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
On November 7 at 5 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan was the first to downgrade it to a tropical depression. At 5 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.  
On November 8 at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

PAGASA: Tonyo  
On November 5, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters north-northwest of the Faraulep Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. On the morning of November 7 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On November 8 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD24. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 24W. At 11 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On November 9 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2021, and named it "Etau." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. On November 10 at 2:30 p.m., Etau made landfall along the coast of Khanh Hoa Province, Vietnam. At 5 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On November 11 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency considered it to have dissipated.

PAGASA: Ulysses  
On November 8, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters south-southwest of Yap Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD25; the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
On November 9, at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2022, and named it "Vamco." At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On November 10, at 2 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 PM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
On November 11, at 5 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 10 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon. Typhoon Vamco made its first landfall near Patnanungan, Quezon Province, Philippines, at 10:30 PM, its second landfall near Burdeos, Quezon Province, at 11:20 PM, and its third landfall near General Nakar, Quezon Province, at 1:40 AM the following day.  
On November 12, at 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  
On November 13, at 6 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon again. At 11 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon again.  
On November 14, at 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  
On November 15, at 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 1:40 PM, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Vamco had made landfall along the coast of Quang Binh Province, Vietnam. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm and further downgraded it to a tropical depression six hours later.  
On November 16, at midnight, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center removed Vamco from the weather map. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

PAGASA: Vicky  
On December 17, a tropical disturbance formed in the southeastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. On December 18 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD26. On December 19 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On December 20 at 2 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 26W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2023 and naming it "Krovanh." At 5 PM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a tropical storm. On December 21 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan, and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a tropical depression. On December 22 at 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On December 25 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

PAGASA: Carina  
On July 11, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 99W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 13 at 5:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:45 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 8:00 AM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 14 at 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigned it the designation TD03, and issued a tropical depression advisory. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On July 15 at 7:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 12:45 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating to "low." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated. At 4:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating.

On July 28, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 90W. At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a subtropical depression.

PAGASA: On August 9, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters east of the Ogasawara Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 06W. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD08. On August 10, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 10 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 11, at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning issued for it. Meanwhile, 06W affected the vicinity of the Ogasawara Islands, carrying volcanic ash from Nishinoshima into its circulation, which was clearly visible in satellite imagery. As a result, this tropical depression was also referred to as the "volcanic ash low." On August 13, at 8 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. The remnants, carrying volcanic ash, continued to move westward, causing poorer air quality near Taiwan.

A low-pressure area formed in the northeastern waters near Iwo Jima on September 9, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 97W. On the morning of the 10th at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical depression. Guided by the subtropical ridge, the system moved northwestward, crossing waters with sea surface temperatures exceeding 29°C. However, it was suppressed by vertical wind shear, causing its convective cloud bands to be displaced to the northeast. Numerical forecasts predicted a low chance of development for the system. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center initially assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," upgraded it to "medium" at 9:30 p.m., and further to "high" at 11:30 p.m. on the 10th, issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert. Ultimately, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center briefly upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 5 a.m. on the 11th, designating it as tropical cyclone 12W, but issued its final warning just six hours later. On the same day, the system shifted to an east-northeastward movement at a speed of about 20 km/h. On the morning of the 13th at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that the system had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone in the waters east of Tokyo. After transitioning, the system continued moving east-northeastward, crossing the International Date Line before dissipating in the waters south of Alaska, USA.

On September 28, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northeast of the Maug Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 98W. At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 1:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "medium." On the morning of September 30 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into a frontal system. At 1:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center removed this weather system from the weather map.

PAGASA: Ofel On October 11, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. On October 13 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD19. On October 14 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On October 16 at 1:45 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating to "low" and canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert at 2 p.m. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

On October 19, a tropical disturbance formed in the southwest sea area of Palau Rock Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On October 20 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 20W. On October 21 at 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On October 23 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into a frontal system.

On the afternoon of December 5th at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that a tropical depression had formed in the sea northwest of Okinotorishima. At 2 AM on December 6th, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. By 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered it to have merged into a frontal system.

On the morning of December 29 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that a tropical depression had formed in the waters southwest of the Philippines. At 2:00 AM on December 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

Once a tropical cyclone in the Western Pacific reaches tropical storm intensity, it is named by the Typhoon Committee. These names are provided by 14 member countries or regions, each contributing 10 names, and then sorted alphabetically by the first letter of the English names of the countries. Names in blue indicate those already used this year, while unused names are shown in gray. The storm names for 2020 may overlap with some storm names from 2002, 2003, 2008, 2009, 2014, and 2015.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form in, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list rotates every four years, with only retired names being replaced. An auxiliary list is also prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2020, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This table lists all tropical cyclones that were active in the Western Pacific in 2020. The contents of this list include the intensity, duration, name, and the casualties and damage caused by the tropical cyclones. All damages are measured in US dollars. Numbers in parentheses indicate indirect deaths (such as traffic accidents or landslides, etc.).

Article_Name: 強烈熱帶風暴鯨魚 (2020年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Kujira (International designation: 2013, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP152020) is the 13th named storm of the 2020 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Kujira" was provided by Japan, meaning the constellation Cetus.

On September 25, a tropical disturbance formed in the southwestern sea area of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. That morning, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." On the afternoon of September 26 at 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD15. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. 

On September 27 at 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 15W. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2013, and named it "Kujira." At the same time, the China Meteorological Administration and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical storm and a mild typhoon, respectively. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. 

On September 28 at 5 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. 

On the afternoon of September 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. 

On September 30 at 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning on Kujira. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Kujira had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 14 of Reiwa 2 (Asian name: Chan-hom) was a typhoon that approached Japan in October 2020.

At 9 PM on October 4, a tropical depression formed, and at 9 AM on October 5, it became a typhoon south of Japan at 22 degrees 10 minutes north latitude and 139 degrees east longitude, named Chan-hom by Asia. The typhoon reached "strong" intensity at 3 PM on October 7. Subsequently, after approaching Japan, it moved southward and transformed into a tropical depression near the Ogasawara Islands at 9 AM on October 12 (according to confirmed data, it transformed into a tropical depression at 3 AM on October 12 at 30.8 degrees north latitude and 142.2 degrees east longitude). This typhoon followed an unusual path, moving southward as if making a U-turn after coming quite close to Honshu. This is believed to have been influenced by factors such as the jet stream, a mobile high-pressure system, and the Pacific high-pressure system. It is thought that the typhoon could not ride the jet stream and was pushed southward, caught between high-pressure and low-pressure systems. The European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF), headquartered in the UK, had predicted this unusual typhoon path in advance using a supercomputer.

Due to the impact of the typhoon that approached the Okinawa region, the mainland, and the Izu Islands, record-breaking heavy rain occurred in the southern Izu Islands, causing landslides in the Izu Islands and the Tokai region. In response to the typhoon's approach, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a special heavy rain warning for Miyake Village and Mikurajima Village from 5:00 PM on October 10 to midnight on October 11. The total rainfall from the start of the rain (3:00 AM on October 6 to 6:00 AM on October 11) reached 707.5 mm in Nishimi, Hachijojima, and 599.0 mm in Tsubota, Miyakejima, exceeding 1.5 times the average rainfall for the entire month of October, resulting in record-breaking heavy rain. The damage included one person seriously injured, two people slightly injured, and partial damage to five buildings.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Tonyo or Typhoon Etau is expected to make landfall, passing through the provinces of Eastern Samar, Masbate, Romblon, Aklan, Oriental Mindoro until it exits the PAR. It first made landfall in Dolores, Eastern Samar, and subsequently passed through the towns of Monreal, Masbate, Torrijos, Marinduque, and San Juan, Batangas until it exited the landmass of the Philippines, heading westward towards "Tuy Hoa, Vietnam." On November 10, 2020, Typhoon 'Tonyo' is expected to make landfall in Central Vietnam before entering Cambodia the following day.

November 7, "Tonyo" (Etau) became a full-fledged storm, slightly intensifying over the South China Sea after passing through Southern Luzon and Eastern Visayas. "Etau" left 2 dead in Quang Nam and Binh Dinh, Khan Hoa, and Phu Yen. Etau blew off roofs, uprooted trees, and damaged buildings due to strong winds. Many were still recovering from Typhoon Quinta and Super Typhoon Rolly. This added to the power supply outage affecting the city of Tuy Hoa in Vietnam.

Article_Name: 2021年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2021 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2021. Although there is no designated formation period, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to typhoons in the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2021 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (international names) with international numbers starting with 21xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter W. Any tropical depression that enters or forms within the Philippine Area of Responsibility is given a local name by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (the international name is considered official). The Chinese names of storms are currently determined through consultation among the China Meteorological Administration, the Hong Kong Observatory, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan. Before the 2020s, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, Macao, and Taiwan might have differed. The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak state during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

According to the forecast by the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau, tropical cyclone activity affecting Hainan Island during the 2021 flood season is relatively active, and the number of impacts and landfalls may be close to or exceed the annual average.

The Shenzhen Meteorological Observatory predicts that Shenzhen will experience typhoon impacts earlier in 2021, and under the background of global warming and La Niña, the risk of severe typhoon impacts is relatively high. It is expected that 5-8 typhoons will enter the 500-kilometer defense zone of Shenzhen in 2021.

The Hong Kong Observatory predicts that the typhoon season will begin by June this year or earlier, with 5 to 8 tropical cyclones expected to enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong throughout the year, which is considered normal to slightly above normal. Due to global warming, the Observatory expects the annual average temperature this year to be higher than normal, likely making it one of the 10 warmest years on record.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau predicts that about 5 to 8 tropical cyclones will affect Macao, with a normal to above-normal quantity, including possibly strong typhoons or higher levels. The typhoon season is expected to begin in early June or earlier and end around mid-October.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation announced the typhoon season outlook on June 29, predicting that the number of typhoons forming from June to December this year will be below average to normal, with the number of typhoons affecting Taiwan being within the normal range, approximately 3 to 4.

On January 20, a tropical depression was forming but lasted only a few hours. On February 16, a tropical depression formed and was named Dujuan, affecting the Philippines and Palau. In April, a rare typhoon formed in the Northwest Pacific and was named Surigae, which rapidly developed and became the third-lowest pressure tropical cyclone of the 21st century. In July, Typhoon In-fa and Typhoon Cempaka performed a "double typhoon dance," with Cempaka intensifying near the coast, while In-fa indirectly caused the July 2021 Henan floods. In September, Typhoon Chanthu formed and was repeatedly rated as a Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale; Typhoon Mindulle was nicknamed the "aesthetic typhoon" by typhoon enthusiasts. In October, Typhoons Lionrock, Kompasu, and Namtheun performed a "triple typhoon dance," with Lionrock and Kompasu successively striking the southern coast of China, while Namtheun "revived" in the open ocean and intensified to typhoon strength. Entering winter, fewer cyclones formed compared to previous years, but all named cyclones developed into super typhoons, which was very rare. Super Typhoon Nyatoh explosively intensified to a Category 4 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale in high-latitude regions; Super Typhoon Rai first explosively intensified near the Philippines and made landfall in central Philippines at peak intensity. After crossing the Philippines and entering the South China Sea, it explosively intensified again in the central South China Sea, becoming the second tropical cyclone in the South China Sea to reach Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content: PAGASA: On February 13, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Enewetak Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 2 PM on February 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 PM on February 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On February 17 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD01. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 01W. On February 18 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded it to a tropical depression and tropical storm, respectively. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2101, and named it "Dujuan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a mild typhoon and tropical storm, respectively. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On February 20 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. On February 22 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Dujuan made landfall on Batan Island. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On February 23 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

PAGASA: Bising  
On April 9, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern waters of the Elato Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W.  
At 11:30 PM on April 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium."  
At 2 PM on April 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
At 8 AM on April 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD02. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 02W. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 2 AM on April 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2102, and named it "Surigae." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 8 AM on April 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 2 AM on April 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  
At 2 AM on April 17, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon, and later at 8 AM, further upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to an intense typhoon.  
At 2 PM on April 20, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  
At 8 PM on April 22, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2 PM on April 23, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5 AM on April 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center determined that Surigae had transitioned into a subtropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5 AM on April 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Surigae had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory stated that Surigae had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
On April 27, after transitioning into an extratropical cyclone, Surigae continued to move across the Northwest Pacific and developed into an explosive cyclone, with its pressure dropping rapidly by 20 hPa from 9 PM on the 26th to 3 AM on the 27th, reaching as low as 945 hPa.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 170 knots (315 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Dante  
On May 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters south of Satawal Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W.  
At 2 PM on May 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium."  
At 2 AM on May 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 04W. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD04. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm.  
At 2 AM on May 31, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2103 and naming it "Choi-wan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8 PM on June 1, Choi-wan made landfall in Sulat, Eastern Samar, Philippines.  
At 8 AM on June 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2 PM on June 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. The Hong Kong Observatory and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan followed suit, downgrading it at 5 PM and 8 PM, respectively.  
At 8 AM on June 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm for the third time. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory stated that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and merged into a stationary front. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.  
At 2 PM on June 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

On June 10, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern waters of the Xisha Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. On the afternoon of June 11, at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD05, and the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory also followed suit in upgrading it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "medium." At 4:15 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal. At 4:30 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued the No. 1 Signal. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. 

On June 12, at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2104 and naming it "Koguma." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2:10 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory canceled the No. 1 Standby Signal. At 5:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 6:00 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals and simultaneously upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.

On June 13, at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. The China Meteorological Administration reported that Koguma made landfall along the coast of Thanh Hóa Province, Vietnam, around 7:45 AM. At 11:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan followed suit in downgrading it. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On June 18, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Pohnpei Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On June 20 at 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On June 21 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 06W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On June 22 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD06. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 23 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and revised the intensity of the previous two reports to 30 knots (55 km/h). At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2105, and named it "Champi." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 24 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On June 25 at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. On June 26 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. On June 27 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Champi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and merged into a stationary front.

PAGASA: Fabian  
On July 14, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On July 16 at 4:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 11 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 09W. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD08.  

On July 17 at 2 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 18 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2106, and named it "In-Fa." At the same time, the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory also followed suit and upgraded it. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On July 19 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 20 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory simultaneously upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  

On July 25 at 12:30 PM, In-Fa made landfall along the coast of Putuo, Zhoushan, Zhejiang Province, with maximum wind speeds near the center reaching 13 on the Beaufort scale (38 m/s) and a central minimum pressure of 965 hPa. On July 26 at 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded In-Fa to a severe tropical storm, and at 5 PM the same day, it was further downgraded to a tropical storm.  

On July 28 at 3 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 30, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On July 31, In-Fa dissipated after making landfall in Liaoning Province.

On July 16, a tropical disturbance formed in the South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. On the morning of July 17 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." On the morning of July 18 at 7 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:55 p.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued Signal No. 1. At 6 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration issued a blue typhoon warning signal. At 8 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD09. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 10W. At 9 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued Signal No. 1 at 9:40 p.m. On July 19 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2107, and named it "Cempaka." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. On July 20 at 1 a.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a typhoon. At 1:45 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On the same day at 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 21 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and downgraded it, and six hours later further downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 22 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 24 at 11 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On July 26 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.
The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its best track released on November 1, revised its peak intensity to 70 knots (130 kilometers per hour) and lowered the pressure to 980 hPa.

On July 22, a tropical disturbance formed in the northern waters of the Pajaros Rock Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On the morning of July 23 at 6 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high," issued a tropical cyclone formation alert, and classified it as a subtropical cyclone. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD10. PAGASA: On August 6, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters south-southwest of Hawaii, and the Central Pacific Hurricane Center designated it as disturbance 91C. On the evening of August 9, under the guidance of a deep subtropical high-pressure ridge to the north, the low-pressure area moved westward across the International Date Line, entering the Northwest Pacific, and the Japan Meteorological Agency took over issuing updates. On August 10 at 9:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. Due to deep convection consolidating the low-level circulation center, at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 16W. Previously, the Madden-Julian Oscillation increased atmospheric instability, leading to the formation of multiple tropical cyclones. Subsequently, as the Madden-Julian Oscillation entered the next phase, subsiding air suppressed convection activity in the Western Pacific. The absence of the southwest monsoon, intrusion of dry air, and vertical wind shear from the southwest displacing convection eastward exposed the low-level circulation center. These unfavorable factors left the system struggling to survive on sea surface temperatures of 28°C or higher. On August 13 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD14. On August 14 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression, but at 2 PM, it was upgraded again to a tropical storm. On August 15 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it again to a tropical depression, while the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On August 16 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. On August 17 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reclassified it as a tropical depression. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning and rated its remnants as "medium." On August 18 at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On August 19 at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating back to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical depression. On August 20 at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan reclassified it as a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reissued a gale warning for it. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2112, and named it "Omais." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 21 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical storm. On August 22 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 23 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At around 11:50 PM, the Korea Meteorological Administration reported that Omais made landfall near the coast of Goseong County, South Gyeongsang Province. On August 24 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Omais had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On September 1 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into a low-pressure area.

The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its best track released on December 1, 2021, downgraded its wind speed to 45 knots (85 kilometers per hour), considering it to have lost severe tropical storm intensity. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, upgraded its peak wind speed to 55 knots (100 kilometers per hour).

On September 7 at 5:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency re-upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  

On September 11 at 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.

At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8 AM on December 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 28W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2122 and naming it "Rai." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 8 AM on December 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency, the Hong Kong Observatory, and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 8 AM on December 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 12 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2 AM on December 16, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a strong typhoon. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 8 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 11 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon.  
At 2 PM on December 18, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it again to a super typhoon. At 8 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it again to a strong typhoon.  
At 2 PM on December 19, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 11 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 8 AM on December 20, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and at the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5 AM on December 21, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
At 2 PM on December 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its first peak wind speed to 150 knots (280 kilometers per hour).

At 8:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On January 20 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 08W. Once a tropical cyclone in the Western Pacific reaches tropical storm intensity, it is named by the Typhoon Committee. These names are provided by 14 member countries or regions, each contributing 10 names, and then sorted alphabetically by the English names of the countries. Names in bold black indicate those already used this year, bold names indicate active storms, unused names are shown in gray, and orange indicates the next name to be used. The storm names for 2021 may overlap with some storm names from 2003, 2004, 2009, 2010, 2015, and 2016.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form within, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list is rotated every four years, with only retired names being replaced. An auxiliary list is also prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2021, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all tropical cyclones that were active in the Western Pacific in 2021, including their intensity, duration, names, and the casualties and damage caused. All damages are measured in US dollars. Deaths in parentheses refer to indirect causes (such as traffic accidents, landslides, etc.).

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 8 of Reiwa 3 (Asian name: Nepartak [named by Micronesia, meaning: the name of a famous warrior]) is a typhoon that occurred in July 2021 and made landfall in Miyagi Prefecture for the first time in history.

At 9 PM on July 23, a developing tropical depression near Minamitorishima (formed at 9 AM on the same day) became Typhoon No. 8 and was named Nepartak. The typhoon then moved northward and proceeded northwest over the sea east of Japan. By 9 PM on the 24th, the radius of the strong wind area reached 500 km, making it a large typhoon. At this stage, it was feared that it could approach or make landfall in the Tohoku or Kanto-Koshin regions by the 27th. If it were to make landfall in areas such as Fukushima, Miyagi, or Ibaraki Prefectures, it would be the first such case since statistics began in 1951. Such a typhoon path is extremely rare, and since the start of statistics in 1951, only two typhoons had made landfall on the Pacific side of the Kanto-Tohoku region from the east: Typhoon No. 13 in 1989 (landed near Choshi City, Chiba Prefecture) and Typhoon No. 10 in 2016 (landed near Ofunato City, Iwate Prefecture). The unusual path of this typhoon was attributed to factors such as the Pacific High being located farther northeast than usual and the presence of an upper cold vortex. 

Subsequently, the typhoon gradually changed its course from northwest to west. Although it did not have a storm zone, parts of the Kanto and Tohoku regions entered the strong wind area on the night of the 26th. The typhoon temporarily moved southward and almost stalled east of Choshi City by the morning of the 27th. At this stage, parts of Hokuriku and Tokai also entered the strong wind area. During the day, it changed its course northward and moved off the southern coast of Kanto. By the night of the same day, it curved north-northwest and moved from off the coast of northern Kanto to off the coast of Sanriku. Later, before 6 AM on the 28th, it made landfall near Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture. As mentioned earlier, this was the first recorded instance of a typhoon making landfall in Miyagi Prefecture. It then moved northward through northeastern Miyagi Prefecture into Iwate Prefecture, reaching 70 km south of Morioka City by 9 AM and 80 km northeast of Akita City by noon on the same day. In the afternoon, it changed its course westward, passed through Akita Prefecture, and entered the Sea of Japan. At 3 PM on the same day, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone off the coast of Akita Prefecture.

This typhoon exhibited characteristics intermediate between a typhoon and an extratropical cyclone, such as accompanying cold air aloft, which caused strong winds and rain in areas far from the typhoon's center. On July 26, maximum wind gusts of 23.1 m/s were observed in Choshi, 16.1 m/s in Iwaki City, and 15.3 m/s in Kitaibaraki City. On the following day, July 27, a maximum wind gust of 25.8 m/s was recorded in Choshi, and Hachijojima experienced extremely heavy rainfall of 64.5 mm in one hour by 4:43 a.m., tying the record for the highest July observation. Additionally, heavy rainfall of 32.0 mm was observed in Higashishirakawa Town, Chiba Prefecture, by 1:11 a.m. that day. Later that night, active rain clouds brought strong rainfall to Minamisoma City, Fukushima Prefecture, with 21 mm of rain recorded in one hour by 8:00 p.m.
It made landfall during the Tokyo Olympics.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Gorio (International designation: Typhoon Mirinae) is a typhoon that formed within the PAR on August 4 and has no effect on the Philippines but will enhance the southwest monsoon affecting the entirety of Luzon, along with Typhoon Huaning, both crossing the northern part of the Philippines.

As a Low Pressure Area (LPA), Gorio (Mirinae) is moving in a northeast direction, traversing the Philippine Sea between Typhoon Nida and Typhoon Nepartak, both active in the Pacific Ocean in August 2021. On August 4, a weather disturbance formed in the eastern part of Taipei, Taiwan. It was spotted at a distance of (172 km; 107 mi) south-southeast of Kadena Air Base, Okinawa, Japan, with the typhoon moving northeast towards Tokyo at a slow pace.
