Article_Name: 颱風納坦 (2004年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Nock-ten (English: Typhoon Nock-ten, International Designation: 0424) is a tropical cyclone in the 2004 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Nock-ten" was provided by Laos, derived from the Lao word "ນົກເຕັນ," meaning kingfisher.

On October 13, 2004, Nock-ten formed in the Marshall Islands. Tropical Depression 28W formed 275 kilometers east-northeast of Pohnpei on October 14 and moved westward. The storm followed its original path moving west-northwest, strengthening into a tropical storm on October 16 and was named Nock-ten. On October 18, the typhoon shifted northwestward and slowed down. In the morning local time, it strengthened into a typhoon and moved westward again. Nock-ten accelerated and moved northwest, with its path passing through the area of Scorpionfish. On October 20, Nock-ten passed near Guam with a ten-minute average wind speed of 155 kilometers per hour. On October 23, Nock-ten was 480 kilometers south of Okinawa, with a one-minute average wind speed reaching 205 kilometers per hour. Moving northward, Nock-ten made landfall near Sandiaojiao in Gongliao District, New Taipei City, Taiwan, at 10:30 a.m. on October 25, and exited near Fugui Cape in Shimen District, New Taipei City, at 1:15 p.m. the same day. That evening, the storm began to weaken and moved east-northeast. Nock-ten moved into the East China Sea, maintaining a wind speed of 110 kilometers per hour. On October 26, Nock-ten transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Lotan brought heavy rain to Taiwan. On October 25 and October 27, the 24-hour rainfall in Taipei City reached 322 millimeters. During its impact on Taiwan, TTV reporter Ping Zong was swept away by floodwaters and died in the line of duty while reporting at the Keelung River. On October 24, the highest wind speed recorded in Lanyu was 54.5 meters per second (196 kilometers per hour), and three buildings collapsed.
In Japan, 133.5 mm of rainfall was recorded on Tanegashima from October 26 to October 27.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Omais (OMAIS) is the 12th typhoon that occurred in the Northwest Pacific in 2021, and its name, submitted by the United States, means "wandering around."[1] It was the first typhoon to make landfall on the Korean Peninsula in 2021.[2]

Typhoon Omais formed as a tropical storm with a central pressure of 1,004 hPa, maximum wind speed of 18 m/s, and a gale radius of 110 km at 9 PM on August 20, approximately 850 km south-southeast of Okinawa, Japan (based on the Japan Meteorological Agency's typhoon information). After formation, it moved north-northwest to northwest and developed, reaching its peak as a strong tropical storm with a central pressure of 996 hPa and maximum wind speed of 26 m/s at 9 AM on August 22, approximately 330 km southwest of Okinawa, Japan. After its peak, it moved into the East China Sea and rapidly weakened due to strong vertical shear, passing through Jeju Island. Shortly after, it made landfall in Gwangdo-myeon, Tongyeong City, Gyeongsangnam-do, at 12 AM on August 24 with a central pressure of 998 hPa and maximum wind speed of 18 m/s, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency. According to the Korea Meteorological Administration, it made landfall in Goseong County, Gyeongsangnam-do, at 11:50 PM on August 23 with a central pressure of 996 hPa and maximum wind speed of 18 m/s. It then moved out to the East Sea from Pohang City, Gyeongsangbuk-do, at around 2:50 AM on August 24, according to the Korea Meteorological Administration, and at 3 AM on August 24, according to the Japan Meteorological Agency. Moving rapidly northeast, it underwent extratropical transition, becoming an extratropical cyclone with a central pressure of 996 hPa at around 6 AM on August 24, approximately 60 km southwest of Ulleungdo (in the East Sea), according to the Korea Meteorological Administration. According to the Japan Meteorological Agency, it became an extratropical cyclone with a central pressure of 998 hPa at 9 AM on August 24, approximately 56 km northeast of Ulleungdo (in the East Sea).

Typhoon Omais was the first typhoon to directly affect South Korea in 2021. According to the Korea Meteorological Administration on the 24th, Typhoon Omais had a central pressure of 996 hPa, maximum wind speeds of 18-19 m/s, and a wind radius of 110 km, classifying it as a relatively small typhoon, but it brought heavy rain and strong winds. In the southern regions affected by the typhoon, torrential rain of up to 100 mm per hour caused flooding on roads and other damages. The areas most affected were Gyeongsangnam-do, Ulsan Metropolitan City, and Busan Metropolitan City, with Jeollanam-do and Gyeongsangbuk-do also suffering significant damage. Overall, it was a rain-heavy typhoon with more damage caused by rain than by wind. No injuries or fatalities were reported due to the typhoon.

Article_Name: 2015年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content:
The 2015 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2015. Although no official timeframe was set for this typhoon season, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. In 2015, tropical storms formed in this region every month, marking the first time this occurred since the Japan Meteorological Agency began keeping records. 

This article is limited to the Pacific Ocean and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are referred to as hurricanes and are included in the 2015 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that formed in the Northwest Pacific were named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (international names) with international identification numbers starting with 15xx, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assigned tropical depressions in this region identification numbers ending with the letter W.

Any tropical depressions that entered or formed within the Philippine Area of Responsibility were given local names by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) for local warning purposes, which could result in two different English names (with the international name being the official one). Additionally, since Hong Kong, Macau, and mainland China use the same Chinese translations, while Taiwan may use different Chinese translations, a single storm could have two different Chinese names. The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak intensity during its existence.

The tropical cyclones of the 2015 season were notably stronger, making it the season with the most super typhoons (13 in total) since the Hong Kong Observatory adopted a new tropical cyclone classification system in 2009, which added the categories of "severe typhoon" and "super typhoon." It was also the first season to have four super typhoons before June.

The Director of the Hong Kong Observatory (HKO), Shun Chi-ming, stated at a press briefing held by the Observatory on March 23 that 4 to 7 tropical cyclones are expected to enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong during the year, which is considered a normal level. He also mentioned that the typhoon season might begin in June or later. The Observatory planned to extend the forecast period for tropical cyclone tracks from 3 days to 5 days during the typhoon season of that year. However, the Director noted that due to the erratic movement of some tropical cyclones, the 5-day forecast would still have significant errors. On June 20, following the formation of Tropical Storm Kujira, the Observatory implemented the 5-day tropical cyclone track forecast. Affected by the El Niño phenomenon, after Typhoon Linfa directly hit Hong Kong in early July, there were nearly three months without any tropical cyclones affecting Hong Kong until early October, when Severe Typhoon Mujigae ended this rare lull. This not only marked the second consecutive year without storms hitting Hong Kong in August but also made it the first typhoon season since records began in 1946 where no storms affected Hong Kong in both August and September. As a result, on August 22, the Hong Kong Observatory revised the expected number of tropical cyclones entering the 500-kilometer range to 3 to 6, which is considered normal to slightly below normal.

The Acting Director of the Meteorological Monitoring Center of the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau (Portuguese: SMG), Wong Chan Sing, stated during a meeting on April 14 that it is predicted that 4 to 6 tropical cyclones will affect Macao within the year, with at least one possibly leading to the issuance of a No. 8 typhoon signal. The first tropical cyclone is expected to appear in mid-June. The Macao Meteorological Bureau will use the electronic display screen outside the Barrier Gate Building to release warnings about tropical cyclones, heavy rain, or storm surges.

The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) of the Ministry of Transportation held a typhoon outlook press conference on June 30, predicting that 2 to 4 typhoons would hit Taiwan during the summer, which is within the normal range. Affected by the El Niño-Southern Oscillation phenomenon, typhoons are expected to develop further east, and higher sea surface temperatures may result in stronger typhoons, all of which are expected to be at least moderate typhoons. Authorities also predict that the likelihood of typhoons affecting Taiwan is higher in summer than in autumn.

According to the "Overview of Marine Disasters in the South China Sea in 2014 and Outlook for Marine Disasters in 2015" published by the National Marine Environmental Forecasting Center of the State Oceanic Administration on May 19, 2015, the number of typhoon wave events in the Northwest Pacific and South China Sea regions during the year is predicted to be slightly below the annual average, approximately 23 to 25 times. The number of typhoon wave events in the South China Sea region throughout the year is expected to be close to the annual average, about 8 to 10 times. At the same time, the report predicts that 3 to 4 typhoon wave events will severely affect the coastal areas of Guangdong, Guangxi, and Hainan during the year, with 2 to 3 of these events severely impacting the Guangdong coast. Additionally, during the period from July to September, 1 to 2 strong typhoons or super typhoons may bring disastrous wave events to South China. The first typhoon wave event affecting the South China coast may occur from late June to early July, slightly later than the annual average, while the last typhoon wave event affecting the South China coast may occur from late September to early October, slightly earlier than the annual average. [4] 

Furthermore, according to the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau's forecast on May 23, during the flood season (May to October) of that year, 3 to 4 tropical cyclones are expected to affect Hainan Island, 2 fewer than the annual average. One tropical cyclone is expected to make landfall on Hainan Island, 1 fewer than the annual average. The intensity of tropical cyclones affecting Hainan Province is expected to be stronger than the annual average. The first tropical cyclone affecting Hainan Island may occur in mid-July, and the last one may occur in late October. [5] The Haikou Meteorological Bureau also predicted on May 26 that 3 to 4 tropical cyclones would affect Haikou City during the year, with 1 to 2 causing severe impacts or making landfall in Haikou City. [6]

The Philippines' PAGASA predicts that the number of tropical cyclones reaching typhoon strength (118 km/h or above) within the year will increase due to the El Niño phenomenon. [7] The agency also forecasts that 11-16 tropical cyclones will enter the Philippine Area of Responsibility from June to December this year. [8]

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content: On January 2, 2015, the leeward low pressure of Tropical Storm Jangmi developed over the sea northwest of Sabah. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly gave it a "MEDIUM" rating for the chance of forming into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." On January 3 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and downgraded its rating to "LOW." On January 4 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center removed its rating. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Amang On January 9, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southwest of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 7 PM on January 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." At 7:30 AM on January 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Mekkhala. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 01W. At 8 AM on January 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM on January 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 AM on January 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 5 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM on January 18, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 AM on January 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 AM on January 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered Mekkhala to have gradually dissipated. Mekkhala was the first named storm to form in the Northwest Pacific this year. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Mekkhala's intensity was revised downward to a severe tropical storm, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 60 knots, and the central minimum pressure revised upward to 975 hPa.

On February 4, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea near Kosrae, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 8 a.m. on February 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 8 p.m. on February 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 6:30 a.m. on February 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 02W. At 2 a.m. on February 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Higos. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on February 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Higos' intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2 a.m. on February 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its intensity to a Category 1 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale, but this downgrade was later canceled. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale, and later revised it to a Category 4 typhoon. At 5 a.m. on February 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly downgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 2 a.m. on February 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On February 13 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Higos had merged into a frontal system. Higos was once the strongest tropical cyclone in February in the Northern Hemisphere on record by the Japan Meteorological Agency, but this record was broken by Typhoon Wutip in 2019. In the best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency afterward, Higos' intensity was revised downward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 90 knots and the minimum central pressure revised upward to 940 hPa.

PAGASA: Betty  
On March 6, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Kiribati, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On the morning of March 9 at 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On the afternoon of March 10 at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical depression. On the morning of March 11 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 1:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 03W.  

On March 12 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Bavi. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical storm. On March 17 at 11:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration classified Bavi, which had entered its area of responsibility, as a tropical storm and named it Betty, issuing the first tropical cyclone advisory. At 8:00 PM on March 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. On March 18 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final advisory. On March 19 at 5:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration downgraded it to a low-pressure area and issued the final (fifth) tropical cyclone advisory. On March 23 at 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered Bavi to have gradually dissipated.

PAGASA: Chedeng Maysak was once the strongest tropical cyclone in the Northern Hemisphere on record from January to April, with its maximum sustained wind speed near the center and central pressure surpassing the record of Typhoon Andy in 1989. However, this record was broken by Typhoon Surigae in 2021. Maysak was also one of the tropical cyclones recorded by the Japan Meteorological Agency to reach the "violent" typhoon classification in March and April. According to the Hong Kong Observatory's classification, Maysak was the second tropical cyclone of the year to reach the super typhoon level (the first being Typhoon Higos in February), indicating that it was the first season since the Hong Kong Observatory introduced the new tropical cyclone classification system in 2009, adding the "severe typhoon" and "super typhoon" levels, to have two super typhoons appear before or in April. Although Maysak's movement path followed the "westward" storm pattern typical of the Northwest Pacific typhoon season, moving from the Northwest Pacific through the Philippines into the South China Sea, this path generally occurs from June to October. Maysak taking this path in April was extremely rare. As a result, Maysak became the first storm since Typhoon Neoguri in 2008 to enter the northern South China Sea in April. At that time, the environment in the South China Sea was unfavorable for tropical cyclone development, and Maysak was ultimately weakened and dissipated in the northern South China Sea under the influence of the northeast monsoon, a situation similar to tropical cyclones entering the northern South China Sea in November.

On March 30, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea southeast of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 2:00 PM on March 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 7:30 AM on April 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8:00 AM on April 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 05W. At 8:00 AM on April 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Haishen. At 2:00 AM on April 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.

PAGASA: Dodong  
On April 30, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the waters near Chuuk, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
At 3 AM on May 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it.  
At 8 AM on May 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 06W.  
At 2 AM on May 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Noul. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2 AM on May 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 8 AM on May 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Noul's intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson scale.  
At 8 AM on May 9, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center temporarily downgraded Noul's intensity to 95 knots, equivalent to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson scale, but at 2 PM, it was upgraded again to 105 knots. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Noul's intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson scale.  
At 2 AM on May 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Noul's intensity to a Category 5 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson scale.  
At 2 AM on May 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 8 AM on May 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 5 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Noul had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
In the best track analysis released afterward by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Noul's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained winds near the center adjusted to 110 knots, but the minimum central pressure was revised upward to 920 hPa.

On May 3, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 8 a.m. on May 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 10:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." At 2 p.m. on May 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 2 a.m. on May 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 07W. At 8 p.m. on May 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m. on May 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Dolphin. At 8 a.m. on May 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 a.m. on May 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Dolphin's intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2 a.m. on May 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 2 a.m. on May 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 5 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m. on May 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm and issued its final warning. At 8 a.m. on May 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on May 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Dolphin had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On June 18, 2015, a low-pressure area formed within a monsoon trough in the central South China Sea. At 8 a.m., the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. On June 19 at 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "MEDIUM." On June 20 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 08W. On June 21 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Kujira. On June 22 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 23 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it back to a tropical storm. On June 24 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it again to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. On June 25 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency considered Kujira to have gradually dissipated. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Kujira's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 45 knots.

PAGASA: Falcon  
On June 25, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Kosrae. At 12:00 noon, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 9:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW."  
On June 27, at 5:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system's rating to "MEDIUM."  
On June 30, at 6:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for the system and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 8:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 09W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Chan-hom.  
On July 1, at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On July 2, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 11:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon.  
On July 3, at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On July 6, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again upgraded it to a typhoon.  
On July 7, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a typhoon.  
On July 8, at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Chan-hom's intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale.  
On July 9, at 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale.  
On July 10, at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale.  
On July 12, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On July 13, at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Chan-hom had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Egay  
On June 30, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northwest of Palau. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. On July 1 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the chance of the system developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its assessment to "MEDIUM." On July 2 at 1:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert for the system and upgraded its assessment to "HIGH." At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 10W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Linfa. On July 3 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 5 at 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 7 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a severe tropical storm. On July 9 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 10 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Linfa had gradually dissipated. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Linfa's intensity was revised downward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center adjusted to 50 knots, and the minimum central pressure revised upward to 980 hPa.

On July 1, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the southeastern waters of the Marshall Islands. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On July 3 at 7 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system's rating to "MEDIUM." At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and upgraded its rating to "HIGH." At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 11W. On July 4 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Chan-hom. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 5 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 6 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. On July 7 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Chan-hom's intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On July 9 at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. On July 10 at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon. On July 12 at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again upgraded its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On July 13 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again upgraded its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On July 17 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 18 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On July 19 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Chan-hom had merged into a frontal system.

PAGASA: Goring On the morning of July 13, 2015, at 5:00 AM, Halola, located in the central North Pacific, crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific region, and was subsequently monitored by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA). At 8:20 AM, the JMA classified it as a severe tropical storm, retaining the Central Pacific name Halola. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) classified it as a tropical storm. On July 14, at 8:00 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the JTWC also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the JTWC further upgraded Halola's intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On July 16, at 11:00 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 17, at 2:00 AM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 18, at 8:00 AM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 19, at 2:00 PM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it. On July 20, at 8:00 AM, the JMA re-upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the JMA re-upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 21, at 8:00 AM, the JMA re-upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the JTWC re-upgraded it to a typhoon. On July 23, at 2:00 AM, the JTWC again upgraded its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On July 24, at 2:00 AM, the JTWC downgraded its intensity to a Category 1 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. On July 25, at 2:00 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 6:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 26, at 5:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression. Simultaneously, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical depression and issued its final warning. On July 27, at 8:00 AM, the JMA determined that Halola had gradually dissipated.

PAGASA: Hanna  
On July 28, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of the Marshall Islands. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. On July 29 at 6:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2:00 PM, the rating was upgraded to "MEDIUM." At 10:30 PM, the rating was further upgraded to "HIGH," and a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert was issued.  

On July 30 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 13W. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Soudelor. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On August 2 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 2 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale.  

On August 3 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 3 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 4 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon.  

On August 4 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its intensity to a Category 5 typhoon under the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale.  

On August 5 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a typhoon.  

On August 8 at 4:40 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan reported that Soudelor made landfall at the mouth of the Liwu River in Xiulin Township, Hualien County, Taiwan.  

On August 9 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm and issued its final warning. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On August 11 at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Soudelor had merged with a front and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On August 5, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea east of the Northern Mariana Islands. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." On August 6, at 6:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the rating to "MEDIUM." At 1:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded the rating to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the system. On August 7, at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 15W. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Molave. On August 8, at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 9, at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a subtropical depression and issued its final warning. On August 11, at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical storm and resumed issuing advisories, with a maximum one-minute average wind speed of 45 knots, later adjusted to 50 knots. On August 14, at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final advisory. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Molave had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

At 2:00 PM on September 1, 2015, Kilo crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific Ocean from the Central North Pacific, and the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) took over issuing advisories. PAGASA: Nona  
A low-pressure area formed approximately 120 kilometers south of Chuuk State on the evening of December 7, 2015, and moved west-northwest along the deep easterly winds on the southern side of the subtropical ridge. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the low-pressure area to a tropical depression at 8 a.m. on December 9. Although the Northwest Pacific experienced over half a month of inactivity after Typhoon In-fa in November, with sea surface temperatures rising above 28 degrees Celsius, restoring a significant energy supply, the system's initial development was slow and disorganized due to strong vertical wind shear. By December 10, as wind shear weakened and upper-level divergence strengthened, the system began to develop deep convection, and a low-level circulation center formed. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the system at 8:45 p.m., predicting it would strengthen into a tropical storm within a day. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for the system at 1:30 p.m. the following day (December 11). However, half an hour later, the Japan Meteorological Agency officially upgraded the system to a tropical storm, naming it Melor and assigning it the international designation 1527. At that time, Melor was located approximately 50 kilometers south of Yap Island. This led the Hong Kong Observatory, which had not previously mentioned the system, to suddenly announce at 4:15 p.m. that "the low-pressure area in the Northwest Pacific has intensified into a tropical depression and has been named Melor." The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded Melor in two consecutive advisories, first classifying it as a tropical depression at 11 p.m. and assigning it the tropical cyclone number 28W, then upgrading it to a tropical storm at 5 a.m. on December 12. The Hong Kong Observatory followed suit at 9:45 a.m.

On December 14, Typhoon Melor made landfall in the Philippines.  
On December 17, Melor transitioned into a low-pressure area.

In addition to tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones assessed as tropical storms by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.

On June 23, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea near Chuuk. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 2 PM on June 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 2 PM on June 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its assessment. At 1 AM on June 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "LOW." At 10:30 AM on June 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system's assessment to "MEDIUM." At 8 PM on July 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM on July 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had merged into the cloud system of Typhoon Chan-hom.

On July 14, 2015, a tropical disturbance formed over the sea east of Luzon. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated. On July 15, its residual cloud system redeveloped over the sea northeast of Luzon. At 5 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 8 p.m. on July 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had merged into the cloud system of Typhoon Nangka.

On July 18, 2015, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Kume Island. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7 a.m. on July 19, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 9 a.m. on July 20, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory canceled the designation. At 2 a.m. on July 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On July 18, 2015, a low-pressure area formed within a low-pressure trough in inland Guangdong. At 11 a.m. on July 20, the Central Meteorological Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression, internally numbered TD02, with a maximum central wind speed of 15 meters per second (54 kilometers per hour). At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Central Meteorological Observatory determined that the tropical depression was approaching the coastal area of Yangjiang, with a maximum central wind speed of 13 meters per second (47 kilometers per hour), and ceased numbering it. At 11 a.m. on July 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On July 23, 2015, a low-pressure area formed near the eastern coast of Luzon. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 12W. On July 24 at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 25 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning on the system. On July 26 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On August 1, 2015, a high-altitude cold vortex over the southeastern sea of Honshu transformed into a tropical disturbance. At 1:00 PM, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the designation 95W. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "MEDIUM." On August 2 at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "HIGH" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 14W. On August 4 at 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On August 6 at 5:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.

On October 7, 2015, at 1:30 AM, 08C in the central Pacific crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific region, and thus came under the jurisdiction of the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA). At 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical depression. On October 9, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.
PAGASA: Onyok

On December 20, 2015, the leeward low pressure of Tropical Depression 29W developed over the sea west of Sabah. On the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On December 24 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that the tropical depression had gradually dissipated.
The following timeline lists the formation and dissipation times of typhoons for this year, and details of each storm can be found in the sections above.

Tropical cyclones formed in the Northwest Pacific region are named by the Japan Typhoon Center (i.e., international naming). Once the tropical cyclone is upgraded to a tropical storm by the Japan Meteorological Agency, names from the following list are used. The names are determined based on the list below and are not divided by year. Storm names are provided by members of the World Meteorological Organization's Typhoon Committee, with each of the 14 member countries and regions submitting five names, arranged alphabetically by the English name of the country. In the list of names used in 2015, five names were replaced: the new names "Barijat," "Mun," "Lan," "Bailu," and "Yun-yeung" replaced "Utor," "Fitow," "Vicente," "Haiyan," and "Lingling," respectively. Storm names in 2015 may overlap with some storm names from 2002-2003 and 2008-2009. Note:

At the 48th session of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee, it was decided to retire the 13th named tropical cyclone of the season, "Soudelor," and the 22nd named tropical cyclone of the season, "Mujigae," due to the significant damage caused by the typhoons in mainland China and Taiwan. It was also decided to retire the 24th named tropical cyclone of the season, "Koppu," and the 27th named tropical cyclone of the season, "Melor," due to the significant damage caused by the typhoons in the Philippines.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form in, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list is rotated every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2015, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all typhoons that were active in the Northwest Pacific in 2015. It includes the typhoon's intensity, duration, name, landfall locations, death toll, and total damages. All damages are measured in US dollars. The storm names in parentheses are the local names used by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration; unnamed tropical depressions are identified using storm numbers provided by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The formula for calculating ACE:

∑ v_max^2 / 10^4

Data is taken every 6 hours, with the unit being 10^4 kt^2. [33]

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Namtheun, on October 8, was located 289 nmi (535 km; 333 mi) from Wake Island starting from a small circulation. Later, the JMA recognized it as a full Tropical Depression on October 9. By October 10, Namtheun became a full storm currently rotating in the Pacific Ocean at a distance of 337 nmi (624 km; 388 mi) in the direction of Enewetak Atoll, with wind speeds of 35 knots (65 km/h; 40 mph), gusts up to 50 knots (95 km/h; 60 mph), a 1-minute sustained wind of 30 knots (55 km/h; 35 mph), and a pressure of 1000 hPa (29.53 inHg).
The JTWC launched from the formation of the storm on October 11 when it became a full-fledged storm and was named Namtheun as its international name.
