Article_Name: 2021年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2021 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2021. Although there is no specific formation period, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to typhoons in the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2021 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (international names) with international numbers starting with 21xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter W. Any tropical depression that enters or forms within the Philippine Area of Responsibility is given a local name by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (the international name is considered official). The Chinese names for storms are currently determined through consultation among the China Meteorological Administration, the Hong Kong Observatory, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau, and the Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation. Before the 2020s, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan might have differed. The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak form during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

According to the forecast by the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau, tropical cyclone activity affecting Hainan Island during the 2021 flood season is relatively active, and the number of impacts and landfalls may be close to or exceed the annual average.

The Shenzhen Meteorological Observatory predicts that Shenzhen will experience typhoon impacts earlier in 2021, and under the background of global warming and La Niña, the risk of severe typhoon impacts is relatively high. It is expected that 5-8 typhoons will enter the 500-kilometer defense zone of Shenzhen in 2021.

The Hong Kong Observatory predicts that the typhoon season will begin by June this year or earlier, with 5 to 8 tropical cyclones expected to enter within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong throughout the year, which is considered normal to slightly above normal. Due to global warming, the Observatory expects the annual average temperature this year to be higher than normal, likely making it one of the 10 warmest years on record.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau predicts that about 5 to 8 tropical cyclones will affect Macao, with a normal to above-normal quantity, including possibly strong typhoons or higher levels. The typhoon season is expected to start in early June or earlier and end around mid-October.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation announced the typhoon season outlook on June 29, predicting that the number of typhoons forming from June to December this year will be below average to normal, with the number of typhoons affecting Taiwan being within the normal range, approximately 3 to 4.

On January 20, a tropical depression was forming but lasted only a few hours. On February 16, a tropical depression formed and was named Dujuan, affecting the Philippines and Palau. In April, a rare typhoon formed in the Northwest Pacific and was named Surigae. Surigae rapidly developed and became the third-lowest pressure tropical cyclone of the 21st century. In July, Typhoon In-fa and Typhoon Cempaka performed a "double typhoon dance," with Cempaka intensifying near the coast, while In-fa indirectly caused the July 2021 Henan floods. In September, Typhoon Chanthu formed and was repeatedly rated as a Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, while Typhoon Mindulle was nicknamed the "aesthetic typhoon" by typhoon enthusiasts. In October, Typhoons Lionrock, Kompasu, and Namtheun performed a "triple typhoon dance," with Lionrock and Kompasu successively striking the southern coast of China, while Namtheun "revived" in the open ocean and intensified to typhoon strength. Entering winter, fewer cyclones formed compared to previous years, but all named cyclones developed into super typhoons, which was very rare. Super Typhoon Nyatoh explosively intensified to Category 4 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale in high-latitude regions, while Super Typhoon Rai first explosively intensified near the Philippines and made landfall in central Philippines at peak intensity. After crossing the Philippines and entering the South China Sea, it explosively intensified again in the central South China Sea, becoming the second tropical cyclone in the South China Sea to reach Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content: PAGASA: On February 13, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of the Ulithi Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 2 PM on February 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 PM on February 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On February 17 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD01. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 01W. On February 18 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded it to a tropical depression and tropical storm, respectively. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2101, and named it "Dujuan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a mild typhoon and tropical storm, respectively. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On February 20 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. On February 22 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Dujuan made landfall on Batan Island. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On February 23 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

PAGASA: Bising  
On April 9, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern waters of the Elato Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 11:30 PM on April 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2 PM on April 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 AM on April 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD02. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 02W. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  

At 2 AM on April 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2102 and naming it "Surigae." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

At 8 AM on April 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  

At 2 AM on April 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  

At 2 AM on April 17, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon, and later at 8 AM, further upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to an intense typhoon.  

At 2 PM on April 20, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  

At 8 PM on April 22, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  

At 2 PM on April 23, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm.  

At 5 AM on April 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center determined that Surigae had transitioned into a subtropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  

At 5 AM on April 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Surigae had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory stated that Surigae had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  

On April 27, after transitioning into an extratropical cyclone, Surigae continued to move across the Northwest Pacific and developed into an explosive cyclone. From 9 PM on the 26th to 3 AM on the 27th, its pressure dropped rapidly by 20 hPa, reaching as low as 945 hPa.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 170 knots (315 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Dante  
On May 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters south of Satawal Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W.  
At 2 PM on May 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium."  
At 2 AM on May 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 04W. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD04. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm.  
At 2 AM on May 31, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2103 and naming it "Choi-wan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8 PM on June 1, Choi-wan made landfall in Sulat, Eastern Samar, Philippines.  
At 8 AM on June 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2 PM on June 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. The Hong Kong Observatory and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan followed suit, downgrading it at 5 PM and 8 PM, respectively.  
At 8 AM on June 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm for the third time. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory stated that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and merged into a stationary front. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.  
At 2 PM on June 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

On June 10, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern waters of the Xisha Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. On the afternoon of June 11, at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD05. The China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory also followed suit in upgrading it. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "medium." At 4:15 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal. At 4:30 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued the No. 1 Signal. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.

On June 12, at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2104 and naming it "Koguma." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2:10 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory canceled the No. 1 Standby Signal. At 5:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 6:00 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals and simultaneously upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.

On June 13, at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. The China Meteorological Administration reported that Koguma made landfall along the coast of Thanh Hóa Province, Vietnam, around 7:45 AM. At 11:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan followed suit. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On June 18, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Pohnpei Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On June 20 at 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On June 21 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 06W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On June 22 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD06. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 23 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression and revised the intensity of the previous two reports to 30 knots (55 km/h). At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2105, and named it "Champi." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. On June 24 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On June 25 at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. On June 26 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. On June 27 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Champi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone and merged into a stationary front.

PAGASA: Fabian  
On July 14, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On July 16 at 4:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 11 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 09W. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD08.  

On July 17 at 2 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 18 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2106, and named it "In-Fa." At the same time, the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory also followed suit and upgraded it. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On July 19 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 20 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory simultaneously upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  

On July 25 at 12:30 PM, In-Fa made landfall along the coast of Putuo, Zhoushan, Zhejiang Province, with maximum wind speeds near the center reaching 13 on the Beaufort scale (38 m/s) and a central minimum pressure of 965 hPa. On July 26 at 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded In-Fa to a severe tropical storm, and at 5 PM the same day, it was further downgraded to a tropical storm.  

On July 28 at 3 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 30, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On July 31, In-Fa dissipated after making landfall in Liaoning Province.

On July 16, a tropical disturbance formed in the South China Sea, and the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. On the morning of July 17 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." On the morning of July 18 at 7 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:55 p.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued Signal No. 1. At 6 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration issued a blue typhoon warning signal. At 8 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD09. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 10W. At 9 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued Signal No. 1 at 9:40 p.m. 

On July 19 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2107, and named it "Cempaka." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. 

On July 20 at 1 a.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a typhoon. At 1:45 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On the same day at 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. 

On July 21 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and downgraded it, and six hours later further downgraded it to a tropical depression. 

On July 22 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. 

On July 24 at 11 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. 

On July 26 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.
The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its best track released on November 1, revised its peak intensity to 70 knots (130 kilometers per hour) and lowered the pressure to 980 hPa.

On July 22, a tropical disturbance formed in the northern waters of the Pajaros Rock Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On the morning of July 23 at 6 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high," issued a tropical cyclone formation alert, and classified it as a subtropical cyclone. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD10. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2108, and named it "Nepartak." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. On July 28 at 5 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Nepartak made landfall in Ishinomaki City, Miyagi Prefecture. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Nepartak had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, downgraded its peak wind speed to 40 knots (75 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Huaning  
On August 2, a tropical disturbance formed in the Gulf of Tonkin, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." At 9 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
On August 3 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On August 4 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2109, and named it "Lupit."  
On August 5 at 11:20 AM, the China National Meteorological Center announced that Lupit made landfall in Nan'ao County, Shantou City, Guangdong Province. At 4:50 PM, the China National Meteorological Center announced that Lupit made landfall again in Dongshan County, Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province.  
On August 8 at 8:44 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it made landfall in Makurazaki City, Kagoshima Prefecture, Kyushu.  
On August 9 at 5:39 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it made landfall again in Kure City, Hiroshima Prefecture, Chugoku region. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Lupit had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
On August 16 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency concluded that it had merged into a stationary front.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, downgraded its peak wind speed to 45 knots (85 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Gorio  
On July 31, a tropical disturbance formed near the eastern coast of Taiwan, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On August 2 at 6 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 4 at 2 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD12. At 4 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 14W. On August 5 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2110, and named it "Ginga." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Hong Kong Observatory respectively upgraded it to a mild typhoon and a tropical depression. On August 6 at 12 p.m., Ginga absorbed tropical depression 12W. On August 10 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Ginga had transformed into an extratropical cyclone. On August 14 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its best track released on November 10, adjusted the peak of Galaxy to 50 knots (95 km/h). The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, adjusted its peak wind speed to 55 knots (100 km/h).

On August 1, a tropical disturbance formed near the waters northwest of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 99W. At 12:00 noon on August 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 15W. At 8:00 p.m. on August 4, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:00 a.m. on August 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2111, and named it "Nida." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a mild typhoon and a tropical storm, respectively. At 2:00 a.m. on August 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 a.m. on August 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Nida had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 8:00 a.m. on August 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.
The Japan Meteorological Agency, in the best track released on November 10, upgraded Nida's peak to 55 knots (100 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: On August 6, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters south-southwest of Hawaii, and the Central Pacific Hurricane Center designated it as disturbance 91C. On the evening of August 9, under the guidance of a deep subtropical high-pressure ridge to the north, the low-pressure area moved westward across the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific, where the Japan Meteorological Agency took over issuing updates. On August 10 at 9:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. Due to deep convection consolidating the low-level circulation center, at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 16W. Previously, the Madden-Julian Oscillation increased atmospheric instability, leading to the formation of multiple tropical cyclones. Subsequently, as the Madden-Julian Oscillation entered its next phase, subsiding airflows suppressed convection activity in the Western Pacific. The absence of the southwest monsoon, intrusion of dry air, and vertical wind shear from the southwest displacing convection eastward exposed the low-level circulation center. These unfavorable factors left the system struggling to survive on sea surface temperatures of 28°C or higher. On August 13 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD14. On August 14 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression but upgraded it back to a tropical storm at 2 PM. On August 15 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it again to a tropical depression, while the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On August 16 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. On August 17 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reclassified it as a tropical depression. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning and rated its remnants as "medium." On August 18 at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On August 19 at 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating back to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical depression. On August 20 at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan reclassified it as a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reissued a gale warning for it. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2112, and named it "Omais." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 21 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a tropical storm. On August 22 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 23 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At around 11:50 PM, the Korea Meteorological Administration reported that Omais made landfall near the coast of Goseong County, South Gyeongsang Province. On August 24 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Omais had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On September 1 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into a low-pressure area.

The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its best track released on December 1, 2021, downgraded its wind speed to 45 knots (85 kilometers per hour), considering it to have lost severe tropical storm intensity. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, upgraded its peak wind speed to 55 knots (100 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Jolina  
On September 5, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. On September 6 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 7 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 18W. Simultaneously, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2113, and named it "Conson." At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, China Meteorological Administration, Hong Kong Observatory, and Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical storm; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Conson made its first landfall in Hernani, Eastern Samar.  

On September 7 at 5 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency re-upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  

On September 11 at 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On September 12 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory followed suit and downgraded it.  

On September 13 at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.  

On September 14 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

PAGASA: On September 2, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea north-northwest of Chuuk Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. On September 6 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 7 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD16. At 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 19W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it.  

On September 7 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2114 and naming it "Chanthu." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 5 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 11 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon.  

On September 8 at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon, with its maximum wind speed rapidly increasing to 240 km/h, indicating its rapid intensification. At 8 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a severe typhoon.  

On September 10 at 5:30 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a sea typhoon warning for it. At 5:30 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a land typhoon warning for it.  

On September 12 at 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8:30 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan lifted the land typhoon warning for it.  

On September 13 at 2:30 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan lifted the sea typhoon warning for it. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  

On September 14 at 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  

On September 16 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  

On September 17 at 6:56 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Chanthu made landfall near Fukutsu City, Fukuoka Prefecture. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On September 18 at 12:22 a.m., it made a second landfall in Matsuyama City, Ehime Prefecture, Shikoku. At 6:24 a.m., it made a third landfall in Arida City, Wakayama Prefecture. At 8 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Chanthu had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  

On September 20 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.

On September 21, a tropical disturbance formed in the western waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 5:00 PM on September 22, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center skipped issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert and directly upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 21W. At 2:00 AM on September 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD19. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2115 and naming it "Dianmu." Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 AM on September 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. Early in the morning, the Vietnam Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center reported that Dianmu made landfall along the coast of Quang Nam Province. At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Hong Kong Observatory also downgraded it. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 11:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8:00 PM on September 25, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

On September 21, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern waters of the Hall Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 99W. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On September 22, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD18. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 20W. On September 23, at 5 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2116 and naming it "Dandelion." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 24, at 5 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On September 25, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. On September 26, at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon, and at 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a severe typhoon. On September 27, at 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On September 28, at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. On September 29, at 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan once again upgraded it to a severe typhoon. On September 30, at 2 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan once again downgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On October 2, at 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan announced that Dandelion had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On October 8, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on August 5, 2022, downgraded its peak wind speed to 140 knots (260 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Lannie  
On October 2, a tropical disturbance formed in the northern waters of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W.  
At 2:00 AM on October 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 6:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
At 2:00 AM on October 4, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration first upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 6:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and downgraded its rating to "medium." At 10:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again upgraded its rating to "high" and reissued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert.  
At 2:00 PM on October 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8:00 AM on October 6, the China Meteorological Administration and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8:00 AM on October 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD20. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 22W. Simultaneously, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 7:00 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued the No. 1 Signal.  
At 2:00 AM on October 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2117, and named it "Lionrock." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 4:00 AM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical storm and issued the No. 3 Signal. At 4:40 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal for it. At 5:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At around 10:50 PM, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Lionrock made landfall in Qionghai City, Hainan Province.  
At 6:00 AM on October 9, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued the No. 8 Southeast Gale Signal, and 40 minutes later, the Hong Kong Observatory also issued the No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal.  
At 2:00 PM on October 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 2:00 AM on October 11, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 45 knots (85 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Maring  
On October 3, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. On October 7 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning at 8 p.m. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD21. On October 8 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2118, and named it "Kompasu," indicating that tropical depression 94W had merged into Kompasu's circulation. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon; the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium"; and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On October 9 at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded 93W to "medium." On October 10 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center deactivated 93W, considering it had been absorbed by 94W, and simultaneously upgraded 94W to a tropical storm, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 24W. On October 11 at 8 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory and the Japan Meteorological Agency both upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On October 13 at 5 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory and the Central Meteorological Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 7 a.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau followed suit. At 5 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 11 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 14 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 3 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 60 knots (110 kilometers per hour).

On October 8, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters south of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 9 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On October 9 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD22. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On October 10 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 23W. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2119, and named it "Namtheun"; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 3 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 13 at 9 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it back to a tropical storm. On October 16 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 4 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 17 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Namtheun had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On October 20 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, downgraded its peak wind speed to 55 knots (100 kilometers per hour), considering it to have lost typhoon intensity.

On October 20, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters near Ujelang Atoll, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. At 3 a.m. on October 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating. At 2 a.m. on October 23, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again rated it as "low." At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD23. At 5:30 a.m. on October 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 25W. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m. on October 25, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2120, and named it "Malou." At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2 p.m. on October 26, the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 a.m. on October 27, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 a.m. on October 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon, and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 p.m. on October 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Malou had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone, and at the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also stated that Malou had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 8 p.m. on November 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

On November 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 93W. On the morning of November 29 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 27W. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, designating it as TD24. 

At 3 a.m. on November 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2121, and named it "Nyatoh." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. 

On December 1 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. 

On December 2 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. 

On December 3 at 8 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. 

On December 4 at 2 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

PAGASA: Odette  
On December 10, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Hauk Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W.  
At 2 PM on December 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium."  
At 8 AM on December 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD25. At 11 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 8 AM on December 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 28W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2122 and naming it "Rai." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 8 AM on December 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency, the Hong Kong Observatory, and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 8 AM on December 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 12 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2 AM on December 16, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a strong typhoon. At 11 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon.  
At 2 PM on December 18, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it again to a super typhoon. At 8 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it again to a strong typhoon.  
At 2 PM on December 19, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 11 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 8 AM on December 20, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and at the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 5 AM on December 21, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
At 2 PM on December 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its first peak wind speed to 150 knots (280 kilometers per hour).

On January 18, a tropical disturbance formed in the southeastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 90W. At 8:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On January 20 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

On the afternoon of March 14 at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that a tropical depression had formed near the Cuyo Islands in the Philippines. On the morning of March 15 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Crising  
On May 9, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. On May 12 at 6 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "low." At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On May 13 at 1 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 6 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 03W. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan classified it as a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD03. At 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory classified it as a tropical depression. At 12 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On May 14 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning for it. At 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.  
On May 15 at 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it.

On May 27, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern waters of Micronesia, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On the morning of May 28 at 9:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On the afternoon of May 29 at 1:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it. On the morning of May 30 at 8:00 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of May 31 at 4:00 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and downgraded its rating. On the morning of June 2 at 8:00 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

On June 29, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Palau Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 95W. At 2 a.m. on June 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On July 1, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map. At 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert and downgraded its rating.

PAGASA: On July 2, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters north-northeast of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. On July 4 at 12:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 3:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD07. At 10:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a tropical depression advisory for it. On July 5 at 4:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 07W. At 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 6:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration issued a blue typhoon warning signal for it. On July 6 at 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. At 3:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area and canceled the No. 1 Standby Signal bulletin for it, while the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 5:00 PM and canceled the No. 1 Signal bulletin for it.

On July 4, a tropical disturbance formed in the Sibuyan Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 97W. At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On July 5 at 5:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau first upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 6 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:15 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal and simultaneously indicated warnings for two tropical cyclones. At 6:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration issued a blue typhoon warning signal for it. At 6:30 AM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau issued the No. 1 Signal, also indicating it was effective for two tropical depressions. At 8:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On July 7, around 11:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration reported that it made landfall along the coast of Lingshui County, Hainan Province. At 2:10 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory canceled the No. 1 Standby Signal for it. At 5:00 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau canceled the No. 1 Signal for it. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 08W. On July 8 at 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to an area of low pressure. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 30 knots (55 kilometers per hour).

On the morning of July 19 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that a tropical depression had formed in the waters northwest of Wake Island. On the morning of July 21 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On the morning of July 28 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that a tropical depression had formed in the sea area north-northwest of Minamitorishima. On the morning of July 30 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On July 28, a tropical disturbance formed east of Kadena, Okinawa Island, and was designated as 95W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. On the morning of July 30 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. By 5 p.m. on August 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had dissipated.

On July 31, a tropical disturbance formed south of Japan, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 96W. At 2 a.m. on August 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 a.m. on August 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that it made landfall in Mie Prefecture, Japan. At 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had dissipated.

In the early hours of August 2nd at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that a tropical depression had formed in the northern waters of Taiwan. By 8 p.m. on August 3rd, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered it to have dissipated.

On August 1, a tropical disturbance formed near the northeastern waters of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. On the morning of August 2 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 12W. At 2 a.m. on August 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency reclassified it as a tropical depression. At 12 p.m. on August 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that it had merged into the circulation of Tropical Storm Khanun.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On September 1, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium" and classified it as a subtropical disturbance. On September 2 at 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 17W. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD15. On September 4 at 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into a stationary front.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On the morning of September 7 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that a tropical depression had formed near the eastern offshore area of Hainan Island. On the evening of September 8 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

On September 27, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northeast of Saipan, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On September 28 at 9 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." On September 30 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating to "low." On October 1 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled its rating. On October 3 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

PAGASA: Nando  
On October 7, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters north-northwest of Yap Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 8 at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that it had merged into the circulation of Severe Tropical Storm Kompasu. At 3:30 AM on October 9, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On October 10 at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm and assigned it the tropical storm number 24W.

On October 22, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 99W. On October 24 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium," and the Hong Kong Observatory, China Meteorological Administration, and Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 25 at 1:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On October 26 at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 26W. On October 27 at 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On October 28 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On December 13, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea area south-southwest of Nanwei Beach, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On the morning of December 14 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:30 a.m. on December 16, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 1:30 a.m. on December 17, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 29W. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in the best track released on August 5, 2022, revised its peak wind speed to 30 knots (55 kilometers per hour).

Once a tropical cyclone in the Western Pacific reaches tropical storm intensity, it is named by the Typhoon Committee. These names are provided by 14 member countries or regions, each contributing 10 names, and then sorted alphabetically by the English names of the countries. Names in bold indicate those already used this year, bold names indicate active storms, unused names are shown in gray, and orange indicates the next name to be used. Storm names in 2021 may overlap with some storm names from 2003, 2004, 2009, 2010, 2015, and 2016.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form within, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list is rotated every four years, with only retired names being replaced. An auxiliary list is also prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2021, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all tropical cyclones that were active in the Western Pacific in 2021, including their intensity, duration, names, and the casualties and damage caused. All damages are measured in US dollars. Deaths in parentheses refer to indirect causes (such as traffic accidents or landslides, etc.).

Whole_Text.content: Eventually, on November 26, a weather disturbance was spotted outside the Philippine Area of Responsibility, 752 nmi (1,393 km; 865 mi) east-southeast of Guam. The following day, it became a fully developed Low Pressure Area (LPA). By November 28, it had the potential to develop into a storm. Six hours later, it was named internationally as Nyatoh.

It completely moved away while entering the Philippine Area of Responsibility or PAR, when Nyatoh slightly brushed against the PAR, it was not expected to be named by PAGASA as Typhoon OdettePH, which was in category 4 according to (JTWC), it completely dissipated in the vast Pacific Ocean.
This article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.

Fatalities: None  
Damage: None  
Affected: Pacific Ocean

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Basyang or (International designation: Typhoon Malakas) is a strong typhoon in the Pacific Ocean and the second typhoon to enter the PAR under the "Severe Tropical Storm" category, located 270 nautical miles (500 km; 310 mi) northwest of Yap. The typhoon is moving in a northeast direction while continuously absorbing "Typhoon Agaton," moving away from the Philippines. The typhoon continued to rotate in the "Pacific Ocean," initially moving slowly in the northeast direction, becoming a "Severe Tropical Storm" on April 11 and April 12 according to JTWC and JMA, until it fully developed into a "Typhoon" during the same period. It entered the PAR of the Philippines and was named Basyang by PAGASA at 10 AM (UTC+8) PST and slightly grazed the PAR before exiting the border of the PAR under the name Malakas within five (5) hours, as a Category 2 "Typhoon." The name Malakas was replaced as it is derived from Greek homophones referred to it.

On April 3, it became a Low Pressure Area (LPA) according to JMA, and in April it developed into a "tropical depression" named "Malakas" by JTWC on April 8, and in the Philippines, it will be called Basyang in the coming days. Meanwhile, "Bagyong Agaton" became a Low Pressure Area and merged with the circulation of the storm Malakas.
