Dissipated: April 15  
Strongest winds: 10-minute sustained: 155 km/h (100 mph) 1-minute sustained: 215 km/h (130 mph)  
Lowest pressure: 950 hPa (mbar); 28.05 inHg

Article_Name: 2022年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2022 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during the year 2022. Although there is no designated formation period, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to typhoons in the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2022 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (international names) with international numbers starting with 22xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter W. Any tropical depression that enters or forms within the Philippine Area of Responsibility is given a local name by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (the international name is considered official). The Chinese names of storms are currently determined through consultation by the China Meteorological Administration, the Hong Kong Observatory, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan. Before the 2020s, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, Macao, and Taiwan might have differed. The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak state during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

According to the forecast by the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau, tropical cyclone activity affecting Hainan Island during the 2022 flood season is relatively active, with the number of impacts and landfalls being close to the average of previous years. The overall intensity of impacts and landfalls is generally close to the average of previous years, but there may be occasional stronger typhoons during this period. The overall tropical cyclone disaster situation is close to the average of previous years.

The Shenzhen Meteorological Observatory predicts that under the influence of a double La Niña, Shenzhen in 2022 will experience typhoon impacts starting earlier, ending later, and being more severe. There will be 5-7 typhoons entering within 500 kilometers of Shenzhen, among which 3-4 will have an impact, with the strongest reaching the level of a severe typhoon.

The Hong Kong Observatory predicts that this year's typhoon season may begin in June or earlier and end in October or later. There may be 5 to 8 tropical cyclones entering within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong this year, which is considered normal to slightly above average.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau predicts that under the global warming trend, 5 to 8 tropical cyclones are expected to affect Macao this year, which is considered normal to slightly above average. Among them, there may be strong typhoons or higher levels, and the typhoon season is expected to start in mid-June or earlier, slightly earlier than the climate average.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation announced the typhoon season outlook on June 28, predicting that the number of typhoons forming from June to December this year will be normal, with the number of typhoons affecting Taiwan within the normal range of about 3 to 4.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content:
PAGASA: Basyang  
On April 3, a tropical disturbance formed in the western waters of the Marshall Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On April 4 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating to "low." On April 6 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD02; the Joint Typhoon Warning Center again upgraded its rating to "medium." At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On April 7 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 02W. On April 8 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2201 and naming it "Malakas." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Hong Kong Observatory respectively upgraded it to a tropical storm and a tropical storm. On April 10 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On April 11 at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. On April 12 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. On April 15 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On April 16 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Malakas had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On April 20 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map. In the Hong Kong Observatory's April tropical cyclone report, Malakas' peak intensity was revised to 185 kilometers per hour, and it was reclassified as a super typhoon.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on September 1, 2023, downgraded its peak wind speed to 105 knots (195 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Agaton  
On March 31, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northeast of the Mortlock Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. On April 9 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert, shortly after which it was upgraded to a tropical depression and assigned the tropical cyclone number 03W. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD03. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On April 10 at 5 a.m., the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2202, and named it "Malakas." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On April 11 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On April 12 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau downgraded it to a tropical depression, as its circulation was gradually absorbed by Typhoon Malakas. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  

On April 13 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had been absorbed into Malakas's circulation.

PAGASA: Caloy  
On June 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W.  
On June 28 at 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On June 29 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD04; the China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 12:20 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau followed suit and upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 12:30 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On June 30 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2203 and naming it "Chaba"; at the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On July 1 at 2:00 AM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
On July 2 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At 8:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon; the Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:45 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 9:00 AM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 3:00 PM, the Guangzhou Meteorological Observatory reported that Chaba made landfall along the coast of Dianbai District, Maoming City, Guangdong Province, with maximum winds near the center reaching 35 m/s (130 km/h) at the time of landfall. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning on Chaba.  
On July 3 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
On July 8 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

PAGASA: On June 27, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of Kadena, Japan, and was assigned the disturbance number 98W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. On June 30 at 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD05. At 11:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 05W. 

On July 1 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2204 and naming it "Aere." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical storm. 

On July 2 at 10:00 PM, Aere made landfall in Nago City, Okinawa. On July 3 at 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 5 at 6:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Aere made landfall along the coast of Nagasaki City, Japan. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Aere had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. 

On July 7 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as a subtropical storm. At 5:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On July 8 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a subtropical depression.

On July 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of Rota Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD07. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On July 27 at 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 28 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2205, and named it "Songda." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. On July 29 at 2 a.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 06W. On August 1 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined it had transitioned into a low-pressure system. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it had dissipated. In the tropical cyclone report released by the Hong Kong Observatory on August 31, Songda was reclassified as a tropical storm with a wind speed of 65 kilometers per hour.

PAGASA: Ester  
On July 29, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of the Ryukyu Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 30 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On July 31 at 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2206, and named it "Trases." The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 1 at 12:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 07W. On August 1 at 4 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and the Hong Kong Observatory also downgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 2 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency considered it to have dissipated. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 1, 2023, its peak intensity was revised to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On August 4, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern waters off Samar Island, Philippines, and was designated as 97W by the United States Naval Research Laboratory. On the morning of August 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2:00 PM on August 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation TD09; the China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2:00 AM on August 9, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau followed the China Meteorological Administration in upgrading it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international designation 2207, and named it "Mulan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon; the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. At around 10:50 AM on August 10, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Mulan made landfall along the coast of Xuwen County, Guangdong Province. At 9:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert and downgraded its rating to "medium." At around 4:30 AM on August 11, the Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center reported that Mulan made landfall again along the northeastern coast of Vietnam. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

On August 9, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea north-northeast of Pagan Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 1 a.m. on August 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD10. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 11, at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 09W. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. On August 12, at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2208, and named it "Mireille." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. On August 13, at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:30 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Mireille made landfall on the Izu Peninsula in Shizuoka Prefecture. On August 14, at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan stated that Mireille had transformed into an extratropical cyclone. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency also stated that it had transformed into an extratropical cyclone. On August 17, at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

PAGASA: Florita  
On August 15, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northeast of Pohnpei Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. On August 21 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD11. At 9:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 11:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 3:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 10W. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On August 22 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2209 and naming it "Ma-on." At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau also upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On August 23 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological Bureau upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At around 10:30 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Ma-on made landfall near Maconacon, Isabela Province.  

On August 24 at 8:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon. At 9:00 PM, the Macao Meteorological Bureau upgraded it to a typhoon.  

On August 25 at around 10:30 AM, the Guangzhou Meteorological Bureau reported that Ma-on made landfall along the coast of Dianbai District, Maoming City, Guangdong Province. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 4:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning, and at the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At around 8:30 PM, the China National Meteorological Center reported that Ma-on made landfall along the coast of Quang Ninh Province, Vietnam.  

On August 26 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:45 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.  

In the Hong Kong Observatory's August tropical cyclone report, Ma-on's peak intensity was revised to 120 km/h, and it was reclassified as a typhoon. In the Joint Typhoon Warning Center's best track report released on September 1, 2023, its peak intensity was revised to 65 knots (120 km/h).

On August 21, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters east of the Maug Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 99W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 22 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, designating it as TD12. At 11 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international designation 2210 and naming it "Tokage." At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 11W. On August 23 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On August 25 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. On August 26 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Tokage had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On August 27 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 1, 2023, its peak intensity was revised downward to 95 knots (175 km/h).

PAGASA: Henry  
On August 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea south-southwest of Minamitorishima, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On August 28 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD13. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2211, and named it "Hinnamnor." Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 12W; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon.  

At 2 a.m. on August 29, the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon; the Hong Kong Observatory marked it as a typhoon on its weather map. At 8 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe typhoon.  

At 2 a.m. on August 30, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a super typhoon. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a severe typhoon.  

At 2 a.m. on September 2, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon, while the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau downgraded it to a severe typhoon.  

At 8 a.m. on September 4, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it again to a severe typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it again to a super typhoon.  

At 2 p.m. on September 5, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it again to a moderate typhoon. At 5 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it again to a severe typhoon.  

At 2 a.m. on September 6, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Hinnamnor to a typhoon. At around 4:50 a.m., the Korea Meteorological Administration reported that Hinnamnor made landfall near Geoje City in southeastern South Korea. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Hinnamnor had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  

At 8 a.m. on September 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on September 1, 2023, revised its peak wind speed to 145 knots (270 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Josie  
On September 6, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of Iwo Jima, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W.  
On September 9 at 11 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On September 14 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2214, and named it "Nanmadol." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a light typhoon; the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On September 15 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon; the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm; the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, while the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.

At 4:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. Simultaneously, the China Meteorological Administration and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm; the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2218, and named it "Roke"; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon.  
On September 29, at 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm; the China Meteorological Administration and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At 5:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  
On September 30, at 2:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At the same time, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On October 1, at 5:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On October 2, at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Roke had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  
On October 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center adjusted its peak intensity to 90 knots (165 kilometers per hour) in the best track released on September 1, 2023.

On October 11, a tropical disturbance formed to the west-southwest of Manila, Philippines, and was designated as 90W by the United States Naval Research Laboratory. On the morning of October 13 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation TD22. At 4 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of October 14 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 22W. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2219, and named it "Sonca." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, while the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. Around 3 a.m. on October 15, the Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center reported that Sonca made landfall along the coast of Haiphong City, Quang Ngai Province, Vietnam. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

PAGASA: Neneng  
On October 8, a tropical disturbance formed east of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W. On October 13 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On October 14 at 8 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD23. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it.  

On October 15 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 23W. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2220 and naming it "Nesat." The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On October 16 at around 3:50 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Nesat made landfall near Calayan Island in the Cagayan Valley, Philippines. At 5 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At 7 AM, the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 10 AM, the Thai Meteorological Department upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the China Meteorological Administration, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon.  

On October 17 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe typhoon.  

On October 18 at 2 PM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a typhoon.  

On October 19 at 2 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 5 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On October 20 at 7 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. The Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan removed the system from its weather map.

On October 11, a tropical disturbance formed north of Minamitorishima, and the United States Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 91W. On the morning of October 18 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it Tropical Cyclone Number 24W. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transitioned from an extratropical cyclone to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2221 and naming it "Haitang." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. On the evening of October 19 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Haitang had transitioned back into an extratropical cyclone.

In the post-event report released by the Japan Meteorological Agency on November 16, the pressure of Haitang was revised upward to 1004 hPa. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 1, 2023, its peak was revised upward to 40 knots (75 kilometers per hour), and its nature was entirely reclassified as a subtropical storm.

PAGASA: Paeng  
On October 21, a tropical disturbance formed south of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. On October 25 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "medium." On October 26 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD27. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On October 27 at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 26W. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2222 and naming it "Nalgae." The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 28 at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On October 29 at around 1:10 a.m., the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Nalgae made landfall near Virac, Catanduanes, Philippines. At around 1:40 a.m., the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Nalgae made a second landfall in Caramoan, Camarines Sur, Philippines. At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At around 6 a.m., the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Nalgae made a third landfall in Buenavista, Quezon, Philippines. At around 8:40 a.m., the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Nalgae made a fourth landfall in Santa Cruz, Marinduque, Philippines. At around 1:40 p.m., the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Nalgae made a fifth landfall in Sariaya, Quezon, Philippines. On October 30 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. On October 31 at 8 a.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency re-upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On November 2 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it again to a tropical storm. At 5 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau downgraded it to a tropical storm. On November 3 at around 4:50 a.m., the China Meteorological Administration reported that Nalgae made landfall along the coast of Xiangzhou District, Zhuhai City, Guangdong Province. At 5 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 1, 2023, its peak intensity was adjusted to 75 knots (140 km/h).

PAGASA: Queenie  
On October 26, a tropical disturbance formed south of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W.  
On October 29 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On October 31 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 27W. At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD28. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory directly upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 12:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency directly upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2223, and named it "Banyan." At 2:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon.  
On November 1 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

In the post-event report released by the Japan Meteorological Agency on November 16, the peak wind speed of Banyan was revised upward to 40 knots (75 kilometers per hour). In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 1, 2023, its peak was also revised upward to 40 knots (75 kilometers per hour).

On November 11, a tropical disturbance formed east of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 96W. On the morning of November 12 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and designated it as TD29. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 28W. Simultaneously, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2224, and named it "Yamaneko." The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2 a.m. on November 13, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m. on November 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On November 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had dissipated. In the best track report released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 1, 2023, its peak intensity was revised to 40 knots (75 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Rosal  
On December 5, a tropical disturbance formed southeast of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. On December 9 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On December 10 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD30. At 11 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On December 11 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 29W. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2225 and naming it "Pakhar." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon; the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. On December 12 at 9 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. On December 13 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

On March 29, a tropical disturbance formed in the northwest-western waters of Balabac Island, Philippines, and was designated as 93W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On March 30 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation TD01. At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 01W. At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. On March 31 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 1, 2023, its peak intensity was revised to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On May 29, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern waters of Palau, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance 93W. On the morning of May 30 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of May 31 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

On July 22, a tropical disturbance formed in the western waters of the Mariana Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 92W. On the morning of July 24 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD06. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On the afternoon of July 25 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning. At 8 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On the morning of July 26 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

On August 2, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as 96W. On the same day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 4:30 PM on August 3, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 5:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau first upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 AM on August 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 08W. At around 9:40 AM, the China Meteorological Administration reported that the tropical depression made landfall along the coast of Huidong County, Guangdong Province, and weakened into a low-pressure area. At 4:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning on the system. On the morning of August 5, at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

On August 14, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea area west of the International Date Line, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 15 at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

On August 20, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern sea area of Minamitorishima, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 97W. On the afternoon of August 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 a.m. on August 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

PAGASA: Gardo  
On August 24, a tropical disturbance formed in the western waters of Agrihan Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W. On the morning of August 30 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD14. At 2:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert for it.  
At 2:00 AM on August 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 13W. On September 1 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Tropical Depression 13W had merged into the circulation of Typhoon Hinnamnor. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

On September 26, a tropical disturbance formed southeast of Japan. At 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On September 27 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

PAGASA: On October 8, a tropical disturbance formed east of Manila, Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 98W. On October 11 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its classification to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. On the evening of October 12 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into the circulation of Sanba.

On October 11, a tropical disturbance formed east of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance 99W. On the evening of October 12 at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it tropical cyclone number 21W. At 2 AM on October 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of October 14 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD24. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning for it. At 2 AM on October 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had merged into the circulation of Typhoon Sanba.

PAGASA: Obet  
On October 17, a tropical disturbance formed east of Luzon, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 92W.  
On the evening of October 18 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On October 19 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "medium." At 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "high."  
On October 20 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 25W. At 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD26.  
On October 22 at 8 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 9 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning.  
On October 23 at 2 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
On October 24 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

Once a tropical cyclone in the Western Pacific reaches tropical storm intensity, it is named by the Typhoon Committee. These names are provided by 14 member countries or regions, each contributing 10 names, and then sorted alphabetically by the English names of the countries. Names in blue italics indicate those already used this year, names in bold indicate active storms, unused names are shown in gray, and orange indicates the next name to be used. The storm names for 2022 may overlap with some storm names from 2004, 2005, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2016, and 2017.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form within, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list rotates every four years, with only retired names being replaced. An auxiliary list is also prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2023, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all tropical cyclones that were active in the Western Pacific in 2022. It includes the intensity, duration, names, and the casualties and damage caused by these tropical cyclones. All damages are measured in US dollars. The numbers in parentheses indicate indirect deaths (such as traffic accidents or landslides, etc.).

Last system dissipated: December 13, 2022 (Tropical Storm Pakhar)  
Name: Nanmadol  
* Maximum wind speed: 195 km/h (120 mph) (10-minute average wind speed)  
* Minimum pressure: 910 hPa (mbar)

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Ester (International designation: Typhoon Trases) is a destructive typhoon that struck the Korean Peninsula, particularly South Korea, forming near the Ryukyu Islands in Japan. According to PAGASA, it was named Ester in the Philippines and exited the Philippine Area of Responsibility while heading north towards Jeju Island.

Typhoon Trases (Ester) made landfall in Jeju near the island of Okinawa, accompanied by Typhoon Songda, which caused destruction in South Korea, leading to submersion and widespread flooding in the capital Seoul. Typhoons Ester and Songda brought over seven days of rainfall, prompting South Korea to declare a "state of calamity" due to the floods. Typhoon Trases dissipated on August 1.

Info_Box:
Formed: July 29  
Dissipated: August 1  
Strongest winds: Over 10 minutes: 65 km/h (40 mph) Over 1 minute: 55 km/h (35 mph)  
Lowest pressure: 998 hPa (mbar); 29.47 inHg

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Ester (International designation: Typhoon Trases) is a destructive typhoon that struck the Korean Peninsula, particularly South Korea, forming near the Ryukyu Islands in Japan. According to PAGASA, it was named Ester in the Philippines and exited the Philippine Area of Responsibility while heading north towards Jeju Island.

Typhoon Trases (Ester) made landfall in Jeju near the island of Okinawa, accompanied by Typhoon Songda, which caused destruction in South Korea, leading to submersion and widespread flooding in the capital Seoul. For more than 7 days, Typhoons Ester and Songda brought continuous rain, prompting South Korea to declare a "state of calamity" due to the floods. Typhoon Trases dissipated on August 1.

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴木蘭 (2022年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Mulan (English: Tropical Storm Mulan, international designation: 2207) is the 7th named storm of the 2022 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Mulan" was provided by mainland China, referring to the magnolia flower, a flower native to China. This name was used for the first time, replacing Typhoon Haima, which severely impacted the Philippines and China in 2016.

On August 4, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern waters off Samar Island, Philippines, and was designated as 97W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. On the morning of August 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On the afternoon of August 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation TD09; the China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 p.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. 

At 2 a.m. on August 9, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 11 a.m., the Macao Meteorological Bureau upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international designation 2207, and named it "Mulan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon; the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. 

At around 10:50 a.m. on August 10, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Mulan made landfall along the coast of Xuwen County, Zhanjiang City, Guangdong Province. At 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert and downgraded its rating to "medium." 

At around 4:30 a.m. on August 11, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Mulan made landfall again along the northeastern coast of Vietnam. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. It is worth noting that the Joint Typhoon Warning Center never recognized Mulan as a tropical cyclone and regarded it as a monsoon depression throughout.

The Hong Kong Observatory, in its tropical cyclone report released on October 26, revised the intensity of Mulan from 75 kilometers per hour down to 65 kilometers per hour. In the post-analysis report published by the Japan Meteorological Agency on November 16, Mulan's pressure was adjusted downward to 994 hPa.

The Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau issued Typhoon Signal No. 1 at 7:00 PM on August 8, when "Mulan" was located about 760 kilometers southwest of Macau. It was expected that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would likely be issued during the day on August 9, and there was a moderate chance of issuing Typhoon Signal No. 8 on the evening of August 9. Typhoon Signal No. 1 was expected to remain in effect until the early morning of August 9. At 10:45 AM on August 9, the Meteorological Bureau announced that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would be issued at 11:30 AM, with a moderate chance of issuing Typhoon Signal No. 8. It was also expected that a blue storm surge warning would likely be issued between 1:00 PM and 3:00 PM, while the chance of a yellow storm surge warning was low to moderate. At 11:30 AM, the Meteorological Bureau officially issued Typhoon Signal No. 3, which was expected to remain in effect during the day. At that time, "Mulan" was located about 630 kilometers south of Macau. At 2:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau issued a blue storm surge warning, with a moderate to high chance of issuing Typhoon Signal No. 8. At 5:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau predicted that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would remain in effect until before 9:00 PM and upgraded the storm surge warning from blue to yellow. It was noted that due to the astronomical high tide in the coming days, combined with the effects of the storm surge and continuous rainfall, flooding was expected in the Inner Harbor and low-lying areas from the early morning to the morning of August 10-11. The maximum flooding height on the morning of August 10 was expected to reach 0.5 to 1 meter. The Meteorological Bureau stated that as "Mulan" was gradually strengthening and might take a more northerly path closer to Macau, wind speeds could reach the lower limit of Typhoon Signal No. 8. The authorities would monitor the development of "Mulan" and local wind changes to decide whether to issue Typhoon Signal No. 8 during the evening or early morning. At 8:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau predicted that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would remain in effect until before midnight. Later, at 11:00 PM, it was announced that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would remain in effect until before 4:00 AM on August 11. At 3:45 AM on August 10, the Meteorological Bureau announced that Typhoon Signal No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal would be issued at 7:00 AM. As "Mulan" was gradually strengthening and would be closest to Macau in the morning, wind speeds could reach the lower limit of Typhoon Signal No. 8. At 7:00 AM, the Meteorological Bureau officially issued Typhoon Signal No. 8 Southeast Gale or Storm Signal, which was expected to remain in effect during the morning. At that time, "Mulan" was located about 400 kilometers southwest of Macau. The Civil Protection Operations Center announced that Macau entered an immediate prevention state starting at 7:00 AM. At 10:00 AM, the Meteorological Bureau canceled all storm surge warnings. At 11:50 AM, the Meteorological Bureau announced that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would be issued at 1:00 PM. At 1:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau officially issued Typhoon Signal No. 3, which was expected to remain in effect for some time. At that time, "Mulan" was located about 430 kilometers west-southwest of Macau. The Civil Protection Operations Center also announced the termination of the immediate prevention state starting at 1:00 PM. At 5:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau stated that Typhoon Signal No. 3 was expected to remain in effect during the evening. At 8:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau considered canceling all tropical cyclone warning signals within the next few hours. Starting around midnight, widespread heavy rain affected Macau due to the outer rainbands of "Mulan." At 11:55 PM, the Meteorological Bureau issued a Yellow Rainstorm Warning Signal. At 12:30 AM on August 11, the Meteorological Bureau announced the cancellation of all tropical cyclone warning signals. At that time, "Mulan" was located about 530 kilometers west-southwest of Macau. The rainbands of "Mulan" continued to affect Macau, and at 1:35 AM, the Meteorological Bureau issued a Red Rainstorm Warning Signal, which was canceled at 3:00 AM. Later in the morning, Macau was again affected by the outer rainbands of "Mulan," and the Meteorological Bureau issued a Yellow Rainstorm Warning Signal from 10:58 AM to 11:40 AM. The Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau stated that during the impact of "Mulan" on Macau, the 10-minute average wind speed recorded on the Friendship Bridge reached the lower limit of Typhoon Signal No. 8, classified as a weak Typhoon Signal No. 8. The authorities noted that "Mulan" developed from a monsoon depression into a tropical cyclone. Although its intensity increased, its structure was relatively loose, and its wind distribution differed from typical tropical cyclones, with weaker central winds and maximum winds located in its outer regions. The Pearl River Estuary was situated on the northeastern edge of the 7-8 wind scale area of "Mulan's" outer region. Additionally, during the period when Typhoon Signal No. 8 was in effect, most areas of Macau recorded over 30 millimeters of accumulated rainfall. The Meteorological Bureau stated that due to the recent astronomical high tide, combined with the effects of the storm surge and heavy rain, flooding occurred in the southern Inner Harbor area on the morning to noon of August 10, with a maximum flooding height of approximately 0.15 meters due to a slight time lag between the storm surge and the astronomical tide.

The Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 3:40 a.m. on August 9, when Mulan was located about 660 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. It stated that the No. 1 Signal would be maintained until 10 a.m. that morning, after which the issuance of the No. 3 Signal would be considered depending on changes in wind strength in Hong Kong. Affected by Mulan's outer rainbands, Hong Kong experienced squally showers and thunderstorms in the morning, with heavy rain at times and strong winds offshore and in highland areas. The Observatory predicted that winds across Hong Kong would strengthen further later in the day and announced at 7:45 a.m. that it would consider issuing the No. 3 Signal between 10 a.m. and 1 p.m., depending on changes in local wind conditions. Subsequently, the Observatory issued the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 11:25 a.m., when Mulan was located about 580 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. It stated that the No. 3 Signal would remain in effect until at least 6 p.m., and whether a higher signal would be issued would depend on changes in Mulan's intensity and local wind conditions. 

In the afternoon, strong winds were generally recorded across Hong Kong, with occasional gale-force gusts due to showers. Offshore and highland areas experienced winds reaching gale force at times. At 4:45 p.m., the Observatory stated that, as the gale-force wind area near Mulan's center was relatively small and it was still far from the Guangdong coast, the No. 3 Signal would remain in effect until 10 p.m. unless Mulan significantly intensified or took a path closer to Hong Kong. The Observatory would closely monitor Mulan's development and movement to assess the need for a higher signal. At 8:45 p.m., the Observatory announced that the No. 3 Signal would remain in effect until 2 a.m. the next day unless Mulan significantly intensified or there was a noticeable increase in wind strength in Hong Kong. It also noted that the next day (August 10) coincided with a high astronomical tide, and storm surges caused by Mulan could lead to flooding in low-lying areas in the morning. Residents were advised to take precautions against strong winds and flooding as early as possible. 

The Observatory extended the duration of the No. 3 Signal to 6 a.m. and then to 12 p.m. on August 10, with announcements at 11:45 p.m. on August 9 and 4:45 a.m. on August 10, respectively. On the morning of August 10, strong winds continued to prevail across Hong Kong, with occasional gale-force winds offshore and in highland areas. At 9:45 a.m., the Observatory stated that the No. 3 Signal would remain in effect until at least 3 p.m., and the No. 1 Signal would be issued when there were signs of weakening winds in Hong Kong. At 11:45 a.m., the Observatory announced that the No. 3 Signal would remain in effect until at least 6 p.m. As winds in Hong Kong eased, the Observatory stated at 4:45 p.m. that it would consider issuing the No. 1 Signal or canceling all tropical cyclone warning signals between 6 p.m. and 9 p.m. Ultimately, the Observatory canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals at 6:20 p.m., when Mulan was located about 540 kilometers west-southwest of Hong Kong. 

During Mulan's impact, three of the eight reference automatic weather stations in the Observatory's wind monitoring network recorded strong winds, with one station even recording gale-force winds. The No. 3 Signal was just one station short of meeting the criteria. Kai Tak narrowly missed recording strong winds. Cheung Chau, the airport, and Sai Kung recorded the highest 10-minute average wind speeds of 78, 50, and 46 kilometers per hour, respectively. In the early hours of August 10, trees fell in Kwun Tong and Chai Wan. At around 1 a.m., a tree approximately 6 meters tall fell at the junction of Hip Wo Street and Tsui Ping Road in Kwun Tong, lying across the traffic lanes. At around 2 a.m., a large tree on Cheung Tai Street in Chai Wan was suspected to have been blown down by strong winds, with its broken trunk crushing five private minibuses parked at a roadside car park. Firefighters and police were dispatched to handle the situation. Additionally, at 3 p.m., an iron rod fell from the sky in Cha Kwo Ling Village, striking three workers on the ground. Two of them were seriously injured and unconscious, while the other was injured and trapped.

According to the meteorological station's forecast, Mulan will have a significant impact on Hainan Province with wind and rain on August 9-10. Affected by this, the strong winds brought by the typhoon will cause the Qiongzhou Strait to suspend navigation, and as Hainan Province is currently experiencing a local COVID-19 outbreak, it will have a certain impact on the transportation, storage, and supply of epidemic prevention materials and daily necessities. Additionally, the wind and rain will affect the smooth progress of outdoor prevention and control work, increasing the difficulty of nucleic acid sampling and temporary road control work. Cai Qinbo, deputy director of the Hainan Meteorological Bureau, stated that while ensuring epidemic prevention, relevant units should strengthen safety inspections and handling of potential hazards. Chen Wu, deputy director of the Hainan Emergency Management Department and deputy director of the Provincial Three Defense Office, stated that Hainan has integrated typhoon preparedness with grassroots epidemic prevention work, and the province's supply and storage of daily necessities are sufficient, with prices remaining basically stable.

Affected by the rainbands of "Mulan," heavy rain occurred in Zhanjiang City on August 10th, with some residents having to wade through water on the streets. The local meteorological station issued an orange heavy rain warning and predicted a heavy to torrential rain process from August 10th to 11th, with cumulative rainfall of approximately 60 to 100 millimeters, and about 120 to 150 millimeters in some areas.

On the morning of August 10, the Guangxi Meteorological Observatory issued a blue typhoon warning signal, indicating that in the next 24 hours, parts of Beihai, Qinzhou, Fangchenggang, Yulin, Wuzhou, Guigang, Laibin, Nanning, Chongzuo, and Hezhou will experience heavy rain to torrential rain, locally extremely heavy rain, accompanied by short-term thunderstorms, strong winds, and other severe convective weather. Due to the previous impact of heatwaves, the provincial capital Nanning had experienced drought and high-temperature weather; after "Mulan" made landfall in Guangdong, the rainfall brought by the typhoon's circulation also caused the local daytime temperature to drop from about 35°C on August 9 to about 25°C on August 10. To alleviate the drought, the Meteorological Bureau of Yongning District, Nanning, also took the opportunity of the typhoon's outer circulation cloud system passing through on August 10 to carry out artificial rainfall operations.
