Article_Name: 熱帶風暴木蘭 (2022年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Mulan (English: Tropical Storm Mulan, international designation: 2207) is the 7th named storm of the 2022 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Mulan" was provided by mainland China, referring to the magnolia flower, a flower native to China. This name was used for the first time, replacing Typhoon Haima, which severely impacted the Philippines and China in 2016.

On August 4, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern waters off Samar Island, Philippines, and was designated as 97W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. On the morning of August 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On the afternoon of August 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, designating it as TD09, and the China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 p.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. 

At 2 a.m. on August 9, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 11 a.m., the Macao Meteorological Bureau upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international designation 2207, and named it "Mulan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. 

At around 10:50 a.m. on August 10, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Mulan made landfall along the coast of Xuwen County, Zhanjiang City, Guangdong Province. At 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert and downgraded its rating to "medium." 

At around 4:30 a.m. on August 11, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Mulan made landfall again along the northeastern coast of Vietnam. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. It is worth noting that the Joint Typhoon Warning Center never recognized Mulan as a tropical cyclone and regarded it as a monsoon depression.

The Hong Kong Observatory, in its tropical cyclone report released on October 26, revised the intensity of Mulan from 75 kilometers per hour down to 65 kilometers per hour. In the post-event report published by the Japan Meteorological Agency on November 16, Mulan's pressure was adjusted down to 994 hPa.

The Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau issued Typhoon Signal No. 1 at 7:00 PM on August 8, when "Mulan" was located approximately 760 kilometers southwest of Macau. It was expected that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would likely be issued during the daytime on August 9, with a moderate chance of issuing Typhoon Signal No. 8 in the evening of August 9. Typhoon Signal No. 1 was expected to remain in effect until the early morning of August 9. At 10:45 AM on August 9, the Meteorological Bureau announced that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would be issued at 11:30 AM, with a moderate chance of issuing Typhoon Signal No. 8. It was also expected that a blue storm surge warning would likely be issued between 1:00 PM and 3:00 PM, while the chance of a yellow storm surge warning was low to moderate. At 11:30 AM, the Meteorological Bureau officially issued Typhoon Signal No. 3, which was expected to remain in effect during the day. At that time, "Mulan" was located approximately 630 kilometers south of Macau. At 2:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau issued a blue storm surge warning, with a moderate to high chance of issuing Typhoon Signal No. 8. At 5:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau predicted that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would remain in effect until before 9:00 PM and upgraded the storm surge warning from blue to yellow. It was noted that due to the astronomical high tide in the coming days, combined with the effects of the storm surge and continuous rainfall, flooding was expected in the Inner Harbor and low-lying areas during the early morning to morning hours of August 10-11, with the highest flooding level on the morning of August 10 reaching 0.5 to 1 meter. The Meteorological Bureau stated that as "Mulan" was gradually intensifying and might take a more northerly path closer to Macau, wind speeds could reach the lower limit of Typhoon Signal No. 8. The authorities would monitor the development of "Mulan" and local wind changes to decide whether to issue Typhoon Signal No. 8 during the evening to early morning. At 8:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau predicted that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would remain in effect until before midnight. Later, at 11:00 PM, it was announced that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would remain in effect until before 4:00 AM on August 11. At 3:45 AM on August 10, the Meteorological Bureau announced that Typhoon Signal No. 8 Southeast would be issued at 7:00 AM. As "Mulan" was gradually intensifying and would be closest to Macau in the morning, wind speeds could reach the lower limit of Typhoon Signal No. 8. At 7:00 AM, the Meteorological Bureau officially issued Typhoon Signal No. 8 Southeast, which was expected to remain in effect during the morning. At that time, "Mulan" was located approximately 400 kilometers southwest of Macau. The Civil Protection Operations Center announced that Macau entered an immediate prevention state starting at 7:00 AM. At 10:00 AM, the Meteorological Bureau canceled all storm surge warnings. At 11:50 AM, the Meteorological Bureau announced that Typhoon Signal No. 3 would be issued at 1:00 PM. At 1:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau officially issued Typhoon Signal No. 3, which was expected to remain in effect for some time. At that time, "Mulan" was located approximately 430 kilometers west-southwest of Macau. The Civil Protection Operations Center also announced the termination of the immediate prevention state starting at 1:00 PM. At 5:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau stated that Typhoon Signal No. 3 was expected to remain in effect during the evening. At 8:00 PM, the Meteorological Bureau considered canceling all tropical cyclone warning signals within the next few hours. Starting around midnight, widespread heavy rain affected Macau due to the outer rainbands of "Mulan." At 11:55 PM, the Meteorological Bureau issued a yellow rainstorm warning signal. At 12:30 AM on August 11, the Meteorological Bureau announced the cancellation of all tropical cyclone warning signals. At that time, "Mulan" was located approximately 530 kilometers west-southwest of Macau. The rainbands of "Mulan" continued to affect Macau, and at 1:35 AM, the Meteorological Bureau issued a red rainstorm warning signal, which was canceled at 3:00 AM. Later in the morning, Macau was again affected by the outer rainbands of "Mulan," and the Meteorological Bureau issued a yellow rainstorm warning signal from 10:58 AM to 11:40 AM. The Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau stated that during the impact of "Mulan" on Macau, the 10-minute average wind speed recorded on the Friendship Bridge reached the lower limit of Typhoon Signal No. 8, classified as a weak Typhoon Signal No. 8. The authorities noted that "Mulan" developed from a monsoon depression into a tropical cyclone. Although its intensity increased, its structure was relatively loose, and its wind distribution differed from typical tropical cyclones, with weaker central winds and maximum winds located in its outer regions. The Pearl River Estuary was situated on the northeastern edge of the 7-8 wind scale area of "Mulan's" outer region. Additionally, during the period when Typhoon Signal No. 8 was in effect, most areas of Macau recorded over 30 millimeters of accumulated rainfall. The Meteorological Bureau stated that due to the recent astronomical high tide, combined with the effects of the storm surge and heavy rain, flooding occurred in the southern Inner Harbor area on the morning to noon of August 10, with the highest flooding level reaching approximately 0.15 meters due to a slight time lag between the storm surge and astronomical tide.

The Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 3:40 a.m. on August 9, when Mulan was located about 660 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. The Observatory predicted that winds in Hong Kong would generally strengthen later that day and announced at 7:45 a.m. that it would consider issuing the No. 3 Signal between 10 a.m. and 1 p.m., depending on changes in local wind strength. Subsequently, the Observatory issued the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal at 11:25 a.m., when Mulan was located about 580 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. It stated that the No. 3 Signal would be maintained at least until 6 p.m. that day, and whether a higher signal would be issued would depend on changes in Mulan's intensity and local wind strength. In the afternoon, strong winds were generally recorded across Hong Kong, with occasional gale-force gusts due to showers. Offshore and highland areas experienced winds reaching gale force at times. At 4:45 p.m., the Observatory stated that since the gale-force wind area near Mulan's center was relatively small and it was still far from the Guangdong coast, the No. 3 Signal would be maintained until 10 p.m. unless Mulan significantly intensified or took a path closer to Hong Kong. The Observatory would closely monitor Mulan's development and movement to assess the need for a higher signal. At 8:45 p.m., the Observatory announced that unless Mulan significantly intensified or there was a noticeable increase in wind strength in Hong Kong, the No. 3 Signal would be maintained until 2 a.m. the next day. It also noted that the next day (August 10) coincided with an astronomical high tide, and the storm surge caused by Mulan could lead to flooding in low-lying areas in the morning. Residents were advised to take precautions against strong winds and flooding as early as possible. The Observatory further extended the duration of the No. 3 Signal to 6 a.m. and then to 12 p.m. on August 10, with announcements at 11:45 p.m. and 4:45 a.m., respectively. 

On the morning of August 10, strong winds continued to prevail across Hong Kong, with offshore and highland areas occasionally experiencing gale-force winds. At 9:45 a.m., the Observatory stated that the No. 3 Signal would be maintained at least until 3 p.m., and the No. 1 Signal would be issued when there were signs of weakening winds in Hong Kong. At 11:45 a.m., the Observatory announced that the No. 3 Signal would be maintained at least until 6 p.m. As winds in Hong Kong eased, the Observatory stated at 4:45 p.m. that it would consider issuing the No. 1 Signal or canceling all tropical cyclone warning signals between 6 p.m. and 9 p.m. Ultimately, the Observatory canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals at 6:20 p.m., when Mulan was located about 540 kilometers west-southwest of Hong Kong. 

During Mulan's impact, three of the eight reference automatic weather stations in the Observatory's wind measurement network recorded strong winds, with one station even recording gale-force winds. Cheung Chau, the airport, and Sai Kung recorded the highest 10-minute average wind speeds of 78, 50, and 46 kilometers per hour, respectively. At around 2 a.m., a large tree on Cheung Tai Street in Chai Wan was suspected to have been blown down by strong winds, with its broken trunk crushing five private minibuses parked at a roadside car park. Firefighters and police were dispatched to handle the situation. Additionally, at 3 p.m., an iron rod fell from the sky in Cha Kwo Ling Village, striking three workers on the ground. Two of them were seriously injured and unconscious, while the other was injured and trapped.

Affected by this, the strong winds brought by the typhoon will cause the Qiongzhou Strait to suspend navigation, and as Hainan Province is currently experiencing a local COVID-19 outbreak, it will have a certain impact on the transportation, storage, and supply of epidemic prevention materials and daily necessities. On the morning of August 10, the Guangxi Meteorological Observatory issued a blue typhoon warning signal, indicating that in the next 24 hours, parts of Beihai, Qinzhou, Fangchenggang, Yulin, Wuzhou, Guigang, Laibin, Nanning, Chongzuo, Hezhou, and other cities will experience heavy rain to torrential rain, localized extremely heavy rain, accompanied by short-term thunderstorms, strong winds, and other severe convective weather. Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 8 of Reiwa 4 (Asian name: MEARI) was a typhoon that formed in August 2022 and made landfall in Japan. It formed south of Japan at 3 a.m. on the 12th [2] and made landfall on the Izu Peninsula in Shizuoka Prefecture around 5:30 p.m. on the 13th [3]. Then, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone near the Kuril Islands at 9 p.m. on the 14th [4].
The damage situation caused by heavy rain from August 3 and Typhoon No. 8 is as follows [5].

The session of the ROCK IN JAPAN FESTIVAL held at Soga Sports Park in Chiba City, where DISH// and SCANDAL were scheduled to perform, was canceled. On the other hand, the Summer Koshien proceeded as planned. In Akita Prefecture, moist air from the typhoon flowed into the front, causing heavy rain. The Ou Line, Akita Nairiku Line, and Hanawa Line were affected, with the Ou Line taking until early October, the Nairiku Line until the end of the year, and the Hanawa Line until May of the following year to recover.

In August 2022, due to the effects of a front and Typhoon No. 8, record-breaking heavy rain occurred mainly in northern Japan (Tohoku and Hokkaido) and Hokuriku, causing damage in various areas. Therefore, the government decided on September 30 of the same year to designate the series of heavy rain disasters as a "severe disaster."
This article is a stub related to meteorology or climatology. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this article (Project: Meteorology and Climate/Portal: Meteorology and Climate).

Article_Name: 2022年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2022 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2022. Although there is no designated formation period, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to typhoons in the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2022 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (international names) with international numbers starting with 22xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter W. Any tropical depression that enters or forms within the Philippine Area of Responsibility is given a local name by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (the international name is considered official). The Chinese names of storms are currently determined through consultation among the China Meteorological Administration, the Hong Kong Observatory, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan. Before the 2020s, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, Macao, and Taiwan might have differed. The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak form during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

According to the forecast by the Hainan Provincial Meteorological Bureau, tropical cyclone activity affecting Hainan Island during the 2022 flood season is relatively active, with the number of impacts and landfalls being close to the average of previous years. The overall intensity of impacts and landfalls is generally close to the average, but there may be occasional stronger typhoons during this period. The overall tropical cyclone disaster situation is close to the average of previous years.

The Shenzhen Meteorological Observatory predicts that under the influence of a double La Niña, Shenzhen in 2022 will experience typhoon impacts starting earlier, ending later, and with greater intensity. There will be 5-7 typhoons entering within 500 kilometers of Shenzhen, among which 3-4 will have an impact, with the strongest reaching the level of a severe typhoon.

The Hong Kong Observatory predicts that this year the typhoon season may begin in June or earlier and end in October or later. This year, there may be 5 to 8 tropical cyclones entering within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong, which is considered normal to slightly above average.

The Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau predicts that under the global warming trend, around 5 to 8 tropical cyclones are expected to affect Macao this year, which is considered normal to slightly above average. Among them, there may be strong typhoons or higher categories. The typhoon season is expected to start in mid-June or earlier, slightly earlier than the climatic average.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation announced the typhoon season outlook on June 28, predicting that the number of typhoons forming from June to December this year will be normal, with the number of typhoons affecting Taiwan within the normal range of about 3 to 4.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content:
PAGASA: Basyang  
On April 3, a tropical disturbance formed in the western waters of the Marshall Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On April 4 at 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating to "low." On April 6 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD02; the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again upgraded its rating to "medium." At 11 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On April 7 at 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 02W. On April 8 at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2201, and named it "Malakas." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Hong Kong Observatory respectively upgraded it to a tropical storm and a tropical storm. On April 10 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On April 11 at 8 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. On April 12 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 11 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. On April 15 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On April 16 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Malakas had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On April 20 at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. In the Hong Kong Observatory's April tropical cyclone report, Malakas' peak intensity was revised to 185 kilometers per hour, and it was reclassified as a super typhoon.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on September 1, 2023, downgraded its peak wind speed to 105 knots (195 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Agaton  
On March 31, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northeast of the Mortlock Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W.  
At 2:00 AM on April 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 10:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert, shortly after which it was upgraded to a tropical depression and assigned the tropical cyclone number 03W. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD03. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 5:00 AM on April 10, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2202, and named it "Malakas." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At 2:00 AM on April 11, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 2:00 AM on April 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau downgraded it to a tropical depression, as its circulation was gradually absorbed by Typhoon Malakas. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
At 2:00 PM on April 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered it to have been absorbed into Malakas's circulation.

PAGASA: Caloy  
On June 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 97W.  
On June 28 at 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On June 29 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD04; the China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 12:20 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau followed suit and upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 12:30 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On June 30 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2203 and naming it "Chaba"; at the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On July 1 at 2:00 AM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
On July 2 at 2:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At 8:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon; the Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:45 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 9:00 AM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau also upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 3:00 PM, the Guangzhou Meteorological Observatory reported that Chaba made landfall along the coast of Dianbai District, Maoming City, Guangdong Province, with maximum winds near the center reaching 35 m/s (130 km/h) at the time of landfall. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 11:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning on Chaba.  
On July 3 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 5:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.  
On July 8 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

PAGASA: On June 27, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of Kadena, Japan, and was assigned the disturbance number 98W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. On June 30 at 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD05. At 11:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) raised its rating to "medium." At 2:00 PM, the JTWC further upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression. Simultaneously, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 05W. 

On July 1 at 2:00 AM, the JMA issued a gale warning for the system. At 8:00 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2204 and naming it "Aere." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the JTWC also upgraded it to a tropical storm. 

On July 2 at 10:00 PM, Aere made landfall in Nago City, Okinawa. On July 3 at 2:00 PM, the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 5 at 6:00 AM, the JMA reported that Aere made landfall along the coast of Nagasaki, Japan. At 8:00 AM, the JMA stated that Aere had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. 

On July 7 at 2:00 AM, the JTWC reclassified it as a subtropical storm. At 5:00 AM, the JTWC issued its final warning for the system. On July 8 at 8:00 AM, the JTWC classified it as a subtropical depression.

On July 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of Rota Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 93W. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation TD07. At 10 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." On July 27 at 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 28 at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international designation 2205, and named it "Songda." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. On July 29 at 2 a.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone designation 06W. On August 1 at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined it had transitioned into a low-pressure system. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency considered it to have dissipated. In the tropical cyclone report released by the Hong Kong Observatory on August 31, Songda was reclassified as a tropical storm with a wind speed of 65 kilometers per hour.

PAGASA: Ester  
On July 29, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southeast of the Ryukyu Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 30 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On July 31 at 11 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2206, and named it "Trases." The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon, and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 11 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

At 12:30 a.m. on August 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 07W. At 4 p.m. on August 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, and the Hong Kong Observatory also downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m. on August 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency considered it to have dissipated.  

In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 1, 2023, its peak intensity was revised to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On August 4, a tropical disturbance formed in the northeastern waters off Samar Island, Philippines, and was designated as 97W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. On the morning of August 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." On the afternoon of August 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation TD09; the China Meteorological Administration also upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5 p.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. 

At 2 a.m. on August 9, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 a.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 11 a.m., the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau followed the China Meteorological Administration in upgrading it to a tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international designation 2207, and named it "Mulan." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon; the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical storm. 

At around 10:50 a.m. on August 10, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Mulan made landfall along the coast of Xuwen County, Guangdong Province. At 9 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert and downgraded its rating to "medium." 

At around 4:30 a.m. on August 11, the Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center reported that Mulan made landfall again along the northeastern coast of Vietnam. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

On August 9, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea north-northeast of Palau Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. At 1 a.m. on August 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD10. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 11, at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 09W. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. On August 12, at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2208, and named it "Mireille." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. On August 13, at 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:30 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Mireille made landfall on the Izu Peninsula in Shizuoka Prefecture. On August 14, at 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center once again upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 4 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan stated that Mireille had transformed into an extratropical cyclone. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency also stated that it had transformed into an extratropical cyclone. On August 17, at 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

PAGASA: Florita  
On August 15, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northeast of Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. On August 21 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD11. At 9:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 11:00 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 3:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 10W. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  

On August 22 at 8:00 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 11:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2209 and naming it "Ma-on." At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau also upgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On August 23 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological Bureau upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At around 10:30 AM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Ma-on made landfall near Maconacon, Isabela Province.  

On August 24 at 8:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon, and at 9:00 PM, the Macao Meteorological Bureau also upgraded it to a typhoon.  

On August 25 at around 10:30 AM, the Guangzhou Meteorological Observatory reported that Ma-on made landfall along the coast of Dianbai District, Maoming City, Guangdong Province. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 4:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning, and at the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm. At around 8:30 PM, the China National Meteorological Center reported that Ma-on made landfall along the coast of Quang Ninh Province, Vietnam.  

On August 26 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:45 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.  

In the Hong Kong Observatory's August tropical cyclone report, Ma-on's peak intensity was revised to 120 km/h, and it was reclassified as a typhoon. In the Joint Typhoon Warning Center's best track report released on September 1, 2023, its peak intensity was revised to 65 knots (120 km/h).

On August 21, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters east of the Maug Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 99W. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 22 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, designating it as TD12. At 11 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international designation 2210 and naming it "Tokage." At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 11W. On August 23 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On August 25 at 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm, and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 10 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning for it. On August 26 at 2 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Tokage had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. On August 27 at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 1, 2023, its peak intensity was revised downward to 95 knots (175 km/h).

PAGASA: Henry  
On August 26, a tropical disturbance formed in the sea south-southwest of Minamitorishima, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On the morning of August 28 at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD13. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2211, and named it "Hinnamnor." Simultaneously, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 12W; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon.  

At 2 a.m. on August 29, the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a strong tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon; the Hong Kong Observatory marked it as a typhoon on the weather map. At 8 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe typhoon.  

At 2 a.m. on August 30, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a super typhoon. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a strong typhoon.  

At 2 a.m. on September 2, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon, while the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau downgraded it to a severe typhoon.  

At 8 a.m. on September 4, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it again to a strong typhoon. At 2 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it again to a super typhoon.  

At 2 p.m. on September 5, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it again to a moderate typhoon. At 5 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it again to a severe typhoon.  

At 2 a.m. on September 6, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Hinnamnor to a typhoon. At around 4:50 a.m., the Korea Meteorological Administration reported that Hinnamnor made landfall near Geoje City in southeastern South Korea. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Hinnamnor had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.  

At 8 a.m. on September 9, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on September 1, 2023, revised its peak wind speed to 145 knots (270 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Inday  
On September 4, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters southwest of Iwo Jima, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W.  
At 5:00 PM on September 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:30 PM on September 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium."  
At 11:30 AM on September 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 14W.  
At 8:00 AM on September 7, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD15. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it.  
At 8:00 AM on September 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2212, and named it "Muifa." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a mild typhoon and a tropical storm, respectively.  
At 2:00 AM on September 9, the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm.  
At 2:00 AM on September 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 11:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon. At 12:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At the same time, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 2:00 AM on September 11, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it to a strong typhoon. At 3:00 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a strong typhoon.  
At 2:00 PM on September 12, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau downgraded it to a typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon.  
At 11:00 AM on September 14, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it again to a strong typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau upgraded it again to a strong typhoon. At 8:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory and the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau downgraded it again to a typhoon. Around 8:30 PM, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Muifa made landfall along the coast of Putuo, Zhoushan City, Zhejiang Province.  
At around 12:30 AM on September 15, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Muifa made a second landfall along the coast of Fengxian District, Shanghai. At 8:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 12:00 PM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
At around 12:00 AM on September 16, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Muifa made a third landfall along the coast of Laoshan District, Qingdao City, Shandong Province. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Muifa transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At around 12:40 PM, the China Meteorological Administration reported that Muifa made a fourth landfall along the coast of Jinpu New District, Dalian City, Liaoning Province.  
At 2:00 PM on September 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.  
In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center on September 1, 2023, its peak intensity was revised down to 110 knots (205 km/h).

On September 9, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. On September 10, at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a tropical depression. On September 11, at 1:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 15W. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD16. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. On September 12, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2213, and named it "Muifa." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On September 14, at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. On September 9 at 11:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

At 2:00 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon. On September 16 at 2:00 AM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 8:00 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe typhoon. At 2:00 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory further upgraded it to a super typhoon.

Around 7:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Nanmadol made landfall near Kagoshima City, Kagoshima Prefecture.  
On September 19 at 2:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Nanmadol made a second landfall near Yanagawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm, and at the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2:00 PM, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a moderate typhoon. Around 4:30 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Nanmadol made a third landfall near Izumo City, Shimane Prefecture, marking the first recorded typhoon landfall in Shimane Prefecture since records began.  
On September 20 around 4:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Nanmadol made a fourth landfall near Niigata City. At 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Nanmadol transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency reported that Nanmadol had merged with a cold front.  
On September 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

On September 20, a tropical disturbance formed southwest of Iwo Jima, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 94W. At 2 a.m. on September 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 p.m., the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 a.m. on September 22, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD18; the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 17W. At 8 a.m. on September 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2215, and named it "Talas." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon; the Hong Kong Observatory and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 a.m. on September 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Talas had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.

PAGASA: Karding  
On September 21, a tropical disturbance formed east of Luzon, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 95W.  
At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On September 22, at 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 18W. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center first upgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number TD19. Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On September 23, at 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 2216 and naming it "Noru." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon.  
On September 24, at 8 AM, the China Meteorological Administration first upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 5 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. At 11 PM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a strong typhoon. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a strong typhoon.  
On September 25, at 2 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a super typhoon. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon. At 5 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon. At around 5:30 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Noru made landfall near Burdeos, Quezon Province, Philippines. At around 8:20 PM, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration reported that Noru made a second landfall near Dingalan, Aurora Province, Philippines. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a strong typhoon. At 11 PM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a strong typhoon.  
On September 26, at 5 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 AM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a typhoon. At 9 PM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it again to a strong typhoon.  
On September 27, at 2 AM, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it again to a super typhoon. At the same time, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it again to a strong typhoon. At 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it again to a super typhoon. At 8 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it again to a strong typhoon. At 11 PM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it again to a strong typhoon.  
On September 28, at around 4:30 AM, the Vietnam National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting reported that Noru made landfall near Da Nang, Vietnam. At 8 AM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm; the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a typhoon. At 10 AM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 PM, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm; the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded it to a mild typhoon; the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm; the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, while the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical storm.  
On September 29, at 2 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from the weather map.
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on September 1, 2023, revised its peak wind speed to 145 knots (270 kilometers per hour).

On September 22, a tropical disturbance formed northeast of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Disturbance 96W. On the afternoon of September 25, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and designated it as TD20. At 2 a.m. on September 26, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 19W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2217, and named it "Roke." Simultaneously, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon; the China Meteorological Administration, the Hong Kong Observatory, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 8 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 a.m. on September 27, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At 8 a.m. on September 28, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At the same time, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a typhoon. At 2 p.m. on September 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency stated that Roke had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 2 p.m. on September 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency removed the system from its weather map.

The Hong Kong Observatory, in its tropical cyclone report for September published on November 20, upgraded Rose's peak intensity to 110 kilometers per hour. The Japan Meteorological Agency, in its post-analysis report published on November 16, revised Rose's pressure downward to 965 hPa. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center, in its best track released on September 1, 2023, upgraded its peak to 75 knots (140 kilometers per hour).

Once a tropical cyclone in the Western Pacific reaches tropical storm intensity, it is named by the Typhoon Committee. These names are provided by 14 member countries or regions, each contributing 10 names, and then sorted alphabetically by the English names of the countries. Names in blue italics indicate those already used this year, bold names indicate active storms, unused names are shown in gray, and orange indicates the next name to be used. The storm names for 2022 may overlap with some storm names from 2004, 2005, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2016, and 2017.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form within, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list rotates every four years, with only retired names being replaced. An auxiliary list is also prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2023, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list includes all tropical cyclones that were active in the Western Pacific in 2022, including their intensity, duration, names, and the casualties and damage caused. All damages are measured in US dollars. Deaths in parentheses refer to those indirectly caused (such as traffic accidents, landslides, etc.).

Article_Name: 颱風苗柏 (2022年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Merbok (English: Typhoon Merbok, International Number: 2213, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP152022) is the 13th named storm of the 2022 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Merbok" was provided by Malaysia, referring to the zebra dove, commonly found in suburbs and wastelands, and a type of bird favored by Malaysians for keeping as pets.

On September 9, a tropical disturbance formed in the waters northwest of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. On September 10, at 8 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency once again upgraded it to a tropical depression. On September 11, at 1:30 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 15W. At 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number TD16. At 8 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. On September 12, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 2213, and named it "Muifa." At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a mild typhoon. At 8 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On September 14, at 2 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon. At the same time, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. On September 15, at 2 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Muifa had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 11 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning. However, Muifa, which had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone, maintained hurricane-force winds as it moved northeast and began impacting Alaska, USA, on September 16.

After transitioning into an extratropical cyclone, Merbok moved northward and struck Alaska, USA, causing significant damage. The U.S. National Weather Service described that the wave height along the coast of the seaside city of Nome reached nearly 3.3 meters, setting a new record since 1974. Then-Governor Mike Dunleavy declared a state of emergency on the 17th. According to past statistics, the water level on the 17th was 9 feet higher than normal, surpassing the peak records caused by severe storms in 2004 and 2011. However, as of that evening, the Alaska Department of Homeland Security and Emergency Management stated that the storm had caused no casualties.
