Article_Name: Mùa bão Tây Bắc Thái Bình Dương 2001 – Wikipedia tiếng Việt

Whole_Text.content: The 2001 Pacific Northwest Typhoon Season has no official boundaries; it occurred throughout the year 2001. However, most tropical cyclones tend to form between May and November. These are the conventional periods that define the timeframe during which most tropical cyclones form annually in the Northwest Pacific. The scope of this article is limited to the Pacific, the area north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms forming east of the International Date Line and north of the equator belong to the 2001 Northeast Pacific Hurricane Season. Tropical storms forming across the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA). Tropical depressions tracked by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) are assigned a "W" suffix after their identification number. Tropical depressions forming or moving into areas monitored by the Philippines are also named by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA). This is why, in many cases, a storm may have two different names.

In the information about the storms below, there is a difference in wind speed values between the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) and the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA), as JTWC applies the U.S. standard of determining sustained wind speed over a 1-minute period, while JMA determines sustained wind speed over a 10-minute period. This difference results in the wind speed values provided by JTWC generally being higher than those of JMA for the same storm.
A tropical depression moved across the Philippines in mid-February.
A tropical depression existed over the eastern waters of the Philippines from April 17 to April 21.
Tropical storm Cimaron formed on May 6 and it also moved through the Philippines.
Tropical depression Darna moved through the northern Philippines, however, no damage was reported.

Tropical Depression 04W formed on June 19 near Palau and moved westward, strengthening into Tropical Storm Chebi. Chebi then moved west-northwest and then northwest with tropical storm intensity before entering the Luzon Strait as a Category 1 storm. Late on June 23, Chebi peaked with winds of 85 knots (100 mph, 160 km/h), with its center located about 75 miles (120 km) south of Taiwan. Subsequently, a low-pressure trough forced Chebi to move northward, making landfall near Fuzhou, China. The storm weakened over land and then accelerated northeastward, passing through southeastern Shanghai before returning to the sea. The JMA and several weather centers ceased issuing advisories on June 30 as Chebi's remnants completely dissipated over the eastern Pacific Ocean.

Typhoon Durian struck southern China on July 1 with winds of 85 mph (135 km/h), causing 78 deaths and damages amounting to 446 million USD (2001 USD). The name Durian was proposed by Thailand and originates from the name of a fruit in Southeast Asia (Durian means durian fruit).

Severe tropical storm Utor developed on June 30 over the eastern waters of the Philippines. It then skimmed along the northern Luzon coastline on July 4 with winds of 90 mph (140 km/h). The storm continued moving west-northwest, striking southeastern China on July 6. Although not very strong, Utor caused a total of 197 fatalities and damages amounting to 297.2 million USD (2001 USD).
Formed over the eastern Philippine Sea, tropical storm Trami moved in a single northwest direction until dissipating on July 13 over southeastern China's mainland.
Tropical depression 08W only existed for a very short time and it remained over the ocean far from land.
The tropical depression classified by JMA also only existed for about 4 days from July 16 to 19.
Typhoon Kong-rey formed over the southern waters of Japan on July 21. Initially, it moved westward but then turned northeast before dissipating on July 28.
Typhoon Yutu made landfall in China before dissipating on July 26.

On July 29, Typhoon Toraji with winds of 115 mph (185 km/h) struck Taiwan before making landfall in southeastern China on the 30th. Torrential rains from the typhoon triggered flash floods and landslides across Taiwan, killing 200 people and causing material damage amounting to 7.7 billion New Taiwan dollars (245 million USD). Rocks and mud completely buried a village in Nantou County, resulting in the deaths of 30 villagers. In the aftermath of the typhoon, Taiwanese Prime Minister Chang Chun-hsiung criticized the excessive development in the region and the lack of attention to its negative impacts. He also initiated a reforestation project to prevent and mitigate the consequences of similar natural disasters in the future.
Man-yi is a storm of moderate intensity. It maintained an offshore trajectory and dissipated on August 9 over the waters east of Japan.
This tropical depression classified by JMA existed for 8 days without any intensification. It dissipated on August 8.
Tropical storm Usagi formed on August 8 in the South China Sea and struck Vietnam on the 10th.
In Japan, Pabuk caused 6 deaths and injured 32 others. The damage amounted to approximately 620 million yen (7.1 million USD).

Three circulations developed in a monsoon trough over the South China Sea in mid-August, and one of them became Tropical Depression Jolina in the western Philippines. Jolina moved very little until dissipating on the 19th.
Tropical depression 15W existed for a short period and did not affect the mainland.
Mainly moving in a northeast direction throughout its lifespan, Wutip developed into a strong storm before dissipating on September 2.

At the end of August 19, a thunderstorm area formed about 100 miles (160 km) south of Pohnpei. By August 22, the system's position was south-southeast of Guam as it moved east-northeast and continued to develop. After turning north, by August 27, it became a tropical depression about 250 miles (400 km) northwest of Wake Island, and by early the next morning, the tropical depression strengthened into Tropical Storm Sepat. Continuing to move northward, the storm peaked with winds of 45 mph before gradually weakening from August 28. The system then accelerated, turned back northeast, and became an extratropical low by the end of August 31 as it approached the International Date Line in the southern Aleutian Islands region.

At the end of August 26, a thunderstorm cloud system formed over the South China Sea, west of Luzon, with the possibility that it was a continuation of the remnants of Tropical Depression Jolina. By the end of August 28, the disturbance had developed into a tropical depression located about 300 miles (480 km) south-southwest of Hong Kong. Moving west-northwest, the tropical depression passed through the northeastern region of Hainan Island late on August 29, before strengthening into Tropical Storm Fitow a day later. Early on August 31, the storm began drifting northward, heading toward mainland China. That evening, it made landfall in Dongxing County and weakened into a tropical depression on September 1, before dissipating the following day. On Hainan Island, economic losses amounted to nearly 1.367 billion yuan (201.7 million USD). In total, 3,680 houses were damaged or destroyed, 4 people were killed, and 3.5 million people were affected by a weak tropical storm.

A tropical depression formed on September 3 and by the following day had strengthened into Tropical Storm Danas. On the 7th, Danas developed a small eye and reached Category 2 hurricane intensity. The next day, the storm continued to intensify into a Category 3 hurricane as it moved northwest toward Japan. Subsequently, Danas turned northeast and made landfall in the country before dissipating on September 11. On September 10, Hurricane Danas generated a tornado near Tokyo. This tornado caused roof damage, uprooted trees, and injured one person. Based on damage assessments, the Tokyo Regional Meteorological Observatory classified it as an F1 on the Fujita scale. According to actual records, 11 tornadoes occurred in the Kanto region. In Japan, Danas caused 8 fatalities, 48 injuries, and damages amounting to 1.1 billion yen (12.8 million USD).
Another tropical depression was classified by JMA. It existed for over a week before dissipating on September 12.

On September 5, a tropical depression formed in the northeastern region of Taiwan. Due to weak steering currents, the system moved erratically for an extended period. Initially, it drifted northeastward and strengthened into a tropical storm on the 6th. Subsequently, Nari remained nearly stationary near Okinawa, and the following day it reached typhoon intensity. Over the next five days, Nari executed three loops in its offshore trajectory, peaking during that time with winds of 115 mph (185 km/h) before weakening into a tropical storm on the 14th. However, Nari later re-intensified into a typhoon, and as it moved southeastward, it reached wind speeds of 100 mph (160 km/h) before striking northeastern Taiwan on the 16th. The storm moved across the island before entering the South China Sea on the 18th as a tropical depression. Moving westward, the tropical depression strengthened into a tropical storm and made landfall east of Hong Kong with winds of 65 mph (105 km/h) on the 20th. Nari caused 92 fatalities and brought rainfall of up to 1300 mm, leading to severe flooding.
Another tropical depression existed for 5 days before dissipating on September 12.

On September 16, a tropical depression formed, and by early the next morning, it strengthened into Tropical Storm Vipa. Two days later, Vipa became a typhoon, and it impacted Japan later that day, causing strong winds and minor damage. On the 21st, Vipa transitioned into an extratropical cyclone before dissipating southeast of the Kamchatka Peninsula on September 23. Later in 2002, the name Vipa was corrected to the proper spelling, Wipha.

Tropical depression 22W formed on September 18 and quickly intensified into a tropical storm with the international name Francisco two days later. On the 21st, Francisco reached hurricane intensity as it moved northward. The next day, the storm peaked with a pressure of 945 mbar and wind speeds of 100 mph (155 km/h) according to JMA. Francisco became an extratropical cyclone on the 25th before dissipating the following day.

A cluster of thunderstorms quickly developed into Tropical Depression 23W on September 22 according to JTWC; earlier it had been named Labuyo by PAGASA. On the 24th, the tropical depression strengthened into Tropical Storm Lekima. The storm then continued to intensify and peaked as a Category 2 storm on the 27th, before weakening and impacting Taiwan. In Taiwan, a total of 2 people were killed due to strong winds and large waves. Due to interaction with land, the storm rapidly weakened and eventually dissipated over mainland China on September 30.

Typhoon Krosa formed on October 3 and was first classified by the JMA as a tropical depression, before the JTWC also designated the system as Tropical Depression 24W later that day. The next day, the tropical depression strengthened into Tropical Storm Krosa, then moved into warm waters and quickly intensified into a typhoon. On October 6, Krosa peaked as a Category 3 typhoon before weakening to a Category 2 typhoon later the same day. The following day, due to moving into cold waters, the storm weakened to a tropical storm. Krosa dissipated on October 9 after being absorbed by a trough. No damage was reported from the storm.

Tropical depression 25W formed over the Philippine Sea on October 11, and just three hours later it was named Maring by PAGASA. Two days later, the system was upgraded to a tropical storm by JTWC. At the same time, JMA also classified it as Tropical Storm Haiyan. The next day, both JMA and JTWC upgraded Haiyan to a typhoon. Haiyan peaked on the 15th as a Category 2 typhoon. Afterward, the storm turned northeast, gradually weakened, and dissipated on the 18th.
Podul developed into a super typhoon according to JTWC, however, it always remained offshore far from land.
Another tropical depression was classified by JMA. It only lasted about 1 day before dissipating on the 22nd.

On November 5, a tropical depression formed over the Philippine Sea and moved westward, striking the Philippines the following day. While over the central Philippines, the tropical depression strengthened into a tropical storm on the 7th. The storm then entered the South China Sea and continued to intensify, eventually peaking with winds of 135 mph (215 km/h) according to the JTWC, equivalent to a Category 4 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson scale. Lingling later weakened, made landfall in Vietnam, and dissipated on the 12th. A total of 189 people were killed by the storm, 171 of them in the Philippines, with the remainder in Vietnam.

A tropical depression moved towards the Philippines around mid-November; however, it turned back to the northeast before reaching the country. The tropical depression dissipated on the 25th. Since JMA did not monitor the system, it did not have an international name.

Tropical depression 29W was active in the southern South China Sea during the latter half of November. This system was classified as a tropical storm by JTWC, but PAGASA considered it to only reach the tropical depression level.
Typhoon Kajiki moved through the Philippines in early December before dissipating over the South China Sea on the 9th.
Initially, JTWC believed that 31W was the early stage, the precursor of Typhoon Faxai, but later they discovered that these were two separate systems.

On December 13, a tropical depression formed off the coast of the Western Pacific, and two days later it strengthened into a tropical storm, with the international name Faxai. As Faxai moved quickly northwestward, it intensified and peaked as a Category 5 super typhoon on the 23rd with 1-minute sustained winds of 180 mph (290 km/h). Subsequently, cold water and upper-level wind shear weakened the storm until it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone on the 25th. Faxai, the strongest storm of the typhoon season and one of the strongest Northwest Pacific typhoons ever recorded in December, remained offshore and did not impact land. Initially, the JTWC believed that Faxai and Tropical Depression 31W were the same system. However, later analyses determined that 31W was an entirely separate storm. As a result, after reanalysis, Faxai was assigned a new designation of 33W by the JTWC (32W was Typhoon Vamei).

Tropical depression 32W formed at a location 200 nautical miles (370 km) east of Singapore on December 26. This was an extremely unusual system as it developed in a very low-latitude area just north of the equator. Its initial position at latitude 1.4°N meant it was only 157 km from the equator. On December 27, the tropical depression was upgraded to Tropical Storm Vamei, and shortly after, it made landfall in Malaysia. By December 29, Vamei entered the Indian Ocean as a tropical depression, then re-intensified before dissipating on January 1, 2002. The name Vamei was retired in 2004 and replaced with Peipah due to its unique position and trajectory.

Within the Northwest Pacific region, both the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) assign names to tropical cyclones forming in this area, resulting in the same tropical cyclone potentially having two different names. The Japan Meteorological Agency assigns international names on behalf of the Typhoon Committee of the World Meteorological Organization, naming tropical cyclones when their 10-minute sustained wind speeds reach 40 mph (65 km/h) or higher, equivalent to the tropical storm level or above. Meanwhile, the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration assigns names to any tropical cyclone forming or entering their "area of responsibility," located between 135°E-115°E and 5°N-25°N, even if the cyclone has already been given an international name. Names of notable tropical cyclones are retired by both PAGASA and the Northwest Pacific Typhoon Committee. When PAGASA's list of names for the Philippine region is exhausted, additional names are taken from a supplementary list, with the first 10 names from that list announced before each typhoon season. Unused names are marked in gray.

During this typhoon season, 26 tropical cyclones were named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, corresponding to the formation of 26 tropical storms. These names were taken from a list of 140 names submitted by 14 member countries and territories of the Northwest Pacific Typhoon Committee. Below is the list of international names used during the 2001 typhoon season. This is the only season in which the name "Vipa" was used. It was replaced with the more accurate name "Wipha" in 2002.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses a separate list to name tropical cyclones that form or move into the area they monitor. If the main list for each year is insufficient, additional names will be taken from a supplementary list, with the first 10 names announced annually before the typhoon season begins. A new set of lists has been implemented since 2001. In the table below, names marked in gray mean they have not been used, and names not retired will be reused in the 2005 typhoon season.
The name Vamei has been retired by the Northwest Pacific Typhoon Committee after this typhoon season. The new name chosen to replace it is Peipah.

In Vietnam, a storm (reaching tropical storm intensity or higher) will be assigned a number when it enters the area monitored by the Vietnam Meteorological and Hydrological Forecasting Center, defined in the East Sea west of the 120°E meridian and north of the 10°N parallel. The storm's number is assigned based on its order of appearance in the year. Below are the storms numbered by the Vietnam Meteorological and Hydrological Forecasting Center in 2001:

Whole_Text.content: Data on typhoons in 1993 (tropical cyclones that occurred in the Northwest Pacific). The number of typhoons that formed was 28. The number that approached Japan was 9, and the number that made landfall was 6, which was the highest on record at the time (currently the second highest). This number of landfalls was about twice the average (approximately 3). Typhoon No. 1 formed on March 13. Typhoons were concentrated between August and October, with 22 typhoons forming from August to December. Typhoons made landfall mainly in July and August, and Typhoon No. 13, which made landfall in August, struck Kyushu with "very strong" intensity, causing extensive damage.

Whole_Text.header: Number of typhoons making landfall in Japan
The active periods of each tropical cyclone

Whole_Text.content: On March 10, 1993, a tropical depression formed near the Marshall Islands and developed into a typhoon on the 13th. It was named Typhoon "Irma." Typhoon No. 1 moved northwest while slightly intensifying and became a tropical depression on the 17th.

199302・06W・Goring  
A tropical depression formed near the Marshall Islands on June 16. It developed into a typhoon on the 21st and was named "Koren." Typhoon No. 2 began to rapidly intensify around the 22nd and temporarily reached "violent" strength around the 24th. It then passed through Luzon Island and became a tropical depression on the 29th. It became the strongest typhoon of the year.

199303・08W・Flyn A tropical depression that formed east of the Philippines around July 7 developed into a typhoon on the 8th. It was named Typhoon Luis. Typhoon No. 3 passed through the Philippines and then developed in the South China Sea. It later became a tropical depression on the continent on the 13th.

199304・10W formed over the sea northeast of the Mariana Islands on July 20. By the 24th, it had developed into a medium-sized, average-strength system over the sea west of Chichijima, and on the 25th, it made landfall in Tokushima Prefecture as a medium-sized, weak system. After landfall, it gradually weakened as it moved northwest to north-northwest, made a second landfall in Okayama Prefecture, exited into the Sea of Japan, and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. Due to the impact of this typhoon, 15 buildings were flooded above floor level, and 10 buildings were flooded below floor level. [1]

199305・11W・Lumin formed on July 26 over the northern sea near Okinotorishima and made landfall on the Osumi Peninsula in Kagoshima Prefecture around 11 a.m. on the 27th. It then moved northeast and made landfall again near Tokuyama City in Yamaguchi Prefecture around 5:30 p.m. on the same day, before advancing into the Sea of Japan on the 28th. Additionally, Typhoon No. 6 followed this typhoon, with two typhoons consecutively making landfall in Kyushu, causing further damage.

199306・12W・Myrin After forming over the sea south of Okinawa on July 28, it strengthened as it moved northward over the sea east of Okinawa's main island and made landfall near Nagasaki City, Nagasaki Prefecture, before midnight on the 30th [2]. It then proceeded through the Tsushima Strait into the Sea of Japan [2]. As mentioned in the previous section, it made landfall immediately after Typhoon No. 5 passed, causing damage to expand in western Japan. Due to these two typhoons, heavy rainfall occurred in the western parts of Kyushu, Shikoku, and the Chugoku region, with total precipitation reaching 966 mm in Asahimaru (Kamikatsu Town, Tokushima Prefecture), 809 mm in Motokawa (Motokawa Village, Kochi Prefecture), and 800 mm in Mitate (Hinoemata Town, Miyazaki Prefecture). Additionally, landslides and other disasters occurred in Oita Prefecture, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Miyazaki Prefecture, and other areas [2].
199310・01C became a transboundary typhoon.

199311・17W formed over the far southern seas of Japan on August 22. It moved north-northwest while intensifying, changed its course to the north over the eastern seas of Torishima in the afternoon of the 26th, slowly moved northward east of the Izu Islands from the early hours of the 27th, and came closest to the Kanto region on the same day. It then brushed past the Boso Peninsula, passed near Choshi City in Chiba Prefecture, moved north-northeast, and made landfall near Kushiro City in Hokkaido on the night of the 27th.

199313・19W・Teshin Formed near Okinotori Island on August 31. It developed while moving westward, changed its course northward on September 1, and continued to move north on September 2 with a central pressure of 925 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 50 m/s, becoming a large and very strong typhoon. It then passed near Kume Island in Okinawa, where a minimum sea level pressure of 928.1 hPa was recorded. Additionally, Kume Island observed a maximum instantaneous wind speed of 53.9 m/s and a maximum wind speed of 36.5 m/s, but the anemometer was destroyed at that moment, and unofficially even stronger winds were observed. The typhoon maintained its strength as it approached Kyushu and made landfall in the southern part of the Satsuma Peninsula before 4:00 PM on September 3 with a record-breaking strength of a central pressure of 930 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 50 m/s. This strength was close to the Ise Bay Typhoon (929 hPa), which caused the worst damage in Japan's typhoon history in 1959, and since the start of statistics in 1951, it became the third-lowest central pressure at landfall after the Second Muroto Typhoon and the Ise Bay Typhoon. However, after landfall, it gradually weakened and became an extratropical cyclone in the Sea of Japan.

199314・20W・Anshin  
It formed over the sea south of Okinawa on September 7 and moved over the eastern sea of the Nansei Islands. It made landfall in southern Wakayama Prefecture on the 9th, transitioned into an extratropical cyclone in southern Nagano Prefecture, and moved to the eastern sea of Japan [3]. Due to the impact of this typhoon, 4 people were confirmed dead or missing, 12 were injured, 1 building was completely destroyed or washed away, 161 buildings were partially or half-damaged, 156 buildings were flooded above floor level, and 1,388 buildings were flooded below floor level [4].
199315・21W・Waldin
199318・23W・Anding
199319・25W・Dinant
199320・26W・Kajang
199321・27W・Gandan
199323・30W・Hashin After hitting the Philippines, it passed through the South China Sea and approached Hong Kong, also triggering the China Airlines Flight 605 overrun accident at Kai Tak Airport.
199328・37W・Pudding
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Whole_Text.header: Liver-related regional wind and water damage
Whole_Text.content: The Kimotsuki Region Wind and Water Disaster was a flood caused by a typhoon that occurred in Kagoshima Prefecture in October 1938 (Showa 13). It occurred in the Kimotsuki River on the Kimotsuki Peninsula (Osumi Peninsula). It is also referred to as the "Kimotsuki Flood" or the "Kimotsuki River Flood."

On October 8, 1938, a typhoon formed east of the Philippines. At 6:00 PM on the 14th, it passed over the sea west of Yakushima. Around 2:00 AM on the 15th, the center of the typhoon reached Yakushima. At 6:00 AM on the 15th, it passed northeastward from the eastern coast of Tanegashima. The typhoon dissipated west of Hachijojima on the 16th. According to records from the Yakushima Rainfall Observation Station, the lowest pressure was 730.2 mmHg (973.52 hPa) at 2:00 AM on the 15th, and the strongest wind speed was 33 meters per second at 3:00 AM.

When passing through Yakushima and Tanegashima between October 14 and 15, the speed was 10 to 15 kilometers per hour [1]. During the night of the 14th, over 400 millimeters of heavy rain concentrated locally in a short period, causing problems [1], and the southern part of the Osumi Peninsula recorded over 400 millimeters of rainfall in 24 hours [6]. At the Kanoya Observatory, the daily rainfall was 389 millimeters, and at the Takayama Observatory, it was 400 millimeters [2]. Significant damage occurred, including the collapse of 10 levees in the Kimotsuki River system [6][1]. The areas most severely affected were Takayama Town, Aira Village, and Uchinoura Town [1]. According to Kagoshima University, there were 310 deaths, 125 missing persons, totaling 435 victims, and 629 seriously injured [1]. However, according to the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, there were 304 deaths, 131 missing persons, and 628 injured [2]. Kagoshima University reported 1,969 completely destroyed houses, 1,397 partially destroyed houses, and 10,568 flooded houses [1], while the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism reported 1,532 destroyed and partially destroyed houses and 5,067 flooded houses [2]. The total damage amounted to approximately 36 million yen at the time, with about 20 million yen related to agriculture [1]. At Tashiro Elementary School in Kinko Town, a landslide from the mountain behind destroyed the wooden school building [6], killing two staff members [6]. In Aira Town, Kanoya City, flooding occurred, and bodies were recovered at the rescue headquarters [6].

The area with the most casualties was the Takayama district in Kimotsuki Town. According to Teru Iwamatsu, an emeritus professor at Kagoshima University, in the Takayama district, "the mountain collapsed, turning into a debris flow that surged downstream, causing flooding and inundation." During the Heisei era, monuments such as the "Stone Monument Conveying the Damage" and the "Takayama River Flood History Monument" were constructed. According to the inscription on the monument, from October 14 to 15, a total rainfall of 420 millimeters in Takayama Town caused a mountain tsunami, resulting in 118 deaths, 53 missing persons, and 253 seriously injured individuals. The massive floodwaters surged like a tide, making it impossible to prevent the disaster. Houses that were inundated became completely submerged, forcing people to evacuate to rooftops, but some were swept downstream.

On the morning of October 15, damage information was conveyed to the prefectural office, but details were not well understood. However, due to the unprecedented nature of the situation, a relief and rescue headquarters was established at the prefectural office, and a branch office was set up in Kanoya Town. A medical relief team was formed with members from the Kagoshima Prefectural Hospital and the Prefectural Medical Association. On the same day, a maritime team was dispatched to Uchinoura on the police ship "Asahi Sakura," accompanied by the medical relief team. A land team was dispatched to Kanoya. After the situation became clear, the 45th Infantry Regiment from Kagoshima was deployed on the 20th, and the Kumamoto Engineering Corps was deployed on the 21st. The funding was covered by national subsidies, the prefecture's recovery and reconstruction budget, and donations collected from across the country. River improvement by the national government had begun in 1937, the year before the flood, but it was fully implemented after the disaster. The river improvement included straightening the meandering Kimotsuki River and constructing embankments. According to the Osumi River and National Highway Office, even if rainfall of the same scale were to occur, flooding is not expected. However, during Typhoon No. 24 in 2018, tributaries temporarily exceeded the flood danger level, indicating that unforeseen situations are possible.

This article is a stub related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this article (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters). Wikimedia Commons has a category related to the Kimotsuki region flood disaster. This article is a stub related to Kagoshima Prefecture. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this article (Portal: Japanese Prefectures / Kagoshima Prefecture).

Article_Name: 颱風莫蘭蒂 (2004年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Meranti (English: Typhoon Meranti; International designation: 0412; JTWC: 14W) was one of the tropical cyclones in the 2004 Pacific typhoon season. The name was provided by Malaysia, and Meranti refers to a tall tree with relatively soft wood, commonly used as a building material in Malaysia.
On the morning of August 4 at 2 a.m., the tropical depression Moranti passed through the waters west of Wake Island, but there was no significant damage.

Article_Name: 태풍 하기비스 (2007년) - 위키백과, 우리 모두의 백과사전

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Hagibis (HAGIBIS) was active from November 21 to November 27, 2007, and was the 24th typhoon of 2007, recording a minimum pressure of 970 hPa. It affected the Philippines. Hagibis was submitted by the Philippines and means "fast." The name was derived from the diaper brand "Huggies," owned by Kimberly-Clark in the United States.

Typhoon Hagibis, the 24th typhoon, formed on November 21, 2007, at 3 a.m. in the sea approximately 690 km southwest of Manila, Philippines. It developed while moving northwestward, and by November 22, it had intensified into a typhoon of "strong" intensity. However, forecasting agencies predicted that the typhoon would make landfall in Vietnam and dissipate in the inland regions of Vietnam. Contrary to these predictions, the typhoon began to stall over the eastern sea of Vietnam starting November 23. While repeatedly moving southwestward, northwestward, and eastward, the typhoon eventually began to move eastward from the night of November 24, and by November 27, it struck the southern part of Luzon Island in the Philippines. During this process, the typhoon significantly weakened, and after moving out to the eastern sea of the Philippines, it soon dissipated. This typhoon exhibited an unusual trajectory, moving westward, stalling, and then reversing its course 180 degrees to move eastward. The reason for this trajectory was that the typhoon stalled under the influence of a cold continental high-pressure system to the northwest, and as it approached within 1,000 km of Typhoon Mitag, which was located over the eastern sea of the Philippines, the Fujiwhara effect occurred, where two tropical cyclones in close proximity influence each other's paths. As a result, "Hagibis" moved eastward, while "Mitag" moved westward.

Article_Name: Tufão Yutu (2007) – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Yutu (international designation: 0702; JTWC designation: 02W; Philippine designation: Amang, also known as super typhoon Yutu) was the third tropical cyclone and the second typhoon of the 2007 Pacific typhoon season. Yutu was also the first super typhoon of the season. The typhoon formed on May 15 and became an extratropical cyclone on May 22. Yutu passed over Iwo Jima, one of several Japanese islands in the northwest Pacific Ocean, but without major consequences.

On May 15, 2007, the QuikSCAT satellite recorded winds of 85 km/h in a tropical disturbance located south-southeast of Guam. Later that day, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) classified this system as a tropical depression. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) issued a tropical cyclone formation alert.

The following day, the JMA began issuing regular advisories on this depression. The system slowly strengthened, resulting in a second tropical cyclone formation alert issued by the JTWC later that day, local time. In this second alert, the JTWC noted that the system had a well-defined strengthening surface air circulation. By 12:00 UTC on May 16, the JTWC also classified the system as Tropical Depression 02W, based on QuikSCAT satellite estimates. On the morning of May 17, the JMA classified the depression as Tropical Storm Yutu. The name Yutu was given by China and refers to a rabbit in a Chinese fable. Three hours later, the JTWC also classified the depression as a tropical storm. On May 18, Yutu changed its course to the northwest and entered the area of responsibility of the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA). At the same time, the JMA classified Yutu as a severe tropical storm. The Philippine agency named the storm "Amang." Later that day, the JTWC classified Yutu as a typhoon and identified a distinct eye in satellite images. At 18:00 UTC, the JMA also classified the storm as a typhoon as Yutu continued to intensify. It began moving toward Iwo Jima, undergoing rapid intensification, with air currents heading north and little vertical wind shear.

On the night of May 20, Yutu reached its peak intensity as a strong typhoon equivalent to a Category 4 hurricane on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale, shortly after the JTWC classified it as a super typhoon. Despite being over cooler waters, its strong northward air currents helped it maintain its strength, with its eye measuring 20 km in diameter on the morning of May 21. The typhoon began to gradually weaken, passing over Okinotorishima and near Iwo Jima that day as it accelerated northeastward. Winds of 122 km/h were recorded in Iwo Jima around 15:00 UTC, with gusts of 192 km/h. At that time, atmospheric pressure of 976 mbar was recorded on the island. Yutu then began transitioning into an extratropical cyclone, and the JTWC issued its final advisory on the morning of May 22. The JMA issued its last advisory after the system had already transformed into an extratropical cyclone the following day. In post-storm analyses, the JTWC increased the peak intensity to maximum sustained winds of 240 km/h. Thus, Yutu was classified by the JTWC as a super typhoon.

Tropical storm alerts and warnings were issued for Yap on May 17 as the JTWC classified the system as a tropical storm. Subsequently, with the arrival of the storm, wind gusts of 63 km/h were recorded at 13:53 UTC on the same day. Yutu quickly passed over the island without causing destruction or fatalities. Later, Yutu, now as a typhoon, passed over the Ogasawara Islands, specifically over Iwo Jima and Okinotorishima. Despite winds of 122 km/h with gusts of 193 km/h, Iwo Jima also reported no damage or casualties.
"Reports on tropical cyclones formed in May 2007 (including Yutu)"

Article_Name: Tufão Vamco (2009) – Wikipédia, a enciclopédia livre

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Vamco (international designation: 0910; JTWC designation: 11W) was an intense tropical cyclone that spent its entire lifespan moving northward in the northwest Pacific Ocean in mid-August 2009. Vamco formed from an area of meteorological disturbances just north of the Marshall Islands on August 16 and became a tropical storm the following day. With favorable weather conditions, Vamco intensified into a severe tropical storm on August 18 according to the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA), and into a typhoon on August 19. From then on, Vamco began to undergo rapid intensification, reaching its peak intensity on August 21, with maximum sustained winds of 215 km/h according to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC), or 185 km/h according to the JMA. From that point, Vamco began to gradually weaken as it gained more latitude and started transitioning into an extratropical cyclone on August 25, when the JTWC issued its final advisory on the system. The JMA maintained regular advisories on Vamco for the remainder of that day and downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. The JMA also issued its final advisory on the system in the early hours (UTC) of August 26. Vamco did not directly impact any coastal regions while in its tropical phase. However, the strong swells caused by the typhoon indirectly triggered rip currents and surf in the Northern Mariana Islands. Vamco also reached eastern Alaska as an extratropical cyclone, causing moderate rainfall and winds exceeding 80 km/h. However, there are no reports of significant impacts associated with the typhoon.

Typhoon Vamco formed from an area of meteorological disturbances that persisted north of Kwajalein Atoll, Marshall Islands, and began showing signs of organization on August 13. Initially, a low-level cyclonic circulation was present within a trough of narrow barometric gradients. The low-level cyclonic circulation within this trough was slowly organizing with the formation of new convection areas, aided by favorable upper-level outflows driven by the presence of a tropical upper tropospheric trough to its northwest. Additionally, wind shear in the region was low, and the warm ocean waters were highly conducive to its intensification. The disturbance moved westward in the following days, and on August 16, the system had already shown sufficient organization for the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC), the United States Navy's tropical cyclone monitoring agency, to issue a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert (TCFA) for the system, indicating that the disturbance could become a significant tropical cyclone within 12 to 24 hours. Later that day, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA), the meteorological agency designated by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) for monitoring tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific Ocean, classified the disturbance as a weak tropical depression. The system continued to organize, and the JMA upgraded the depression to a full tropical depression in the early hours (UTC) of August 17. A few hours later, the system's low-level cyclonic circulation already had maximum sustained winds of 55 km/h, prompting the JTWC to also classify the system as a tropical depression, assigning it the designation "11W." The system moved almost directly north throughout its lifecycle due to the presence of a strong subtropical high to its northeast. Later that afternoon (UTC), the JTWC upgraded the depression to a tropical storm. At that time, upper-level outflows were aiding the production of new convection areas and consequently intensifying the cyclone; these outflows were being established by the presence of a tropical upper tropospheric trough, as well as the formation of a mesoscale anticyclone over the system. A few hours later, the JMA also classified the system as a tropical storm, naming it "Vamco," a name submitted to the typhoon naming list by Vietnam, referring to a river in the southern part of the country. From the early hours (UTC) of August 18, Vamco began to consolidate further as its outflows became more defined. Gradually intensifying that day, Vamco became a severe tropical storm, according to the JMA, later that day. In the early hours of August 19, both the JMA and the JTWC upgraded Vamco to a typhoon as the system acquired more upper-level outflows, forming new areas of deep convection as a result. From that morning, Vamco began undergoing rapid intensification, and an eye, approximately 18 km in diameter, began forming within its convection areas. Additionally, Vamco's movement was nearly stationary, as the same tropical upper tropospheric trough providing favorable outflows weakened the dominant subtropical high. As a result, the atmospheric anticyclonic movement in that region was nearly halted. Vamco continued to intensify until the early hours of August 20. From then on, its intensity remained stable, with maximum sustained winds of 195 km/h. Vamco maintained its stable intensity until the morning (UTC) of August 21, when it began to intensify again. At that time, Vamco presented itself as a typical intense tropical cyclone, with a well-defined eye surrounded by intense areas of deep convection. At that time, Vamco reached its peak intensity, with maximum sustained winds of 215 km/h. However, from that afternoon, Vamco began to weaken slowly due to a slight deterioration in upper-level outflows caused by the approach of a mid-latitude trough. From August 22, Vamco's maximum wind radius began to shrink with the loss of deep convection areas. However, Vamco was able to maintain its stable intensity at 175 km/h during that day. But from that night, Vamco's eye began to disappear, along with the deep convection areas, due to the intrusion of drier air into the typhoon's cyclonic circulation. The typhoon's eye reappeared during the early hours of August 23 as Vamco managed to maintain its intensity at 165 km/h, even under the effects of the drier air, which began to sever the typhoon's connection to the tropical air mass to its south. Vamco began accelerating northward during the afternoon of August 23 as the subtropical high to its east began to intensify, thereby increasing atmospheric circulation. During the morning of August 24, Vamco's eye diameter increased more than fourfold, and the typhoon became an annular cyclone, characterized by a slow response to external influences. That night (UTC), Vamco began moving more northeastward as it reached the northwestern edge of the subtropical high and began to be influenced by westerly winds. In the early morning of August 25, Vamco began interacting with the baroclinic zone, a typical mid-latitude area where the atmosphere is highly unstable. In the region, wind shear was strong, which began to separate the typhoon's low-level cyclonic circulation from its upper-level circulation. Additionally, Vamco began undergoing extratropical transition at that time, meaning Vamco began transforming into an extratropical cyclone. As a result, the JTWC issued its final advisory on Vamco on the morning of August 25 as the typhoon began exhibiting frontal characteristics, such as the formation of an associated cold front and warm front, indicating that the extratropical transition was well underway. Furthermore, its eye disappeared, and its deep convection areas rapidly declined as the cyclone moved into cooler waters. However, the JMA still maintained Vamco as a tropical cyclone for the remainder of that day and downgraded it to a severe tropical storm around noon (UTC). In the early hours of August 26, the JMA also issued its final advisory on Vamco as the cyclone completed its extratropical transition.

The United States National Weather Service office in Guam issued special weather statements for the Northern Mariana Islands as the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) began issuing warnings about the newly formed tropical depression 11W. Residents of Guam, Rota, Tinian, and Saipan were warned about the possible arrival of a severe storm over the islands and to check their emergency plans in case a severe storm hit the islands. However, Vamco moved northward for most of its lifespan and did not directly affect the islands. Nevertheless, the strong swells caused by the typhoon generated high surf and strong rip currents on these islands. After Vamco became an extratropical cyclone, the system reached the Aleutian Islands, causing moderate rain and winds of up to 85 km/h.

Article_Name: 強烈熱帶風暴泰利 (2012年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Talim (English: Severe Tropical Storm Talim, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP062012, International Number: 1205, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Carina) was the fifth named storm of the 2012 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Talim" (Tagalog: Talim) was provided by the Philippines and means sharp and pointed. Talim developed from a low-pressure center associated with a trough. Before Talim formed, the coast of South China was affected by a trough; as the trough gradually weakened in the northern South China Sea, a low-pressure area less than 100 kilometers southeast of Hainan Island developed into Tropical Cyclone Talim. Talim was one of the few tropical cyclones to move eastward in the South China Sea, advancing eastward from Hainan under the guidance of the equatorial anticyclone, eventually weakening and dissipating after moving through the Taiwan Strait to the East China Sea. In its early stages, Talim exhibited characteristics of a "monsoon depression," with stronger winds on the outside and weaker winds on the inside, causing occasional strong winds along the South China coast. However, as Talim intensified, the monsoon depression characteristics disappeared, and the Hong Kong Observatory issued the first No. 3 tropical cyclone warning signal of the year for Talim, but after the signal was issued, wind speeds unexpectedly decreased instead of increasing.

On June 16, 2012, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded tropical disturbance 92W located in the northern South China Sea to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. At 8:00 PM on June 16, the Macao Meteorological Bureau reported that a tropical depression had formed in the northern South China Sea east of Hainan Province. At 9:10 AM on June 17, the Hong Kong Observatory stated that a low-pressure area east of Hainan Island was "gradually intensifying into a tropical depression." At 10:45 AM on the same day, the Hong Kong Observatory officially upgraded the low-pressure area to a tropical depression, which was located about 480 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong at the time. At 4:25 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory reported that the tropical depression had slightly intensified in the afternoon and began moving in an easterly direction. At 7:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert, upgrading it to a High rating, predicting that the tropical disturbance would move northeast or east-northeast, approaching the Taiwan Strait. Later in the evening, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a tropical storm. In the early hours of June 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded the tropical depression to a tropical storm and named it Talim. At 4:00 AM, the Macao Meteorological Bureau upgraded Talim to a tropical storm. At 4:45 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory also upgraded Talim to a tropical storm. At 10:45 PM, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded Talim to a severe tropical storm. Starting June 18, the storm's northward component increased. At 8:00 AM on June 19, the Macao Meteorological Bureau upgraded Talim to a severe tropical storm. At 12:00 PM on June 19, the China Meteorological Administration upgraded Talim to a severe tropical storm. In the evening, the Japan Meteorological Agency followed suit and upgraded it. At 8:00 AM on June 20, the Macao Meteorological Bureau downgraded Talim to a tropical storm. At 8:45 AM on June 20, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Talim to a tropical storm. On June 21, under the influence of strong vertical wind shear, Talim weakened rapidly. At 4:35 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 5:45 AM, the Hong Kong Observatory also downgraded Talim to a tropical depression, while the Macao Meteorological Bureau downgraded it to a tropical depression at 8:00 AM on the same day. At 11:45 AM on the same day, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Talim to a low-pressure area.
The circulation caused heavy rain in central Vietnam.

On June 17, Talim was about to form, and the Observatory issued a "Special Weather Alert" at 9:10 a.m. Talim strengthened into a tropical depression near the southeastern coast of Hainan at 10:45 a.m., and the Hong Kong Observatory updated the special weather alert at 11:07 a.m., stating that the tropical depression was initially moving slowly but would issue a tropical cyclone warning signal if it further strengthened or approached Hong Kong. The Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 1 Standby Signal at 4:20 p.m. that same afternoon, with Talim located about 470 kilometers southwest of Hong Kong. At 8:45 p.m. that evening, the Observatory stated that it would consider issuing the No. 3 Tropical Cyclone Warning Signal the following morning and unusually urged parents to pay attention to weather information before sending their children to school.

On June 18, Talim continued to move slowly, gradually entering within 400 kilometers of Hong Kong. The Observatory delayed the issuance of the No. 3 Signal to later in the morning and later stated that "the chance of issuing the No. 3 Signal this morning is not high." At 2:00 p.m., the Observatory issued another "Special Weather Alert," stating that it would consider issuing the No. 3 Signal between 4:00 p.m. and 8:00 p.m.; however, as Talim remained stationary between 2:00 p.m. and 4:00 p.m., the Observatory further delayed the issuance of the No. 3 Signal, stating that the chance of issuing the No. 3 Signal in the evening was quite high. At 10:40 p.m. that evening, the Observatory issued the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal, with Talim located about 360 kilometers south of Hong Kong and having strengthened into a severe tropical storm. The Observatory stated that the No. 3 Signal would be maintained for some time; however, at 7:45 a.m., the Observatory stated that Hong Kong would turn to northerly winds, which would be blocked by terrain, and it would consider replacing the No. 3 Signal with the No. 1 Signal in the next few hours. At 10:20 a.m., the Observatory replaced the No. 3 Signal with the No. 1 Standby Signal, with Talim located about 300 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. However, after replacing the No. 1 Signal, Talim continued to approach Hong Kong.

Talim came closest to Hong Kong at 5:00 p.m. on June 19, passing about 260 kilometers southeast of Hong Kong. The Observatory canceled all tropical cyclone warning signals at 8:40 p.m. that evening, with Talim located about 270 kilometers east-southeast of Hong Kong. On June 20, under the influence of the northwesterly continental airflow associated with Talim, the weather in Hong Kong was extremely hot, with the Observatory recording a maximum temperature of 33 degrees Celsius. The Observatory issued a Very Hot Weather Warning at 8:45 a.m. that day and canceled it at 11:00 p.m. the same day.

During the storm, only one of the eight designated automatic weather stations in the Observatory's wind measurement network recorded strong winds, and the No. 3 Signal did not meet the standard; Cheung Chau recorded the highest 10-minute average wind speed of 48 kilometers per hour.

The Geophysical and Meteorological Bureau hoisted Typhoon Signal No. 1 at 7:15 PM on June 17. On the same evening, the bureau stated that it would consider whether to hoist Typhoon Signal No. 3 early the next morning depending on the actual situation. In the early hours of June 18, the bureau stated that it would consider whether to hoist Typhoon Signal No. 3 in the morning depending on the actual situation; later that morning, the bureau stated that it would consider whether to hoist Typhoon Signal No. 3 during the day depending on the actual situation; in the afternoon, the bureau stated that it would consider whether to hoist Typhoon Signal No. 3 in the evening depending on the actual situation. In the early hours of June 19, the bureau stated that the chance of hoisting Typhoon Signal No. 3 in the morning was low. At 9:59 AM, the bureau stated that Typhoon Signal No. 1 would be maintained until the evening. At 10:03 PM, the bureau stated that it would consider removing all typhoon signals in the next few hours. At 4:00 AM on June 20, the bureau removed all typhoon signals.

Whole_Text.header: Reason for maintaining Typhoon Signal No. 1
Whole_Text.content:
Since the Hong Kong Observatory hoisted the No. 1 typhoon signal on the evening of June 17, strong winds began to blow across the three major bridges (with maximum wind speeds of 45, 43, and 42 kilometers per hour that evening). This led the Observatory to believe that the winds would persist and continue to strengthen. However, the winds eased before midnight, and there was no significant increase in wind strength in the early hours of June 18. Coupled with Typhoon Talim's continued eastward movement, the Observatory decided not to upgrade to the No. 3 typhoon signal in the early morning.

Throughout June 18, the Observatory's tropical cyclone updates in the early morning, morning, and afternoon consistently mentioned the possibility of upgrading to the No. 3 signal in the next period. This was due to intermittent strong winds on the three major bridges, sustained moderate winds in urban areas, and Typhoon Talim's continued eastward trajectory, which made the Observatory cautious about making any hasty decisions.

From the early morning to the morning of June 19, Macau's wind conditions showed no significant changes, and Typhoon Talim's trajectory continued to shift eastward. As a result, the Observatory stated that the likelihood of upgrading to the No. 3 signal in the morning was low. They also announced in the morning that the No. 1 signal would remain in effect until the evening, indicating a very low chance of upgrading to the No. 3 signal. However, by the evening, Typhoon Talim's trajectory began to shift northward, prompting the Observatory to refrain from lowering all typhoon signals that night. Later in the evening, Typhoon Talim's trajectory shifted northeastward, leading the Observatory to extend the No. 1 signal until 4 a.m. on June 20.

This marked the first time since Tropical Cyclone Nalgae that the Observatory, citing "actual conditions," decided not to upgrade to a higher typhoon signal for a tropical cyclone.

The Central Weather Bureau stated on June 18 that Typhoon Talim was expected to approach the waters near Taiwan in the early morning of June 19, issuing a sea typhoon warning, and a land and sea typhoon warning might be issued during the day. The deputy director of the Weather Forecast Center mentioned that Typhoon Talim had three characteristics: "occurring during the plum rain season," "forming in the South China Sea," and "moving northeastward," making it the first case recorded by the Central Weather Bureau since 1948. [8][9] Due to concerns about introducing a southwest airflow and causing extremely heavy rainfall, the media compared it to the 1987 and 1972 floods. [10][11][12] At 5:30 a.m. on June 19, 2012, the Central Weather Bureau issued a sea typhoon warning, followed by a land and sea typhoon warning at 8:30 p.m. the same day. 

Due to the storm's impact, the Central Weather Bureau issued a land and sea typhoon warning, and the Directorate-General of Personnel Administration of the Executive Yuan announced the suspension of work and classes on its website. The following areas met the criteria for suspension: [13] On June 20, based on the 10th report from the Weather Bureau, the Taiwan Railways Administration predicted that all regions in Taiwan should take strict precautions against strong winds and heavy rain. The South Link Line began suspending operations gradually from 11:02 a.m., and the Western Main Line from 1:17 p.m., to ensure passenger safety. 

In the early morning of June 21, as Typhoon Talim continued to weaken and moved away from the northern sea of Taiwan at a speed of at least 30 kilometers per hour, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the land typhoon warning at 2:30 a.m. and the sea typhoon warning at 5:30 a.m. Due to its rapid movement, the Weather Bureau revised the estimated rainfall for June 20 to half of the original forecast, which drew criticism and complaints from the public about the "inaccuracy" of the Central Weather Bureau's predictions. [16] Below are the areas with significant rainfall and their amounts from midnight on June 19 to 5 a.m. on June 21. [17]
The warnings issued by the meteorological departments of the affected areas are as follows:

Whole_Text.header: Typhoon No. 9 of the Heisei 22nd year
Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 9 of 2010 (Heisei 22, Asian name: Malou, named by Macau, meaning: agate (mineral name)) was a typhoon that caused damage by bringing heavy rain, mainly to the Tokai and Kanto regions.

The typhoon formed over the southern seas of Okinawa on September 3, approached Okinawa's main island on the same day, passed through the East China Sea, the Tsushima Strait, and the Sea of Japan along the San'in coast, and made landfall in Tsuruga City, Fukui Prefecture, on September 8. It transformed into a tropical depression less than four hours after landfall. Although the typhoon was small in scale, a linear rainband formed near the Tanzawa Mountains in Kanagawa Prefecture, causing significant damage in Oyama Town, Suntō District, Shizuoka Prefecture. Notably, Tanzawa Lake recorded 489.5 mm of rainfall in five hours by 4 p.m. on September 8, which is said to be 1.6 times the average rainfall for September. This typhoon became the first on record to make landfall in Fukui Prefecture since statistics began in 1951, and it also marked the first typhoon landfall in the Hokuriku region as a whole. Due to the significant damage in Oyama Town, Shizuoka Prefecture, and Yamakita Town, Kanagawa Prefecture, it was decided to designate the event as a severe disaster (localized severe disaster).

In Shizuoka Prefecture, rain began to fall around 6:00 PM on the 7th due to the approaching typhoon, with torrential rain in the eastern region. On the 8th, the daily rainfall reached 224.5 mm in Ikawa and 218.0 mm in Gotemba in some areas.  
In Kanagawa Prefecture, rain intensified in the western region before noon and in the eastern region after noon, with some areas experiencing extremely heavy rain exceeding 50 mm per hour.
This article is a draft related to meteorology or climatology. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this article (Project: Meteorology and Climate/Portal: Meteorology and Climate).

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Judith (Typhoon Judith, Showa 24 Typhoon No. 9, International Name: Judith) was a typhoon that made landfall in Kyushu in August 1949, causing significant damage to the Southwest Islands, Kyushu, and Shikoku regions.

On August 7, 1949, Typhoon No. 9 formed near the Palau Islands. It moved north-northeast over the sea east of the Nansei Islands, gradually changing direction to the north-northwest, and reached its peak around 9 a.m. on the 14th south of Yakushima Island in Kagoshima Prefecture, recording a central pressure of 960 hPa. It then made landfall near Shibushi Bay in Kagoshima Prefecture around 9 p.m. on the 15th. Around 3 a.m. on the 16th, it moved out to the Yatsushiro Sea and advanced to the sea west of Nagasaki Prefecture, where it stalled west of Tsushima in Nagasaki Prefecture on the 17th. It began moving east on the 18th and dissipated near Wakasa Bay in Fukui Prefecture on the 19th [1]. Due to the typhoon's impact, the total rainfall in Saga Prefecture reached 493.9 mm, and heavy rains of 200–400 mm occurred in Kyushu, causing damage in various parts of Kyushu, including Saga Prefecture [1]. Additionally, the heavy rains caused frequent river flooding in various areas of Kyushu and Shikoku, resulting in a major flood disaster. On September 1, 1949, Emperor Showa and Empress Kojun granted relief funds to Saga Prefecture, Miyazaki Prefecture, Fukuoka Prefecture, and Nagasaki Prefecture, which were heavily affected [2].
This entry is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this entry (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).
Typhoon No. 5 of 1998 (Heisei 10, International name: Stella) was a typhoon that formed on September 14, 1998 (Heisei 10) and caused damage in eastern and central Japan.

Typhoon No. 5, which formed over the southern seas near Chichijima on September 14, strengthened as it moved northward and made landfall near Omaezaki, Shizuoka Prefecture, around 4:30 a.m. on the 16th. It then traversed from the Kanto region to the Tohoku region, making a second landfall near Kushiro City, Hokkaido, after 8 p.m. on the 16th, and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone in eastern Hokkaido at 9 p.m. [1]. This typhoon was the latest to form as Typhoon No. 5 in recorded history [2]. Additionally, the occurrence of Typhoon No. 5 in September or later has only happened in 1998 [2]. The total rainfall during the typhoon reached 393 mm in Hakone Town, Kanagawa Prefecture, and ranged from 300 to 400 mm, particularly along the mountainous areas from the Tokai to Kanto regions [1]. In Hokkaido, heavy rainfall exceeding 300 mm was also recorded, including 350 mm in Hiroo Town. Strong winds were observed, with a maximum instantaneous wind speed of 45.7 m/s recorded in Choshi City, Chiba Prefecture, and areas along the Pacific coast from the Tokai region to Hokkaido experienced maximum instantaneous wind speeds exceeding 30 m/s. On the 16th, a significant wave height of 8.87 m was observed at Ishirozaki, Shizuoka Prefecture [1].

Due to this typhoon, 7 deaths and 47 injuries have been confirmed, along with 4 completely destroyed houses, 17 partially destroyed houses, 1,296 houses flooded above floor level, and 5,044 houses flooded below floor level.
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 16 of 1999 (Heisei 11, international name: Zia) was a typhoon that made landfall in Kyushu in September 1999 (Heisei 11) and caused damage in western Japan.

A tropical depression formed over the southern seas of Japan on September 11. Initially, it was predicted that this depression would not develop into a typhoon, but contrary to expectations, it intensified while moving northward toward Kyushu. On September 14, it became Typhoon No. 16 as its maximum wind speed exceeded 17.2 m/s near Tanegashima Island in Kagoshima Prefecture (south of Toi Cape). The typhoon made landfall in southern Miyazaki Prefecture at around 5:00 PM on September 14 with a central pressure of 985 hPa. It made a second landfall near Uwajima City in Ehime Prefecture around 3:00 AM on September 15, traversed Shikoku, and made a third landfall near Akashi City in Hyogo Prefecture around 10:00 AM the same day. It then moved from the Kinki region through the Chubu region and transitioned into a tropical depression near Iida City in Nagano Prefecture at 3:00 PM on September 15 [1]. 

Examples of tropical depressions that were upgraded to typhoons in sea areas close to land, like this typhoon, include Typhoon No. 11 in 2004 and Typhoon No. 9 in 2009. Meanwhile, a stationary front lingered near Honshu during this period, and as the typhoon moved northward, the activity of the front also intensified, resulting in heavy rainfall over a wide area from the Tohoku region to the Kyushu region. The total precipitation during this period reached 519 mm in Hirugano, Takasu Village, Gifu Prefecture, and ranged from 300 to 450 mm in parts of Gifu Prefecture, Oita Prefecture, Kochi Prefecture, and Tokushima Prefecture. This heavy rainfall caused significant damage, including the flooding of the Nagara River, particularly in Gifu Prefecture [1].

As a result of this typhoon, 7 deaths, 1 missing person, and 11 injured people have been confirmed, along with 9 completely destroyed houses, 22 partially destroyed houses, 308 houses flooded above floor level, and 3,006 houses flooded below floor level. Furthermore, the total damage amounted to 2.1 billion yen.
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Parma of 2003 (Heisei 15 Typhoon No. 18, Asian name: Parma, named by Macau, meaning: name of a Macau dish) occurred in October 2003 (Heisei 15) and interacted with Typhoon No. 17, creating a perfect loop over the Pacific Ocean. Its most notable feature was its extremely rare and unprecedented path, setting multiple records.

Typhoon No. 18 formed far south of Japan on October 21. To its west, Typhoon No. 17 was present, and an interaction occurred between them. The typhoon initially moved northeast and was expected to weaken and transition into an extratropical cyclone, but it suddenly began moving southward, rode the easterly winds westward, and redeveloped. At one point, its intensity had weakened to a central pressure of 975 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 30 m/s (60 kt), but it regained strength to a central pressure of 935 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 45 m/s (90 kt). It then followed the same route northeast again and later transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At its peak intensity, the central pressure was 930 hPa, and the maximum wind speed was 50 m/s (95 kt). This typhoon followed such an unusual path because it circled the edge of the Pacific High over the course of about a week. Due to this complex path, the southward movement of this typhoon spanned 8.9 degrees in latitude, ranking first since records began in 1951, and its total travel distance ranked as the third longest in history. Such a typhoon had not occurred in the past several decades, and despite causing no damage to Japan as it circled the Pacific, it became a famous typhoon.
This entry is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this entry (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 26 of 1994 (International name: Orchid) was a typhoon that formed in September 1994 and made landfall in the Kinki region.

Typhoon No. 26, which formed over the southwestern sea near Guam on September 19, strengthened as it moved north-northwest, reaching its peak around the 24th with a central pressure of 925 hPa (maximum wind speed of 50 m/s), becoming a large and very strong typhoon. After moving north over the eastern sea of Minamidaitojima on the 27th, the typhoon changed its course to north-northeast, accelerated, and moved north off the coast of Shikoku before making landfall in southern Wakayama Prefecture at 7:30 PM on the 29th. At the time of landfall, the typhoon remained strong, with a central pressure of 950 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 40 m/s. The typhoon crossed from the Kinki region to the western Hokuriku region and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone over the Sea of Japan by 3 PM on the 30th.  

Due to this typhoon, the daily rainfall on the 29th reached 733 mm at Mount Hinode in Kamikitayama Village, Nara Prefecture, 449 mm in Miyagawa, Miyagawa Village, Mie Prefecture, and 374 mm in Yanase, Umaji Village, Kochi Prefecture, resulting in heavy rainfall exceeding 300 mm, particularly on the southeastern slopes of Shikoku and the Kii Peninsula. On the same day, a maximum wind speed of 34.1 m/s (maximum instantaneous wind speed of 48.7 m/s) was recorded in Tsu City, Mie Prefecture, and along the Pacific coast from Shikoku to Hokkaido, there were areas where maximum wind speeds exceeded 20 m/s. On the 29th, a significant wave height of 6.61 m was observed in Sakihama, Kochi Prefecture.  

Strong winds caused building damage, particularly in the Tokai and Kinki regions. Additionally, Kansai International Airport, which had just opened on September 4 of the same year, was closed for the first time due to this typhoon. Furthermore, two large tankers under construction at Nippon Kokan Tsu Shipyard (now Universal Shipbuilding) were swept away and drifted ashore, grounding near Gotenba Beach.  

This typhoon resulted in 3 fatalities, 62 injuries, 18 completely destroyed houses, 167 partially destroyed houses, and 569 houses flooded above floor level.
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Whole_Text.header: List of typhoon articles by year
Whole_Text.content: List of typhoon articles by year is a compilation of articles summarizing typhoons that occurred in the Northwest Pacific by year.

Whole_Text.header: How to view typhoon articles by year
Whole_Text.content: Explain how to view typhoon articles for each year on Wikipedia.

In the opening part of the article, (including the use of templates), the focus is primarily on the trends of typhoons for that year. For example, it discusses the number of typhoons that occurred, their impact on Japan (approaches and landfalls), and whether there were any notable typhoons. It also mentions whether the number of occurrences, landfalls, or approaches to Japan was average, above average, or below average compared to normal years. Additionally, if there were typhoons during that year's typhoon season that caused significant impact or severe damage to Japan, typhoons that set records for early or late occurrence, typhoons that developed into record-breaking strength or size, long-lasting typhoons, or rare crossing typhoons, these are also briefly mentioned. Furthermore, if there were typhoons that caused significant damage to countries or regions outside Japan and attracted global attention, these are also added.

[Example: Opening part of the 2013 typhoon article]  
[Note 1] Data on typhoons in 2013 (tropical cyclones that occurred in the Northwest Pacific).  
Typhoon No. 1 occurred as early as January 3, marking the sixth earliest occurrence since statistics began in 1951. Up until August, the number of occurrences was average, but in September and October, seven typhoons occurred each month, exceeding the average. As a result, the total number of typhoons reached 31 (average value: 25.6), surpassing 30 in a year for the first time in 19 years since 1994. The seven typhoons that occurred in October were the highest since 1951, tying with 1984 and 1992.  

Fourteen typhoons approached Japan from Typhoon No. 3 in June to Typhoon No. 28 in October, with two making landfall (both in September). This number of landfalls was slightly below the average (2.7), but there were many typhoons approaching the mainland in autumn, with six in October alone, the highest on record.  

Additionally, two consecutive crossing typhoons (No. 13 and No. 14), which are said to occur once in 100 cases, crossed the 180-degree longitude line.  

Typhoon No. 18, which made landfall in Aichi Prefecture in September, prompted the first issuance of a special warning, which began operation in August of the same year.  

Typhoon No. 26, which approached the Kanto region in October, caused a landslide due to heavy rain on Izu Oshima in the Izu Islands, resulting in significant damage.  

In November, Typhoon No. 30 became a "super typhoon," directly hitting the Philippines, causing record-breaking storm surges, and resulting in over 6,000 fatalities and extensive damage.

Whole_Text.header: Number of typhoons generated, number approaching Japan, number making landfall in Japan
Whole_Text.content: If the number of typhoons that occurred that year, the number that approached Japan, or the number that made landfall ranked among the highest or lowest, insert the applicable one from the three tables below. (As of 2020) (As of 2020) (As of 2020)

In the section "Number of Typhoons by Month," the number of typhoons that occurred each month of the year is presented in a table. If no typhoons occurred in a given month, the space is left blank. [Example: Monthly Number of Typhoons in 2015]

Whole_Text.header: The active periods of each tropical cyclone
Whole_Text.content: "In the section 'Activity Periods of Each Tropical Cyclone,' the timeline is used to explain when typhoons and tropical cyclones that occurred in that year were active during the year. [Example: Activity periods of each tropical cyclone in the typhoons of 2019]"

In the section "Tropical Depressions Classified as 'Typhoons'," each tropical depression that reached the strength of a "typhoon" during the year is explained individually in separate sections (using templates as well). The typhoon number in the format "Typhoon No. ○" is used as the heading for each typhoon's section, with the international name (Asian name) added in parentheses to the right. Below the section, the six-digit typhoon number and the tropical depression number assigned by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) are noted in bold. Additionally, if the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) assigned a Philippine name, it is also included. For example, in the case of Typhoon No. 30 of 2013 (Asian name: Haiyan), the section heading would be "Typhoon No. 30 (Haiyan)," with the typhoon number "201330," the tropical depression number "31W," and the Philippine name "Yolanda" noted below. Regarding section headings, even for notable typhoons to which the Japan Meteorological Agency later assigned a unique name, such as the Isewan Typhoon (international name: Vera), the unique name is not used as the section heading. Instead, the aforementioned rules are followed. For the Isewan Typhoon, the heading would be "Typhoon No. 15 (Vera)" rather than "Isewan Typhoon." Additionally, if there is an individual article about the typhoon, a link to that article is provided. [Example: Section for Typhoon No. 30 of 2013] [Note 2]

Whole_Text.header: A tropical depression not classified as a "typhoon" by the Japan Meteorological Agency.
Whole_Text.content: In the section "Tropical Depressions Not Classified as 'Typhoons' by the Meteorological Agency," it explains those tropical depressions that occurred in that year but were not treated as "typhoons" because they did not reach the strength of a "typhoon."

Whole_Text.content: The official statistics on typhoons began in 1951, so on Wikipedia, typhoons since 1951 are summarized and explained as individual articles for each year in which they occurred.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 12 of 1996 (International name: Kirk, Philippine name: Isang) was a typhoon that made landfall in Kyushu in August 1996 after taking a complex path near the Okinawa region.

Typhoon No. 12, which formed near Okinawa on August 6, initially exhibited complex movements, such as moving southward near Okinawa. However, around August 11, it changed its course northward and approached Okinawa's main island between August 12 and 13. After nearing Okinawa, it intensified while moving northward over the East China Sea and made landfall near Kumamoto City, Kumamoto Prefecture, around 10 a.m. on August 14 with a central pressure of 960 hPa and maximum wind speeds of 40 m/s. The typhoon passed through Kunisaki City, Oita Prefecture, exited into Suo-nada, and made landfall again in Tokuyama City, Yamaguchi Prefecture (now Shunan City), at 3 p.m. the same day. It then passed through the Chugoku region, exited into the Sea of Japan, passed near Sado Island, Niigata Prefecture, around 6:30 a.m. the following day, and made landfall again near Murakami City, Niigata Prefecture, at 9 a.m. before moving out to the Sanriku coast and transitioning into an extratropical cyclone on August 16.

The diameter of a typhoon's eye is generally several tens of kilometers, but during Typhoon No. 12's approach to Okinawa's main island, it exceeded 100 km. The main island of Okinawa began entering the typhoon's eye around noon on the 12th, and after 3 p.m. the typhoon's center passed through the central part of the island, with the entire island entering the eye. Due to the typhoon's slow movement, it was late at night on the same day when the island exited the eye, resulting in a state of weak wind and rain lasting for nearly half a day.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 8 of 1997 (Heisei 9, international name: Peter) was a typhoon that formed on June 24, 1997 (Heisei 9) and made landfall in Japan.

Typhoon No. 8, which formed over the eastern seas of the Philippines at 3:00 PM on June 24, moved northward while intensifying, approaching the Nansei Islands on June 26, two days after its formation, and passing through on June 27. After passing through the Nansei Islands, the typhoon reached its peak in the East China Sea west of Kyushu on June 27, and made landfall near the Nishisonogi Peninsula in Nagasaki Prefecture on June 28 with a central pressure of 975 hPa and maximum wind speeds of 30 m/s. The typhoon then passed through the Seto Inland Sea, made a second landfall in Kurashiki City, Okayama Prefecture, and crossed the Honshu region, becoming an extratropical cyclone off the Sanriku coast at 6:00 AM on June 29. It is rare for a typhoon to make landfall in June even in the Kyushu region, but in 1997, Typhoon No. 7 had also made landfall in Gamagori City, Aichi Prefecture, just eight days earlier, resulting in two typhoons making landfall in June. The occurrence of two typhoons making landfall in June is rare, with only two instances recorded in statistics since 1951: in 1997 and 2004.
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).
