Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 9 of 1997 (Heisei 9, international name: Rosie) was a typhoon that made landfall in eastern Shikoku in July 1997 (Heisei 9) and caused damage along the Pacific coast from Shikoku to the Kanto region.

Typhoon No. 9, which formed over the eastern seas of the Philippines on July 20, moved northward while intensifying over the southern seas of Japan and reached Category 5 status according to U.S. Navy analysis around 9 p.m. on July 22. The typhoon made landfall near Anan City, Tokushima Prefecture, with a central pressure of 970 hPa and strong intensity after 5 p.m. on July 26. It then passed through Harima-nada and made a second landfall near Bizen City, Okayama Prefecture, before crossing the Chugoku region before 9 p.m. on the same day. On July 27, it stalled over the Sea of Japan off the San'in region and became a tropical depression in the same area at 6 a.m. on July 28. This tropical depression exhibited complex movements, moving southward from the western Hokuriku region to the Tokai region between the night of July 28 and the morning of July 29, and dissipated over the southern seas of the Kii Peninsula on July 31. Due to this typhoon and tropical depression, heavy rain occurred in areas such as the Tokai, Kinki, Shikoku, and Chugoku regions. Particularly in the Kii Peninsula, torrential rain centered on July 26 resulted in a total precipitation of 958 mm at Mount Hinode in Kamikitayama Village, Nara Prefecture, and 600–800 mm in mountainous areas. Daily precipitation reached 734 mm at Mount Hinode and 612 mm in Miyagawa Village, Mie Prefecture. Additionally, total precipitation exceeded 500 mm in parts of Hiroshima and Shimane Prefectures, and over 100 mm of rain fell in northern Kanto. On July 26, winds of around 20 m/s blew from the Shikoku region to the Tokai region, with a maximum wind speed of 26.6 m/s (maximum instantaneous wind speed of 35.4 m/s) recorded in Tsu City, Mie Prefecture, 37.5 m/s (maximum instantaneous wind speed of 52.2 m/s) at Cape Muroto in Muroto City, Kochi Prefecture, 38.2 m/s maximum instantaneous wind speed in Kobe City, and 33.9 m/s maximum instantaneous wind speed in Osaka City. On the same day, a significant wave height of 8.73 m was observed in Sakihama, Kochi Prefecture, marking the highest record since observations began in 1977. Furthermore, as the typhoon moved into the Sea of Japan, the foehn phenomenon occurred, resulting in extreme heat on the Sea of Japan side, including the Hokuriku region.

Whole_Text.header: Typhoon No. 13 of the first year of Heisei.
Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 13 of the first year of Heisei (International name: Mac) was a typhoon that made landfall in the Kanto region in August 1989 (the first year of Heisei). At one point, it developed into a large and strong typhoon.

In 1989, typhoons made landfall and approached frequently starting in June. By July, Typhoon 6 and Typhoon 11 had made landfall in Kyushu, and in August, Typhoon 12 approached, bringing heavy rain. Even after the landfall of Typhoon 13, typhoons continued to make landfall and approach frequently, with a total of five landfalls that year, ranking fourth in history (at the time in 1989, it was tied for first place). Typhoon 13, which formed near Minamitorishima at 3:00 PM on July 31, moved northward over the southeastern seas of Japan, becoming a large typhoon with a gale diameter of 1,390 km and a central pressure of 950 hPa at its peak. Around August 5, the typhoon changed its course toward the Kanto region, and at around 3:00 PM on August 9, it made landfall near Choshi City, Chiba Prefecture. By this time, its strength had weakened compared to its peak, and although it still maintained a storm zone, it was no longer a large-scale typhoon. The typhoon traversed the Kanto region and Niigata Prefecture, transforming into a tropical depression in the northern Sea of Japan at 3:00 AM on August 8.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 3 of 1956 (Showa 31, International name: Thelma) was a typhoon that made landfall in the Philippines in April 1956 and subsequently in Kagoshima Prefecture, Japan. It was the earliest typhoon to make landfall in Japan in a year since statistics began in 1951, and it remains the only typhoon to have made landfall in Japan in April.

At 3:00 PM on April 16, 1956, Typhoon No. 3 formed in the Caroline Islands (6°0'N, 145°7'E). The typhoon made landfall on Luzon Island in northern Philippines around 6:00 PM on the 21st. It changed course northward in the South China Sea, approached the Nansei Islands around 6:00 AM on the 24th, and passed near Miyako Island at 9:00 AM on the same day. Then, around 7:30 AM on the 25th, it made landfall on the Osumi Peninsula in Kagoshima Prefecture and dissipated at 9:00 AM on the same day. As a result, newspapers reported that "Typhoon No. 3 has disappeared." This typhoon temporarily developed to a central pressure of 935 hPa east of the Philippines, but its strength rapidly weakened as it turned and moved northward.

There is no other example of a typhoon making landfall in Japan before April in a year like this typhoon, making it the earliest landfalling typhoon in recorded history, and as of 2021, this record has not been broken. Even the second earliest landfalling typhoon (Typhoon No. 6 in 1965) made landfall on May 27, more than a month later than this typhoon.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 7 of 1968 (Showa 43, International name: Polly) was a typhoon that formed on August 7, 1968 (Showa 43) and caused damage in Japan.

A tropical depression formed over the far southeastern seas of Japan at 9 PM on August 3. By 9 AM on August 7, it had developed into Typhoon No. 7 (Polly) at 24°2'N, 155°6'E near Minamitorishima. The typhoon moved northwest toward the Japanese archipelago, reaching the southern seas of Honshu by 3 AM on August 11. It then slowly moved southwest, approaching Tokunoshima with a central pressure of 985 hPa by 9 AM on August 13. The typhoon slowed down near the Okinawa seas, remaining stationary in the East China Sea from 9 AM on August 13 to 3 PM on August 15. By 9 PM on August 14, it changed course northeastward toward Kyushu, approaching Tsushima with a central pressure of 970 hPa by 3 PM on August 16. It exited into the Sea of Japan by 6 PM the same day and transitioned into an extratropical cyclone at 9 PM on August 17 at 45°4'N, 135°8'E in the Primorsky Krai region of the Soviet Union (now Russia). The typhoon's path, which included stalling in the East China Sea and making a sharp U-turn, was highly unusual and complex.  

Due to the typhoon, ship damage occurred off the northern coast of Kyushu. From the night of August 17 to August 18, the autumn rain front (cold front) extending from the remnants of the typhoon caused extremely heavy rainfall, particularly in the Chubu region. In Minami Village, Gujo District, Gifu Prefecture (now Minami, Gujo City), over 100 mm of rainfall was recorded in one hour. In Shirakawa Town, Gifu Prefecture, which was hit by this torrential rain, two tourist buses were caught in a landslide and fell into the swollen Hida River, resulting in 104 fatalities.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 10 of 1970 (Showa 45, International name: Anita) was a typhoon that occurred in August 1970 (Showa 45) and caused damage in western Japan. The damage was particularly severe in Kochi Prefecture, and it is also called the Tosa Bay Typhoon due to the record-breaking storm surges in areas such as Tosa Bay. However, this name was not officially designated by the Japan Meteorological Agency like the "Ise Bay Typhoon."

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon No. 16 of 1979 (Showa 54, International name: Owen) was a typhoon that occurred in September 1979 (Showa 54) and traversed the Japanese archipelago.

Typhoon No. 16, which formed over the eastern seas of the Philippines on September 23, moved northwest and developed into a very strong typhoon with a central pressure of 920 hPa and a maximum wind speed of 45 m/s over the southern seas of Okinawa on September 26. However, the typhoon's path was blocked by a high-pressure system, and the westerly jet stream did not shift southward. As a result, the typhoon moved very slowly northward over the eastern seas of Okinawa and the Amami Islands until September 29. These regions experienced stormy weather for nearly two days. On September 30, as the typhoon crossed 30 degrees north latitude, it rapidly accelerated northeastward, making landfall near Muroto City, Kochi Prefecture, around 6:30 PM. The central pressure at landfall was 955 hPa, and it remained a strong typhoon. Around 11 PM, it made a second landfall in Osaka, traversed the Chubu and Tohoku regions, and exited into the sea off Hachinohe by 9 AM on October 1. By 3 PM on the same day, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. Due to its strong intensity, the typhoon recorded a maximum wind speed of 47.7 m/s and a maximum instantaneous wind speed of 66.9 m/s at Cape Muroto, as well as winds exceeding 40 m/s in areas such as Tokushima, Nara, and Hikone. 

In Shiga Prefecture, on the Kosei Line, a freight train derailed due to a gust of wind, causing two freight cars to fall off an elevated track. A notable characteristic of this typhoon was its very slow movement while passing east of the Southwest Islands, contrasted with its rapid acceleration as it approached the mainland. By the time it made landfall near Muroto City, it was traveling at 45 km/h, and by the time it traversed the Tohoku region, it had reached speeds of 90 km/h. Notably, three weeks later, Typhoon No. 20 followed a similar path, causing significant damage in Japan.

Article_Name: Mùa bão Tây Bắc Thái Bình Dương 2019 – Wikipedia tiếng Việt

Whole_Text.content: The 2019 Northwest Pacific typhoon season is an event in which tropical cyclones formed in the Northwest Pacific region during 2019, primarily from May to December. This article only refers to storms formed within the Pacific region in the Northern Hemisphere and between the 100th and 180th meridians. Tropical storms formed across the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA). Tropical depressions monitored by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) will have the suffix "W" added to their sequence number. Tropical depressions that form or move into the area monitored by the Philippines will also be named by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA). This is why a storm may sometimes have two different names. This is also the second consecutive typhoon season where the first storm formed from the final days of the previous year. The 2019 typhoon season had a unique feature as it began in the final days of 2018 with a tropical depression forming from a low-pressure area on December 31, 2018, and strengthening into a storm on January 1, 2019, named Pabuk (designation 1901). The 2019 typhoon season was unusual as Typhoon Wutip intensified to Category 5 in February, the strongest typhoon recorded during this period since February 1911. Three storms—Lekima (making landfall in Fujian Province, China, in early August), Faxai, and Hagibis (making landfall in the Kanto region, Japan, in early September and mid-October)—caused the most significant damage to lives and property that year.

Whole_Text.header: Summary and forecast of the hurricane season

Whole_Text.content:
Japan Typhoon Scale (JMA)  
Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale  

Across the region, the 2019 Northwest Pacific typhoon season began quite early, starting in the final days of 2018 with a tropical depression forming on December 31, which strengthened into a typhoon on January 1, 2019, named PABUK (designation 1901). In February 2019, a strong typhoon named Wutip appeared, marking the strongest typhoon ever recorded in February. However, from March to June, no typhoons formed, only a few weak tropical depressions. It wasn't until late June 2019 that Typhoon Sepat appeared.  

In July, cyclonic activity increased, but weather conditions inside and outside the typhoons (sea surface temperature, thermal energy, wind shear, etc.) hindered their development, resulting in mostly weak typhoons such as Mun, Danas, Nari, and Wipha. By August 2019, typhoon activity intensified with the emergence of typhoons Francisco, Lekima, Krosa, Bailu, and Podul. Among them, Typhoon Lekima made landfall in eastern China, causing $9 billion in damages.  

In September and October, Typhoon Lingling made landfall in North Korea, while Typhoons Faxai and Hagibis struck Japan, causing over $23 billion in damages. The typhoon season became more active from the latter half of October until the end of the year, with the appearance of 10 typhoons, most of which were strong. Notably, Typhoons Matmo and Nakri made landfall in South Central Vietnam, Typhoon Kammuri struck the Philippines during the 30th SEA Games, and Typhoon Phanfone hit the Philippines on Christmas.  

The combined damages from just three typhoons—Lekima, Faxai, and Hagibis—amounted to over $32 billion, accounting for 92% of the total damages for the entire typhoon season, making the 2019 typhoon season the most devastating in the history of Northwest Pacific typhoon seasons.

Whole_Text.header: On the East Sea and the mainland of Vietnam
Whole_Text.content: Except for Typhoon No. 1, which was a late-season typhoon of 2018, the 2019 typhoon season in our country is considered to have officially begun when Typhoon No. 2 (Mun) formed in the northern South China Sea on July 1, 2019 (2-3 weeks later than the average) and made landfall in Thai Binh. By mid-July, a tropical depression appeared but exited the South China Sea; at the end of July and early August, Typhoon No. 3 (Wipha) appeared and made landfall in Quang Ninh, causing heavy rain in the Northern region and Thanh Hoa. At the end of August 2019, Typhoon No. 4 (Podul) made landfall in Quang Binh, and shortly after, in early September, the first tropical depression of September (Typhoon Kajiki) made landfall in Quang Tri - Thua Thien Hue, causing heavy rain and severe flooding. On September 2, 2019, there were also two tropical depressions active in the South China Sea at relatively close distances. From September 5 to October 27, 2019 (in the following month and a half), due to the influence of various factors such as a weak intertropical convergence zone and the Madden-Julian Oscillation, the typhoon season in the South China Sea became quiet. It wasn't until October 28 that Typhoon No. 5 (Matmo) formed and made landfall in Phu Yen two days later; this province was also the landfall area for Typhoon No. 6 (Nakri) 10 days later. Both typhoons caused significant damage to the southern central coastal region. In December 2019, two typhoons, Kammuri (No. 7) and Phanfone (No. 8), entered the South China Sea with strong intensities of category 12-13 but both weakened and dissipated in the middle of the South China Sea. Typhoon Phanfone weakened and dissipated on December 28, marking the end of the 2019 typhoon season in the South China Sea. The 2019 typhoon season was similar to those of 1981 and 1994.

Storm level (Japan): 80kts - typhoon. Minimum pressure: 965hPa. Storm level (USA): 95kts - Category 2 typhoon. A low-pressure area formed in the Caroline Islands region on September 26 and was designated by JTWC as 19W.

Storm intensity (Japan): 105kts - Minimum pressure 915 hPa (mBar). Storm intensity (United States): 160kts - Category 5 super typhoon. Storm intensity (South Korea): On October 4, a low-pressure area formed near Wake Island. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) issued a warning that low-pressure area 20W could intensify into a storm within the next 24 hours. The following day, JMA began monitoring and forecasting the tropical depression. By October 6, JMA named the storm Hagibis. Hagibis underwent an extremely rapid intensification process, transforming from a tropical storm on October 6 to a Category 5 super typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson scale with wind speeds increasing by 140 km/h within just 12 hours. This was considered the most explosive intensification of a tropical cyclone on Earth since Super Typhoon Yates in 1996. On the afternoon of October 7, Hagibis surpassed Typhoon Wutip from February to become the second strongest storm in the Northwest Pacific this year, only behind Typhoon Halong. The storm then shifted northwest, passing through the Mariana Islands at 15:30 UTC on October 7 while reaching its peak intensity with maximum 10-minute sustained winds of 195 km/h, a minimum pressure of 915 hPa (27.02 inHg), and 1-minute sustained winds of 295 km/h (185 mph). By the morning of October 8, Hagibis weakened slightly to a Category 4 super typhoon and successfully underwent an eyewall replacement cycle, with its eye reorganized and regaining Category 5 super typhoon status with 1-minute sustained winds of 280 km/h (175 mph) by the morning of October 9. Hagibis gradually moved northward and weakened due to diminishing favorable conditions for storm activity. Around 09:00 UTC (6 PM local time) on October 12, Hagibis made direct landfall on the Izu Peninsula, Chiba Prefecture, Honshu, with maximum 10-minute sustained winds of 150 km/h and a minimum pressure of 950 hPa. The storm was described as "the strongest and worst in over a decade" in eastern Japan, prompting the government to issue emergency warnings for strong winds, flash floods, dangerous landslides, and widespread flooding in the Kantō region, including Shizuoka, Nagano, Kanagawa, Saitama, Gunma, Tokyo, and Yamanashi. All railway and aviation systems in Japan were temporarily suspended. As of the morning of October 13, Hagibis had caused at least 35 fatalities and 17 missing persons.

On November 2, a well-organized low-pressure system quickly developed into a tropical depression a few hundred miles east of the Northern Mariana Islands. The depression rapidly intensified and was upgraded to Tropical Storm Halong on the same day. The storm continued to strengthen over open waters, reaching typhoon status. As Halong formed an eye, explosive intensification occurred on November 4, and Halong became a Category 5 super typhoon on November 5 with peak 1-minute and 10-minute sustained winds of 305 km/h and 215 km/h, respectively, and a lowest pressure of 905 mbar.  

On November 6, Halong began undergoing an eyewall replacement cycle and entered a less favorable environment with decreasing sea surface temperatures and the intrusion of dry air, which started to weaken the system. The storm's convection was heavily affected, causing it to weaken to a Category 4 typhoon by 18:00 UTC. By November 8, Halong had weakened below typhoon strength and eventually transitioned into an extratropical state the following day.

On November 26, a new low-pressure area formed and intensified into a storm, internationally named Kammuri, off the coast of the Caroline Islands and was designated as 29W by JTWC. The storm maintained its intensity while moving slowly towards the Philippine Islands. By the morning of December 2, as it approached the Philippine mainland, Kammuri entered a phase of rapid intensification. Around 8:00 PM PLT (local time) on December 2, Kammuri made landfall directly in the Bicol region and northern Samar with its peak intensity and maximum winds reaching up to 215 km/h. Kammuri continued moving westward, entering the South China Sea on the afternoon of Tuesday, December 3, with its winds decreasing to level 12, becoming the 7th storm of the year. The storm weakened rapidly due to strong northeastern wind shear and low sea surface temperatures of approximately 25-26 degrees. JTWC issued its final forecast on the morning of December 7.

On December 20, JTWC began monitoring a tropical disturbance north of Papua New Guinea, designated as 98W. The next day, JMA issued a warning and the first forecast bulletin for a tropical depression, designated as 30W, and upgraded it to a tropical storm the following day, with the international name Phanfone. By the evening of December 23, the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting (NCHMF) issued a storm forecast bulletin near the South China Sea for Phanfone. On the evening of December 24, the storm made landfall in the Tacloban Strait between Leyte and Samar. Due to favorable conditions, Phanfone reached Category 2 typhoon status immediately after making landfall. The storm made landfall five times as it passed through central Philippines, causing at least 28 fatalities. By the morning of December 26, the storm officially entered the South China Sea, becoming the 8th storm of the year and also the strongest storm in the South China Sea that year. The storm's path was very similar to Super Typhoon Haiyan six years earlier, differing only in intensity and timing.

The table above summarizes all systems that developed in or moved into the North Pacific, west of the International Date Line in 2019. The tables also provide an overview of intensity, duration, affected land areas, and any related casualties or damages.

Tropical cyclones are named according to the list below by the Regional Specialized Meteorological Center in Tokyo, Japan, when a cyclone reaches tropical storm intensity. The names are proposed by members of the ESCAP/WMO Typhoon Committee. Each of the 14 member countries and territories provides 10 names, used in alphabetical order based on the English name of the country. The following are the names expected to be used for storms in 2019:

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) uses its own list of storm names to assign to a tropical cyclone when it enters their area of responsibility. PAGASA names tropical depressions that form within their area of responsibility and tropical cyclones that move into their area of responsibility. If the list of names for that year is exhausted, names will be taken from an auxiliary list, and the list of storm names is issued before the typhoon season begins.

In Vietnam, a storm is assigned a number when it enters the monitoring area of the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting, defined in the East Sea west of the 120th meridian east and north of the 5th parallel north. The storm's number is assigned based on its order of appearance in the year, for example: Storm No. 1, Storm No. 2, etc. In 2019, there were 8 (9) storms and 4 (3) tropical depressions in the East Sea recognized by our country.[nb 1] Storm No. 1 formed on January 1, 2019. The last storm (Phanfone) dissipated on December 28, 2019. Below are the storms numbered by the National Center for Hydro-Meteorological Forecasting in 2019 (along with their landfall areas):

Article_Name: Tropical Storm Nari - Simple English Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Nari was a storm that devastated Japan.

On the afternoon of July 23, a tropical disturbance formed in the southern waters of Japan, and the US Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 91W. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated the system as "low" and upgraded it to "medium" at 10 am.  
At 5 am on July 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 8 am, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning, and Taiwan's Central Meteorological Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the number 11. At 11 am, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. In the afternoon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone warning.  
At 10 am on July 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 07W. At 9 pm, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system to a tropical storm. At 8 am on July 26, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 9 am, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 1906 and naming it "Nari." The Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Nari to a tropical depression at 2 am on July 27 and further downgraded it to a low-pressure zone at 2 pm. At 6 am, Nari made landfall in southern Mie Prefecture, Japan. At 3 pm, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of July 28, Nari completely dissipated.

The city of Wakayama recorded rainfall of 47.5 millimeters in an hour through to 9:05 a.m. A maximum instantaneous wind speed of 25 meters per second was registered at the cape of Shionomisaki in Kushimoto, Wakayama Prefecture, at around 5:20 a.m. The storm, which was downgraded to a tropical depression at around 3 p.m., was projected to travel across the Tokai central region before reaching the seas east of the Kanto region by Sunday morning. The agency warned residents in the Tokai and Kanto-Koshinetsu regions to be on high alert for heavy rain. Heavy rain and gusty winds spread across central Honshu through Saturday. Localized downpours will also spread over eastern Shikoku.

Info_Box:
Duration: July 24 - July 28  
Peak intensity: 65 km/h (40 mph) (10-min) 998 hPa (mbar)

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴圓規 (2016年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Kompasu (English: Tropical Storm Kompasu; International designation: 1611; Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP132016) was the 11th named tropical cyclone of the 2016 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Kompasu" (コンパス) was used for the third time, with the previous uses in 2004 and 2010. This name was provided by Japan, referring to the constellation Circinus. Kompasu was the 7th tropical cyclone under the "monsoon gyre" and the 6th storm to pass close to Japan, classified as a typical tropical cyclone that transformed into an extratropical cyclone after passing Japan.

On August 16, 2016, a low-pressure area formed over the sea northeast of Guam. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 98W at 9 PM. On the evening of the 17th at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 7:30 AM on the 18th, but the Japan Meteorological Agency declared it dissipated at 8 AM. However, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a tropical depression at 8 PM. On the 19th at 7:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its development chance within 24 hours from "low" directly to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning at 9:25 PM. On the 20th at 2 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm and assigned it the number 13W. Subsequently, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm at 8 AM, naming it Kompasu and assigning it the international number 1611. On the evening of the 21st at 10 PM, Kompasu made landfall in Kushiro City, Hokkaido. The Japan Meteorological Agency assessed it as having transitioned into an extratropical cyclone at 2 AM the following day.

Article_Name: 2017年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2017 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during 2017. Although no official timeframe is set for the typhoon season, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to the waters of the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are called hurricanes and are included in the 2017 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) with international names and are assigned international numbers starting with 17xx. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assigns tropical depressions in this region a number ending with the letter "W." Tropical depressions that enter or form within the Philippine Area of Responsibility (PAR) are given local names by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (with the international name being the official one). Additionally, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, and Macau may differ from those used in Taiwan. The information for each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak intensity during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

The Hong Kong Observatory (HKO) reported the latest developments of the observatory on March 23, 2017, indicating that 2016-2017 was one of the warmest winters on record since 1884. The observatory predicted that the annual rainfall would be normal to below normal, with four to seven tropical cyclones entering within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong, a number close to the normal level. However, during June to August of that year, four consecutive storms directly hit Hong Kong, prompting the observatory to issue tropical cyclone warning signals of No. 8 or above, far exceeding expectations. As a result, the observatory revised its forecast in late August to six to nine tropical cyclones, reaching the normal level.

Lau Ying Wai, Senior Technical Officer and Meteorological Consultant of the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau (Portuguese: SMG), stated during the tropical cyclone prevention meeting held by the government civil defense structure on April 5 that it is expected that 5 to 7 tropical cyclones will affect Macao this year, with the first and last tropical cyclones anticipated to occur in mid-June and late September, respectively. This year, 5 to 7 tropical cyclones are expected to affect Macao, and all agencies and departments within the civil defense structure must remain vigilant and carry out prevention and publicity work.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (CWB) presented the 2017 weather outlook and risk assessment at the 3531st Executive Yuan meeting on January 12, predicting that 3 to 4 typhoons would hit Taiwan during the summer, and the formation of the first typhoon in the Northwest Pacific would occur earlier than the previous year. On June 26, the Central Weather Bureau held a typhoon outlook press conference, forecasting that 3 to 5 typhoons would hit Taiwan during the summer, with the climate average being 3.6. The total number of typhoons forming in the western North Pacific was estimated to be about 21 to 25, close to the climate average of 23.1. Lu Guochen, director of the Weather Forecast Center, stated that the climate this year is normal, with a low likelihood of El Niño or La Niña events. Therefore, the formation and impact of typhoons this year are also expected to be normal. Regarding the intensity of typhoons hitting Taiwan, he mentioned that there is a 70% to 80% chance of them being of medium intensity or higher, and the possibility of autumn typhoons cannot be ruled out, reminding the public to prepare for typhoon prevention.

The China National Marine Forecast Center predicted that 11 to 13 typhoons in the Northwest Pacific and South China Sea would affect China's seas in 2017, with 6 to 7 typhoons making landfall on China's southeastern coast. Additionally, according to the Fujian Provincial Meteorological Bureau's forecast on April 11, 6 to 7 tropical cyclones would affect Fujian Province during the typhoon season (June to September), with 1 to 2 typhoons possibly making landfall or severely impacting Fujian Province in the summer.
The Philippine PAGASA predicts that 8-12 tropical cyclones will enter the Philippine Area of Responsibility from April to September this year.

The Vietnam Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center predicts that ENSO will transition to El Niño in the second half of this year. The typhoon season will become increasingly evident in the latter half of the year, with an estimated 13-15 storms entering the South China Sea, of which about 3-4 are expected to directly or indirectly affect Vietnam.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content:
PAGASA: Dante  
In mid to late April 2017, a low-pressure area formed over the sea south of Chuuk near the equator. Although this low-pressure area formed over the open ocean, its center was initially very disorganized. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W at 9 a.m. on the 20th of the same month, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 8 a.m. on the 21st. With the assistance of high atmospheric pressure, low wind shear, and relatively high sea temperatures, the low-pressure area began to consolidate, and its structure became more organized. Major weather agencies predicted its movement path to be west-northwest, with some agencies optimistic about its development and intensity, while others were less so.  

The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression at 8 p.m. on the 23rd, followed by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raising its rating to "medium" at 4 a.m. on the 24th and then to "high" at 1 p.m. the same day. Benefiting from favorable environmental conditions nearby, the low-pressure area continued to develop. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 03W at 2 a.m. on April 25, while the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for Tropical Depression 03W at 8 a.m. the same day. As Tropical Depression 03W rapidly developed and intensified, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm at 2 a.m. on April 26, and the Japan Meteorological Agency followed suit at 8 a.m., upgrading it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 1701, and naming the tropical cyclone "Muifa," making it the first named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season.  

Although the tropical storm was named, major weather agencies were not optimistic about its subsequent intensity development and predicted it would change direction, shifting from west-northwest to north and then to east-northeast, due to the influence of the eastward-moving westerly trough. As expected, "Muifa" moved along the weak point of the subtropical ridge southeast of Japan, gradually moving toward the westerly trough and slowly weakening. As "Muifa" weakened, the Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression at 8:50 p.m. on April 27, with the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issuing its final warning at 5 a.m. the next day. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 8 p.m. on the 29th. Finally, "Muifa" dissipated over the open ocean east of the Philippines, with some of its cloud systems merging into an extratropical cyclone.

Merbok was the second named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 04W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, and was also the first tropical cyclone to impact the South China region that year. After the formation of Muifa in April, the Northwest Pacific remained calm throughout May until a low-pressure area developed in central Philippines in June. It intensified into a severe tropical storm, was named Merbok, crossed the South China Sea towards eastern Guangdong, and eventually moved inland and gradually dissipated.

PAGASA: Emong, also known as Nanmadol, was the third named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 05W. Initially identified as disturbance 98W, it was later reclassified as 99W. It moved northwestward from the waters east of the Philippines to the waters east of Taiwan, gradually intensifying into a severe tropical storm before turning northeastward. Its first landfall was in Nagasaki City, Nagasaki Prefecture, Japan; the second landfall was in Uwajima City, Ehime Prefecture; and the third landfall was in Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture. Eventually, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Talas was the fourth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 06W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Talas originated from a monsoon depression, and initially, some weather agencies predicted it would merge with a tropical disturbance near the Philippines and strike the Pearl River Delta. However, it eventually developed independently and intensified into a severe tropical storm. It made landfall in Vietnam's Nghe An Province at 2:10 AM on July 17. After landfall, its intensity rapidly weakened due to the frictional effects of the terrain, and it dissipated on July 18. Although it had dissipated, the trailing airflow brought heavy rain to the northern South China Sea and the coastal areas of South China.

Olu was the fifth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 07W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Olu to a tropical depression at 8 a.m. on the 19th, when it was over the sea 2,000 kilometers east-southeast of Japan. Six hours later, authorities issued a gale warning, and subsequently upgraded it to a tropical storm at 8 a.m. on the 21st, assigning it the international number 1705 and naming it Olu. On the afternoon of the 23rd, it began to be influenced by Tropical Storm Rose and took a southeastward path, while also starting to intensify rapidly. Between the 25th and 27th, it gradually absorbed Rose and resumed a westward path, with its intensity significantly decreasing. On the evening of the 27th, it shifted to a southwestward movement, approaching the Ogasawara Islands. From the night of the 30th to the 31st, it intensified rapidly again to reach the strength of a Category 5 hurricane, weakening to a typhoon on August 5 and making landfall on Yakushima, Japan. On the morning of August 8, although its structure had already become loose, it still affected northern Japan. In the Joint Typhoon Warning Center's best track data, Olu's maximum wind speed was downgraded from 140 knots (equivalent to a Category 5 hurricane) to 135 knots (equivalent to a Category 4 hurricane).

Rose was the sixth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 09W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. As Mawar intensified, a baroclinic system west of the International Date Line gradually transformed into a low-pressure area on the morning of the 19th, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 97W at 9 a.m. The low-level circulation center of this low-pressure area was partially exposed to the west due to dry air intrusion and vertical wind shear, but its eastern outflow channel continued to improve, and the warm sea surface provided sufficient energy. At 2 a.m. on the 20th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 5 a.m.

In the afternoon, its deep convection gradually filled the previously exposed eastern side of the low-level circulation center, forming a broader low-level circulation center. Its extratropical cyclone characteristics also gradually weakened. Additionally, as the system was located beneath a strong upper-level low-pressure area, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium" at 2 p.m. and classified the system as a subtropical depression. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning at 3:30 p.m., indicating the possibility of intensifying into a tropical storm within a day. On the morning of the 21st, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system to a subtropical storm at 8 a.m., then raised its rating to "high" at 1:30 p.m. and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 3:15 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency officially upgraded the tropical depression to a tropical storm, naming it Rose and assigning it the international number 1706. The China Meteorological Administration followed suit at 3:48 p.m. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center subsequently announced at 5 p.m. that the system had transitioned into a tropical storm, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 09W.

Initially influenced by a deep subtropical ridge, Rose moved northward. On the morning of the 22nd, it shifted westward, approaching Tropical Cyclone Mawar, and developed a "pinhole eye" in the afternoon. In the evening, Rose moved into cooler waters, and its subtropical characteristics re-emerged. Temperature scanning systems indicated that Rose developed partial cold-core structures, suggesting it was a "hybrid system." Its low-level circulation center was once again exposed, with upper-level convection nearly dissipated, though low-level clouds continued to spiral into the center. By the 24th, it formed a central dense overcast area. On the 25th, Rose began interacting with Mawar, and Mawar's outflow caused strong vertical wind shear on Rose, leading to significant weakening. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Rose to a tropical depression at 5 p.m. and 9 p.m., respectively, with the latter issuing its final warning at 11 a.m. on the 26th. Rose rotated counterclockwise around Mawar and was fully absorbed into Mawar's circulation by midnight on the 28th.

PAGASA: Fabian (Roke) is the seventh named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 10W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Following the appearances of Nesat and Haitang, another disturbance emerged over the waters southeast of Eluanbi. On July 21 at 12:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Roke to a tropical depression. On the afternoon of the 22nd at 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency further upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Roke. Subsequently, it continued moving northwest towards the South China Sea and made landfall near the Sai Kung East Country Park in Hong Kong. As it moved over Shenzhen, it rapidly weakened due to terrain disruption.

Sangka was the eighth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 08W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Shortly after Talas dissipated, a low-pressure area formed in the central Philippine Sea on July 19, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 96W. Initially, major agencies believed Sangka would develop further, with a chance of making landfall near the Pearl River Estuary. However, predictions later changed, forecasting it to move toward Hainan Island as a tropical depression. It initially had strong convection, but its intensity began to weaken after entering the southern South China Sea due to high wind shear and low sea temperatures. However, as it moved to the central South China Sea, it strengthened again, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression at 11 a.m. on July 21. Although it redeveloped, its intensity did not significantly increase and it lingered near the waters off Hainan Island, even interacting slightly with Roke through the Fujiwhara effect. After Roke moved inland into Shenzhen, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Sangka at 3 p.m. on July 23. Subsequently, it made landfall in Quang Binh Province, Vietnam, at 4:30 p.m. on July 25. By 8 p.m., as it moved further into Laos, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression due to land friction.

PAGASA: Gorio Nesat is the ninth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 11W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Nesat to a tropical depression at 3 PM on the 25th and issued a gale warning six hours later. At 11 AM on the 26th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Nesat. On the morning of the 28th, various agencies adjusted its path westward, indicating it would head directly toward Taiwan. At 7:10 PM on the 29th, it made landfall in Su'ao Township, Yilan County, Taiwan, and at 10:30 PM the same evening, it exited into the Taiwan Strait from Zhunan Township, Miaoli County. On the morning of the 30th, it made landfall in Fuqing City, Fuzhou, Fujian, weakened into a severe tropical storm, and continued to weaken on the same day.

PAGASA: Huaning (Nesat) is the 10th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 12W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the morning of July 26, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned disturbance number 92W to a low-pressure area that formed in the northeastern waters of the Paracel Islands. The next day, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Nesat to a tropical depression at 2 PM. On July 28, as its structure gradually improved, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a tropical cyclone formation alert at 5 AM and subsequently upgraded it to a tropical depression at 3 PM, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 12W. The following day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. At 3 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Nesat. At 4:30 PM on July 30, it made landfall in Fenggang, Fangshan, Pingtung, Taiwan, and exited to sea from Fangyuan, Changhua, at 12:30 AM on July 31. At 2 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a remnant low.

Nesat was the eleventh named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 13W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the morning of August 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Nesat. It weakened and dissipated on August 6.

The banyan tree was the twelfth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 14W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The banyan tree formed on August 10 in the northwest Pacific, moved northwest, and gradually strengthened. It began to weaken on the evening of the 15th and dissipated on August 17.

PAGASA: Typhoon Hato was the 13th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 15W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Hato formed on the afternoon of August 20, with the Japan Meteorological Agency assigning it the international designation 1713. Benefiting from the favorable environment of the Luzon Strait and the South China Sea, along with reduced vertical wind shear and warm sea waters that stored energy for nearly a month, it began to intensify rapidly. At this time, satellite imagery revealed the gradual development of an eye structure at its center. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded its intensity from the upper limit of a tropical storm to the upper limit of a severe tropical storm at 2:50 PM, and further upgraded it to a typhoon at 11:40 PM. That night, it slowed down again before resuming a steady west-northwest path by early morning on the 23rd, heading directly toward the area west of the Pearl River Estuary. At noon on the 23rd, it passed over the waters near the Pearl River Estuary and made landfall south of Zhuhai, Guangdong, at 12:50 PM, gradually weakening thereafter. Supported by an active southwest monsoon, its weakening slowed as it crossed the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region on the 24th. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression at 2:40 PM.

PAGASA: Jolina Paka was the 14th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 16W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On August 23, Paka formed as a tropical depression over the waters east of the Philippines, with the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigning it the disturbance number 96W. On August 24, it continued to develop and showed a well-organized structure. At 8 PM, the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a tropical storm. At 2 AM on the 25th, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Paka, assigning it the international number 1714. On the evening of the 25th, it crossed central Luzon, where its intensity temporarily weakened due to the terrain of Luzon. It then entered the central South China Sea the following morning. After entering the South China Sea, its movement speed significantly increased, moving northwestward at approximately 30 kilometers per hour, heading directly toward the area west of the Pearl River Estuary, and it re-strengthened. Paka made landfall along the southeastern coast of Taishan, Guangdong, around 9 AM. It subsequently weakened into a tropical storm, moved into inland Guangxi by the evening, and dissipated on the 28th.

Coral was the 15th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 17W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On August 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Coral to a tropical storm. On August 30, various meteorological agencies upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On August 31, it was gradually upgraded to a typhoon by various meteorological agencies. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a typhoon. On September 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

Mawar was the sixteenth named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 18W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the afternoon of August 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Mawar to a tropical depression. At 3 a.m. on September 1, it was upgraded to a tropical storm. It dissipated on September 4.

PAGASA: Kiko (Gu Chao) is the 17th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 19W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On the morning of September 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Gu Chao to a tropical depression. On September 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm. On September 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it back to a tropical depression. On September 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency indicated in the weather map that it had merged into a frontal system.

PAGASA: Lannie Talim is the 18th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 20W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. On September 9, it was confirmed by the Japan Meteorological Agency to have intensified into Talim. At 2 a.m. on September 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 9 a.m. on the same day, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. On September 15, it began to weaken. On September 18, it transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Maring (Doksuri) was the 19th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 21W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. At 3:00 AM on September 11, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Doksuri to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning six hours later. On September 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to Tropical Depression 21W. That evening, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, naming it Doksuri and assigning it the international designation 1719. After being named, it began to intensify. On the afternoon of September 15, it made landfall in Vietnam and quickly weakened, completely dissipating by September 16.

PAGASA: Odette Kanu was the 20th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 24W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. At 12:40 AM on October 13, Kanu made landfall in Santa Ana, Cagayan, Philippines, shortly after which it moved out to sea, continuing towards the coast of mainland China and intensifying. On October 15, it made landfall on the Leizhou Peninsula and weakened. On October 16, it lingered in the Gulf of Tonkin, soon weakening into a tropical depression, and completely dissipated the following day.

PAGASA: Paolo Lan was the 21st named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 25W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and classified as a "super large" typhoon by the Japan Meteorological Agency. Influenced by a strong subtropical high-pressure ridge, there was a lull in typhoon activity in the Northwest Pacific from late September to early October, until the ridge shifted northward, allowing tropical disturbances to redevelop in the region. On October 11, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned disturbance number 91W to a low-pressure system near the Chuuk Islands. Favorable conditions, including warm sea temperatures and weak wind shear, facilitated the disturbance's intensification. On October 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to Tropical Depression 25W, and the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm the following day, naming it, with other meteorological agencies subsequently upgrading it as well. On October 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a typhoon. On the morning of October 20, Lan's cloud-wrapped eye expanded into a large eye, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center indicated that Lan had entered a phase of rapid intensification. On the afternoon of October 20, the China Meteorological Administration and the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded Lan to a severe typhoon. At 2 a.m. on October 21, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a super typhoon, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also classified Lan as a super typhoon, while the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded it to a very strong typhoon at 8 a.m. On October 22 at 2 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded Lan to a moderate typhoon. At 3 a.m. on October 23, it made landfall in Kakegawa City, Shizuoka Prefecture, Japan. At 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan downgraded Lan to a mild typhoon, and at 2 p.m., the bureau determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. In the post-analysis best track released by the Japan Meteorological Agency, Lan's intensity was revised upward, with the maximum sustained wind speed near the center increased from 95 knots (175 km/h) to 100 knots (185 km/h), and the central minimum pressure lowered from 925 hPa to 915 hPa.

PAGASA: Quedan (Saola) was the 22nd named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 27W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. The Japan Meteorological Agency analyzed it as a low-pressure area at 9 a.m. on the 19th and later analyzed it as a tropical disturbance at 3 p.m. on the same day. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert at 5:30 a.m. on October 19, designating it as Tropical Depression 27W, and subsequently upgraded it to a tropical storm. On the evening of October 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression. At 4:25 a.m. on October 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. On October 24, it was upgraded to a tropical storm and named Saola. At 12:50 p.m. on October 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Ramil (Damrey) was the 23rd named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 28W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
At 9 a.m. on October 31, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the same day, at 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning. On November 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Damrey. On the evening of November 2, various agencies upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. By noon on November 3, it was upgraded to a typhoon by all agencies. On the morning of November 4, it made landfall in Vietnam and gradually weakened. By 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Salome, Hai Kui is the 24th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 30W. The Japan Meteorological Agency marked it as a tropical depression on the weather map at 8 a.m. on the 9th. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the designation Tropical Depression 30W. It was expected to gradually strengthen after entering the South China Sea and head towards the Hainan Island area. On the same day at 9 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the designation 1724 and naming it Hai Kui. On November 12 at 3 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression and considered it to have completely dissipated a day later.

PAGASA: Tino (Haikui) is the 25th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 31W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. This tropical depression entered the South China Sea and gradually intensified. On November 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Haikui, with the designation 1725. It entered the central South China Sea in the afternoon of the 18th. At 3 a.m. on November 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Haikui to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Urduja (Kai-tak) was the 26th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 32W. Kai-tak formed on December 12. It then crossed the central Philippine islands and southwestern Palawan Island.  
On December 19, it moved southwestward across the southern South China Sea, heading toward the southern Malay Peninsula and Singapore area. On the morning of December 22, at 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Kai-tak to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Vinta (Tembin) is the 27th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 33W. On December 21, Tembin rapidly intensified into a severe tropical storm. Initially moving southwestward, it later shifted to a westward direction and made landfall on Mindanao, Philippines, in the evening. On December 22, it weakened into a tropical storm due to the influence of land terrain and crossed Mindanao to reach the Sulu Sea in the evening, moving westward toward Palawan and the South China Sea. On the evening of December 23, as its center passed near the southwestern coast of Palawan, it absorbed moisture and heat from the Sulu Sea, causing its cloud system to expand, deep convection to intensify, and the development of an eye-like feature. On December 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Tembin to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Agaton (Bolaven) was a tropical cyclone that spanned two years (2017 Pacific typhoon season to 2018 Pacific typhoon season). Its precursor low-pressure area formed on December 21, 2017, south of the Marshall Islands at low latitudes, and was initially designated as disturbance 98W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory. However, the designation was later removed due to unfavorable environmental conditions for development. The low-pressure area redeveloped on December 28, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it a new disturbance number, 99W. On December 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency marked the system as a tropical depression on its weather map. Subsequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 01W on January 2, 2018, and the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm on January 3, naming it Bolaven. Bolaven thus became the first tropical cyclone of 2018 and was also the third earliest recorded storm in the Northwest Pacific to form and be named. However, upon entering the South China Sea, the cooler sea temperatures hindered its development, and the system eventually dissipated in the central South China Sea.

In addition to tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones assessed as tropical storms or tropical depressions by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, but only classified as tropical depressions by the Japan Meteorological Agency.

PAGASA: Auring, disturbance number 96W by the US Naval Research Laboratory, was designated as Tropical Depression 01W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
On January 7, 2017, a low-pressure area formed east of the Philippines and developed into the first tropical cyclone of 2017 the following day, receiving the tropical cyclone designation 01W from the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Computer numerical forecast models accurately predicted it would pass over the Philippines and enter the South China Sea, though there was an error in intensity prediction as it lingered over the Philippines, cut off from moisture supply, and weakened into a low-pressure area. However, after entering the South China Sea, it was able to rebuild its cloud bands, but vertical wind shear caused its intensity to fluctuate between a low-pressure area and a tropical depression. Subsequently, the northeast monsoon brought dry air, causing it to weaken significantly. It then made landfall in Vietnam and quickly moved out to sea but failed to reorganize, eventually dissipating near the Gulf of Thailand.

PAGASA: Bising, U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 98W → 99W.  
On January 31, 2017, a low-pressure area formed in the waters east of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it disturbance number 98W. At that time, it was guided by the equatorial anticyclone and influenced by the northeast monsoon, developing slowly. However, in an environment with weak vertical wind shear, warm sea temperatures, and good upper-level divergence, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 2 PM on February 2, and upgraded it to "medium" at 2 PM the following day. Due to its convection becoming active, the Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded it to a tropical depression and immediately issued a gale warning, indicating it would strengthen into a tropical storm within a day. However, on the 5th, vertical wind shear in the area significantly increased, exposing its low-level circulation center and dissipating its convection. The Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning at 8 AM, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its rating back to "low" at 2 PM that afternoon, further canceling the rating at 2 PM on the 6th. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory also canceled its disturbance number. However, the Japan Meteorological Agency maintained its classification as a tropical depression, predicting it would remain stationary. As the northeast monsoon weakened, it became more favorable for it to absorb sea energy and gradually repair its low-level circulation center. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it a new disturbance number, 99W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center reclassified it as "low" at 2 PM on the 7th. Affected by an extratropical cyclone, it gradually weakened, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating again at 2 PM on the 8th. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 8 AM.

U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 91W.  
On the afternoon of March 17, 2017, a low-pressure area formed over the waters south of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 91W. At 2:00 PM on March 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of March 21 at 8:00 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area. At 2:00 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it again to a tropical depression. At 8:00 PM on March 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it again to a low-pressure area.

PAGASA: Crising, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 92W, was designated as Tropical Depression 02W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
02W was a relatively weak tropical cyclone, but the heavy rains it brought caused disasters in the Philippines. After crossing the Philippines, it entered the South China Sea, where it was temporarily affected by dry air and vertical wind shear. Later, supported by moist air, it strengthened several times, but after passing through the Luzon Strait, it was again affected by vertical wind shear and weakened, eventually dissipating.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 97W.  
On the morning of June 22, 2017, a low-pressure area formed over the northeastern waters of Pohnpei Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it disturbance number 97W. By midday on June 22, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," upgraded it to "medium" on the 24th, and further to "high" by midday on June 25, simultaneously issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert, which was canceled at 5 a.m. the following morning. Subsequently, its rating was downgraded to "medium" and "low," and the rating was canceled at 2 p.m. on the 28th. At 8 a.m. on June 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, at which time it was located over the waters east of Taiwan. In the early hours of June 30, it crossed the waters near Okinawa and entered the East China Sea, with its low-level circulation center no longer clearly visible on radar. On July 1, it reorganized, causing strong winds, heavy rain, and lightning near Yakushima and Tanegashima in the early hours. After making consecutive landfalls on the two islands, its low-level circulation center was once again disrupted. It subsequently moved northward along the coast of Kyushu, carried by the jet stream.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 90W → 91W.  
After Severe Tropical Storm Nanmadol, another low-pressure area formed in the waters east of the Philippines and was assigned disturbance number 90W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, which was later canceled. On the morning of July 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, and on the same day, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it a new disturbance number, 91W. At 4:30 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," but by 3 AM the next day, it was directly upgraded to "high," and a tropical cyclone formation alert was issued simultaneously, indicating a higher likelihood of it strengthening into a tropical depression within the next day and moving towards the waters east of Taiwan. After crossing the waters east of Taiwan and entering the East China Sea, it showed no signs of strengthening. Therefore, at 3 AM on the 7th, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded its 24-hour tropical cyclone formation rating to "medium" and canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert. By 2 PM, its rating was canceled, and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On the afternoon of July 12, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated a low-pressure area formed in the northwest waters of Iwo Jima as disturbance number 93W. The next day, at 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "medium" at 2 p.m. However, as it moved to higher latitude regions where the environment was unfavorable for tropical cyclone development, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the related rating at 4 a.m. on the 15th, and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area at 2 p.m. the following afternoon. It eventually transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 93W → 96W. On the morning of July 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded a low-pressure area near the International Date Line to a tropical depression [55]. Three hours later, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it disturbance number 93W. As it gradually moved southeast, the surrounding environment caused its warm system to gradually turn cold, and the U.S. Ocean Prediction Center classified it as a subtropical cyclone at 8 PM [56][57].  
On July 29, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it disturbance number 96W, and the U.S. Ocean Prediction Center continued to classify it as a subtropical storm [58][59]. The Japan Meteorological Agency determined at 10 PM that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone [60].

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 98W was upgraded to a tropical depression by the Japan Meteorological Agency at 2 a.m. on the 26th, but soon dissipated and merged into the circulation of Pakhar.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory disturbance number 90W.  
On the afternoon of August 28, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression at 6 PM and issued a gale warning three hours later. On the afternoon of August 29, at 3 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area and canceled the gale warning.

PAGASA: Nando, designated as disturbance 90W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory, was classified as Tropical Depression 22W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
A low-pressure area formed in late September near the waters off Luzon and gradually developed after moving into the northern South China Sea. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 90W. On September 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, with a central minimum pressure of 1002 hPa. Subsequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number "22W." It moved quickly west-northwest at a speed of about 30 km/h, interacting with the northeast monsoon, which strengthened winds along the Guangdong coast. The China Meteorological Administration reported that it made landfall in Wanning City, Hainan Province, at 9:20 PM on September 24. It then crossed the Beibu Gulf and began moving toward northern Vietnam, gradually weakening. It made landfall in Quang Ninh Province, Vietnam, at 2 PM on September 25 and dissipated on September 26.  
As the low-pressure area in the northern South China Sea intensified into a tropical depression, the Hong Kong Observatory issued the Standby Signal No. 1 at 11:10 PM on September 23. Under the combined influence of its outer rainbands and easterly airflow, some areas in Hong Kong recorded over 20 mm of rainfall, and offshore areas experienced strong winds on the 12th. Among the Observatory's eight reference automatic weather stations, Cheung Chau recorded strong winds, and Cheung Chau Beach briefly experienced gale-force winds. During this period, an incident occurred where a sudden voltage drop trapped 17 people in an elevator for about an hour, who were later rescued by firefighters. All tropical cyclone warning signals were canceled at 7:20 PM, with the system located about 520 km southwest of Hong Kong at the time. Under its influence, some offshore and highland areas recorded strong winds.  
Meanwhile, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau hoisted Signal No. 1 at midnight on September 24, with the tropical depression located about 570 km south-southeast of Macao at the time. Strong winds were consistently recorded on the three major bridges during the day. The Meteorological Bureau updated its "Special Report" at 12:30 PM, advising drivers to exercise caution due to occasional strong winds and gusts on the bridges. All signals were removed at midnight on September 25, with the hoisting duration lasting exactly one day, as the system was located about 480 km southwest of Macao at the time.  
Typhoon blue warnings were issued in Hainan, Guangdong, and Guangxi. Due to heavy rainfall, the China Meteorological Administration issued a yellow rainstorm warning for southern regions, with some areas experiencing up to 140 mm of precipitation. It made landfall in Quang Ninh Province, Vietnam, at 2 PM on September 25 and dissipated in northern Vietnam on the 26th. The heavy rains it triggered caused landslides, but fortunately, there were no casualties. The Vietnam Central Hydrometeorological Forecasting Center recorded 150 mm of rainfall in Hanoi, and waves as high as 3 meters (9.8 feet) were observed in Ha Long Bay.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 97W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as Tropical Depression 23W.  
On October 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, and at 8 p.m. the same evening, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
At 5 a.m. on October 9, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning.  
At 5:50 a.m. on October 10, it made landfall in Ha Tinh Province, Vietnam, and dissipated that evening.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 94W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigned it the number Tropical Depression 26W.  
A day later, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning, and shortly after, it merged into Lan's circulation.

The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as disturbance number 95W, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as Tropical Depression 29W. On the morning of October 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 2 p.m. on November 1, a maritime strong wind warning was issued, but it was canceled by 2 a.m. the next day as it failed to develop due to the influence of Typhoon Damrey. On November 3, it made landfall on the Malay Peninsula and gradually moved away from the Gulf of Thailand into the Andaman Sea, after which the Japan Meteorological Agency ceased tracking it. However, it later interacted with the remnants of Damrey's low-pressure area through the Fujiwhara effect and returned to the Gulf of Thailand, at which point the Japan Meteorological Agency classified it as a low-pressure area.

The northern part of the Malay Peninsula was affected by it, bringing 15 hours of continuous storms to Penang starting in the afternoon of November 4. This caused over 80% of the area to suffer from flooding, land subsidence, landslides, storm surges, and other disasters, resulting in 7 deaths.
The following timeline lists the formation and dissipation times of typhoons for this year, and details of each storm can be found in the sections above.

Tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (i.e., international naming). Once a tropical cyclone is upgraded to a tropical storm by the Japan Meteorological Agency, names from the following list are used. The names are determined based on the list below and are not divided by year. Storm names are provided by members of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee, with each of the 14 member countries and regions submitting 10 names, arranged alphabetically by the English name of the country. Unused names for the year are shown in gray, while names already used this season are shown in black. Storm names in 2017 may overlap with some storm names from 2000, 2004 to 2005, and 2011 to 2012.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form in, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list is rotated every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2017, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list summarizes all systems that developed or moved into the North Pacific west of the International Date Line during 2017. It also outlines the system's intensity, duration, affected land areas, and any deaths or losses associated with the system.

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Roke (English: Tropical Storm Roke, International Number: 1707, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: 10W) was the 7th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. This tropical cyclone struck Hong Kong directly on the morning of July 23, 2017, at tropical storm intensity, making landfall on the Sai Kung Peninsula. The Hong Kong Observatory issued the No. 8 Gale or Storm Signal at the time, but since none of the 8 reference automatic weather stations in Hong Kong recorded even strong winds during the storm's passage—falling far short of the standard for the No. 3 Strong Wind Signal—some citizens criticized the Observatory for being too lenient in issuing the signal.

Whole_Text.content: A long-lived typhoon (Chōju Taifū) refers to a typhoon with a long lifespan, from its development into a typhoon until it transitions into a tropical depression or an extratropical cyclone.

The top rankings of long-lived typhoons are shown below [2], but if a typhoon weakened to a tropical depression once and then redeveloped into a typhoon, the period as a tropical depression is not included [3]. In the rankings under this condition, the typhoons with the longest lifespans since the start of statistics in 1951 to the present are Typhoon No. 5 of 2017 and Typhoon No. 7 of 1972. On the Japan Meteorological Agency's website, a ranking that includes the period when the typhoon was not classified as a typhoon (temporarily downgraded to a tropical depression) is also published [1]. In this ranking, the typhoon with the longest lifespan since the start of statistics in 1951 to the present is Typhoon No. 14 of 1986, followed by Typhoon No. 5 of 2017 and Typhoon No. 7 of 1972.

The term "short-lived typhoon" exists as the opposite of "long-lived typhoon." This refers to typhoons with a short duration from their development into a typhoon to their transition into a tropical depression or extratropical cyclone. The typhoon with the shortest lifespan in recorded history was Typhoon 13 of 1970. This typhoon formed on the 180-degree longitude line (International Date Line) and moved eastward, resulting in a "typhoon" duration of 0 hours. Therefore, excluding such "crossing typhoons," Typhoon 29 of 1974, with a lifespan of 3 hours, holds the record for the shortest duration.
