Article_Name: 熱帶風暴谷超 (2017年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Guchol (English: Tropical Storm Guchol, International Designation: 1717, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP192017, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Kiko, Taiwan translation: Guchol) was the 17th named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Guchol" ([xʊʃɔl̩]) was provided by the Federated States of Micronesia and means turmeric in the Yapese language. This storm developed in the eastern waters of the Philippines, briefly strengthening to a tropical storm while crossing the Luzon Strait, but dissipated in the Taiwan Strait due to increased vertical wind shear.

Guchao developed in the eastern sea area of the Philippines, becoming the fourth tropical cyclone to form in this nearby sea area since late August. On September 1, numerical forecasts from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts predicted that this system would pass through northern Luzon Island but was expected to have no room for development. However, on the 3rd, vertical wind shear in the sea area where the system was located weakened, and the sea surface temperature remained high, giving the system a chance to develop. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 4 a.m. the next day. Shortly after, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan marked the system as a tropical depression on its weather map. By 9 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency predicted that the tropical depression would strengthen into a tropical storm within 24 hours and issued a gale warning. About an hour later, the China National Meteorological Center also upgraded the system to a tropical depression. The Central Weather Bureau predicted in the afternoon that it might strengthen into a mild typhoon that evening or the next day. However, due to deteriorating environmental conditions, it was expected to remain a tropical depression by the 7th. At 5 a.m. the next morning, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded the system to a tropical depression. Due to slightly increased vertical wind shear in the sea area it passed through, the system's upper and lower layers became separated, and the low-level center was fully exposed, slowing its development and even showing signs of weakening. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final report at 11 a.m. At this time, the Macao Meteorological and Geophysical Bureau predicted that it would pass through the Luzon Strait and enter the South China Sea. Numerical forecasts from the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts predicted landfall in southern Taiwan, while the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration predicted it would brush past the eastern sea area of Taiwan. The Central Weather Bureau postponed the estimated time for it to strengthen into a mild typhoon to the next day. As vertical wind shear in the sea area it passed through slightly weakened, cloud clusters near the center began to organize, and its intensity started to increase significantly. At 5 a.m. the next day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center resumed issuing reports on the system. At 9:25 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency was the first to upgrade the system to a tropical storm, assigning it the number 1717 and naming it Guchao. Later, the China National Meteorological Center followed suit. At 8 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan upgraded Guchao to a mild typhoon (although internally, the bureau did not agree that it had already developed into a typhoon, but it upgraded it to align with Japan). The Hong Kong Observatory did not upgrade Guchao to a tropical depression until 10 a.m. Due to increased vertical wind shear in the sea area where Guchao was located, the separation between its upper and lower layers became more severe, causing its intensity to weaken. At 11:29 p.m., the China National Meteorological Center downgraded Guchao back to a tropical depression. At 2:30 a.m. the next day, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also downgraded it to a tropical depression. The Japan Meteorological Agency also downgraded Guchao to a tropical depression, and at 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final report. Although it had been downgraded, Guchao's center remained clearly visible but later gradually dissipated. At 5 p.m. that afternoon, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Guchao to a low-pressure area. Later, as the circulation center became difficult to distinguish, the China National Meteorological Center stopped assigning a number to Guchao at 8 p.m. The next day, the Japan Meteorological Agency indicated on its weather map that Guchao had been absorbed into a frontal system.

As this system continued to approach, it was expected to move towards Taiwan after crossing the Luzon Strait. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration upgraded this system to a tropical depression at 5 PM on September 4, indicating that a Signal No. 1 storm warning would be issued that evening. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration issued a Signal No. 1 storm warning at 11 PM, when Guchao was located approximately 365 kilometers east of Aurora Province. Subsequently, Guchao gradually moved away, about to enter the Bashi Channel and exit the agency's area of responsibility. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration lifted the storm warning at 11 AM on the 6th, when Guchao was located approximately 115 kilometers west of Basco.

The Central Weather Bureau predicts that the eastern part of Taiwan will experience rainfall on the 5th and 6th due to the influence of Typhoon Koinu and expects Koinu to be closest to Taiwan on the 7th, during which a typhoon warning may need to be issued. On the morning of the 6th at 10:10 AM, the Central Weather Bureau issued a special report on a tropical depression, with Koinu located 650 kilometers southeast of Eluanbi at the time. The Central Weather Bureau stated that if Koinu strengthens into a mild typhoon, a sea typhoon warning will be issued, and the possibility of issuing a land typhoon warning is not ruled out. As Koinu strengthened into a mild typhoon, the Central Weather Bureau issued a sea typhoon warning at 10:30 AM, with Koinu located 190 kilometers south-southwest of Eluanbi at the time. On the 7th, Koinu weakened into a tropical depression, and the Central Weather Bureau issued a special report on a tropical depression at 2:30 AM, with Koinu located about 160 kilometers south-southwest of Penghu at the time. As Koinu weakened and dissipated on the 8th, the Central Weather Bureau lifted the tropical depression special report at 4:00 AM.

As Gu Chao strengthened into a tropical storm in the Luzon Strait, the National Meteorological Center issued a blue typhoon warning signal at 10 a.m., with Gu Chao located approximately 455 kilometers southeast of the Fujian-Guangdong border. Due to Gu Chao weakening into a tropical depression, the National Meteorological Center lifted all typhoon warning signals at 6 a.m. the following day (7th), when Gu Chao had moved to about 210 kilometers southeast of the Fujian-Guangdong border. However, after the signal was canceled, Gu Chao continued to approach and weakened into dissipation after entering the Taiwan Strait on the morning of the 7th. The National Meteorological Center warned of 5-6 level winds and level 7 gusts in the Taiwan Strait and along the central coast of Fujian.

Whole_Text.content: Severe Tropical Storm Saola (International designation: 1722, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP272017, Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration: Quedan) was the 22nd named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season. "Saola" was provided by Vietnam, referring to the Asian unicorn, the saola (scientific name: Pseudoryx nghetinhensis), a rare and precious animal recently discovered in a province in central Vietnam, now listed as a protected species.

Sura was the 22nd named tropical cyclone of the 2017 Pacific typhoon season, designated as Tropical Depression 27W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center.  
On October 16, the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W.  
The Japan Meteorological Agency analyzed it as a low-pressure area at 9 a.m. on the 19th and as a tropical disturbance at 3 p.m. on the same day.  
The Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert at 5:30 a.m. on October 19, rated as [MEDIUM], and designated it as Tropical Depression 27W, upgrading it to Tropical Storm 27W, but downgraded it back to a tropical depression on the same day.  
At 4:25 a.m. on October 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning.  
On October 24, it was upgraded to a tropical storm, named Sura, and designated as 1722.  
At 12:50 p.m. on October 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.
The Japan Meteorological Agency has issued a storm warning for Amami City and the central and southern parts of Okinawa Island.

Whole_Text.content: Typhoon Kezia (Kezia Typhoon, Typhoon No. 29 of 1950, International name: Kezia) is a typhoon that occurred in September 1950. It is also referred to as "Kijiya Typhoon" or "Kija Typhoon," among other names.

The formation began near Saipan Island in the Mariana Islands and became Typhoon 29 on September 7. The typhoon moved northwest and grew to a central pressure of 945 mb (equivalent to hPa) and wind speeds of 50 m/s around 500 km south of Cape Muroto on the 11th. After changing its course to west-northwest and slightly weakening, it made landfall near the Osumi Peninsula in Kagoshima Prefecture from Shibushi Bay at noon on the 13th. When it passed near Miyakonojo City in Miyazaki Prefecture, it had a central pressure of 960 mb and wind speeds exceeding 30 m/s. It then traversed the Kyushu region and exited into the Sea of Japan around 3 a.m. on the 14th. After moving eastward over the Sea of Japan, it made landfall again near the Matsumae Peninsula in Hokkaido, crossed Hokkaido, and dissipated into the Sea of Okhotsk on the 15th. The typhoon caused significant damage in various areas due to factors such as the short interval of only 10 days since the arrival of Typhoon Jane, continued heavy rain from low pressure after the typhoon passed, and storm surges affecting areas where the ground had subsided due to the 1946 Showa Nankai Earthquake.

In 17 prefectures from Kyushu to Kinki, damage from storms and high tides affected not only houses but also ships and railways. There were 30 fatalities, 19 missing persons, and 35 injured. A total of 4,836 houses were completely or partially destroyed, washed away, or damaged, and 121,924 houses were flooded. The inundated farmland area was 518.1 hectares. On September 13, at Itsukushima Shrine in Itsukushima Town, Saeki District, Hiroshima Prefecture (now Hatsukaichi City), the shrine buildings were damaged by high tides. On September 14, in Iwakuni City, Yamaguchi Prefecture, the Kintai Bridge was washed away due to the rising waters of the Nishiki River. On September 21 of the same year, Yamaguchi Prefecture, Miyazaki Prefecture, Oita Prefecture, and Hiroshima Prefecture, which suffered significant damage, received relief funds from Emperor Showa and Empress Kojun. At that time, during the height of the Korean War and just before the Incheon Landing Operation, records from the publicly available Advanced Military Research Institute mention that "the fleet was struck by 125-mile-per-hour winds."
This item is a draft related to disasters and disaster prevention. We are seeking collaborators to add or correct this item (Project: Disasters / Portal: Disasters).

Article_Name: 熱帶風暴格美 (2018年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: Tropical Storm Gaemi (English: Tropical Storm Gaemi, International Number: 1806, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP082018) is the 6th named tropical cyclone of the 2018 Pacific typhoon season. The name "Gaemi" (개미) was provided by South Korea, meaning ant.

On June 14, a subtropical depression located southwest of Taiwan developed into a tropical disturbance along a stationary front, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 95W at 2 a.m. The Japan Meteorological Agency simultaneously classified it as a tropical depression and issued a gale warning. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued a tropical depression advisory at 5:15 a.m. At 7 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low." By 12:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours directly to "high," skipping "medium," and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Later that afternoon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 08W. 

On June 15 at 10 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1806, and named it Kaimi. However, most meteorological agencies did not follow suit in upgrading it, instead maintaining it at the upper limit of tropical depression intensity. This included Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau, which continued to classify it as a tropical depression. Kaimi made landfall in Kaohsiung between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m. and exited to sea from Taitung around 12 p.m., but the Central Weather Bureau maintained the tropical depression advisory instead of upgrading it to a tropical storm and issuing sea and land typhoon warnings. 

It was not until June 16 that various meteorological agencies upgraded Kaimi to a tropical storm. The Central Weather Bureau also upgraded Kaimi to a tropical storm on the morning of June 16. On the morning of June 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Kaimi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

As Kemi approached, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan issued heavy rain and torrential rain warnings for 11 counties and cities on June 15, stating that Kemi made landfall along the coast of Kaohsiung between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m. that day, and subsequently exited to sea from Taitung at noon. Affected by Kemi, power outages were reported in many areas in southern Taiwan. Taiwan Power Company stated that the heavy rain caused power outages for a total of 13,500 households in Kaohsiung City at one point, with sporadic outages in Pingtung County and Tainan City, which were restored after emergency repairs. Additionally, flooding occurred in areas such as Jiadong Township and Linbian Township in Pingtung County, with traffic control implemented on multiple road sections within the county. The heavy rainfall also caused damage to crops, with bananas suffering the most severe damage.

Under the combined influence of Kemi and the Meiyu front, Okinawa Prefecture experienced strong winds and heavy rain. At 9:29 a.m. on June 16, the weather station at Ie Village Airport recorded a maximum instantaneous gust of 62.1 meters per second (224 kilometers per hour). In Okinawa Prefecture, a total of three people were injured: a man in his 30s suffered a wrist fracture after being crushed by an iron plate blown over by strong winds, and two women were injured by being caught in a car. Additionally, Kemi brought once-in-50-years heavy rainfall to Okinawa Prefecture. The 24-hour rainfall in Ie Village reached 404.5 millimeters, and in Aguni Village, it reached 309 millimeters, both breaking local records.

Article_Name: 2018年太平洋颱風季 - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content: The 2018 Pacific typhoon season refers to any tropical cyclones that formed in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and west of the International Date Line, including the South China Sea, at any time during the year 2018. Although no official timeframe was set for this typhoon season, most tropical cyclones in the Northwest Pacific typically form between May and December. This article is limited to the waters of the Pacific and South China Sea north of the equator and west of the International Date Line. Storms that form in the Pacific Ocean north of the equator and east of the International Date Line are referred to as hurricanes and are included in the 2018 Pacific hurricane season. Tropical storms that form in the Northwest Pacific are named by the Japan Meteorological Agency (international names) with international numbers starting with 18xx, while the United States Joint Typhoon Warning Center assigns tropical depressions in the region a number ending with the letter W. Any tropical depression that enters or forms within the Philippine Area of Responsibility is given a local name by the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration for local warning purposes, which may result in two different English names (the international name is considered official). Additionally, the Chinese translations used in mainland China, Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan may differ. The information on each tropical cyclone below is based on its peak form during its existence. For more information on typhoons in the Western Pacific, please refer to the Pacific typhoon season.

The Shenzhen Meteorological Bureau predicts that 6 to 7 tropical cyclones will enter within 500 kilometers of Shenzhen in 2018, with a higher probability of the first tropical cyclone entering within 500 kilometers of Shenzhen in mid-June, and it is predicted that 4 of them will affect areas near Shenzhen.

The Hong Kong Observatory predicted that the number of tropical cyclones entering within 500 kilometers of Hong Kong in 2018 would be normal to above normal, approximately 5 to 8. Additionally, the Hong Kong Observatory forecasted that the La Niña phenomenon in 2018 would be relatively weak, so the typhoon season in 2018 might not be particularly long. However, it was also suggested that the typhoon season that year could last until December.

The Central Weather Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation announced the typhoon season outlook on June 29, predicting that the total number of typhoons forming in the Northwest Pacific from June to December 2018 will be slightly above normal, with a total of about 21 to 25 typhoons, and 3 to 5 of them potentially affecting Taiwan. There is about a 50% chance of an El Niño phenomenon forming in the summer, leading to higher sea temperatures in the central Pacific and typhoon formation locations shifting eastward. Under the condition that typhoon formation locations are farther from Taiwan, if a typhoon does affect Taiwan, its intensity may be stronger than usual.

On December 31, 2017, a tropical depression formed east of the Philippines and made landfall in the southern Philippines the following evening. After entering the South China Sea, the tropical depression intensified into the first named tropical cyclone of the year: Bolaven. Bolaven weakened and dissipated in the South China Sea due to increased vertical wind shear. A month later, Sanba formed and affected the same area in the Philippines, dissipating due to terrain effects. Another month later, Jelawat formed near Guam, initially affected by vertical wind shear. As the wind shear weakened, Jelawat intensified into the season's first typhoon on the morning of March 30 and unexpectedly strengthened into the year's first super typhoon that afternoon. Jelawat later weakened due to vertical wind shear and unusually transitioned into a subtropical cyclone. From Jelawat's dissipation until Ewiniar's formation, no tropical cyclones were named by the Japan Meteorological Agency in the Northwest Pacific. 

At the end of May, numerical forecast models began predicting low-pressure areas or tropical cyclone activity in the South China Sea and east of the Philippines in early June. Two low-pressure areas formed simultaneously on May 31, and another low-pressure area formed near Guam on June 1. The low-pressure area in the South China Sea intensified into a tropical depression and moved northward, strengthening into a tropical storm named Ewiniar by the Japan Meteorological Agency when it made landfall in Xuwen, Guangdong, on June 6. It then crossed the Qiongzhou Strait southward, made landfall in Haikou, Hainan, and moved eastward. On June 7, it took a northeastward path and made landfall in Yangjiang, Guangdong, that evening, gradually weakening and dissipating. Meanwhile, the tropical depression east of the Philippines absorbed another system and intensified into a tropical storm named Maliksi by the Japan Meteorological Agency. 

In mid-June, Gaemi made landfall in Taiwan, but most meteorological agencies did not upgrade it to a tropical storm until after landfall. In late June, Prapiroon formed, moving northward and affecting Japan and South Korea. On the afternoon of July 4, Prapiroon transitioned into an extratropical cyclone in the Sea of Japan. That evening, Maria formed and rapidly intensified, reaching typhoon status within a day according to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center and the Japan Meteorological Agency. On July 6, Maria reached super typhoon status according to the Joint Typhoon Warning Center. Maria then moved quickly northwestward, impacting northern Taiwan, Ishigaki Island, and areas in Fujian and Zhejiang. 

In mid-to-late July, the monsoon trough and easterly waves became active, leading to the formation of multiple tropical systems. Son-Tinh accelerated significantly, crossing the northern South China Sea at 40 km/h and making landfall in Vietnam on July 19. Son-Tinh's remnants re-entered the sea and re-intensified into a tropical depression, lingering in the Gulf of Tonkin before dissipating. Ampil became the third storm on record to make landfall in Shanghai from the East China Sea. Wukong reached typhoon intensity at high latitudes. Jongdari's movement path was highly unusual, becoming the fourth tropical cyclone since 1951 to move east to west into Japan's Honshu and the first to sweep across Honshu and Kyushu inland. This system also became the fourth storm to make landfall in Shanghai from the East China Sea and the second typhoon to do so in the year. After Jongdari dissipated, the first active period of the monsoon trough and easterly waves in the Northwest Pacific ended. 

In early August, Shanshan passed close to Japan before moving northward and transitioning into an extratropical cyclone. Yagi made landfall in Zhejiang, China, on August 12 and weakened into a tropical depression the next day. In mid-August, the monsoon trough and easterly waves became active again. Leepi initially intensified rapidly but later weakened due to the influence of tropical disturbance 98W (later Tropical Storm Bebinca). Bebinca lingered over the sea for a time before making landfall in Vietnam on August 17. On August 13, Hurricane Hector from the Eastern Pacific crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific. Hector weakened into a tropical depression on August 15. Rumbia became the fifth tropical cyclone since 1949 to move westward over the sea and make direct landfall in Shanghai, and it was the first time since 1873 that three tropical cyclones made direct landfall in Shanghai within a single month. Soulik broke the record for the highest gusts measured in nine years on Nakano-shima, with wind speeds reaching 50.1 m/s (180 km/h). Cimaron formed on August 18, reaching its peak intensity on the morning of August 22 with a clear eye. That afternoon, Cimaron moved into cooler waters, and its intensity began to weaken. On August 23, Cimaron and Soulik made landfall in Japan and South Korea, respectively, transitioning into extratropical cyclones on August 24 and 25. From Son-Tinh's formation on July 17 to Soulik's transition into an extratropical cyclone on August 25, the Northwest Pacific experienced nearly 40 consecutive days of named typhoon activity, setting a new record for prolonged typhoon activity in the region. 

On August 28, Jebi formed. Jebi's naming marked the season as having the most named tropical cyclones formed from January to August on record, with 21, just two fewer than the 1965 and 1971 Pacific typhoon seasons. Many of the tropical cyclones formed in August developed at higher latitudes and moved northward due to a stronger subtropical high, allowing Jebi to move westward and rapidly intensify by absorbing energy stored in the region. At 5 a.m. on August 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Jebi to a super typhoon, with wind speeds reaching Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, making it the second tropical cyclone of the year to reach this level after Maria. On the morning of September 4, Jebi made landfall in Tokushima Prefecture, Japan, and two hours later in Kobe, Hyogo Prefecture. On the morning of September 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared Jebi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. 

On September 7, Mangkhut formed, becoming the third typhoon of the year to reach Category 5 intensity on the Saffir-Simpson scale. Mangkhut had a broad circulation and strong winds, causing severe damage in multiple regions. On September 11, Barijat formed, making landfall in Zhanjiang, Guangdong, on the morning of September 13. At 3:45 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. On September 21, Trami formed. Trami's location had sea surface temperatures of 28°C, weak vertical wind shear, and good upper-level outflow, allowing it to rapidly intensify and develop a central dense overcast with radiating outer bands. At 5 a.m. on September 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its wind speed to 140 knots (260 km/h), making it the fourth typhoon of the year to reach Category 5 intensity on the Saffir-Simpson scale after Maria, Jebi, and Mangkhut. The Pacific high ridge slightly strengthened on September 28, causing Trami to accelerate northwestward. At 7 p.m. on September 30, Trami made landfall in Tanabe, Wakayama Prefecture, Japan. On October 1, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared Trami had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. 

On September 29, Kong-rey formed. Kong-rey's naming marked the season as having the most named tropical cyclones formed from January to September since 1994, with 25. Kong-rey's location had sea surface temperatures of 29–30°C and weak wind shear, allowing it to rapidly intensify. On October 2, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its wind speed to 140 knots (260 km/h), making it the fifth typhoon of the year to reach Category 5 intensity on the Saffir-Simpson scale after Maria, Jebi, Mangkhut, and Trami. That evening, Kong-rey moved into cooler waters, and its intensity began to decrease significantly. At 8 a.m. on October 6, Kong-rey made landfall in Tongyeong, Gyeongsangnam-do, South Korea. On October 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency declared Kong-rey had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. 

On October 22, Yutu formed. At 11 a.m. on October 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a super typhoon, with wind speeds reaching 145 knots (269 km/h), making it the sixth typhoon of the year to reach Category 5 intensity on the Saffir-Simpson scale. Later, its wind speed was further upgraded to 155 knots (287 km/h). The Japan Meteorological Agency also raised its maximum sustained wind speed to 215 km/h at 5:45 p.m. that day, surpassing Mangkhut to become the strongest storm of 2018 and the seventh typhoon to be rated as "violent" by the Japan Meteorological Agency. On the evening of October 25, Yutu developed a double eyewall west of Guam and entered an eyewall replacement cycle, leading the Central Weather Bureau to downgrade it to a moderate typhoon. On October 26, Yutu completed its eyewall replacement cycle, and the Central Weather Bureau re-upgraded it to a strong typhoon. In the early hours of October 30, Yutu made landfall in Dinapigue, Isabela Province, Philippines. At 2:45 p.m. on November 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression. 

In early November, Usagi formed, reaching its peak intensity before weakening and making landfall in Vietnam. On November 17, Toraji formed. On November 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression, but its remnants persisted until completely dissipating on November 21. On November 20, Man-yi formed. Despite having a well-organized structure, it was in an unfavorable environment and began weakening shortly after reaching its peak due to dry air and low sea temperatures.

Whole_Text.header: Tropical cyclone that has been internationally named

Whole_Text.content: PAGASA: Agaton Bolaven was a tropical cyclone that spanned the years 2017 to 2018. Its initial low-pressure area formed on December 21, 2017, in the low latitudes south of the Marshall Islands, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 98W. However, the designation was later removed due to unfavorable environmental conditions for development. The low-pressure area redeveloped on December 28, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it the disturbance number 99W. On December 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency marked this system as a tropical depression on its weather map. Subsequently, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center designated it as Tropical Depression 01W on January 2, 2018. On January 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Bolaven, assigning it the international designation 1801. Bolaven thus became the first tropical cyclone of 2018 and was also the third earliest recorded storm in the Northwest Pacific to form and be named. However, upon entering the South China Sea, the lower sea temperatures in the region hindered further development, and the system eventually dissipated in the central South China Sea. In the best track report published by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center in October 2019, its peak intensity was revised to 35 knots (approximately 65 kilometers per hour).

PAGASA: Basyang  
On the morning of February 5, 2018, a low-pressure area formed over the waters southeast of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 93W at 6:30 AM. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assessed the chance of the low-pressure area developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" on the afternoon of the following day (February 6). Initially, the system had weak convection, disorganized structure, and lacked spiral characteristics. However, convection began to intensify, and a polar outflow channel opened, showing signs of a developing tropical cyclone. On the morning of February 7, at 8:00 AM, the JTWC upgraded the system's chance of forming into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "medium." By the morning of February 8, at 6:00 AM, the chance was further raised to "high," and a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert was issued. Meanwhile, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression at 8:00 AM.  

At 5:00 AM on February 9, the JTWC followed suit and upgraded it, assigning the tropical cyclone the number 02W. At that time, numerical weather prediction models indicated that the system would take a westward path, though there were differences in intensity forecasts. On February 11, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Sanba, assigning it the international number 1802. Due to the influence of vertical wind shear, Sanba's intensification stalled repeatedly on February 12, only slightly strengthening later that evening as convective cloud bands filled the previously exposed low-level circulation center.  

The subtropical ridge remained strong, steering Sanba westward at a speed of 25 km/h toward the Philippines. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical, and Astronomical Services Administration (PAGASA) announced that Sanba made landfall in Hinatuan, Mindanao, at 9:15 AM. Later in the morning, Sanba quickly passed over the northeastern tip of Mindanao and entered the Bohol Sea. PAGASA announced its second landfall in Clarin, Bohol, at 2:00 PM. Affected by terrain, Sanba weakened, and the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical depression at 11:00 PM.  

Sanba entered the Sulu Sea in the early hours of February 14, and the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression at 8:45 AM. Under the influence of strong wind shear, Sanba's low-level circulation center became exposed, and the JTWC issued its final warning at 5:00 PM. Sanba later crossed Palawan and entered the South China Sea, where the JMA reported at 2:00 AM on February 17 that Sanba had weakened and dissipated.

PAGASA: Caloy  
On March 16, 2018, a low-pressure area formed in the waters northwest of Pohnpei Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 96W at 3:30 PM. Benefiting from sea surface temperatures near 30°C, weak vertical wind shear, and a favorable low-level convergence zone environment, the system's convective cloud bands wrapped around and consolidated the low-level circulation center, showing the characteristics of a developing tropical cyclone. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) upgraded the system's chance of forming into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours from "low" to "medium" at 4 AM the next day (March 17) and further to "high" at 10:30 AM, but downgraded it back to "medium" at 11 PM. As the system's convection re-intensified, the JTWC raised the rating to "high" again at 12:30 PM on March 23 and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a tropical depression at 8 AM on March 25, stating that it had the potential to develop into a tropical storm. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) also upgraded it to a tropical depression at 12:05 PM and issued a gale warning, indicating that it could strengthen into a tropical storm within a day. With the westerlies opening up strong polar outflow, the JTWC upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 5 AM on March 25, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 03W. Guided by the subtropical ridge, the system moved westward at a speed of about 25 km/h. The JMA officially upgraded the system to a tropical storm at 3:10 PM, naming it Jelawat and assigning it the international number 1803.  
On March 30, Jelawat underwent explosive intensification, reaching the JTWC's "super typhoon" category. However, it quickly weakened due to wind shear, with its wind speed dropping by 120 km/h within a day. In the early hours of April 2, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression. By the evening, the JMA determined that Jelawat had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

After experiencing the persistent heatwave in South China in May, computer numerical forecast models began predicting tropical cyclone activity in the South China Sea in early June, but with significant variability and repeated changes in forecasts. The low-pressure area in the forecast formed in the central South China Sea off the coast of Palawan, Philippines, on May 31, initially moving west-northwest. The next day (June 1), it intensified into a tropical depression. From June 2 to 3, the system moved northwest-northward along the southwestern side of the subtropical ridge at a speed of 12 km/h, hindered by strong vertical wind shear, with convection continuously displaced southwestward. On June 4, the system moved slowly, lingering off the coast of central Vietnam, bringing severe weather to the area. Subsequently, on June 5, it took a northeast-northward path, accelerating toward the vicinity of Hainan, China, and the Leizhou Peninsula in Guangdong. On the morning of June 6, it intensified into a tropical storm and was named Ewiniar by the Japan Meteorological Agency, with the international designation 1804. Ewiniar then turned westward, making landfall in Xuwen, Guangdong, circling counterclockwise between Leizhou and Hainan, crossing the Qiongzhou Strait southward at noon, and making landfall again in Haikou, Hainan, in the afternoon before shifting eastward, bringing strong winds and heavy rain to the region and the Guangdong coast. On June 7, Ewiniar took an east-northeast path, approaching the western coast of Guangdong, and made landfall in Yangjiang that evening. However, supported by moisture from the outbreak of the southwest monsoon, Ewiniar weakened slowly. On June 9, Ewiniar weakened into a tropical depression and gradually dissipated.

PAGASA: Domeng  
On May 31, a low-pressure area formed southeast of Luzon, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 90W. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center gave it a "LOW" rating.  
On June 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "MEDIUM."  
On June 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression.  
On June 5, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "HIGH" in the evening and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At the same time, it absorbed disturbance 91W located to its northeast.  
On the afternoon of June 6, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it.  
At 4 a.m. on June 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Maliksi, assigning it the international number 1805. At 8 a.m., the Hong Kong Observatory increased Maliksi's wind speed by 20 kilometers within six hours.  
At 8 p.m. on June 9, the Hong Kong Observatory upgraded Maliksi to a severe tropical storm.  
On June 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon, at which point Maliksi had developed a cloud-filled eye.  
At 2 a.m. on June 12, both the Taiwan Central Weather Bureau and the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Maliksi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Ester  
On June 14, a subtropical depression located southwest of Taiwan developed into a tropical disturbance, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 95W at 2 a.m. The Japan Meteorological Agency simultaneously classified it as a tropical depression and issued a gale warning, while Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau issued a tropical depression advisory at 5:15 a.m. At 7 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low." By 12:30 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center skipped the "medium" classification and directly upgraded its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "high," issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Later that afternoon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 08W.  

On June 15 at 10 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, naming it Gaemi and assigning it the international number 1806. However, most meteorological agencies did not follow suit and maintained its classification as a strong tropical depression, including Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau, which continued to classify it as a tropical depression despite its impact on Taiwan. Gaemi made landfall in Kaohsiung between 7 and 8 a.m. and exited to sea from Taitung around noon. However, the Central Weather Bureau maintained the tropical depression advisory instead of upgrading it to a light typhoon and issuing sea and land typhoon warnings.  

It was not until June 16 that various meteorological agencies upgraded Gaemi to a tropical storm. Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau also upgraded Gaemi to a light typhoon on the morning of June 16. On the morning of June 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Gaemi had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Florita  
On June 25, a cold-core low pressure system over the eastern waters of the Philippines transitioned into a warm-core system, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 90W. On June 26, after merging with the tropical disturbance 99W to its southeast, it began consolidating its cloud system. The next day, the Japan Meteorological Agency marked it as a low-pressure area. Benefiting from favorable convergence and weak vertical wind shear, the system began to rapidly develop on June 28. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center initially rated it as "low" in the morning, upgraded it to "medium" at noon, and further to "high" in the afternoon, issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded it to a tropical depression, as did the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan. Later that evening, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 09W. An hour later, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it.  

At 10 a.m. on June 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Prapiroon, assigning it the international number 1807. On July 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. The Central Weather Bureau also upgraded it to a moderate typhoon at 8 a.m. the same day. On July 3, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On July 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm. Later that afternoon, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Prapiroon had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Gardo  
On June 26, a low-pressure area formed over the waters near Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 91W. On the morning of June 28, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated it as "low." On the morning of July 2, the JTWC upgraded the system's rating to "medium." At noon that day, the JTWC further upgraded the system's rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. The next day (July 3), the JTWC classified it as a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 10W. Simultaneously, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) also classified it as a tropical depression. At 3 p.m., the JMA issued a gale warning for the system.  

On the evening of July 4, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm and named it Maria, assigning it the international number 1808. Due to favorable environmental conditions, including a sea surface temperature of 29°C, weak vertical wind shear, and good upper-level outflow, Maria began to intensify rapidly, developing a central dense overcast. On July 5, the JMA was the first to upgrade Maria to a severe tropical storm in the morning. That day, Maria continued to absorb energy from the ocean, developing a "cloud-filled eye" and later a "pinhole eye" in the evening. The JTWC upgraded Maria to a typhoon that afternoon, followed by the JMA in the evening.  

On July 6, Maria continued to strengthen, and the JTWC upgraded it to a super typhoon in the morning, reaching its peak intensity. In the evening, Maria underwent an eyewall replacement cycle, prompting the JTWC to downgrade it to a typhoon. On July 8, Maria completed the eyewall replacement and reopened its "pinhole eye," leading the JTWC to re-upgrade it to a super typhoon that afternoon, once again reaching peak intensity.  

On July 9, Maria moved into cooler waters, and its intensity began to weaken. The JTWC downgraded Maria to a typhoon again. On July 11, Maria made landfall in Fujian Province, China. The JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm at 5 p.m. that day. In the evening, the JMA further downgraded it to a tropical storm.  

On July 12, the JMA downgraded Maria to a tropical depression, and the JTWC issued its final advisory on the system.

PAGASA: Henry, a low-pressure area, formed in the southern waters of Guam on July 9. Computer numerical forecast models indicated that the system's path and intensity were difficult to predict due to the binary typhoon effect caused by another low-pressure area to the southwest (which later developed into Tropical Cyclone Ampil), adding uncertainty to the system's development. In fact, after its formation, the system interacted with that low-pressure area, competing for moisture and causing slow development. Initially, the system moved northwest at a speed of about 10 km/h. By the 14th, it shifted to a west-northwest direction. At the same time, computer model discrepancies gradually narrowed, predicting that the system would not absorb the low-pressure area to its south but would move into the South China Sea via northern Luzon or the Bashi Channel, though its subsequent path remained uncertain. On the 15th, the system's speed increased to 20 km/h, shifted to a west-southwest direction, and intensified into a tropical depression with increasing spiral structure. 

Under the significant strengthening of the subtropical ridge extending westward from the north of the system, the system further accelerated to 30 km/h on July 16, moving directly west and breaking free from the influence of the low-pressure area to its southeast. Although vertical wind shear slightly affected its development, the system continued to consolidate its low-level circulation center due to sea surface temperatures of 30°C. Numerical forecast discrepancies further narrowed, predicting the system would move rapidly westward across the northern South China Sea via the Balintang Channel and make landfall between Hainan and the Leizhou Peninsula. The tropical depression passed over the Babuyan Islands in the evening. After entering the South China Sea early on the 17th, it accelerated to 40 km/h, crossing the northern South China Sea, and strengthened into a tropical storm in the morning, named Son-Tinh by the Japan Meteorological Agency with the international designation 1809. During the day, Son-Tinh moved steadily westward, slightly shifting to a west-southwest direction at night, heading directly for Hainan, and eventually made landfall in Wanning, Hainan, early on the 18th. Due to its rapid movement, the impact of terrain was significantly reduced, and Son-Tinh moved into the Beibu Gulf before noon, subsequently slowing down and reorganizing. By early on the 19th, it made landfall again in northern Vietnam, weakened into a tropical depression in the morning, and further weakened into a low-pressure area the next day (20th).

However, benefiting from the continuous moisture supply from the southwest monsoon, the remnants of Son-Tinh's low-pressure area did not dissipate but maintained its spiral structure, unaffected by terrain erosion, lingering over northern Vietnam and Laos, causing flooding in the region. By the 21st, under the strengthening of the equatorial anticyclone to the south, Son-Tinh "turned around" and moved eastward back into the Beibu Gulf, re-intensifying into a tropical depression in the afternoon. Son-Tinh crossed Hainan again from the 22nd to the 23rd and made landfall on the Leizhou Peninsula, then slowly moved northward. By the morning of the 24th, it shifted northwest into Guangxi, and by the 25th, it had completely dissipated.

PAGASA: Inday  
On July 11, a low-pressure area formed over the eastern waters of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 94W. On July 12, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated 94W as "low." However, due to the influence of the convection enhancement of tropical disturbance 92W to its northwest, the environmental conditions ahead of tropical disturbance 94W deteriorated, and the low-level circulation center gradually became exposed, leading the JTWC to cancel the rating the next day.  

On July 14, as the system entered a region with favorable development conditions and tropical disturbance 92W accelerated westward and moved away, deep convection gradually covered the exposed low-level circulation center. The JTWC directly upgraded the system's rating to "medium," skipping "low." On July 16, under the influence of the southwest monsoon, the system began to develop, and its structure gradually improved. On the morning of July 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded the system to a tropical depression. At 5 PM the same day, the JTWC upgraded the system's rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 9 PM the same day, the JMA issued a gale warning for the system.  

At 5 AM on July 18, the JTWC upgraded the system to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 12W. At 9:15 PM the same day, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm, naming it Ampil and assigning it the international number 1810. On the same day, Ampil gradually consolidated and developed, with its center slightly shifting eastward.  

On July 19, Ampil continued to strengthen, and at 2 AM, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm, followed by similar upgrades from multiple meteorological agencies. At this time, Ampil left the monsoon trough and, guided by the subtropical high-pressure system, gradually shifted from northeast to northwest, with clouds concentrated in the southwestern quadrant. Ampil passed near the waters of Okinawa on July 21.  

At 12:30 PM on July 22, Ampil made landfall in Xinhai Town, Chongming District, Shanghai. After landfall, Ampil roughly maintained its intensity, and the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression on July 24. The following day, the JMA determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On July 20, a low-pressure area formed in the open ocean southeast of Minamitorishima, Japan, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Tropical Disturbance 97W. At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency also marked it as a low-pressure area. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low" and upgraded it to "medium" later that night. As the system's structure gradually improved and its spiral characteristics became evident, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "high" on the afternoon of July 21 and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. In the evening, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 14W. The Japan Meteorological Agency and the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan followed suit shortly after. On the afternoon of July 22, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical storm. In the evening, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. On the evening of July 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, named it "Wukong," and assigned it the international number 1811. On July 25, the China Meteorological Administration was the first to upgrade it to a severe tropical storm, followed shortly by the Japan Meteorological Agency. In the afternoon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a typhoon but downgraded it to a tropical storm later that evening. On the morning of July 26, the China Meteorological Administration downgraded it to a tropical storm. In the afternoon, the Japan Meteorological Agency also downgraded it to a tropical storm. On July 27, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Wukong had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On the evening of July 19, a low-pressure area formed southeast of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 96W. On the afternoon of July 20, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated it as "low." On the morning of July 21, the JTWC upgraded the system's rating to "medium." Later that evening, the JTWC further upgraded the system's rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On July 22, the JTWC classified the system as a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 15W. At this time, the circulation center was difficult to discern, so the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) continued to mark the system as a low-pressure area on weather maps, upgrading it to a tropical depression the following day. In the early hours of July 25, the JMA upgraded the system to a tropical storm, assigning it the international designation 1812 and naming it Jongdari. Later that evening, the JMA upgraded Jongdari to a severe tropical storm. 

Although Jongdari encountered increased vertical wind shear on July 26, the JMA still upgraded it to a typhoon that afternoon. After reaching its peak, Jongdari began to be influenced by the subtropical high to the northeast, causing it to shift from northeast to north and then west over the waters south of Japan. Subsequently, subsidence caused its intensity to weaken. At 4:00 PM on July 28, Jongdari made landfall in Ise City, Mie Prefecture, Japan. After landfall, friction from the terrain caused its intensity to weaken rapidly. Shortly after landfall, the JMA downgraded Jongdari to a severe tropical storm, while the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm in its next advisory. In the early hours of July 29, the JMA downgraded Jongdari to a tropical storm. At 8:30 AM that morning, Jongdari made a second landfall in Buzen City, Fukuoka Prefecture, Japan. Shortly thereafter, the JTWC downgraded Jongdari to a tropical depression.

On July 30, the JMA determined that Jongdari had entered the East China Sea and absorbed the warm tropical disturbance 91W, which had previously been a cold-core low. At 2:30 AM on August 3, the China Meteorological Administration (CMA) announced that Jongdari had made landfall in Jinshan District, Shanghai. At 9:00 AM, the CMA downgraded Jongdari to a tropical depression. At 1:00 PM, the JMA downgraded Jongdari to a tropical depression. At 3:00 PM, the CMA ceased issuing advisories for Jongdari.

On August 1, a low-pressure area formed northeast of Guam, and the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 94W at 6:30 a.m. that day. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 2 p.m. On August 2, at 9 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium," and by 2 p.m., it was raised to "high," with a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert issued simultaneously. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 2 p.m. and issued a gale warning at 9:15 p.m. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 5 a.m. on August 3, assigning it the number "17W." The Japan Meteorological Agency officially upgraded the system to a tropical storm at 9:10 a.m., naming it Shanshan and assigning it the international number 1813, with the Joint Typhoon Warning Center following suit at 5 p.m. that day. 

Benefiting from favorable sea surface conditions, Shanshan steadily intensified in the afternoon, with deep convection wrapping into the center, forming a central dense overcast, and its circulation extending up to 300 kilometers from Guam. At 2:45 a.m. on August 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. That day, Shanshan accelerated northwestward at a speed of 20 kilometers per hour, developing a "cloud-filled eye" and opening a low-level eye. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded Shanshan to a typhoon at 2:50 p.m., with the Joint Typhoon Warning Center following at 5 p.m. On the afternoon of August 5, Shanshan experienced a brief northward deviation but resumed its northwestward path later that night. On August 6, Shanshan ingested dry air in the afternoon, weakening its western circulation. However, on August 7, it connected with the westerly jet stream, reopening its previously deteriorated outflow, with deep convection once again wrapping into the center and forming a slightly rough eye.

On August 8, Shanshan, located on the western side of a high-pressure ridge, turned northwestward. After a brief peak in intensity, the sea surface conditions around Shanshan deteriorated, causing its intensity to weaken. Its eye became a "cloud-filled eye," and the central convection was sheared eastward. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm at 11:45 a.m. On the early morning of August 9, Shanshan turned northward, passing close to the coastal waters off Choshi City, Kanto, Japan. Affected by Japan's terrain and lower sea surface temperatures, Shanshan rapidly weakened. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm at 5 p.m. and issued its final advisory six hours later. The Japan Meteorological Agency also downgraded Shanshan to a tropical storm at 11:45 p.m. On August 10, at 3:05 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Karding  
A low-pressure area formed near the waters of Guam on August 1, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 93W. Due to the influence of Tropical Cyclone Shanshan to the east, the system developed slowly for several days, with sparse and weak convection, making the low-level circulation center difficult to identify. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated the chance of the low-pressure area developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 2 PM on August 1, upgraded it to "medium" on the 5th, and further to "high" at 2 PM on the 6th, issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. As Shanshan gradually moved northward and away, the southwest monsoon that had been drawn away by it reconnected to this system, which then began to develop rapidly, consolidating its convective cloud clusters and showing the characteristics of a tropical cyclone. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 8 AM.  

Due to the subtropical ridge retreating eastward under the influence of a shortwave trough and Tropical Cyclone Shanshan, the system was guided by weak steering flows north of the equatorial anticyclone, moving slowly northeastward at a speed of about 5 km/h. As the system's organization further improved, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression at 5 AM on the 7th, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 18W. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning at 3:25 PM and officially upgraded the system to a tropical storm at 12:10 PM the next day, assigning it the international number 1814 and naming it Yagi. On the same day, Yagi moved slowly northwestward.  

On August 10, Yagi turned westward and passed through the waters south of Okinawa and north of Miyako Island on the 11th, later turning northwestward again. At 11:35 PM on August 12, the China Meteorological Administration announced that Yagi made landfall in Wenling City, Taizhou, Zhejiang Province. After landfall, Yagi gradually weakened. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression at 3:50 PM on August 13.

A low-pressure area formed in the South China Sea on August 4, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 96W. On the afternoon of August 9, the National Meteorological Center first upgraded the system to a tropical depression. In the early hours of August 10, the Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded it to a tropical depression. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the tropical cyclone formation alert at 11 p.m. on August 11, only to reissue it at 1:30 p.m. the following day. At 9:25 p.m. on August 12, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for the system. At 11 p.m. that night, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, designating it as tropical cyclone 20W. At 9:25 a.m. on August 13, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical storm and named it Bebinca, assigning it the international designation 1816. 

At 5:25 p.m. on August 14, the China National Meteorological Center upgraded Bebinca to a severe tropical storm. Starting at midnight on August 15, Bebinca began moving westward at a speed of about 10 kilometers per hour, moving away from the Pearl River Estuary area and heading toward the Leizhou Peninsula. Subsequently, Bebinca moved west-southwest, and the China National Meteorological Center reported that Bebinca made landfall in Leizhou, Guangdong, at 9:40 p.m. that night and weakened into a tropical storm. In the early hours of August 16, Bebinca moved into the Beibu Gulf, where it reorganized due to the hot sea surface temperatures of 31 degrees Celsius, regaining strength. The downgrade by the China National Meteorological Center lasted only about seven hours before Bebinca was re-upgraded to a severe tropical storm at 5:10 a.m. However, the Japan Meteorological Agency did not upgrade Bebinca to a severe tropical storm until the evening and later retracted this upgrade in its post-event "best track" analysis.

On the same day, Bebinca continued moving west-southwest at a speed of about 10 kilometers per hour, crossing the Beibu Gulf and steadily heading toward northern Vietnam. Before making its final landfall the next morning (August 17), the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded Bebinca to a tropical storm again at 6:30 a.m. and announced at 9:45 a.m. that Bebinca had made landfall in northern Vietnam. Due to terrain friction and strong vertical wind shear, Bebinca's central dense overcast quickly disintegrated upon landfall, with deep convection once again shearing southwestward, causing its intensity to rapidly and significantly decline. At 3:10 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded Bebinca to a tropical depression, by which time Bebinca had already entered Laos.

A low-pressure area formed near the waters of Guam on August 7, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 97W at 8 PM that evening. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assessed the chance of the low-pressure area developing into a tropical cyclone within one day as "low" at 6 AM on August 10. By 2 PM, the JTWC raised the development chance to "medium," and on the following day (August 11), it skipped the "high" rating and tropical cyclone formation alert, directly upgrading the system to a tropical depression at 11 AM, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 19W. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) followed suit at 2 PM.

The JTWC reported at 11 PM that the system was rapidly intensifying, with its center tightly wrapped by strong convective cloud bands and a central dense overcast forming, upgrading it to a tropical storm. The JMA also skipped the gale warning and directly upgraded the system to a tropical storm at midnight, naming it Leepi and assigning it the international number 1815. Leepi moved steadily northwestward that day.

By dusk, Leepi developed a "cloud-filled eye," and satellite imagery later showed the formation of an eye, which soon disappeared. The JTWC upgraded Leepi to a typhoon at 11 PM but downgraded it to a tropical storm at 11 AM the next day (August 13). The JMA upgraded Leepi to a severe tropical storm at 11:45 AM. The JTWC reclassified it as a typhoon at 5 PM and downgraded it again to a tropical storm at 11 PM.

From August 11 to 15, Leepi continued moving northwestward. At 2 AM on August 15, Leepi made landfall in Hyuga City, Miyazaki Prefecture, Japan, and gradually weakened. The JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression in the afternoon.

On the evening of August 13, Hector, located in the central Pacific, crossed the International Date Line into the Northwest Pacific region, and thus came under the jurisdiction of the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) for reporting. The JMA classified it as a tropical storm, retaining the Eastern Pacific name Hector. The Central Weather Bureau classified it as a mild typhoon. On August 14, Hector moved into a region with lower sea temperatures and was affected by dry air and strong vertical wind shear, causing it to weaken. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical depression at 7 PM and issued its final warning early the next day (August 15). The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression at 10 AM on August 15.

A low-pressure area formed in the southeastern waters of Taiwan on August 12, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 98W. Due to the lack of steering flow, the system moved slowly northward toward the Ryukyu Islands. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," upgrading it to "medium" on August 14, and shortly after to "high," issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On August 14, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 15 at 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified the system as a tropical depression, designating it as tropical cyclone 21W. Shortly after, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning, indicating the system could strengthen into a tropical storm within 24 hours. At 12:30 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical storm and named it Rumbia, assigning it the international designation 1818. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded Rumbia to a tropical storm in the evening, at which time Rumbia was near Okinawa. Affected by strong wind shear, Rumbia's deep convection was displaced eastward, exposing the low-level circulation center. That day, Rumbia began moving on a west-northwest path at a speed of about 15 kilometers per hour, gradually heading toward the Shanghai area. On the following day (August 16), Rumbia continued moving west-northwest. As wind shear began to weaken that day, Rumbia started drawing deep convection into its center, successfully repairing the previously exposed low-level circulation center and filling the western circulation. At 4:05 a.m. on August 17, the China National Meteorological Center announced that Rumbia made landfall in Shanghai's Pudong New Area. Terrain friction caused Rumbia to weaken after landfall, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final warning on Rumbia at 11 a.m. On August 18 at 10:05 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical depression.

A low-pressure area formed over the waters east of Guam on August 13, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Tropical Disturbance 99W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low." At 11 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the chance to "medium," and by 10:30 a.m. on August 15, it was raised to "high," with a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert issued. The Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression in the afternoon and issued a gale warning at 9:30 p.m. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression at 10 p.m., designating it as Tropical Cyclone 22W. 

At 9:30 a.m. on August 15, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded the system to a tropical storm, naming it Soulik and assigning it the international designation 1819. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center followed suit at 11 a.m. On August 17 at 6:05 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. Later that evening, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a typhoon. On August 18, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded it to a moderate typhoon. 

On August 19, Soulik turned westward and began an eyewall replacement cycle, causing its intensity to slightly weaken. On August 20, Soulik completed the eyewall replacement and developed a large, rough-edged eye, with its intensity peaking again. From August 20 to August 21, Soulik maintained its large eye structure and continued moving northwest, skimming past Japan's Amami Islands. On August 22, Soulik entered the cooler waters of the East China Sea, where its intensity began to decline, and its eye structure started to collapse. 

On August 23, Soulik turned northward, entering the Yellow Sea, with its intensity continuing to weaken. That morning, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. In the afternoon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. In the evening, Soulik made landfall in Jindo County, South Jeolla Province, South Korea. 

At 3 a.m. on August 25, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that Soulik had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. At 5 a.m. the same day, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final advisory on Soulik.

A low-pressure area formed over the eastern waters of Guam on August 15, and the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 91W at 8:30 PM. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated it as "low." On August 16, the JTWC upgraded the rating to "medium." On the same day at 9 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression. On August 17 at 12:30 PM, the JTWC raised the rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 5 AM on August 17, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 23W. At 9:30 AM, the JMA issued a gale warning for it. At 9:30 PM, the JMA upgraded the system to a tropical storm, named it Cimaron, and assigned it the international number 1820. 

On August 19, the JMA upgraded the system to a severe tropical storm. On the same day, the JTWC upgraded it to a typhoon. On August 21, the JMA upgraded the system to a typhoon. On the morning of August 22, Cimaron reached its peak intensity, with a clear eye visible. In the afternoon, Cimaron moved into cooler waters, and its intensity began to weaken. 

At 8 PM on August 23, the JMA announced that Cimaron made landfall in Anan City, Tokushima Prefecture, Shikoku, Japan. At 10 PM, Cimaron made a second landfall near Himeji City, Hyogo Prefecture. In the early hours of August 24, the JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm, and the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm at the same time. At 3 PM on August 24, the JMA determined that Cimaron had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone, and the JTWC issued its final warning at 5 PM on the same day. 

In the best track analysis published by the JTWC in October 2019, Cimaron's peak intensity was revised upward to 115 knots (approximately 215 km/h).

PAGASA: Maymay, a low-pressure area, formed on August 24 in the waters near Enewetak Atoll. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 94W. On the afternoon of the 26th, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within one day as "low," which was raised to "medium" by 4:30 a.m. on the 27th. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded the system to a tropical depression. At 10 a.m. on the 27th, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 5 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the system to a tropical depression, assigning it the number 25W. The Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning at 9:05 p.m. and upgraded the system to a tropical storm half a day later, naming it Jebi and assigning it the international number 1821. 

Benefiting from the favorable surrounding environment, Jebi developed a central dense overcast, and its outer cloud bands exhibited a radial pattern. At 2:50 a.m. on August 29, the Japan Meteorological Agency first upgraded Jebi to a severe tropical storm. On the same day, Jebi shifted its course west to west-northwest, absorbing energy continuously supplied by the warm sea water. It rapidly intensified in the afternoon, resisting dry air and developing a "cloud-filled eye," with a low-level eye also visible in microwave imagery. The Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Jebi to a typhoon at 2:45 p.m. and 5 p.m. on August 29, respectively. Jebi underwent explosive intensification on August 30, forming a "pinhole eye" during the day. 

The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded Jebi to a super typhoon at 5 a.m. on August 31, rating it as a Category 5 typhoon on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale, making it the second tropical cyclone of the year to reach this level after Super Typhoon Maria. Subsequently, Jebi exhibited a double eyewall phenomenon, indicating it had entered an eyewall replacement cycle. On the morning of September 2, Jebi completed the eyewall replacement cycle and formed a large eye. At the same time, Jebi moved to the western side of the subtropical high and began turning northward, later shifting northeastward and accelerating, entering an area with lower sea surface temperatures, causing its intensity to decrease. 

At 11 a.m. on September 4, Jebi made landfall in southern Tokushima Prefecture, Japan, and two hours later made a second landfall in Kobe, Hyogo Prefecture. After landfall, Jebi's intensity continued to weaken, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm that evening. The Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a severe tropical storm at 5 a.m. the following day and declared it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone three hours later. 

In the best track analysis published by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center in October 2019, Jebi's peak intensity was revised to 155 knots (approximately 285 km/h).

PAGASA: Ompong  
On September 4, a low-pressure area formed over the sea west of the International Date Line, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 99W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated it as "low" in the early hours of September 6 and upgraded it to "medium" later that evening. On September 7, JTWC raised the rating to "high" in the early hours and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert, upgrading it to a tropical depression at 11 a.m. the same day, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 26W. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression at 8 a.m. and issued a gale warning at 12:05 p.m. At 9:15 p.m., JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1822, and named it Mangkhut.  

The subtropical ridge to the north of Mangkhut extended westward, steering it westward at a speed of 30 km/h. Although Mangkhut was suppressed by upper-level dry air from the subtropical ridge to the north, favorable sea surface conditions allowed its intensity to begin increasing, developing a central dense overcast with radiating outer cloud bands. At 2:45 a.m. on September 9, JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm and further upgraded it to a typhoon six hours later, with JTWC following suit at 11 a.m. On September 10, Mangkhut continued moving west-southwest, passing near Guam. At the same time, Mangkhut continued to be affected by dry air intrusion and moved into an area with stronger wind shear, slowing its development and delaying the formation of an eye.  

Mangkhut underwent explosive intensification on September 11, overcoming dry air intrusion and successfully forming a "pinhole eye." At 8 p.m. that evening, JTWC increased its central wind speed to 260 km/h, making Mangkhut the third typhoon of the year to reach Category 5 intensity on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. On the evening of September 12, Mangkhut developed a double eyewall and entered a replacement cycle, weakening in intensity but maintaining Category 5 strength. On September 14, Mangkhut again developed a double eyewall and entered another eyewall replacement cycle but maintained its intensity. Due to the subtropical ridge to the east extending southward, Mangkhut moved in a slightly northward direction on the same day.  

At 1:40 a.m. on September 15, Mangkhut made landfall in Cagayan Province, Philippines, and began to weaken. At 9 a.m., Mangkhut's center exited the Philippine landmass and entered the South China Sea, reorganizing its circulation and reopening a rough eye in the afternoon. On September 16, Mangkhut continued moving northwest, crossing the northern South China Sea. At 5 p.m., the China Meteorological Administration announced that Mangkhut made landfall in Taishan, Jiangmen City, Guangdong Province. On September 17, JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression.

PAGASA: Neneng  
On September 6, a low-pressure area formed near the coast in the waters southwest of Luzon, Philippines. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 90W. At the same time, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated it as "low." Guided by the equatorial anticyclone, the system slowly moved northeastward, crossing Luzon. On September 8, the system re-entered the sea, returning to the Bashi Channel, and began consolidating under 30-degree sea temperatures, with increasing spiral structure. At 3:30 AM on the same day, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "medium." At 2 PM on September 8, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) classified it as a tropical depression. At 3:30 AM on September 9, the JTWC upgraded its rating to "high" and issued a tropical cyclone formation alert.  

Due to the terrain of Luzon and Taiwan, as well as the influence of vertical wind shear, the system's development was slow. At the same time, the system lost its guiding airflow and lingered southeast of Taiwan. After two days of stalling and consolidation, the system experienced a convective burst as wind shear weakened. In the early hours of September 10, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 27W. With the subtropical ridge extending southwestward, the system began to take a west-southwestward path. At 9:30 AM on the same day, the JMA issued a gale warning for the system. At 5 PM that afternoon, the JTWC first upgraded it to a tropical storm, followed by the JMA at 9:30 AM on September 11, assigning it the international number 1823 and naming it Barijat. On the same day, Barijat steadily moved west-southwestward at a speed of 12 to 14 km/h, entering the northeastern South China Sea. Constrained by dry air brought by the northeast monsoon and suppressed polar outflow, Barijat's intensity remained relatively unchanged throughout the day, despite the warm waters in the northern South China Sea.  

The next day (September 12), Barijat slightly accelerated to a speed of 20 km/h, moving west-northwestward across the northern South China Sea. The China Meteorological Administration announced that Barijat made landfall in Potou District, Zhanjiang, Guangdong, at 8:30 AM on September 13. At 3:45 PM, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression, and by 8 PM, Barijat was no longer marked on the synoptic weather map. The JTWC followed suit at 5 PM, issuing its final warning at 5 AM on September 14.

PAGASA: Paeng  
On September 16, a low-pressure area formed over the waters east of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 92W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low" in the early hours of September 18 and upgraded the rating to "medium" later that afternoon. At 10 a.m. on September 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also upgraded the rating to "high" at 5 p.m. that day and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 3:20 a.m. on September 21, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 5 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 28W. At 9:10 p.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1824, and named it Trami.  

On September 22, Trami began to intensify rapidly.
