At 2:45 p.m. that day, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a severe tropical storm, and at 2:45 a.m. the next day (September 23), it was upgraded to a typhoon, with the Joint Typhoon Warning Center following suit at 5 a.m. Trami successfully developed a "pinhole eye" that afternoon and exhibited a double eyewall that evening, entering an eyewall replacement cycle. On the following day (September 24), it developed a large eye after completing the eyewall replacement cycle, continued to intensify, and began moving northwest.  

At 5 a.m. on September 25, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center increased its central wind speed to 140 knots (260 km/h), making it the fifth typhoon of the year to reach Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. However, Trami remained stationary, consuming the latent heat of the seawater and causing cooler water to upwell, leading to a weakening trend. The Pacific High Ridge slightly strengthened on September 28, prompting Trami to accelerate northwestward.  

On September 29, Trami continued moving northward while maintaining its intensity, passing west of Okinawa in the afternoon. That evening, Trami turned northeastward and accelerated to 40 km/h, slightly weakening. On September 30, Trami continued moving northeastward. The Japan Meteorological Agency announced at 7 p.m. that Trami made landfall in Tanabe City, Wakayama Prefecture, Japan. Trami crossed Honshu that night and exited into the sea off Iwate Prefecture on the morning of October 1. After landfall, Trami gradually weakened, with the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issuing its final warning at 5 a.m. that day, and the Japan Meteorological Agency declaring at 11:50 a.m. that Trami had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: Queenie, a low-pressure area, formed near Pohnpei Island on the evening of September 22. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 94W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated it as "low" on the afternoon of September 25 and upgraded it to "medium" on the afternoon of September 26. On September 27 at 3:30 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On September 28 at 11:00 AM, the JTWC classified it as a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 30W. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) also upgraded it to a tropical depression at 3:25 PM the same day and issued a gale warning. Later in the afternoon, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1825, and named it Kong-rey. 

After being named, Kong-rey began to intensify rapidly due to favorable conditions in the nearby sea. At 2:45 AM on September 30, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm and further upgraded it to a typhoon at 11:50 AM, followed by the JTWC at 2:00 PM. On October 2, the JTWC increased its central wind speed to 140 knots (260 km/h), making it the fifth typhoon of the year to reach Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. That evening, Kong-rey moved into an area with lower ocean heat content, causing its intensity to decrease significantly. The JTWC downgraded it to a typhoon at 8:00 AM on October 3. Kong-rey crossed the waters east of Taiwan that day, where the sea's energy had been significantly depleted during Typhoon Trami's stalling, with sea temperatures dropping below 26°C, unable to sustain tropical cyclone development, leading to continued weakening. The JTWC downgraded Kong-rey to a tropical storm at 8:00 PM on October 4.

On October 5, Kong-rey turned northeastward, maintaining its intensity as it crossed the East China Sea. In the early hours of October 6, around 3:00 to 4:00 AM, it passed near the eastern coast of Jeju Island. Affected by South Korea's terrain, Kong-rey weakened slightly. The JMA downgraded it to a severe tropical storm at 8:00 AM. At 8:50 AM, the Korea Meteorological Administration reported that Kong-rey made landfall in Tongyeong, South Gyeongsang Province, South Korea. On October 7, the JMA determined that Kong-rey had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone while it was located over the Sea of Japan. 

In the JTWC's best track analysis published in October 2019, Kong-rey's peak intensity was revised to 150 knots (approximately 280 km/h).

PAGASA: Rosita  
On October 19, a low-pressure area formed near Pohnpei, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 97W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated it as "low" in the early hours of October 20 and upgraded it to "medium" in the afternoon. At 5 a.m. on October 21, the JTWC upgraded the rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 a.m., the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) classified it as a tropical depression and issued a gale warning in the afternoon. At 11 p.m., the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 31W. At 3:15 a.m. on October 22, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international designation 1826, and named it Yutu.  

At 8 p.m. on October 22, the JMA upgraded it to a severe tropical storm. On the morning of October 23, both the JMA and JTWC upgraded it to a typhoon. At 8 a.m. on October 24, the Central Weather Bureau also upgraded it to a strong typhoon. The JTWC upgraded it to a super typhoon at 11 a.m. on the same day, increasing its central wind speed to 145 knots (270 km/h), making Yutu the sixth typhoon of the year to reach Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale. In the evening, the JTWC further increased its central wind speed to 155 knots (285 km/h).  

On the evening of October 25, Yutu developed a double eyewall west of Guam and entered an eyewall replacement cycle. On October 26, Yutu completed the eyewall replacement and reopened a 40-kilometer-wide eye.  

In the early hours of October 30, Yutu made landfall in Dinapigue, Isabela Province, Philippines. In the afternoon, Yutu exited Luzon and entered the South China Sea. At 3:30 a.m. on October 31, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a severe tropical storm. At 5 a.m. on November 2, the National Meteorological Center downgraded it to a tropical storm. At 2:45 p.m. on November 2, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression.  

In the best track analysis published by the JTWC in October 2019, Yutu's peak intensity was revised down to 150 knots (approximately 280 km/h).

PAGASA: Samuel  
On November 3, a low-pressure area formed in the central-north Pacific, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 98C. On November 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) gave it a "low" rating. On November 8, the JTWC upgraded the rating to "medium" and further upgraded it to "high" the next day, issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) also upgraded it to a tropical depression on November 9. On November 10, the JTWC canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert, downgraded the rating to "medium," and further downgraded it to "low" on November 11. The JMA downgraded it to a low-pressure area on the same day.  

On November 14, the system redeveloped, and the JMA upgraded it to a tropical depression again at 8 PM. The JTWC also upgraded the rating to "medium" at 2 AM the following day. On November 17 at 10:30 PM, the JTWC upgraded the rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 3:30 AM the next day, the JMA issued a gale warning for the system. On November 18 at 5 PM, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 33W. On the evening of November 22, the JMA upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1829, and named it Usagi.  

The JMA and the China Meteorological Administration upgraded it to a severe tropical storm and a strong tropical storm, respectively, at 9:05 AM and 8 PM on November 23. On November 24 at 11 AM, the JTWC upgraded it to a typhoon, followed by the JMA at 2:55 PM.  

On November 25, Usagi made landfall in Tien Giang Province, Vietnam. On the morning of November 26, the JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression. In the JTWC's best track analysis published in October 2019, its peak intensity was revised to 90 knots (approximately 165 km/h).

A low-pressure area formed southeast of Mindanao, Philippines, on November 11, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 91W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated it as "low" on November 16 and upgraded it to "medium" at 9 PM that evening. On November 17, the JTWC upgraded the rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Simultaneously, the Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) classified it as a tropical depression. On the afternoon of November 17, the JMA skipped the gale warning stage and directly upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigning it the international number 1827 and naming it "Toraji." The JTWC, however, did not upgrade it to a tropical storm until 11 PM that evening, classifying it as a tropical depression with the designation 32W.

On November 18, Toraji crossed the southern South China Sea and made landfall in Vietnam that afternoon. The JMA downgraded it to a tropical depression at 3 PM, and the JTWC issued its final warning at 7 PM. On the morning of November 20, Toraji's remnants entered the Gulf of Thailand and redeveloped. The JTWC upgraded its rating to "medium" at 1 PM and further upgraded it to a tropical depression at 11 PM. On November 21, after making landfall in Nakhon Si Thammarat, Thailand, it weakened. Upon entering the Andaman Sea, the JTWC issued its final warning again.

PAGASA: Tomas  
On the morning of November 17, a low-pressure area formed, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 92W. In the afternoon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." On the morning of November 19 at 11:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium." In the afternoon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center further upgraded it to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. At 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On November 20 at 3:30 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency issued a gale warning for it. At 5 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the number 34W. On the same day at 9:05 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international number 1828, and named it Man-yi.  

On November 21 at 5 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center was the first to upgrade it to a typhoon. At the same time, Man-yi had already developed a central dense overcast, and its outer cloud bands appeared radiating, but the Japan Meteorological Agency delayed upgrading it to a severe tropical storm until the early hours of November 22. That afternoon at 2 PM, it entered the Hong Kong Observatory's area of responsibility, and the Hong Kong Observatory classified it as a typhoon. The Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded it to a typhoon at 8:45 PM. On November 23, Man-yi reached its peak intensity and developed an eye on November 24. Shortly after, it began to weaken due to factors such as wind shear and dry air.  

On the morning of November 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a tropical storm and further downgraded it to a tropical depression at noon. On November 27, the Hong Kong Observatory downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On December 28, a low-pressure area formed in the southern part of the South China Sea, and the United States Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 97W. On December 30, the system absorbed tropical depression 35W located to its northeast. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium" at 2 a.m. and further upgraded it to "high" the next day, issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert. At 2 p.m. on December 31, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 36W. The Japan Meteorological Agency followed suit at 3:15 p.m., upgrading it to a tropical depression and issuing a gale warning. At 2:55 p.m. on January 1, 2019, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical storm, assigned it the international designation 1901, and named it "Pabuk." On the evening of January 4, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Pabuk had exited its area of responsibility and entered the North Indian Ocean, with the India Meteorological Department taking over issuance of advisories.

In addition to tropical cyclones named by the Japan Meteorological Agency, there are also some unnamed tropical depressions and tropical cyclones assessed as tropical storms or tropical depressions by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, but only classified as tropical depressions by the Japan Meteorological Agency.

On May 4, two low-pressure areas formed in the waters southwest of Guam, designated as tropical disturbances 96W and 97W by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center, with a "low" chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours. The next day, 97W absorbed 96W and intensified, prompting the Joint Typhoon Warning Center to skip the "medium" classification and directly rate the chance of forming a tropical cyclone as "high." On May 10, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 04W. On May 15, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final advisory, subsequently declaring its dissipation.

On June 1, 2018, a low-pressure area formed in the waters southeast of Guam, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 91W at 9:30 PM. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" on June 2. Affected by vertical wind shear, its low-level circulation center was difficult to identify, convection was sparse, and the outflow channel was weak; however, warm sea waters supported the system's development, gradually consolidating its low-level circulation center. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the system's chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "medium" at 5 AM on June 4. Due to deep convection continuing to wrap into the center and improved polar outflow, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "high" four hours later, at 9 AM, and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Meanwhile, the Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan and the Japan Meteorological Agency simultaneously upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 2 PM. The tropical depression accelerated westward, approaching a tropical depression to the west, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center began predicting that the system would merge with Maliksi. The next day (June 5) at 9:30 AM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded the rating to "medium" and canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Subsequently, under the "Fujiwhara effect," the system shifted northwestward, with its low-level circulation center exposed and convection weakening. The Japan Meteorological Agency and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center stated at 8 PM and 10 PM, respectively, that the system had been absorbed by Maliksi. The Central Weather Bureau of Taiwan also confirmed this at 2 AM on June 6.

On June 12, a mesoscale convective complex developed into a tropical disturbance along a stationary front, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the disturbance number 93W at 9 a.m. At 2 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center assessed its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low," and upgraded the rating to "medium" at 10 p.m. The following morning at 10 a.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its chance of developing into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Half an hour later, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a subtropical depression and maintained the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency identified it as a low-pressure area at 8 p.m. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression at 5 a.m. the next morning, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 07W, and upgraded it to a tropical storm at 8 a.m. However, the Japan Meteorological Agency identified it as having transitioned into an extratropical cyclone at 8 a.m. In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center in early October 2019, the nature of 07W was adjusted to a subtropical storm.

On June 16, a monsoon depression formed in the northern part of the South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 96W. The Central Weather Bureau issued a tropical depression advisory for it on the morning of June 18, and the system made landfall in Fujian on the afternoon of June 18. The Hong Kong Observatory had forecasted from June 15 to 17 that the system might develop, but the situation remained uncertain. It also issued several special weather alerts, reminding citizens to pay attention to weather changes when going out during the holiday. Ultimately, it failed to strengthen to the intensity of a tropical depression.

On July 10, a low-pressure area formed in the South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Tropical Disturbance 93W. On July 16, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On July 18, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that the system had dissipated.

PAGASA: Josie  
On July 20, a low-pressure area formed in the South China Sea, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 98W. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." Due to favorable development conditions and evident spiral characteristics, the Japan Meteorological Agency marked it as a low-pressure area on the morning weather map and upgraded it to a tropical depression in the evening.  
On the morning of July 21, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center directly upgraded the rating to "high," skipping "medium," and simultaneously issued a tropical cyclone formation alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency also issued a gale warning for it. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 13W.  
At 9 a.m. on July 23, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning issued for it.  
On July 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had dissipated.  
In the best track released by the Joint Typhoon Warning Center in early October 2019, the peak intensity of 13W was revised to 35 knots (65 kilometers per hour).

On the evening of July 28, a low-pressure system formed, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 90W. On the afternoon of July 29, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." On the morning of July 30, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center skipped the "medium" rating and directly upgraded it to "high," issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert at the same time. In the evening, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression, designating it as tropical cyclone 16W. On the morning of July 31, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. In the early hours of August 1, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final advisory on the system. On the evening of August 2, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

PAGASA: On August 22, a low-pressure area formed in the northern part of the South China Sea during the early morning, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 92W. In the morning, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." At the same time, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. At 10:30 a.m., the Central Weather Bureau issued a tropical depression advisory for it. In the afternoon, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded its rating to "medium," and shortly after, further upgraded it to "high," issuing a tropical cyclone formation alert. On August 23, the system made landfall in Donggang Township, Pingtung County, Taiwan. On August 24, in the early morning, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded it to a tropical depression and assigned it the tropical cyclone number 24W. On August 25, at 9:40 a.m., the system made landfall again in Xiuyu District, Putian City, Fujian Province. At 2:00 p.m., the China National Meteorological Center stated that its circulation center had become difficult to identify, thus declaring it dissipated and ceasing updates. At 5:00 p.m., the Joint Typhoon Warning Center issued its final advisory. On the evening of August 26, the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area.

On August 23, a low-pressure area formed in the waters east of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 93W, with the Joint Typhoon Warning Center giving it a "low" rating. On the afternoon of August 24, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. Shortly after, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised its rating to "medium." On August 26, the system made landfall in Shanghai, and the Japan Meteorological Agency downgraded it to a low-pressure area, while the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled all ratings.

On September 3, a low-pressure area formed in the waters east of the Philippines, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as Tropical Disturbance 98W. On September 4, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." On the morning of September 5, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression, and the Joint Typhoon Warning Center raised the rating to "medium" that evening. At 10:30 a.m. on September 6, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. Two hours later, the Japan Meteorological Agency also issued a gale warning for it. At 3 a.m. on September 7, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center also downgraded the rating to "low" at 10:30 a.m. the same day and canceled the Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On the afternoon of September 8, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center removed the rating.

The remnants of Hurricane Olivia entered the Northwest Pacific as a low-pressure area, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory reassigned it the tropical disturbance number 93W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) rated it as "low" at 10:30 a.m. on September 19, but downgraded the rating by 2:00 p.m. On September 21, at 10:30 a.m., the JTWC again rated it as "low." The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded it to a tropical depression at 8:00 p.m. on September 21. By 3:00 p.m. on September 23, the JMA determined it had dissipated. On September 25, at 1:00 p.m., the JTWC raised the rating to "medium," and later at 10:30 p.m., upgraded it to "high," issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. The JMA also upgraded it to a tropical depression again at 2:00 p.m. on the same day. On September 26, at 5:00 p.m., the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression, assigning it the tropical cyclone number 29W. On September 27, the JTWC issued its final warning for the system. On September 28, the JMA determined it had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

On October 19, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded a low-pressure area located in the southern waters of Vietnam to a tropical depression. The U.S. Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance number 98W at 2 a.m. on October 20. On October 20, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had left the Northwest Pacific and entered the Bay of Bengal.

On October 18, a low-pressure area formed, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 96W. On October 19, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low." On the evening of October 20, at 8 PM, the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression. On the morning of October 21, at 8 AM, the Japan Meteorological Agency determined that it had transformed into an extratropical cyclone. At 2 PM, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center canceled the rating.

PAGASA: Usman  
On December 22, a low-pressure area formed, and the United States Naval Research Laboratory assigned it the tropical disturbance designation 96W. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center rated it as "low" on the evening of December 23 and upgraded the rating to "medium" an hour later. On December 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center upgraded the rating to "high" and issued a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. On the evening of December 24, the Joint Typhoon Warning Center classified it as a tropical depression and assigned it the designation 35W. In the early hours of December 25, the Central Weather Bureau upgraded 35W to a tropical depression. The Japan Meteorological Agency followed in the afternoon and issued a gale warning in the evening. Affected by strong wind shear and the terrain of the Philippines, 35W began to weaken. At 2 a.m. on December 30, the Japan Meteorological Agency canceled the gale warning and downgraded it to a low-pressure area. Subsequently, the remnants of 35W merged into the circulation of Pabuk.

The Japan Meteorological Agency and the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration both name tropical cyclones that develop in the Western Pacific, so a single tropical cyclone in these regions may have two names. As the Regional Specialized Meteorological Center for the Western Pacific, the Typhoon Center of the Japan Meteorological Agency in Tokyo is responsible for assigning international names to tropical cyclones with 10-minute sustained wind speeds reaching 65 kilometers per hour on behalf of the World Meteorological Organization's Typhoon Committee. The responsibility area of the Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration is between 115 to 135 degrees east longitude and 5 to 25 degrees north latitude. This agency names all tropical cyclones entering this area, and this naming process does not consider whether the cyclone already has an international name. The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration and the Japan Meteorological Agency's Typhoon Committee retire the names of tropical cyclones that cause significant impacts. The storm names in 2018 may be the same as some storm names from 2000, 2001, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2012, and 2013.

Once a tropical cyclone in the Western Pacific reaches tropical storm intensity, it is named by the Typhoon Committee of the Japan Meteorological Agency. These names are provided by 14 member countries or regions, each contributing 10 names, and are then sorted alphabetically by the first letter of the country's English name. Names in black indicate those already used this year, bold names indicate active storms, unused names are shown in gray, and orange indicates the next name to be used.

Whole_Text.header: The name of the delisted tropical cyclone
Whole_Text.content: At the 51st session of the World Meteorological Organization Typhoon Committee, it was decided to retire the 18th named tropical cyclone of this season, "Rumbia," due to significant damage caused by the typhoon in mainland China; and to retire the 22nd named tropical cyclone of this season, "Mangkhut," due to significant damage caused by the typhoon in the Philippines.

The Philippine Atmospheric, Geophysical and Astronomical Services Administration uses an independent naming method for tropical cyclones within its area of responsibility. All tropical depressions that form in, enter, or are likely to enter its area of responsibility are given names. The naming list is rotated every four years, with only retired names being replaced. Additionally, a supplementary list is prepared to substitute when all names are used up. Below is the list of storm names for 2018, with unused names shown in gray, and the international names of the storms indicated in parentheses:

This list enumerates all tropical cyclones that were active in the Western Pacific in 2018. It includes the intensity, duration, name, landfall locations, fatalities, and damages caused by each tropical cyclone. All damages are measured in US dollars. Numbers in parentheses indicate indirect fatalities (e.g., traffic accidents, landslides, etc.). The formula for calculating ACE is:

∑ v_max^2 / 10^4, with the unit being 10^4 kt^2. [33]

Article_Name: 颱風榕樹 (2017年) - 维基百科，自由的百科全书

Whole_Text.content:
Typhoon Banyan (International designation: 1712, Joint Typhoon Warning Center: WP142017) was the 12th named tropical cyclone in the Northwest Pacific. The name "Banyan" (International Phonetic Alphabet: [ˈbæn.jən]) was provided by Hong Kong and refers to a common type of tree in the South China region. Banyan was an oceanic storm that did not affect any land throughout its course. The cyclone originated from a low-pressure area southeast of Wake Island, and the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory designated it as tropical disturbance 90W at 3 PM on the 10th. The system rapidly developed, and the Japan Meteorological Agency upgraded it to a tropical depression and issued a gale warning at 9:05 AM the following day. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center followed suit three hours later and upgraded it further to a tropical storm six hours after that. The Japan Meteorological Agency also upgraded the system to a tropical storm and named it Banyan at 8:50 PM. At the time, various agencies predicted Banyan would strengthen to a tropical storm or severe tropical storm intensity, but its slow movement allowed it to develop faster than expected. Banyan developed a central dense overcast on the afternoon of the 12th and intensified into a severe tropical storm. Benefiting from warm sea temperatures, high specific heat capacity, weak vertical wind shear, and a favorable environment with enhanced outflow on the eastern side due to an upper-level tropical trough, it developed a "pinhole eye" and intensified into a typhoon. The China National Meteorological Center further upgraded Banyan to a strong typhoon at 5:31 PM. 

Due to increased vertical wind shear, Banyan's intensity dropped to Category 1 on the Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale but re-intensified to Category 2 by the early hours of the 14th. That evening, Banyan moved to the western side of the subtropical ridge, shifted to a northeastward path, and encountered cooler sea temperatures, leading to weakening. Its eye became obscured, and the China National Meteorological Center downgraded Banyan to a typhoon at 8:30 PM. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center downgraded it to a tropical storm at 5 PM on the 16th but re-upgraded it to a typhoon six hours later at 11 PM. On August 17, the Japan Meteorological Agency announced that Typhoon Banyan had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. Later, the China National Meteorological Center also confirmed that Banyan had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

The first typhoon active period of 2017 ended with Typhoon Noru weakening and dissipating after ravaging Japan, but soon another tropical cyclone formed. A low-pressure area developed on August 10 west of the International Date Line, southeast of Wake Island, and was designated as tropical disturbance 90W by the U.S. Naval Research Laboratory at 3 PM. The system initially developed rapidly, with convective bands wrapping into the center. The Joint Typhoon Warning Center (JTWC) assessed its chance of forming into a tropical cyclone within 24 hours as "low" at 10 PM but upgraded it directly to "high" six hours later at 4 AM on August 11, issuing a Tropical Cyclone Formation Alert. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 9:05 AM and issued a gale warning. Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau (CWB) also upgraded the system to a tropical depression at 8 AM. As the system continued to strengthen, with deep convection further wrapping into the center, the JTWC upgraded it to a tropical depression at 11 AM, designating it as Tropical Cyclone 14W. By 5 PM, even before being named, the system was upgraded to a tropical storm by the JTWC. The CWB upgraded it to a light typhoon at 8 PM, and the JMA officially upgraded it to a tropical storm at 8:50 PM, naming it Banyan and assigning it the international designation 1712. China's National Meteorological Center (NMC) followed suit at 9:16 PM.

On that day, the subtropical ridge extended southeastward, causing Banyan to maintain a west-northwest trajectory at a speed of about 15 km/h. Official agencies predicted Banyan would become a "recurving" tropical cyclone, turning northward under the influence of a mid-latitude westerly trough weakening the subtropical ridge. However, its intensity was not expected to exceed tropical storm to severe tropical storm levels. Nevertheless, the warm sea surface temperatures, weak vertical wind shear, and favorable outflow environment on the eastern side of the system allowed Banyan to intensify rapidly, prompting agencies to revise their intensity forecasts upward. As the westerly trough weakened the subtropical ridge, Banyan gradually turned northwestward. Despite a slight increase in vertical wind shear, the system's central convection remained consolidated, forming a central dense overcast. The JMA and NMC upgraded Banyan to a severe tropical storm at 2 PM and 2:57 PM on August 12, respectively.

As vertical wind shear decreased, Banyan developed a "pinhole eye" on August 13, prompting the JMA, NMC, and JTWC to upgrade it to a typhoon at 2 AM, 2:34 AM, and 5 AM, respectively. The NMC further upgraded Banyan to a strong typhoon at 5:31 PM. Banyan reached its first intensity peak at noon, but increasing vertical wind shear later exposed its low-level circulation center to the north. The JTWC anticipated Banyan to reach a peak intensity of 130 knots, the threshold for a super typhoon, just shy of Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson scale. The NMC predicted Banyan would weaken to a typhoon during its recurvature and reintensify into a strong typhoon afterward. However, the JMA did not forecast Banyan to reach the "very strong typhoon" category. Subsequently, Banyan's equatorial outflow channel was blocked, and its eye disappeared, leading the JTWC and NMC to retract their intensity forecasts.

On August 14, vertical wind shear decreased, and Banyan reorganized over 30°C waters, with signs of reestablishing its polar outflow and eye. Banyan reached its second peak intensity on August 15, but its circulation remained very small. The JMA assessed Banyan's gale-force wind radius to be only 60 km, with a 30-knot wind radius of 280 km to the east and 170 km to the west. The NMC and CWB estimated Banyan's western circulation's 7-level wind radius at 150 km, with the NMC assessing its eastern circulation at 180 km and its 10-level wind radius at 80 km to the east and 50 km to the west. The CWB estimated its 10-level wind radius at only 50 km. These estimates indicated Banyan's circulation was even smaller than the earlier weak tropical storm Nesat.

Banyan began weakening at dusk, with its "pinhole eye" filling in and becoming a "cloud-filled eye." Cloud-top temperatures warmed, and convection near the center weakened. The NMC downgraded Banyan to a typhoon at 8:30 PM, and the JTWC downgraded it to a tropical storm at 5 PM on August 16. Agencies predicted Banyan would accelerate northeastward and possibly cross the International Date Line into the Central Pacific. Banyan reorganized and redeveloped a "pinhole eye" that evening, prompting the JTWC to re-upgrade it to a typhoon at 11 PM. On August 17, the JMA declared Banyan had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone. The NMC later also declared Banyan had transitioned into an extratropical cyclone.

In the "2017 Tropical Cyclone Best Track Data" released by the NMC on May 1, 2018, Banyan's intensity was revised downward to a typhoon, with its maximum sustained winds near the center reduced from 45 m/s (160 km/h) to 42 m/s (145 km/h), and its central pressure adjusted upward to 955 hPa.
